WASHINGTON -- Through the fog of questionable calls and Alex Ovechkin's hit to defenseman Dan Girardi, a larger truth emerged from the Rangers' 3-2 loss to the Washington Capitals on Saturday. For the last two months, the top-seeded Rangers have basically been a .500 team. So it should be of little surprise that they find themselves tied with the seventh-seeded Capitals as this Eastern Conference semifinal series shifts back to Madison Square Garden for Game 5 on Monday night.

The International Center of Photography in midtown Manhattan announced on Thursday that it had appointed a new executive director, Mark Robbins, Dean of the School of Architecture at Syracuse University. Mr. Robbins has worked as a photographer and administrator, a fundraiser and curator. Before joining the architecture school he served as director of design for the National Endowment for the Arts and as architecture curator at the Wexner Center for the Arts in Columbus, Ohio. His own work, which is part of the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art's permanent collection, will also be on display this fall at a solo show at Colgate University's Clifford Gallery in Hamilton, N.Y.

An article on Friday about President Obama's race as a continuing issue for some voters referred imprecisely to his position on the Keystone pipeline, one of the main quarrels that some Democrats have with him. While the president rejected TransCanada's earlier application to build the full pipeline from Canada to the gulf coast, he has made no final decision on whether the project will go forward. (The president, who has invited the company to submit another plan, said he rejected the earlier plan because a Congressional mandate that called for him to decide by mid-February did not allow adequate time to complete environmental reviews.)

TOKYO -- Japan's last operating reactor was taken offline Saturday, as public distrust created by last year's nuclear disaster forced the nation to at least temporarily do without atomic power for the first time in 42 years. The reactor, at the Tomari plant on the northern island of Hokkaido, was shut down for legally mandated maintenance, said its operator, Hokkaido Electric. As Japan's 50 functional commercial reactors have been shut down one by one for maintenance, none have been restarted because of safety concerns since last year's Fukushima disaster.

LOUISVILLE, Ky. -- Dr. Kendall Hansen is a man of many words. Mike Maker, the trainer of Hansen's namesake colt, is just the opposite. ''You ask him, 'How did Hansen work today?' '' said Hansen, who operates a pain management clinic in Crestview Hills, Ky., referring to Maker. ''And he'll say, 'Great.' And then there's a long pause.''

Drivers moving along Chicago's inbound Eisenhower Expressway on Friday may have been surprised to see Ted Kaczynski, the so-called Unabomber, staring at them from a massive billboard. ''I still believe in global warming. Do you?'' the billboard read in large maroon letters. Just below was the Web address www.heartland.org. Hours later, the digital billboard was gone. It seems that the ad campaign, sponsored by the conservative Heartland Institute, had bombed.

I LIKE backpackers as individuals and tolerate them in small groups, but this crowd terrified me. They were lining up for a bright yellow catamaran called the Yasawa Flyer to speed from Fiji's main island to some of its tiniest and most idyllic. And I was with them, worried I was about to spend my five precious days in paradise on a spring break-style debauch. That was until I overheard a woman with cropped blond hair and at least a few decades on the average Flyer passenger talking to a group of young Americans who appeared not quite as sunscreen-slathered or iPod-attached as the rest. ''Can you imagine if you were living on an island that had not had much contact with the western World and everyone was coming and getting drunk?'' I heard her say. ''They're not going to have the best impression of us.''

KANSAS CITY, Mo. -- After a particularly dispiriting loss Saturday night, Alex Rodriguez set out the core expectations that he and his teammates in the middle of the batting order hold sacred: damage, production, wins. In a game the Yankees felt they had to win, they followed that formula rigorously and came away with a 10-4 victory over the Kansas City Royals on Sunday to salvage a split in a series that was a disaster even before the first game was played.

At the I.C.F.F., the writer and designer Suzanne Trocmé curates British Bone, a selection of china produced by 1882LTD, including Max Lamb's hand-carved tableware. Now in its second edition, WantedDesign again takes over the Terminal Stores building (28th Street at 11th Avenue), where it will host an exhibition of contemporary Brazilian design and a three-day workshop where design students will make their own light fixtures. In the garment district, the recently opened Moss Bureau (256 West 36th Street, 10th floor) will present ''Midway,'' a giant, zoetropic Ferris wheel and carousel by the artist and metalsmith Cathy McClure; ''Mortal Stillness,'' an exhibition of taxidermy by Kelly McCallum, assorted artist-made vessels and Jennifer Trask's ivory, bone and gilded wood jewelry. And check out the new Standard Hotel East Village (25 Cooper Square), where the Sight Unseen founders (and T contributors), Monica Khemsurov and Jill Singer, will install the work of West Coast designers for the aptly named ''Hotel California.'' The British designer Tom Dixon will introduce his soon-to-be-available Etch Light Web at London Underground in the basement of the Bleecker Street Theater (45 Bleecker Street). Walk away with a Mirrorball or Jack Light, or order one for home delivery from Fab.com on special iPad stations. And finally, Jamie Gray will introduce the newest pieces of his MatterMade collection, including Meg Callahan's digitally printed quilts at Matter (405 Broome Street) and at a ''secret'' location nearby. Happy hunting. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

It's the biggest summer for superheroes in years, with at least eight of them muscling into movie theaters, starting with the just-out ''Avengers'' (that's a six-in-one shot with Marvel's Iron Man, Captain America, Thor, the Hulk, Black Widow and Hawkeye) and following with ''The Amazing Spider-Man'' (July 3) and Christopher Nolan's final Batman epic ''The Dark Knight Rises'' (July 20). Given that ''The Avengers'' already made an astounding $178.4 million in its initial overseas release last weekend, this could be a $3 billion season for costumed crusaders.

WERNER--Howard, 81, died May 3, 2012 at his home. He was born September 4, 1930 in New York and is survived by his wife, Toni, of 58 years; children Craig and Barbara Werner, Margery and David Warheit, Wynn and Denise Werner; grandchildren Rachel, Melissa, Zachary, Ashley, Sarah and his sister Harriet. An avid golfer, photographer and gardener. Howard will be greatly missed by his family.

The Treasury's schedule of financing this week includes Monday's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday. At the close of the New York cash market on Friday, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 0.07 percent. The rate on the six-month issue was 0.14 percent, and the rate on the four-week issue was 0.05 percent.

For all the baggage inherited and hauled around, all the mishaps endured or missteps taken, the Knicks deserved one. If for no other reason that they showed up battered and bandaged, they merited an endgame buzzer that put a bounce in their steps and teeth in their smiles. They earned the streamers that fell from the Madison Square Garden rafters, a spontaneous celebration of sheer -- and mere -- survival. ''I know what it's like to be a winner in the playoffs -- I can finally say that,'' the second-year Knick Landry Fields said after Miami's Dwyane Wade misfired on what would have been a series-ending 3-pointer from the right corner and the Knicks broke their 11-year playoff victory drought, 89-87. ''It feels good.''

Old-school train conductors are finally ready to give up their hole punchers to try something new: the iPhone. Amtrak, the government-owned corporation that oversees the nation's railroad train services, has been training conductors since November to use the Apple handset as an electronic ticket scanner on a few routes, including from Boston to Portland, Me., and San Jose, Calif., to Sacramento.

For more than 30 years now Symphony Space has set aside a day to focus at length on a specific composer, artist, era or theme: Wall to Wall, the enduring marathon concept that started with a daylong Bach concert in 1978. In most of these events it can seem as if Symphony Space were attempting to cram an entire voluminous world into 12 hours on a single stage, to varying if nearly always edifying effect. This year's installment, ''Wall to Wall Gertrude's Paris,'' presented on Saturday, felt different: more open, yet, paradoxically, unusually focused. To start with, the event, assembled by Laura Kaminsky, a composer and the Symphony Space artistic director, took its lead from another institution's doings: ''The Steins Collect: Matisse, Picasso and the Parisian Avant-Garde,'' a collection now on display at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
ORBAN--John, Jr.,formerly of Garden City, New York, passed away recently in Sun City, Arizona at age 100.

''An avalanche of words'' is how Mark Waldrop, the host of the Lyrics & Lyricists program ''Mad Dogs and Educated Fleas: Nöel and Cole, a Battle of Wits'' described the program at the 92nd Street Y on Saturday evening. By the end of the two-and-a-half-hour show, the Kaufmann Concert Hall was half-buried in drifts of refined light verse invented eons before ''whatever,'' ''no problem,'' ''awesome'' and ''dude'' dominated everyday language. This was the first time Mr. Waldrop, a frequent behind-the-scenes director of many Lyrics & Lyricists shows, stepped to the fore; he appeared stiff and flustered. Ignoring its subjects' great love songs, the show concentrated on their wittier lyrics sung and recited by a mostly well-chosen cast accompanied by a backup quartet led by the pianist Don Rebic.

''I SING the body electric,'' Walt Whitman wrote in 1855, inspired by the novelty of useful electricity, which he would live to see power streetlights and telephones, locomotives and dynamos. In ''Leaves of Grass,'' his ecstatic epic poem of American life, he depicted himself as a live wire, a relay station for all the voices of the earth, natural or invented, human or mineral. ''I have instant conductors all over me,'' he wrote. ''They seize every object and lead it harmlessly through me... My flesh and blood playing out lightning to strike what is hardly different from myself.'' Electricity equipped Whitman and other poets with a scintillation of metaphors. Like inspiration, it was a lightning flash. Like prophetic insight, it illuminated the darkness. Like sex, it tingled the flesh. Like life, it energized raw matter. Whitman didn't know that our cells really do generate electricity, that the heart's pacemaker relies on such signals and that billions of axons in the brain create their own electrical charge (equivalent to about a 60-watt bulb). A force of nature himself, he admired the range and raw power of electricity.

A picture caption on April 22 with the Frugal Traveler column, about a $100 weekend in Melbourne, misidentified the structure shown behind a passing tram. It is the Visitor Center, at right, with St. Paul's cathedral at left. It is not the Flinders Street Station, which was not shown, but is opposite the center.

In his column in last Sunday's Arts & Leisure section, Zachary Woolfe, writing about the Metropolitan Opera's HD broadcasts that appear in theaters nationwide, posed this question: When it comes to the complete opera experience, is watching the art in HD good enough? His column, the first of two about the Met, and that underlying question provoked a strong reader response online, with most pleased that they can, for example, go see an opera production screened at a theater in Wichita, Kan. The column and the comments are at nytimes.com/music.

Over Thanksgiving weekend 2010, a popular hip-hop blog, Dajaz1.com, was shut down as part of a sweep by federal authorities of dozens of Web sites suspected of copyright infringement and selling counterfeit goods. A year later, the government dropped its case against Dajaz1 and returned the site to its owner. But why? Little explanation was given at the time, and the answer is still unclear. But court documents released last week offer a window into the investigation, and reveal some of the finger-pointing between the government and the industry groups that push for copyright enforcement.

YEARS ago, realtors attempted to gussy up a gritty slice of the Western Addition area of San Francisco -- home to wig shops, greasy diners and its fair share of crime -- with a catchy acronym, NoPa, after its city-central location, north of the Panhandle. When the restaurant Nopa took over an abandoned Laundromat in 2006, the moniker started to catch on -- and it now seems to have officially stuck. Rents are rising, retail options are evolving, and the neighborhood is expanding up, down and around Divisadero Street. Check-cashing joints have become trendy salons; landscaped parklets and do-it-yourself schools have cropped up; and artisanal pies and pizza are making a Popeyes look increasingly out of place. With plans for better bike lanes, a branch of the cult-favorite grocery and ice cream shop Bi-Rite coming this fall, and a Four Barrel cafe and ''toast bar'' (called the Mill) opening soon, NoPa is poised to become the next Mission -- just leafier and more low-key. RACHEL LEVIN

ROUNER--Rita Rainsford, of Sandwich, NH, formerly of Wayland, MA and Watertown, MA, died peacefully on March 28, 2012 at age 85. Born in Katonah, NY, Rita was a graduate of Smith College and pursued graduate studies at Andover Newton Theological School, Union Seminary, and Boston University. She was a poet and a spiritual counselor, who worked at Wellesley College, the Episcopal Divinity School, and Bethany Convent, all in the Boston area. She was married to the late Dr. Leroy S. Rouner, Professor of Philosophy and Religion at Boston University, and was the mother of four children: Stephen Rainsford of Chelsea, MA, Jonathan and Christina, both of Brooklyn, NY, and Timothy, who died in 1977. A memorial service will be held May 30, 2012, 10:30am at the chapel of the Society of St. John the Evangelist (SSJE) Episcopal Monastery, 980 Memorial Dr, Cambridge, MA.

Lawsuits over copycatting in reality television have gone nowhere in the past, but CBS has suggested to ABC that it may consider one over a summer show called ''Glass House.'' The format is similar to CBS's long-running summer series ''Big Brother,'' and ABC has hired many former production members from that show. On Friday CBS sent a sternly worded letter to ABC about it. The letter implies, without directly saying so, that CBS will sue ABC over copyright infringement. The letter said that CBS was ''putting ABC on notice that its continued development and production of 'Glass House' exposes ABC to liability.'' The letter said the elements of the new show are ''substantially and strikingly'' similar to ''Big Brother.'' In ''Glass House,'' which has its debut on June 18, 14 people are chosen to live in a house all summer with cameras on them in pursuit of a cash prize -- the essence of ''Big Brother'' competition. In the past copyright cases have proved nearly impossible for reality-show plaintiffs to win because, in simple terms, everybody's reality is inherently different. The total number of former staff members on ''Glass House'' is at least 18, according to the CBS letter, all of whom signed nondisclosure agreements when they worked for ''Big Brother.'' The CBS letter argued that it would be impossible for anyone who signed such a letter to help produce a similar show without breaching the agreement. ABC had yet to respond to the CBS letter or requests for comment by Sunday afternoon.

Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. said on Sunday that he was ''absolutely comfortable'' with same-sex marriages and was heartened by their growing acceptance across the country, a position that moves well beyond the ''evolving'' views that President Obama has said he holds on the issue. The comments, which aides described as the off-the-cuff views of a vice president not known for fidelity to a script, sent the White House scrambling to clarify that Mr. Biden was not articulating an official change in policy, a reaction that highlighted the administration's unease over the subject.
To the Editor: Re ''Cozy Deal'' (editorial, April 29):
To the Editor: Re ''Writers of the World'' (Sunday Review, April 29):

MORALITY in big business -- that enduring oxymoron -- is a hot cinematic topic again (for reasons too obvious and painful to mention), with movies like last year's ''Margin Call'' and the forthcoming ''Cosmopolis'' brooding over Faustian deals made by white-collar heels. The director and writer Paul Weitz, who has brought a distinctively mordant perspective to both theater (''Trust'') and film (''About a Boy''), is now tilling that territory onstage, though presumably with a lighter touch. His ''LONELY, I'M NOT,'' which opens Monday at Second Stage Theater, considers the plight of Porter, a burnt-out corporate nova trying to reignite his life. Porter is being portrayed, most auspiciously, by Topher Grace, in his professional stage debut. Mr. Grace, though best known as the endearingly awkward Eric Forman on ''That '70s Show'' on television, brought disarming charm to what might be considered a before-picture variation on Porter in Mr. Weitz's 2004 film, ''In Good Company.'' Trip Cullman here directs Mr. Grace and a cast that includes Olivia Thirlby (of the movies ''Juno'' and Mr. Weitz's ''Being Flynn'' released in March) and the invaluable Lisa Emery. Through May 27, 305 West 43rd Street, Clinton; (212) 246-4422, 2st.com; $75.

I feel Daniel Smith's pain, because I, too, am a worrywart. Like him, I imagine that if I had a big religion, I could pray and believe, and that would take care of all the worries. But how does an atheist pray? I worry about everything from whether my dog is bored to decapitation by ceiling fan. A friend calls my worries ''white-girl worries,'' and I worry about that. SUSAN ORLINS,

The school held its fashion graduation show on Thursday, and Ms. Menkes and I -- along with Mr. Treacy, Sarah Burton of Alexander McQueen, and Princess Reema Bandar Al-Saud, a prominent retailer -- were there to meet students and talk about our jobs.

LAS VEGAS -- Late Saturday, Miguel Cotto did to Floyd Mayweather what opponents rarely, if ever, do to Floyd Mayweather. Cotto made him bleed. It started when Cotto landed a quick, direct left hand square on Mayweather's nose in the fifth round. Blood trickled down his chin and dripped off his face, an announcement to the packed Grand Garden Arena that Mayweather, the self-proclaimed best boxer in the sport's history, had himself a fight.

Thomas Beller In ''In-Between Days'' (Page 62), Thomas Beller, a writer and assistant professor of English at Tulane University, waxes metaphysical on a life divided between two places he loves /-- New York and New Orleans. He was a co-founder of Open City, a literary magazine started in 1990 that shut down last year, but his Web site Mr. Beller's Neighborhood continues to publish original work by city dwellers like Jonathan Ames and Saïd Sayrafiezadeh. The author of three books, including ''How to Be a Man: Scenes From a Protracted Boyhood,'' Beller is at work gathering his cache of autobiographical essays into a collection; he has also just inked a deal with Amazon Lives to write a biography of J. D. Salinger.

Fascinators, those miniature hats worn at rakish angles that came into focus at the royal wedding a year ago, were the highlight last week of the 30th Frederick Law Olmsted luncheon of the Women's Committee of the Central Park Conservancy. Even a carriage horse wore one. Another highlight of this glorious spectacle: the profile hat. White was a favorite color, and the printed spring coats were standouts, along with dresses of all lengths. Towering headdresses included a nest of owls, paper roses and a bamboo umbrella frame.

Next month, pop culture's court painter, LeRoy Neiman, turns 91, an occasion he'll celebrate by publishing an often amusing autobiography, ''All Told'' (Lyons Press, $30). ''Plenty of others have had their say about me and my art, for better or worse,'' Neiman said in an e-mail interview, perhaps alluding to critics who have dismissed as commercial his crazy-colored renderings of athletes, presidents and Playboy Bunnies. ''But until now, I've never told my own story.'' That story begins in Minnesota, where Neiman grew up tough and poor. Enough happens to him in the 1940s alone to fill a book: he spends a night in jail for brawling and ships off to basic training the next day. When G.I.'s land on Omaha Beach, the Army gives them condoms to protect their rifle muzzles; Neiman uses his to safeguard his cigars. He eventually goes AWOL in Belgium, paints murals for the Red Cross, bootlegs Cognac and loses a girlfriend to Marlene Dietrich.

Seau, who made 12 Pro Bowls, went to two Super Bowls and was named to the 1990s All-Decade Team, had a gunshot wound to the chest. His death was later ruled to be a suicide. (Published May 2)

An article on April 15 about the actress Julia Louis-Dreyfus and her new television series ''Veep,'' in which she plays the vice president, misstated the timing of the filming of a scene that parallels a similar event that happened to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. The frozen yogurt scene was filmed after Biden's similar real-life experience in a custard shop, not before.

The Chemex, that iconic nonelectric coffee maker, has finally met its match. The Kone filter from Able Brewing Equipment ($55 at ablebrewing.com) is a gorgeous piece of coffee gear, a stainless steel filter that fits most cone drippers, and whose precise holes (cut by a photochemical process) allow for a steady flow while minimizing sediment. The resulting best-of-both-worlds brew has the richness of French press and the clean flavor of drip. And unlike other metal filters, there's no mesh to scrub. Now in its third iteration (a bumper was added, and its holes reconfigured), the Kone is a fixture at next-generation coffee bars like Café Grumpy on Manhattan's Lower East Side and Intelligentsia Coffee and Tea in Venice, Calif. Able's founder, Keith Gehrke, a former roaster at a coffee company and a co-founder of Coava in Portland, Ore., is now working on a ceramic coffee maker. Soon, the Kone will have its match, too. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

The couple, both 24, graduated cum laude from Columbia and met at the university's summer program in Beijing. They will both use the surname Ma-Weaver.
Here are Michael R. Bloomberg's main realms of power and his key aides and allies.

When a city politician speaks about schools, you can be sure a conversation with Michael Mulgrew happened first. Mr. Mulgrew, president of the United Federation of Teachers, the city's largest union of public school workers, has become one of the most influential figures in New York education, the hot topic of next year's mayoral race. Labor has fallen out of favor in City Hall thanks to a wealthy mayor who does not depend on unions' donations or their formidable get-out-the-vote efforts, but that will change in 2013, when the race could be decided in a Democratic primary with heavy turnout from the left-leaning teachers' union, which has 200,000 active and retired members.

AS multiple tornadoes struck the Dallas area on April 3, a custom-built Ford F-550 Super Duty pickup suddenly went from show truck to fully engaged fire department support vehicle. ''We were scared when we took it out there, because it had never been driven more than three miles,'' Brad Snyder, vice president for marketing at NewScope Marketing, the branding and design company that customized the truck for Ford Motor, said. ''It came through with flying colors.''

Melissa Ann Lun, a daughter of Christine and Paul Lun of Orinda, Calif., was married Thursday at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau in New York to Samuel Paul Frankfort, the son of Bobbie and Lew Frankfort of New York. Josephine Tagliarini, a staff member of the New York City Clerk's Office, officiated. On May 12, the couple will take part in a religious ceremony in the Bahamas, to be led by Rabbi Bruce S. Block, at the Ocean Club, a hotel on Paradise Island. Mrs. Frankfort, 30, is the public relations and marketing director in New York for Le Top, a company in Richmond, Calif., that designs and manufactures children's clothing. Her parents founded the company; her father is president, her mother is vice president. The bride graduated magna cum laude from the University of San Diego.

Yellow-cab drivers may not like Carl E. Heastie, the six-term assemblyman from the Bronx who has helped to lead efforts to expand livery pickups in northern Manhattan and the other boroughs. But political insiders say Mr. Heastie's power lies in his ability to unite the famously fractious Bronx, where rival political families have taken grudge-holding to new levels (Example A: the Díaz versus Espada saga). Now, for the first time in years, there is a truce in the borough, with political leaders not just on speaking terms but also actively working toward common goals like economic development.

LEVENSON--Stanley M.,M.D., 95, University Professor Emeritus, Albert Einstein College of Medicine, Bronx, NY, died on March 28, 2012, in San Francisco, CA. He was born in Boston, MA, on May 25, 1916, the son of Anna and Nathan and brother of Irving. He attended Boston Latin School '33; Harvard College '37; and Harvard Medical School '41. After medical school, he worked on development of the oxygen mask used during World War II. As an intern at Beth Israel Hospital in Boston, he met Eleanor Belloff, a nurse, who became his wife of more than 51 years. He began work at Boston City Hospital as a burn fellow shortly before the Cocoanut Grove fire, a major event in the history of burn care. Beginning in 1947, he served as Chief, Radiobiology, Army Medical Nutrition Laboratory in Chicago. At the Medical College of Virginia in Richmond, he was a resident in surgery. In 1953, he moved to Walter Reed Army Institute of Research, Washington, D.C., where he was Chief, Surgical Metabolism; Director, Basic Surgical Research; and Director, Germfree Research. He was also Associate Clinical Professor of Surgery, Georgetown Medical School. In 1961, he joined the faculty of Albert Einstein College of Medicine, Bronx, NY, as Professor of Surgery; Director, Surgical Intensive Care Burn Unit; and Director, Germfree Research Program. He became University Professor in 1986 and University Professor Emeritus in 1987. He worked until 2002, when he moved to San Francisco, CA. He was the author or co-author of more than 390 publications on burns, nutrition, wound healing, and other subjects. He received many honors including: National Institutes of Health Research Career Award, 1962-1987; Harvey S. Allen Distinguished Service Award, American Burn Association, 1976; McCollum Award, American Society for Clinical Nutrition, 1983; first Lifetime Achievement Award, Wound Healing Society, 1993; first Lifetime Achievement Award, Jacobi Hospital, Bronx Municipal Hospital Medical Center, 1999. He was predeceased by his parents, brother, and wife. He is survived by his daughters: Toby Sherwood of San Francisco, CA, and Laurie (Gary) Mesibov of Chapel Hill, NC; two grandsons: Brian (Sally) Mesibov of Charlotte, NC, and Todd Mesibov (Kate Eyes) of Chapel Hill, NC, and three great-granddaughters: Anna, Claire, and Eleanor. A Funeral was held April 1, 2012, and he was buried next to his wife in Greenwich, CT. The family may be reached at: smlevensonfamily @gmail.com.

To the Sports Editor; Re ''Rivera Hurts Knee; Career May Be Over,'' May 4: Identifying the greatest baseball hitter who ever lived will always be a subject of debate. But when it comes to the greatest closer, the debate focuses on who is second best. Even if he never throws another pitch, Mariano Rivera is and I believe always will be the greatest closer who ever lived.

FRANCK--Vanya, April 28th aged 83: actor, writer, teacher, designer, counselor, friend. Formerly married to Charles Jarrott. Survived by sister Esther, nieces Elaine, Vivian, Jennifer: nephews Ted, Wood. Her credo: "Creating beauty is never a waste of time".

The unpredictable nature of this season's Stanley Cup playoffs asserted itself yet again last week when the Nashville Predators, who were trailing Phoenix by two games to none and being solidly outplayed, suspended their top two scorers for Game 3 of their second-round series, and were better off for it. Without Alexander Radulov and Sergei Kostitsyn in the lineup, the Predators shut out the Coyotes, 2-0. Even with the suspension lifted for Game 4, Radulov and Kostitsyn did not dress Friday and their team was shut out, 1-0, in Nashville.

Allison Beth Kelrick and Andrew Harold Labovitz were married Saturday evening at the Harbor Beach Marriott Resort & Spa, a hotel in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. Rabbi Jeffrey Kurtz-Lendner officiated, with Rabbi Ron Segal taking part. The bride, 28, is an assistant vice president specializing in regulatory affairs at Markit, a financial information services company in New York. She graduated from Emory and received a law degree from the Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law at Yeshiva University.

The Rev. A. R. Bernard, pastor of the 36,000-member Christian Cultural Center in southeast Brooklyn, can identify, it seems, with half the city. He is Panamanian by birth, but a New Yorker since age 4. African-American, but also of white and Latino heritage. Republican, but he voted for Barack Obama. A born-again Christian, but once a member of the Nation of Islam. He spreads the Gospel, but is close with Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who is Jewish, and speaks with him roughly every other week. ''We clicked,'' Mr. Bernard said. Mr. Bernard, 59, is an adept political force in New York City, a preacher who would rather guide public policy behind the scenes than shout about it in front of the cameras. His discretion and his willingness to work with people with whom he disagrees on some matters -- like, he said, Christine C. Quinn, the City Council speaker who is a lesbian -- have made him a moderate in the evangelical Christian world, and a sought-after bridge between liberal politicians and more conservative constituencies. (His church is the largest in the region.)

ROTHMAN--Barbara. Barbara Greenebaum Rothman, 77, died peacefully on May 1 after doing what she loved most, spending celebratory time with family. Bobbi raised three children, earned her Master's and Ph.D., became a family and child therapist and opened a successful practice in Beverly Hills. She co-authored "The Crowded Bed", a framework for couple therapy. She was a proud graduate of Smith College '56, and generously supported both Smith and The Southern California Counseling Center. Bobbi will best be remembered by family and her many friends as a source of strength, encouragement, and love that continually filled our lives with joy and security. She leaves her beloved husband of almost forty years, Bernard Rothman; her children, Ellen, Jimmy (and Jane) and Andrew; brother Carl Schlanger (and June); nephew Eric; step children, Tibby, Mike, David, Jenn and Nick; lifelong best friend Jo-Ann Malkin, and the most recent loves of her life, her grandchildren; Casey, Claire, Luke, Dillon, Matthew, Emma, Chris, Trevor, Jack Ryan and Bodhi. A celebration of Bobbi's life will be held on May 18 at 11am at Hillside Memorial Park in Los Angeles.

The story unfurls along the West Side of the city's hallowed underground cartography, more than 30 years after a zealous band of mapmakers first converged to reimagine New York's sprawling jigsaw of subway lines. Their task was formidable: devise a modern guide to replace the old map, designed by Massimo Vignelli in 1972 with an artist's touch but a less-than-faithful adherence to the city's true geography.

One way to look at ballet is to concentrate on the choreography; and in this respect New York City Ballet has unmatched wealth in terms of both quantity and quality. Its spring season, which began on Tuesday, brought 12 ballets into repertory by Saturday night, going all the way back to 1934 (George Balanchine's ''Serenade''), and up to 2006 (Christopher Wheeldon's ''DGV: Danse à Grande Vitesse''). Next week's additions include two world premieres. This abundance, phenomenal elsewhere, is ordinary at City Ballet. There are other ways to take in ballet, though: for example, by concentrating on dancers, on dancing (not necessarily the same thing), on history and on music. Wednesday night's performance began with one of the company's rightly popular See the Music talks, in which the conductor Andrews Sill spoke of Tchaikovsky's ''Serenade for Strings'' and of Balanchine's structural reordering of it in ''Serenade.'' (The third movement is played after the fourth.) He also paid a touching personal tribute to the conductor Hugo Fiorato, who died last month. For decades Mr. Fiorato was a constant part of City Ballet's existence and gave many performances a particular warmth.

LOS ANGELES -- Moments before the opening face-off between the Los Angeles Kings and the St. Louis Blues on Sunday, the Staples Center video board showed a message for fans of a team with a predominantly frustrating history. ''It's our time!''

Samuel Jacob Zalutsky and Edward Martin Boland are to be married Sunday evening at Studio 450, an event space in Manhattan. Piper E. Kerman, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, is to officiate. Mr. Zalutsky (left), 42, is a filmmaker in Manhattan. He wrote, directed and produced ''You Belong to Me,'' a psychological thriller that appeared on pay-per-view television and was released on DVD in 2008. His other work includes ''Stefan's Silver Bell'' (2001) and ''SuperStore'' (2004), short narrative films that later appeared on the WNET television series ''Reel New York.'' He is also a screenwriting instructor at Spalding University in Louisville, Ky. He graduated from Yale and received a Master of Fine Arts degree in film from New York University.

An opinion essay last Sunday about President Obama's record as a wartime president misstated one of the countries where he has embraced the use of drones or covert military units. It is Somalia, not Syria. In addition, the biographical note with the essay referred incorrectly to the writer, Peter L. Bergen. He is the director of the national security studies program at the New America Foundation, not the director of the foundation. (Steve Coll is the foundation's president.)

ASHWORTH--Lou, died April 30th, 2012 at home in Eugene, Oregon. Born Betty Lou Sawyer in 1920 in Santa Barbara, Lou married the late William Ashworth in 1945. She is survived by her children Margaret Ashworth Wilson, Polly Ashworth, and Warren Ashworth, and a remarkably symmetrical brood of male grandchildren, Peter and Eric Wilson, Geoffrey and Seth Horner, Sam and Jacob Ashworth. Lou worked most of her life, first with the writer's unit at MGM then as Norman Corwin's assistant producing radio shows. Later she worked at Simon and Schuster-in its heyday, then American Heritage Publishing, Vinyard Books, and for many years at McGraw-Hill where she was a senior editor of trade books. Donations may be made to the Eugene Public Library or the Larchmont Public Library.

He was 83. His death was announced by the Marshall Donnelly Combs Funeral Home in Nashville. Mr. Lindsey had been in poor health after a stroke in March.

I think there's another reason we don't have legal access to entheogenic substances in addition to the three the story's author, Lauren Slater, presented: our society's profound fear of transcendence. It's instructive to note that it was the early Christian Church that prohibited the Eleusinian Mysteries, during which ancient Greek and Roman people, for many hundreds of years, experienced a transcendent religious experience through the skillful use of myth, ritual and some sort of psychoactive drug. The church felt threatened by the ability of individuals to have spiritual experiences outside of its domain. TARA,

A few months after the abstract painter Richard Diebenkorn died in 1993 his family visited Knoedler & Company, the gallery on the Upper East Side of Manhattan that had long been his dealer. His wife, Phyllis; his daughter, Gretchen; and an art scholar went to see two gouache drawings that the gallery had recently acquired and that it hoped to sell as works from Diebenkorn's celebrated Ocean Park series. What happened at the meeting nearly two decades ago is now a matter of dispute, one that has only grown in significance as the gallery, once venerable and now closed, battles accusations that it sold many works of modern art that were actually sophisticated forgeries.

SULLIVAN--Daniel Downs. Daniel Downs Sullivan, AIA. March 29, 1930-April 8, 2012. Palm Springs, CA/Truro, Cape Cod, MA. It is with sadness that Dan's family shares their loss. A devoted family man and friend, passionate modernist architect; his spirit lives on. He is survived by his former wife, Louise; daughter, Catherine; sons, David; Peter, daughter-in-law, Diane; sister, Mary Simons and husband Walter; nieces, nephews, cousins and life partner, Al Gentle. He was predeceased by sons, Danny and Michael. Those wishing to make a contribution in his memory may call 760 864-6340 for details.

Accounts MillerCoors, Chicago, reorganized its agency roster by ending a long relationship with DraftFCB, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies, which had been the lead creative agency for brands like Coors Light and Coors Banquet beers, and also dismissing Razorfish, part of the Publicis Groupe, which created digital campaigns for Coors brands and also handled digital media duties for those brands. MillerCoors hired WPP to form a team of agencies in Chicago to handle the creative tasks for Coors brands and named Saatchi & Saatchi, New York, part of Publicis, to create campaigns for Miller Lite beer. Digitas, another Publicis unit, will continue to create digital ads for Miller Lite and also handle its digital media account. There were other changes as well, affecting tasks like media planning. DraftFCB had recently shared creative duties on Miller Lite with Saatchi & Saatchi and traced its ties to Coors to the work a predecessor, Foote Cone & Belding, began creating for Coors in 1979. DraftFCB said it would continue to work for MillerCoors in Canada and handle Coors in some overseas markets. Under DraftFCB, Coors Light passed Budweiser as the No. 2 beer brand in the United States, behind Bud Light. Prestige Brands, Irvington, N.Y., named AFG&, New York, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies, as agency of record for 16 over-the-counter drug and remedy brands, including Beano, Chloraseptic, Clear Eyes, Ecotrin, Efferdent, Goody's, Little Remedies and PediaCare. Billings were not disclosed. The assignments had been handled by agencies that included the Via Group, Portland, Me.

The Studio Company of American Ballet Theater has undergone various changes over the years, but in 2011 the group officially became a part of the ballet theater's Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis School. On Friday night that connection was apparent as injuries led to some prominent cast changes; dancers, plucked from the school as well as Ballet Theater, were called in to fill the gaps. With her performance in Balanchine's ''Tarantella,'' Catherine Hurlin, still a student at the school, could have filled an abyss.

For 14 years, Willie Mays Aikens had longed for this weekend to arrive. Convicted in 1994 on four counts of crack cocaine distribution and one count of using of a firearm during drug trafficking, Aikens, a World Series star for the Kansas City Royals, said May 5, 2012, was once his release date from federal prison. ''To look at my life the last four years, and everything I've accomplished,'' Aikens said by phone last week, ''where would I be if I had stayed incarcerated?''

Edged in snowcapped mountains that protect tidewater glaciers that calve into the sea, the 3.3-million-acre Glacier Bay National Park and Preserve (nps.gov/glba) in Alaska is mostly water. Yet, with the exception of charters, few cruise ships or tour boats spend more than a day in the park. But this summer, InnerSea Discoveries (innerseadiscoveries.com) will offer passengers eight-day itineraries that spend three days in the park aboard its new 76-passenger ship, Wilderness Explorer. Park rangers board the ship throughout the stay, guiding tours including rain-forest hikes on land, visits to remote coves via inflatable skiff and excursions by kayak.

1786 John Jacob Astor, a German immigrant, opens a fur shop in New York and subsequently dominates the trade. He puts his profits into real estate.

A full-floor apartment at 1030 Fifth Avenue that sold for $31.5 million was the biggest sale of the week, according to city records. The sale of the six-bedroom apartment, on the ninth floor, is also evidence that the wealthiest buyers still want to live in spacious prewar co-ops, despite a recent flurry of astronomical sales in luxury condominium buildings like 15 Central Park West and the Plaza.

Kirk Lombard, A Bay Area Fisherman And Self-Described ''Fish Nerd,'' Is Not Interested In Marquee Species. ''I Fish For The Things Nobody Wants,'' He Says. Rock Crab, Surf Smelt And Monkeyface Eel Have Long Been His Bread And Butter, And He Proudly Holds The California Record For The Largest Monkeyface Ever Caught (6.1 Pounds). When The Foraging Trend Took Off -- That Is, When He Started Noticing ''Young People In Tight Pants Pulling Wild Asparagus From Cracks In Sidewalks'' -- Lombard Founded A Company, Sea Forager, To Show Landlubbers How To Find The City's Little-Known Sea Creatures. He Conducts Sold-Out Tours To Some Of His Secret Fishing Holes, Where He Demonstrates Poke-Poling, A Method To Retrieve The Elusive Monkeyface. ''It's Great In Gumbo,'' Lombard Says.
