For the first time in history, the most precious achievements for a pitcher and a hitter have occurred in the same season. Josh Hamilton of the Texas Rangers belted four home runs on Tuesday night in Baltimore, just 17 days after Philip Humber of the Chicago White Sox tossed a perfect game in Seattle. The Rangers thumped the Orioles, 10-3, with Hamilton adding a double to set the American League's single-game record for total bases, with 18.

Americans expect politicians to be scripted on that great, unbounded stage that is public life. (The dangers of not being so have been confirmed in recent months by Mitt Romney's occasional moments of spontaneity.) But wouldn't life be more entertaining -- not to mention more euphonious -- if someone like Gore Vidal were writing their dialogue? That's what I was thinking as I watched the enjoyable Broadway revival of ''Gore Vidal's The Best Man,'' the 1960 drama about rivals for their party's presidential nomination. And I have the feeling that much of the audience was thinking the same thing. I mean, those guys up onstage were so naturally epigrammatic, especially the ones with whom Mr. Vidal's sympathies lie, that they couldn't open their mouths without casting pearls before us swine in the audience.

OMAHA -- ''When Charlie and I took this job, we did not agree to put our citizenship in a blind trust.'' That's what Warren Buffett said here over the weekend at Berkshire Hathaway's annual meeting when confronted by a shareholder question complaining that Mr. Buffett had become a public advocate for President Obama and the so-called Buffett Rule, which seeks to raise the tax rate on the wealthiest Americans - many of whom were in the audience.

WASHINGTON -- The suicide bomber dispatched by the Yemen branch of Al Qaeda last month to blow up a United States-bound airliner was actually an intelligence agent for Saudi Arabia who infiltrated the terrorist group and volunteered for the mission, American and foreign officials said Tuesday. In an extraordinary intelligence coup, the double agent left Yemen last month, traveling by way of the United Arab Emirates, and delivered both the innovative bomb designed for his aviation attack and inside information on the group's leaders, locations, methods and plans to the Central Intelligence Agency, Saudi intelligence and allied foreign intelligence agencies.

State Senator Adriano Espaillat's campaign to unseat Representative Charles B. Rangel received a boost on Tuesday from an unexpected quarter, when a ''super PAC'' based in Texas announced that it planned to support Mr. Espaillat against Mr. Rangel. The group, called the Campaign for Primary Accountability, has received most of its financing from a few businessmen with histories of donating to Republican causes, but it describes itself as nonpartisan and says its mission is to defeat longtime Congressional incumbents on the right and the left.

WASHINGTON -- Continuing its crackdown on Internet privacy violations, the Federal Trade Commission charged Myspace on Tuesday with violating federal law by breaching its promise not to share users' personal information, including their Web browsing habits, with advertising companies. The advertisers that tracked the online browsing habits of Myspace users were not charged, reflecting a general lack of laws governing online privacy. On Wednesday, the Senate Commerce committee will question officials from the F.T.C. and the Obama administration about their recent proposals to require companies to obtain consumers' permission to be tracked online.

You can see how ''Protected'' would work well at the New York International Fringe Festival, where it had its start. There's this comically nervous guy, afraid of his own shadow (for good reason -- he is brand-new in the witness protection program), dealing with his next-to-worst nightmare: a series of odd characters turning up, in rapid succession, at his front door. And he hasn't even finished installing the new locks. First there's Myrna (Cam Kornman in this Workshop Theater Company production), the wild-eyed older lady next door, who has brought a meat loaf supposedly made by her single daughter, Debra. Then there's Matt (Matt Walker), a new colleague who has followed our hero back from Home Depot -- and brought beer -- for no discernible reason. Then Debra (Dee Dee Friedman) shows up, carrying her omnipresent parasol (because SPF 50 isn't enough in the New Mexico sun), getting all obsessive-compulsive over dish washing and refusing to touch the doorknob.

The N.F.L. is making some of its former players aware of a study that found that they are likely to live longer than men in the general population. The study was commissioned by the players union and was sent by the league Tuesday to men who played in the N.F.L. before 1993. The study did not address the cognitive and mental health issues that have recently been linked to repeated blows to the head and that currently dominate the conversation about player safety. The National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health (Niosh), which conducted the study and released its findings in late January, said in its summary that it was now studying neurodegenerative causes of death among the same group.

DIGGING DEEPER The hedge fund Third Point sent Yahoo a request for records relating to its selection of Scott Thompson, below, a former eBay executive, as its chief executive, after Yahoo admitted that it had misstated its leader's academic credentials. The request follows Yahoo's admission, after prodding by the activist hedge fund, that while Mr. Thompson's official biography said that he had earned degrees in accounting and computer science from Stonehill College, in reality he held only the first. MICHAEL J. de la MERCED

An obituary on Monday about the actor George Lindsey misstated, in some copies, the current name of Florence State Teachers College, from which he graduated. It is the University of North Alabama, not the University of North Carolina.

NEW DELHI -- Admittedly, the timing was awkward. Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton arrived in New Delhi this week after declaring that India should reduce imports of Iranian oil and comply with Western sanctions. Yet across town, India and Iran were trying to figure out ways to do business together. In the main ballroom of a five-star hotel, an Iranian trade delegation met with Indian exporters, exchanging cards, sipping tea and nibbling on cookies. The Iranians met one Indian trade group on Monday, another on Tuesday and had more meetings planned in the country's financial capital, Mumbai -- a business courtship seemingly in open defiance of Mrs. Clinton's hard line.

GREENSBORO, N.C. -- In August 2009, with a grand jury investigating former Senator John Edwards and the public still unclear about whether the affair he admitted to a year earlier had indeed produced a child, he struggled with how to finally tell the truth. To do that, he turned to Wendy Button, 43, his longtime speechwriter, who had drafted speeches for Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama when they were in the Senate. At the heart of the conversations between Ms. Button and Mr. Edwards, and at the heart of this trial, is whether Mr. Edwards knew more than he now claims about the money used to cover up the affair. According to Ms. Button's testimony on Tuesday, he did.

Washington THE case of Chen Guangcheng, the dissident who escaped house arrest and sought refuge in the American Embassy in Beijing, attracted global attention not only because Mr. Chen bravely stood up for human rights in China but also because American officials seemed to stumble when he sought our help. But these cases are never simple.
To the Editor: Re ''A Battle With the Brewers,'' by Nicholas D. Kristof (column, May 6):

For more than a decade, the fiery guitar licks and pounding drums of Metallica's ''Enter Sandman'' were synonymous with winning in the ears of Yankees fans. But on Tuesday night, that heavy metal anthem was replaced in the ninth inning by the Southern finger pickings of ''Sweet Home Alabama,'' the Lynyrd Skynyrd classic that signified a changing of the guard, for at least this year. ''Enter Sandman'' was the tune that blared across Yankee Stadium when Mariano Rivera jogged in from the bullpen in save situations. But Rivera is gone for the season with a torn anterior cruciate ligament in his right knee, replaced, at least for now, by the Alabama native Dave Robertson.

Imagine a network of private highways that reserved a special lane for Fords to zip through, unencumbered by all the other brands of cars trundling along the clogged, shared lanes. Think of the prices Ford could charge. Think of what would happen to innovation when building the best car mattered less than cutting a deal with the highway's owners. A few years ago, Tim Wu, a professor at Columbia Law School and a leading thinker about the evolution of the ''information economy,'' warned members of the House judiciary committee that this could be the fate of the Internet. Companies offering broadband access, he said, should not be allowed to discriminate among services online. If they did, the best service would not always win the day. ''It's not who has a better product,'' he explained. ''It's who can make a deal with AT&T, Verizon, Comcast or Time Warner.''

The Department of Defense has identified 1,947 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently: CHILDS, Gregory L., 38, Master Sgt., Army; Warren, Ark.; Defense Logistics Agency.

A New Jersey roofer fell 30 to 40 feet through a partly collapsed roof into a container of acid on Monday and was rescued by co-workers, including one who jumped in to grab him, fire officials in Clifton, N.J., said. The roofer, Martin Davis, 44, was working on the roof of Swepco Tube, a pipe and tube manufacturer in Clifton, when part of the roof gave away and he plunged into a container of hydrofluoric acid, which fire officials said measured about 5 feet deep and 30 feet long. He was critically injured.

JEFFERY--Reuben, Jr.,of Southport, CT, beloved husband of the late Ann Jeffery, passed away peacefully in his home Saturday, May 5, 2012. Born January 31, 1923 in Syracuse, NY, the son of late Marie and Reuben Jeffery. He served in Japan with the U.S. Army 11th Airborne Division leaving the service at the end of the war as a Captain. Graduated from Yale, B.E. 1944 and Harvard Business School, M.B.A. 1949, with High Distinction and as a Baker Scholar. Thirty year career as an executive with E.I. DuPont de Nemours & Co. in the commercial resins division. He is survived by his two children; Reuben Jeffery, III of New York, NY and Martha Ann Jeffery of Bridgeport, CT; three grandchildren, Jocelyn Ann Jeffery, Reuben Jeffery IV and Robert Walker Jeffery; and his sister Jean Jeffery Greene of Syracuse, NY. He was predeceased by his brother, John Jeffery. A Memorial Service will be held Friday, May 18, 2012 at 11:00am at Greenfield Hill Congregational Church, 1045 Old Academy Road, Fairfield, CT. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory can be made to Greenfield Hill Congregational Church.

To the Editor: In ''The Campus Tsunami'' (column, May 4), David Brooks argues that American higher education must deal with online education, embracing it as a tool to transmit inexpensive and global knowledge. He suggests that the test will be how online education can push higher education away from information transmission and up to higher things.

ESTIN--Hans Howard, 83, of Hamilton, MA, died May 4, 2012. Investor, philanthropist and trustee, graduate of Tabor Academy and earned a BA in Economics from Harvard. Husband of Claudia Estin. Father of Hilary Hood of Mill Valley, CA and Alexandra Estin of Andover, NH. A memorial celebration of his life will be held at the Essex County Club, Manchester, MA 12:00pm on Saturday, May 12th. Complete obit and information: www.campbellfuneral.com.

The push for the N.F.L. to release the evidence it gathered during its investigation of the New Orleans Saints intensified Monday, when the lawyer for linebacker Jonathan Vilma -- who has been suspended for the 2012 season -- sent a letter to Commissioner Roger Goodell that contained a sweeping request for 17 types of evidence. In addition to asking for documents and communications that would establish that there was a bounty system and that Vilma had assisted in its formation and had pledged money for it, the lawyer, Peter Ginsberg, requested the names of the people the N.F.L. interviewed as part of its inquiry. Disclosing those names would almost surely reveal the identity of the whistle-blowers who reignited what was then a dormant investigation late in the 2011 season.

The Pop artist Robert Indiana, best known for his ''LOVE'' sculptures, in which the letters ''L'' and a tilted ''O'' rest above the letters ''V'' and ''E,'' is being sued by Joao Tovar, a collector from Monaco who says the artist renounced work that Mr. Tovar bought after first certifying it was authentic, according to The Bangor Daily News. Mr. Tovar bought 10 sculptures called ''PREM'' -- in which that word, Hindi for love, was spelled out in Roman letters arranged much like those in ''LOVE'' -- from John Gilbert, a longtime business associate of Mr. Indiana's. The sculptures, which Mr. Tovar claims were valued at $1.5 million in 2009, were slated to be auctioned at Christie's before Mr. Indiana rejected them as his work, according to the suit. Mr. Indiana says that the piece of paper saying ''For Tovar'' that he signed was simply a souvenir signature.

LESSER--Lawrence. It is with deep sorrow that we record the passing of our esteemed member, Mr. Lawrence Lesser, and extend out deepest sympathy to his wife Caroline, and their family. Old Westbury Golf & Country Club Jeffrey Sands, President for the Board of Governors

A retired truck driver who was sentenced last year to 20 years in prison for sending text messages deemed insulting to Thailand's monarchy died in prison on Tuesday, his lawyer said. The man, Ampon Tangnoppakul, 61, was sentenced in November to five years for each of four text messages sent from his mobile phone. The court did not reveal the content of the messages but said they went against the ''evident'' fact that King Bhumibol Adulyadej and Queen Sirikit ''are full of mercy and concerned about the entire population'' and could incite hatred of the rulers.

WHITE RAIN. Halo.Breck. Drene. Prell. Agree. Hälsa. Lustre-Creme. Gee, Your Hair Smells Terrific. Vidal Sassoon. Flex. There are enough discontinued, forgotten, moribund or also-ran hair-care brands to make marketers want to, well, pull out their hair. But that is not deterring Unilever, the consumer products giant. Unilever, which sells hair-care products under names like Dove, Finesse, Nexxus, Suave, TRESemmé and VO5, is introducing another hair-care brand in the United States.

LOS ANGELES -- Turning left, David Ayer swings his black Lexus up Martin Luther King Boulevard, through the battered area that used to be known as South Central. One side is lined with the alleys and ratty bungalows in which, last July, Mr. Ayer shot a movie about the underside of Los Angeles -- his third such effort as a director -- called ''End of Watch.'' On the other side is a liquor store, where, he mentions, his wife and her sister used to work and where the sister was robbed at gunpoint.

Having recently wrapped up its 11th annual running in New York, the Tribeca Film Festival is preparing to take a Tuscan holiday. On Monday, Tribeca Enterprises, the parent company of the Tribeca Film Festival, said it was working with IMG Artists, the performing arts management company, to create Tribeca Firenze, a series of film programming that will run in Florence, Italy, June 11 to June 18. Press representatives for Tribeca Firenze said that it would run as part of the Tuscan Sun Festival, the weeklong series of cultural and culinary events presented by IMG. Among the films that will be shown at Florence's Odeon Cinema, they said, will be the European premiere of ''The Zen of Bennett,'' a documentary about the singer Tony Bennett during the making of his album ''Duets II.'' Mr. Bennett is also scheduled to perform at the Teatro della Pergola on June 18 as part of the Tuscan Sun Festival's 24 Hour Plays project.

McCONNELL--John P.,on May 6, 2012. Retired Attorney, Navy Veteran WWII, St. John's University and Law School. Beloved husband of Theresa (Nee Murphy), devoted father of Patrick (Olena), Chris, Terence, Kevin (Virginia), Moira Tolan (Frank), Bernadette O'Donnell (Kevin), Margaret McCormick (Michael), and the late John. Loving grandfather of 27 and great-grandfather of two. Reposing at Denis S. O'Connor Funeral Home, 91-05 Beach Channel Dr., Rockaway Beach, NY. Funeral Mass Thursday 10:45am at St. Francis de Sales Church, Belle Harbor. Interment Calverton National Cemetery. Visiting Tuesday 7-10pm, Wednesday 2-5 and 7-10pm.

I CANNOT claim to have been an intimate friend of Craig Claiborne -- that fraternity could fit in a roomy banquette -- although over two decades of friendship I was the beneficiary of many quiet acts of kindness by this shy and complicated man. When I was a green freelance writer for The New York Times, for example, suddenly I became a candidate for a staff position. And I got it, only later to learn that Craig had pulled the strings. Astonishingly, after only nine months at the paper, I was offered the job of restaurant critic. Again, it was Craig working behind the scenes. And there were many more examples. I suppose the closest I came to intimacy was the day I asked him to lunch in order to elicit advice concerning the job. A little emotional back story: Craig's mansion of woes had many rooms, one of which centered on his amorous relationship with a certain retired pediatrician named Jim. Jim lived in Florida with his unsuspecting (until she suspected) wife. Consequently, the two saw each other only occasionally. This is about all I knew, or cared to know.

On ''Glee'' this spring, a transgender character named Unique is competing in a sing-off. On ''Grey's Anatomy,'' Arizona and Callie are adjusting to married life, having been pronounced ''wife and wife'' last year. On ''Modern Family,'' the nation's most popular television show, Cameron and his partner Mitchell are trying to adopt a second child.

To the Editor: You report that White House aides are attempting to create distance between official policy and Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.'s claim to being ''absolutely comfortable'' with same-sex marriages (''A Scramble as Biden Backs Same-Sex Marriage,'' front page, May 7). If President Obama will not come out in support of equal marriage rights for the gay community now, then when will he?

KIEL, GERMANY -- When the results in Germany's most recent state election came down, the Pirate Party cued up what could be their new theme song: ''We are the Champions'' by the rock group Queen blared from the speakers as exit polls showed the young party entering the third regional legislature in three elections. The 8.2 percent share of the vote the Pirates won on Sunday in Schleswig-Holstein, the largely rural, northernmost state, solidified the presence of the upstart party in Germany's political landscape, proving its ability to attract voters beyond the Twittersphere who are fed up with a political bureaucracy they view as disconnected from the people.
Coastal erosion in South Kingstown, R.I., has shrunk parts of the town’s beach to less than a dozen feet during high tide.
Despite a momentary slip three days earlier, the Heat, led by LeBron James’s 29 points, left no doubt about their superiority in clinching the first-round series over the Knicks, four games to one.

The Eastern Conference finals were within the Rangers’ grasp Wednesday night, but they fell behind 1 minute 28 seconds into the game on a power-play goal from the Capitals’ Alex Ovechkin and went on to lose.
The columnist William C. Rhoden talks about the important things he received from his recently deceased father.
President Obama endorsed same-sex marriage in a television interview on Wednesday, taking a definitive stand on one of the most contentious and politically charged social issues of the day.
The choreographer and style setter Jack Cole is celebrated in “Heat Wave,” a musical revue.

Signs that Ciudad Juárez is on the road to recovery after years of an onslaught by drug-trafficking cartels include the young people who have joined art collectives in lieu of gangs and the recently reopened nightclubs that are drawing crowds out after dark.
A three-story glass box anchored on a steep slope, designed by the architect Allyn Morris, becomes home to an octogenarian admirer.
Tell us how much of an impact President Obama’s endorsement of same-sex marriage will have on your vote in the 2012 election.
Properties in Hawaii, Connecticut and Los Angeles.
ABC News Interview
The hair pioneer, who died at the age of 84, helped women change the way they thought about their tresses.
President Obama declares support for same-sex marriage in an interview with ABC.
Seven of nine states expected to be close in the presidential election have laws or constitutional provisions that prohibit same-sex marriage.
The defense lawyer for Thomas Gioeli reacts to the jury’s decision to acquit his client in the 1997 murder of an off-duty police officer, but convict him of other charges.
With gay marriage the hot-button topic, the president sits for a TV interview | A double agent’s role in thwarting a terrorist bomb plot | Steve Coll on the near-sovereign power of Exxon Mobil.
A mini-mammoth that stood about three feet high joins Sifrhippus, the first horse, which shrank to the size of a cat as the climate warmed about 56 million years ago.
Full text of Richard Lugar’s statement distributed shortly after his concession speech Tuesday night.
Two new books teach the basics of ballet, and a third stars a swan auditioning for — what else? — “Swan Lake.”
A shake-up at Green Mountain Coffee; Toyota on the road to recovery; and how being gay on TV became uncontroversial.
Days of drama preceded the agreement between the United States and China in the case of Chen Guangcheng, but the negotiations ultimately reflected a maturing relationship, officials said.
Corrections appearing in print on May 9, 2012.

Mike McQueary, the Penn State football assistant whose report that Jerry Sandusky sexually abused a child in the showers led to Joe Paterno’s firing, filed a notice of a lawsuit against the university.
Connecticut reached a four-year, $4.55 million agreement with the regional cable network SNY to televise its women’s basketball games.
Novak Djokovic, unhappy with the condition of center court, overcame a frustrating debut on the blue clay at the Madrid Open to reach the third round.
Liverpool took advantage of Chelsea’s erratic defending to earn a 4-1 victory Tuesday, gaining a small measure of revenge for its F.A. Cup final loss Saturday.
The ultramarathon runner Micah True, 58, died from heart disease while on a routine 12-mile run in late March in the mountains of southwestern New Mexico, authorities said.
Host Finland, the defending champion, regained the top spot in its group at the world championships in Helsinki with a 5-2 win over Switzerland.
Mike Rizzo was upset that Phillies pitcher Cole Hamels hit the rookie Bryce Harper with a pitch and then said he deliberately plunked him.
Playing without Derrick Rose and the emotional leader Joakim Noah, the undermanned Bulls beat the Philadelphia 76ers, 77-69, to stave off elimination and cut their first-round series deficit to 3-2.
A South African judge ordered prosecutors to investigate whether the government of Zimbabwe had committed human rights abuses, saying it would benefit Zimbabweans and South Africans.
Ai Weiwei, the rebel artist, said Tuesday that a court in Beijing had agreed to hear his lawsuit against the city’s tax authorities.

The Foreign Ministry announced that it would postpone a summit meeting of Central and Eastern European countries because many leaders planned to boycott it to protest the treatment of an opposition leader.
Lawyers on both sides of the Roger Clemens perjury trial have been told to stop asking unnecessary questions and stop showing needless photos.
Anton Stralman scored the opening goal in Game 5 against the Capitals on Monday and had a key role in the game-winner in overtime.
The Mets scored four runs in the seventh inning and, for the second night in a row, staged a late rally to defeat the Phillies.
Josh Hamilton of the Texas Rangers belted four home runs on Tuesday night in Baltimore, just 17 days after Philip Humber of the Chicago White Sox tossed a perfect game in Seattle.
After Ivan Nova allowed two runs in seven innings, Dave Robertson loaded the bases in the ninth but escaped the jam to cap a 5-3 victory over the Rays.
“Orange, Red, Yellow,” a 1961 canvas by Mark Rothko, sold for nearly $87 million, and prices for artists like Pollock also brought record amounts.
The candidate, Karen Turner, placed second in the three-way race.
Mr. Totenberg influenced generations of musicians, and appeared on countless recordings.
Mr. Wolfe, who got his start at the BBC, went on to help start up a zany American comedy.
Philadelphia, a Stanley Cup favorite after defeating Pittsburgh, was bounced out in five games after David Clarkson scored a fitting go-ahead goal for the aggressive, opportunistic Devils.
Germany’s devotion to the euro runs extremely deep, but there is a growing conviction that it is up to Greece to follow through on its commitments and that Europe is done negotiating.
Two N.C.A.A. enforcement officials traveled to Everett High School in Massachusetts, where Nerlens Noel spent his freshman and sophomore years.
Progress is reported in allowing an oversight board to inspect auditing firms in China whose clients issue securities traded in public markets in the United States.
The Knicks return to Miami, improbably, with their playoff hopes narrowly alive and Amar’e Stoudemire thriving again.
Under a bill signed last week, New York City will study whether it is feasible to generate hydroelectric power from the city’s water supply.
Cate Jenkins argued that the agency had fired her for accusing it of understating the toxicity of the dust at the Lower Manhattan site.
In Andy Pettitte, , the Yankees have again turned to a great from the past, underscoring the franchise’s struggle to develop young starters.

In a rare step, doctors revising psychiatry’s diagnostic manual have retreated from two controversial proposals that would have expanded the number of people identified as having psychotic or depressive disorders.
High prices can be a major obstacle for low-income Americans who want to access the Internet.
Federal officials said William Barnason, a building superintendent, would try to enter women’s apartments while drunk and demanded sexual favors for rent reductions.
The Washington University School of Law will offer a master’s degree in United States law in partnership with 2tor, an education technology company.
Amsterdam’s Repair Cafe encourages people to bring old items that they might have otherwise thrown out to have them restored by expert volunteers.
The sheik, who is the prime minister and foreign minister of Qatar and a member of that country’s royal family, hoped to buy two apartments at 907 Fifth Avenue and join them together as one.
After a career-worst 40th-place finish at the Masters and a missed cut a week ago, Tiger Woods is facing criticism from all corners at the Players Championship.
The outrage is gone. Today, it’s rare to hear a complaint about shows like “Modern Family” or the drama “Smash,” which has five gay characters.
Brad Richards’s goal with 7.6 seconds left in regulation of Monday’s Game 5 win over the Washington Capitals was the latest score to tie a playoff game in Rangers history.
The French act as though they don’t care about politicians’ private lives, but, behind the scenes, there’s as much lusty action as a French farce.
Jason Itzler, who pleaded guilty to promoting prostitution three weeks ago, told a judge that he wanted a new lawyer after reading a profile of the one he had.
Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, who had spent 15 years under house arrest, received her passport on Tuesday. She has planned a trip to Norway and Britain.
Moto-polo, a game in Rwanda that utilizes motorcycles instead of horses, has few rules, lots of beer breaks and frenzied speeds of up to 45 miles per hour.
The plans to renovate the flagship building of the New York Public Library are forward-thinking. But the essence of this cultural landmark should be preserved.
The winning numbers for May 8, 2012, in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
Bill de Blasio, a potential mayoral candidate, wants Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to determine whether the police stops are warranted and based on reasonable suspicion.

The Campaign for Primary Accountability, which aims to defeat longtime Congressional incumbents, is supporting State Senator Adriano Espaillat, a Democratic opponent of Representative Charles B. Rangel’s.
In Rwanda, where horses are few and motorcycles are abundant, a variation of polo known as moto-polo has sprung up, becoming a popular sport to watch and play among locals and foreigners.
The majority of senators retiring or facing tough re-elections this year were ranked in the middle of the Senate’s ideological spectrum in 2011.
Financial institutions should be required to explain their overdraft programs and include complete pricing information about different overdraft options.
The Supreme Court must reaffirm the legal right of prisoners who are held without charges to challenge their detention.
Notable measures taken up or approved during Connecticut’s legislative session, which is to end on Wednesday.
President Obama once ran on hope. Now he needs to spend more time persuading dubious and disillusioned voters how he is going to achieve his goals.
The ruling overturned a decision that sided with County Executive Robert P. Astorino, who vetoed an antidiscrimination measure in 2010.

WHITNEY--Edward Farley, died on May 6, 2012 in Portsmouth, New Hampshire at the age of 96. Born on August 12, 1915 in Locust, New Jersey, he graduated with honors in 1938 from Harvard University where he was captain of the rugby team. A resident of Dublin, New Hampshire for over 60 years, he served as selectman for many years and was active in the life of the town. He was predeceased by his much-loved wife, Millicent Bonner Bowring Whitney on December 25, 1987, and is survived by his children, Cynthia Farley of Lee, NH, Edward Bonner of New York City, Amy Susan of Lambertville, NJ, Richard Duane of Lee, NH, and James Warren of Bowdoinham, ME, and by ten grandchildren and six great- grandchildren. A gentle, kind and generous man, he will be much missed. A funeral service will be held at 3pm on May 13, 2012 at the Dublin Community Cemetery, followed by a reception at the Dublin School.

New York City's budding technology industry is growing rapidly by attracting investors and engineering talent despite spotty access to a reliable broadband network, according to a study released on Wednesday. The study, ''New Tech City,'' conducted by the Center for an Urban Future, concluded that the technology industry is growing faster in New York City than anywhere else in America and that the city now trails only Silicon Valley as a hub for the development of new technology companies. The study's authors, Jonathan Bowles and David Giles, identified 486 technology companies that had been founded in the city since 2007 and determined that the financial crisis and the recession that followed did not slow the industry's growth.

Nicholas deB. Katzenbach, who helped shape the political history of the 1960s, facing down segregationists, riding herd on historic civil rights legislation and helping to map Vietnam War strategy as a central player in both the Kennedy and Johnson administrations, died Tuesday night at his home in Skillman, N.J. He was 90. His death was confirmed by his wife, Lydia.

MIAMI - Based on callers to radio sports-talk shows and some fan comments on social media here, one would think the Miami Heat are the ones on the brink of elimination from the N.B.A. playoffs. But inside American Airlines Arena, the vibe from the players and Heat Coach Erik Spoelstra is quite the opposite. Two days removed from a tough 89-87 loss to the Knicks in Game 4 of their first-round matchup, Spoelstra, LeBron James and Dwyane Wade are looking forward, not backward.

10 P.M. (BBC America) WHITE HEAT As this six-part series created by Paula Milne (''Endgame'') begins, Charlotte (Juliet Stevenson) is summoned with her former roommates to the place where one of their own has died. A snapshot prompts memories of 1965, when she and five others were brought together by the apartment's owner, Jack (Sam Claflin), as a social experiment. The classes and professions are covered: Charlotte (played in her youth by Claire Foy) is a budding feminist; Lilly (MyAnna Buring), an artist; Victor (David Gyasi), a Jamaican law student; Jay (Reece Ritchie), the son of Indian immigrants who is pursuing a medical degree; Alan (Lee Ingleby), a geek; and Orla (Jessica Gunning), an Irish psychology major. Set against seminal moments from five decades, starting with the death of Winston Churchill, ''White Heat'' is fueled by bonds forged and broken. Above, from left, Mr. Claflin, Mr. Ingleby, Ms. Foy, Mr. Gyasi, Ms. Buring, Ms. Gunning and Mr. Ritchie. 7:15 P.M. (HBO Signature) SOMEWHERE (2010) Johnny Marco (Stephen Dorff), a movie star existing in a mind-numbing purgatory -- he drinks, he has anonymous sex, he burns rubber in his Ferrari -- at the Chateau Marmont hotel in Hollywood, finds something to live for after his ex-wife leaves Cleo (Elle Fanning), their 11-year-old daughter, in his care in what A. O. Scott, writing in The New York Times, called ''Sofia Coppola's exquisite, melancholy and formally audacious fourth feature.'' What happens, Mr. Scott added, ''is something marvelous: a film that never raises its voice (its loudest and most assertive sound is that Ferrari) or panders to your emotions, but that nonetheless has the power to refresh your perceptions and deepen your sympathies.'' Mr. Dorff portrays an insane director who kidnaps an actress (Melanie Griffith) and forces her to be in his movie in John Waters's ''Cecil B. Demented'' (2000), at 8 on Flix. Writing in The Times, Stephen Holden called this ''an amusing, cunningly made but less-than-hilarious outcry against Hollywood philistinism, an easy target if ever there was one.''

In most cases, ''Mad Men'' is bound by the history of the era in which it takes place. But on Sunday night, a new episode of that 1960s period drama that concluded with the Beatles song ''Tomorrow Never Knows'' appears to have made some history of its own, marking a rare instance in which a song written and recorded by that band has been licensed for use on a television series. ''It was always my feeling that the show lacked a certain authenticity because we never could have an actual master recording of the Beatles performing,'' Matthew Weiner, the creator and show runner of ''Mad Men,'' said in a telephone interview on Monday. ''Not just someone singing their song or a version of their song, but them, doing a song in the show. It always felt to me like a flaw. Because they are the band, probably, of the 20th century.''

GOULD--Honorable Bruce J.,83. Never out of love from the first evening walk with his wife to be, Karolyn, of 53 years. Experienced his greatest sense of contentment when simply in the same room as his wife, children and grandchildren. Innovative policy maker and judge. Relentless advocate dedicated to a life of public service, particularly to improving and safeguarding the housing of New Yorkers. His family's loss will be eased by the legacy of his significant contributions to improve the lives of others and by the love he shared with family and his remarkable world of friends. Predeceased by his wife. Survived by his four children, and their spouses: Sarah Kagan and her husband Stewart, Tom and his wife Maura, Roger and his wife Cathy Wagner, Melinda Konopko and her husband Elliot and nine grandchildren--Andrew, Joan, Ruth, Leo, Penelope, Aviva, Adam, Charlotte and Oliver. He is also survived by his brother Arnold and his wife Pearl and his sister-in-law, Barbara Elliot. Funeral will be at Riverside Memorial (76th and Amsterdam) on Friday, May 11 at 11 am. Donations: Karolyn and Bruce Gould Literacy Fund InwoodHouse.com

After months of planning, President Obama's media team has prepared an aggressive strategy to portray Mitt Romney as insensitive to the plight of working people and beholden to powerful interests. They have researched possible lines of attack and drafted language that can be dropped into an advertisement at a moment's notice.

PARKER--Sheryl (also known as, Sheryl Parker Zinberg) died peacefully in her home on Monday May 7, 2012, after a valiant fight with cancer. She will be missed for her great courage, intelligence, and generosity by her loving sister, Marian Schwartz, daughter, Louise (Stuart McMuldroch) and son James (Christan), nephews Robert (Ellen Brown) and Andy Schwartz, her niece Meli, and step-children Adele, David, and Helene Zinberg, together with many loving family and friends. She was the beloved wife of Arthur Parker (d. 1976) and Eugene Zinberg (d. 2004). Sheryl was a life long advocate for the poor and civil rights. She had a passion for world travel, culture, and politics. She is remembered for her dedication to the League of Women Voters where she was Vice-President and to the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services (JBFCS) where she worked in social services until her retirement in 1991. Services will be on Thursday May 10, 11am at the Riverside, Great Neck. In lieu of flowers, please send donations in her memory to the Hospice Care Network or the JBFCS.

9:12 p.m. | Updated In a court ruling with significant implications for the music industry, a California judge has dismissed a suit by two song publishing companies aimed at preventing Victor Willis, former lead singer of the 1970s disco group the Village People, from exercising his right to reclaim ownership of ''YMCA'' and other hit songs he wrote.

What amazing songs. That's the lingering impression from Tuesday night's Beacon Theater concert by the reunited Beach Boys, who until this year had not performed with Brian Wilson since 1996. Over half a century after three brothers (Brian, Carl and Dennis Wilson), a cousin (Mike Love) and a high school classmate (Al Jardine) started a band in 1961 in Hawthorne, Calif., the surviving original Beach Boys have put schisms, battles for credit and lawsuits behind them to perform songs that are no less startling for their Top 40 familiarity. The Beach Boys are in their 60s and 70s now, and it showed, but memory and a knowing backup band supplied what mortal performers cannot.

K. is now bringing that special to television. FX, the cable channel that is home to Louis C. K.'s scripted comedy series, ''Louie,'' said Monday that it would broadcast his most recent stand-up concert film, ''Live at the Beacon Theater,'' starting on Saturday, following its successful run as an Internet-only download.

WASHINGTON -- A federal judge presiding over the Roger Clemens perjury trial gave prosecutors and defense lawyers a stern talking to on Tuesday because the proceedings -- in their fourth week now -- were plodding along so slowly that the jurors were losing interest. ''Those folk are fed up because they see their time being wasted,'' the judge, Reggie Walton of United States District Court, said to the lawyers before the jury entered the courtroom.

An article on April 24 about a boom in the construction of art museums in China and the showing of more Chinese modern art in the United States referred incorrectly in some instances to Fan Di'an, director of the National Art Museum of China in Beijing, which is holding an international competition to choose the architect for a new building. Fan is his surname and thus he is Mr. Fan, not Mr. Di'an.

Some outdoor advertising companies regard municipal fines for illegal signs as just another cost of doing business. New York City is suggesting they think again. The cost has now reached six figures. On Friday, the Landmarks Preservation Commission and the Law Department announced that the city had collected $225,000, a record fine, for the illegal installation of wall signs in a historic district without permission from the landmarks agency.

An activist shareholder sought to shake up a money-losing company. It was shaping up to be a typical corporate dogfight - until the Federal Reserve stepped in. That's what happened recently in the case of First Financial Northwest when a major shareholder, the Stilwell Group, sought to elect two nominees to the board of the savings and loan.
A picture caption on Tuesday with an article about mysterious dolphin and seabird deaths in Peru misidentified the dead bird shown. It was a blue-footed booby, not a cormorant.

BERKOWITZ--Morris. Peacefully passed away on May 5, 2012 in New York. Born on July 16, 1914 to Davis and Bluma Berkowitz. Morris had six siblings -- all deceased. Morris served in World War II, 1943-1946.

LANSING, Mich. - Mitt Romney often finds himself on the defensive in Rust Belt states for having been against the auto industry bailout, which many credit with saving the industry. Now, he is taking a new tack on the sensitive issue: he's taking credit for the industry's rebound. Though Mr. Romney's closest aides acknowledge that he is politically vulnerable over his opposition to the government bailout - immortalized in a New York Times op-ed in 2008 titled ''Let Detroit Go Bankrupt'' - Mr. Romney on Monday told WEWS-TV in Cleveland that he deserved some praise for the auto industry's recovery. (In fact, that headline was written by the paper, not Mr. Romney, who originally submitted the piece as, ''The Way Forward for the Auto Industry.'')

CHICAGO -- The Bulls may be missing their All-Star star point guard and starting center, but depleted did not mean eliminated Tuesday at the United Center. Playing without Derrick Rose, who tore his anterior cruciate ligament in Game 1, and the emotional leader Joakim Noah, who badly sprained his ankle in Game 3, the undermanned Bulls beat the Philadelphia 76ers, 77-69, to stave off elimination and cut their first-round series deficit to 3-2.

LIFLAND--William. Fordham Law School notes with profound sorrow the passing of William Thomas Lifland, long-time adjunct faculty member and friend of Fordham. We extend our deepest sympathy to his family. He will always remain in the heart of the Fordham Law community. Michael M. Martin, Dean

Because of an editing error, an obituary on Tuesday about Bob Stewart, the creator of several television game shows, referred incorrectly to Alex Trebek, who briefly hosted one of those shows, ''To Tell the Truth.'' Mr. Trebek had been hosting ''Jeopardy'' for several years before he joined ''To Tell the Truth.'' He was not the host of that show before he became the host of ''Jeopardy.''

Waffles and coffee on a breakfast tray for Mom? Instead, how about a dinner party for 8 or 10 at home, cooked by an accomplished (and maybe even famous) chef? Kitchit, a service that started last year in San Francisco and last month in Los Angeles, has just landed in New York. It offers custom-tailored dinners, lunches, brunches, cocktail parties and even picnics and barbecues at home, with chefs doing all the shopping and cooking. Kitchit is the brainchild of three entrepreneurs - Brendan Marshall, Ian Ferguson and George Tang - who say they have been running more than 100 events a month in California. For New York, their Web site lists celebrity chefs like Floyd Cardoz of North End Grill, Dan Kluger of ABC Kitchen and Harold Dieterle of Kin Shop, along with several private chefs and cooking instructors. You set your price, starting at $40 a person, including tips and tax. Wines and other beverages, flowers, waiters and other extras are additional. Then you request a date, survey the choice of available chefs and the matchmaking begins.
Host Finland, the defending champion, regained the top spot in its group at the world championships in Helsinki with a 5-2 win over Switzerland. Valtteri Filppula Jarkko Immonen each scored twice.

TAKEOVER TARGET The Mexican telecommunications giant América Móvil is offering 2.6 billion euros, or $3.4 billion, to increase its stake in KPN, the Dutch wireless phone and Internet service provider. Under the terms of the deal, América Móvil, which is owned by Carlos Slim Helú, left, will pay 8 euros a share in cash to raise its stake in KPN to up to 28 percent from 4.8 percent. MARK SCOTT

KATZ--Dr. Sidney, MD. Friends and colleagues at the Columbia University Stroud Center for Study of Quality of Life mourn and honor the life of Dr. Sidney Katz, MD, who passed away at home on Friday, May 4, aged 88. He was buried on Sunday, May 6 in Cleveland, the city of his birth. He founded and co-directed this Center and the Professorship named for him. Among his many honors, he was Professor Emeritus of Geriatric Medicine at Columbia University, a member of the National Institute of Medicine, and a decorated volunteer physician in the Korean war. He received many honors, including the Pollack and Kent awards from the Gerontological Society of America. He developed the most widely cited measure of health in aging, and chaired a national committee that pioneered standards of quality in nursing homes. Motivating his deeply intellectual scientific accomplishments was an intense and warm engagement with people in his personal and collegial circles. Dr. Katz is survived by his wife of 66 years, Beverly, in Byron Center, MI.

Yahoo sought to contain the turmoil surrounding its chief executive's embellished academic record on Tuesday, as the director who led the search for the executive said that she would not stand for re-election to the board. The company also announced that it had created a three-director committee to examine how the erroneous credentials of the C.E.O., Scott Thompson, were overlooked during his hiring process. Yahoo has acknowledged that Mr. Thompson claimed a degree in computer science that he did not have.

On ''Grey's Anatomy,'' Arizona and Callie are adjusting to married life, having been pronounced ''wife and wife'' last year. On ''Modern Family,'' the nation's most popular television show, Cameron and his partner Mitchell are trying to adopt a second child.

LOS ANGELES - Climbing ad sales and subscription fees at ESPN and cable channels like ABC Family helped the Walt Disney Company increase its quarterly profit by 21 percent from a year earlier, to $1.14 billion. Disney's financial results, reported on Tuesday afternoon, also carried an optimistic message about consumer confidence from its sprawling theme park operation - a sharp contrast to last week's downbeat job growth and retail sales reports. Operating income at Walt Disney Parks and Resorts, watched as a barometer of the broader economy, surged 53 percent, to $222 million.

MORRIS--Arthur C. and Madeleine F. Aged 88 and 89, they passed away on May 3rd, 2012, succumbing to the elements after a minor car accident in the Catskills. Learning that numerous 911 calls failed due to poor cellular coverage worsened the loss. Arthur, originally from Cambridge (OH) was always a gentleman whose quiet disposition belied a dry sense of humor. He graduated from Juilliard; a pianist and organist, he taught music and was a church organist on Long Island. Madeleine, born in Bellegarde, France, endured Nazi occupation and was named one of the Just for her actions during the war. She immigrated to the USA; widowed at 30 and with two children, she earned a Ph.D. in French Literature at Columbia University. She was a pioneer as one of the first women to become a professor at Brown University, and later taught at Queens College as well as the CUNY Graduate Center. She was an energetic leader with a passion for life, and remarried in 1963. Arthur and Madeleine were inseparable, even in death, just shy of their 50th anniversary. Arthur is survived by his niece Emily and nephew Carl. Madeleine is survived by her sister Dr. Colette Jeantet, two sons Ronald and Robert, a grandson Jeantet and a great-granddaughter, Lyra. A memorial service will be held at Noon on Saturday, May 12th at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, on 73rd Street. In lieu of flowers, please make a donation to Doctors Without Borders in their names.

BOSTON - Senator Scott P. Brown on Tuesday asked Elizabeth Warren, his likely Democratic opponent, to publicly release her applications to law schools and personnel files from the universities where she has taught. He cited ''legitimate questions'' about whether Ms. Warren had claimed American Indian heritage as a way to advance her academic career. The Brown campaign and the Republican Party have sought to keep such questions circulating since The Boston Herald reported late last month that Harvard Law School, where Ms. Warren currently teaches, once cited her as American Indian in the 1990s, when it was under attack for not having a diverse faculty.

Ai Weiwei, the rebel artist, said Tuesday that a court in Beijing had agreed to hear his lawsuit against the city's tax authorities. Mr. Ai is suing the officials for bringing a tax case against him. Tax officials have said Mr. Ai's company, Beijing Fake Cultural Development, owes the equivalent of $2.4 million in back taxes and penalties. Mr. Ai said he did not owe that amount and has argued that his wife, Lu Qing, is formally in charge of the company. Mr. Ai was detained for 81 days last year and has continued to mock the Chinese government and the Communist Party since his release.

West of Hillsborough, NC and Peter H. Munro of Connecticut. Reposing Friday 7pm-9pm at The Church of the Advent, 555 Advent St., Westbury, NY 11590. Funeral Mass Saturday 10am at the Church. Interment to follow in Maple Grove Cemetery, Kew Gardens, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Church of the Advent. www.donohue-cecere.com

Margin calls can be merciless, as the founder of Green Mountain Coffee Roasters has now found out. The founder, Robert P. Stiller, lost his post as chairman of the board on Tuesday after he sold five million shares, worth around $125.5 million, to pay off loans he had taken out against his sizable stock holdings in the company.

KABUL, Afghanistan -- After a harsh winter killed children in refugee camps around the Afghan capital and brought attention to poor conditions there, a new study by a French aid agency said the disaster was more extensive than originally thought, with at least 100 young children claimed by the cold. The study, carried out in March by the French aid group Solidarités International, sought to collect information from families at all of the 45 camps in or near Kabul, according to Julie Bara, who conducted the survey for the group, one of few international relief agencies that have long been active in the camps.

Rangers slugger Josh Hamilton has collected experiences over the past year like a rolling ball of tape collects everything in its path. There was the horrifying moment last July when he tossed a ball to a fan, who fell to his death over a too-short railing trying to catch it. The World Series then delivered a crushing competitive blow as the Rangers blew an all-but-certain victory in Game 6. The offseason brought an ugly relapse into alcoholism. All of which makes Hamilton's four-homer game on Tuesday night that much more mesmerizing because Hamilton is a living, breathing poster for the full range of human emotion. If he weren't real, you get the feeling Maurice Sendak might have made him up. He is definitely a wild thing. Of course, you know none of that if you just watch Hamilton's ludicrously easy swing as he launched all four balls over the fence. His effort might be among the best of the 16 four-homer games in history, writes Cliff Corcoran on SI.com, and it had writers like Richard Durrett of ESPN.com and Ken Rosenthal of Foxsports.com, reaching for their thesauruses for different ways to say wow. When you take into account all of who Hamilton is, as Jeff Passan writes on Yahoo.com, the combination of incredibly talented, likeable player and troubled alcoholic makes him fascinating. As Richard Justice writes on MLB.com, Hamilton inspires people with both sides of his story.

IN the middle of 2010, Tom Sesti decided he needed to do something about the cost pressures that had been plaguing his business, Bandals. Based in Rochester, Mich., the company had introduced a product, women's sandals with interchangeable decorative tops, soon after the economic crisis hit in 2008. Almost immediately, the five-employee company was hit with cost increases of 15 to 30 percent for manufacturing and raw materials. Mr. Sesti decided Bandals needed to sell its way out of the problem. ''We had to get to a level where our economies of scale cleared the hurdle of all our fixed costs,'' he said. To that end, he considered two paths -- offering a new product or expanding overseas. After running the numbers, he decided to do both.

Savvy politicians know how to disclose unwanted news in a way that will get the least possible amount of media coverage. They send the information out in an e-mail in the middle of the night. The subject lines are often bland, giving nothing away. And they hold back the news from social networks, hoping to slow the viral spread of the disclosure.

SALTZMAN--Nathan, age 80, of Delray Beach, FL and Bayonne, NJ passed away peacefully on Sunday, May 6, 2012. Predeceased by his beloved wife Debbie. Son of the late Isidore and Ida Saltzman; brother of the late Solomon and Shia. He is survived by children Rina, Seth and Debbie, Donna and Sam Wach; grandchildren Yitzhak, Tzvi and Binyamin Wach and Sara and Jared Saltzman. Passions were family, work and Yiddishkeit. Contributions may be made to the Jewish charity of your choice.

BELASCO--Steven R.,of Scarsdale, NY, and Boca Raton, FL, on May 8. Beloved husband of Fran, father of Daniel, Judith, and Sara, and grandfather of Frieda, Noah, and Reuben. Steve was generous, kind, and devoted to his family, friends, community, and profession. A cum laude graduate of Brooklyn College (B.S.), University of Virginia School of Law (J.D.), and New York University School of Law (LL.M.), Steve was an Officer and V.P. of Taxation and Global Real Estate at Colgate-Palmolive, where he worked for 33 years. A lifelong stamp enthusiast, Steve, after retirement, served for several years as Executive Director of The Philatelic Foundation and later as a Trustee. Steve also sat for 17 years on the Town of Greenburgh Zoning Board, the last 12 as chair. He was highly ethical with a strong moral compass. His loss is immeasurable to all who loved him. Funeral at Temple Israel Center, 280 Old Mamaroneck Rd, White Plains, NY, 12:30pm on Wednesday.

A beloved Manhattan pediatrician and international eating disorder expert, he was predeceased by his wife of 43 years, Joy Myers Silverman, and is survived by his children, Carol Silverman-Kurtz(Barry Kurtz), Elizabeth Stewart, Ted Silverman (Kristen) and John Silverman, four grandchildren, his brother, Michael Silverman, MD and sister, Ethel Siris, MD. Funeral services will be held at Gutterman- Musicant in Hackensack, NJ on May 9 at noon. Please direct donations to Parkinson's Disease Foundation.

11:55 a.m. | Updated LONDON - A shareholder revolt against executive pay gained momentum on Tuesday with the unexpected resignation of Andrew Moss, the chief executive of Aviva, the British insurance company, after its pay practices lost investor support.

MOSCOW -- The wreckage of a demonstration airplane for a Russian-made passenger jet that vanished on Wednesday during a 50-minute flight over Indonesia was found there on Thursday on the side of a mountain volcano shrouded in mist. There were no signs of survivors among the 50 people, including crew members, journalists and airline representatives, aboard the plane, the Sukhoi Superjet 100, a spokesman for Indonesia's Search and Rescue National Agency told The Associated Press.
MARASSE--Henry F.,MD, member of the New York Psychoanalytic Association, died May 3, 2012 at the age of 92 at Kendal on Hudson, survived by his wife Annette and children Richard and Leah.

The Smithsonian's National Museum of American History has a new director: John Gray, the former president of the Autry National Center of the American West in Los Angeles. Mr. Gray, who will be responsible for 234 employees, a $34 million budget, and the revitalization of a 120,000-square-foot exhibition wing, is to take the reins at the museum in Washington on July 23. Before joining the world of cultural nonprofits like the Autry center, Mr. Gray spent 25 years in commercial banking, including a stint as executive vice president of First Interstate Bank of California in Los Angeles. He also worked briefly for the Small Business Administration in Washington.

3:39 p.m. | Updated There will be no salvation for ''Leap of Faith,'' the struggling Broadway musical about a con artist posing as a man of God. On Tuesday its producers said that the production would close on Sunday, after 24 previews and 20 performances at the St. James Theater. The musical, adapted from the 1992 movie starring Steve Martin and featuring Raúl Esparza as the fraudulent evangelist Jonas Nightingale, came to New York after a 2010 run at the Ahmanson Theater in Los Angeles. But the Broadway production, directed by Christopher Ashley and choreographed by Sergio Trujillo (who both worked on ''Memphis''), was poorly received.

At the outset of the second season of ''The Voice'' Jermaine Paul was all about business. In his initial blind audition, he sang Avril Lavigne's bratty ''Complicated'' with muscle and imagination, if not total grace. Two of the show's four coaches turned their chairs to face him: Cee Lo Green, a whimsical eccentric who's attracted to idiosyncratic vocal powerhouses, and Blake Shelton, a gentle soul who often appears to be guided by emotion and gut more than talent. After some theatrical hemming and hawing, Mr. Paul chose Mr. Shelton, and it seemed, at the time, to be a strategic decision. On Mr. Green's team Mr. Paul would be one of several heavyweights, but surely Mr. Paul could power his way through Mr. Shelton's collection of feel-good stories.

An article on Tuesday about plans for a music festival in New York this summer by investors who bought the assets of the punk-rock club CBGB, which closed in 2006, misstated the name of one of the bands for which the club served as an incubator in its heyday. It was Talking Heads, not ''the Talking Heads.'' (One of the band's albums was called ''The Name of This Band Is Talking Heads.'')

WASHINGTON -- The United States Postal Service said Wednesday that it would keep hundreds of small post offices open by reducing business hours or offering stamps and packaging in grocery stores, whittling down its ambitious plan to streamline its services and balance its books by closing thousands of post offices. Giving Congress more time to pass legislation to overhaul the financially struggling agency, the service held back from the wholesale closings of mostly rural post offices that it had proposed last year. The Postal Service's hope is that Congress, given more time, will come up with a plan to overhaul the agency. But Wednesday's action signals that the Postal Service needs to move forward with staffing cuts.

The singer-songwriter Paul Simon and the cellist Yo-Yo Ma have been named the winners of Sweden's Polar Music Prize, which is typically given to a pop and a classical musician, The Associated Press reported. Each will receive $166,000.

Celebrate Brooklyn!, the Prospect Park summer festival, will begin on June 5 with a free concert by Jimmy Cliff, above, and end on Aug. 11 with a free concert by Lyle Lovett and Aoife O'Donovan, Bric Arts Media Brooklyn, the festival's producer, will announce on Wednesday. Twenty-five of the 32 shows, all at the Prospect Park Bandshell, are free, with a suggested $3 contribution at the gate. The highlights of the festival, now in its 34th year, include a multimedia collaboration between the pianist Geri Allen and the photographer and video artist Carrie Mae Weems on June 15, with performances by Esperanza Spalding, Lizz Wright and Maurice Chestnut, among others; Ballet Hispanico on June 28; and Sweet Honey in the Rock on July 8. On June 30, Angélique Kidjo will join other artists for ''Women Waging Peace,'' a concert tribute to Wangari Maathai, the Kenyan Nobel Peace Prize winner who died last year. Benefit concerts include Childish Gambino, Danny Brown and Schoolboy Q (June 26); Dirty Projectors, Wye Oak and Purity Ring (July 10); Sigur Ros (July 31); and M. Ward and Yo La Tengo (Aug. 7). The festival's ''Music & Movies'' series is also back, pairing classic films shown on a gigantic outdoor screen with live performances. The series includes a 35th-anniversary screening of ''Saturday Night Fever,'' on July 14. More information is at bricartsmedia.org.

WASHINGTON -- Over two days of meetings with China's leaders in Beijing last week, Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton had not uttered a word about Chen Guangcheng as her aides arranged to transfer the blind Chinese dissident from the United States Embassy to a hospital, only to have the plan unexpectedly blow up. Then, last Friday, she finally broached the subject with China's senior foreign policy official, Dai Bingguo. Mr. Chen, she said, should go to the United States after all.

Brad Richards's last-gasp goal in regulation, Marc Staal's overtime slap shot, Henrik Lundqvist's third-period save on a breakaway that tipped the crossbar. Those were the indelible images from one of the most thrilling victories in Rangers history, a 3-2 triumph over the Washington Capitals in Game 5 on Monday night at Madison Square Garden. None of them, perhaps, would have mattered if not for Anton Stralman.

VISICH--Genevieve, of Township of Washington, NJ on Monday, May 7, 2012. Wife of the late Edward T., Sr. Mother of Stephen, Kathryn (Brad), Edward Jr., the late Andrea (Tim), Robert (Tammy), Peter and five grandchildren. Sister of Francine Buccola (Charles).

OPENINGS The film noirish footwear label CHARLOTTE OLYMPIA has arrived from London, setting up its first free-standing United States store on the Upper East Side. With prices that range from $595 for flats to more than $2,000 for sumptuous evening shoes, it is not surprising that Charlotte Dellal's designs have a following among red-carpet denizens like Beyoncé and Sarah Jessica Parker. In addition to its Sirens collection of about 30 ultrafeminine styles and several exclusive designs, the shop, at 22 East 65th Street, (212) 744-1892, stocks the label's jewelry, evening bags and hosiery.

DENVER -- A call for a special legislative session by Gov. John W. Hickenlooper could revive a bill that would have allowed civil unions for same-sex couples in Colorado. The bill died late Tuesday night after lawmakers reached an impasse over whether it would be heard on the floor of the House of Representatives before the legislative session concluded on Wednesday. The apparent end to the civil unions bill that night was a blow to its supporters, who appeared to have mustered enough votes, including those of several Republicans, to pass it. The bill, which had already passed the State Senate, needed to be heard on the House floor before midnight. Mr. Hickenlooper, a Democrat, had said he intended to sign it.

An article on Sunday about commercial aerospace ventures in Mojave, Calif., misstated the site of the uninterrupted round-the-world flight by the experimental airplane Voyager in 1986. The Voyager took off from and landed at Edwards Air Force Base -- not in nearby Mojave, where it was built.

SIEGEL--Jonathan Elihu. July 28, 1944 - May 5, 2012. Beloved father and grandfather. Survived by his daughter Jodi Siegel Sward, her husband Brian Sward, grandchildren Zoe and Joseph, his sister and her husband, nieces, his former wife and many dear friends. Jonathan's fighting spirit never gave up while battling a series of illnesses. He remained dedicated to Cornell University, Israel and the Arts. A Memorial Service will be held in New York July 8, 2012. Donations may be made to Boston University School of Medicine Amyloidosis Research Fund.

ATHENS -- Greece's political leaders failed again on Wednesday to form a government, as increasingly anxious and irritated European leaders urged the country to keep its commitments to creditors and decide whether it wanted to stay with the euro. ''We want Greece to stay in the euro zone, but whether Greece stays in the euro zone is in Greece's hands, and it's now a decision to be taken in Greece,'' the German foreign minister, Guido Westerwelle, said in Brussels.

The Foreign Ministry announced Tuesday that it would postpone a summit meeting of Central and Eastern European countries because many leaders planned to boycott it to protest the treatment of Yulia V. Tymoshenko, an opposition leader who has been imprisoned since October. The countries planning to stay away include Germany, Italy, Austria, Croatia, Slovenia, Estonia, Bulgaria and the Czech Republic. Ms. Tymoshenko, a rival of President Viktor F. Yanukovich, was sentenced to seven years on charges of harming Ukraine's interests during gas negotiations with Russia. Moscow and the West have said the prosecution was politically motivated and are pressing Mr. Yanukovich to free her. Some countries are also boycotting the Euro 2012 soccer championship, for which Ukraine is scheduled to serve as a co-host next month.

Husband and Best Friend Forever to Carol Art. Father to Jeffrey (Martha) and Don. Predeceased by his son Douglas. Grandfather to Megan. Brother to Harold (Betty), Robert (Mary). Brother-in-law to Shirley and Judy Dreyfus. Uncle to many nieces and nephews. Memorial Service Saturday, May 12, 2012, 5:30pm at Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West 64th St., New York City. In lieu of flowers, donations in memory of Donald Keane, Payable to VNSNY Hospice, c/o Stefanie Steel, 1250 Broadway, 7th Floor, New York, NY 10001 or online: VNSNY.ORG (Click on Donate).

A picture caption on Tuesday with the continuation of an article about Amazon.com's foray into high-end fashion referred incorrectly to William Norwich's role Monday night at the Metropolitan Museum of Art's Costume Institute Gala, which was sponsored by Amazon. Mr. Norwich was a host of the live online video coverage, not the host of the gala. And a credit for a front-page picture omitted the given name of the photographer. The picture of Jeff Bezos, chief executive of Amazon, was taken by Matthew Ryan Williams for The New York Times.

TOKYO -- Japan is ready to nationalize Tokyo Electric Power, the operator of the ravaged Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant, under a 1 trillion yen ($12.5 billion) bailout plan that was approved on Wednesday. The Japanese government has been scrambling to keep the utility company from collapsing so it can meet the billions of dollars in compensation claims and decommission the reactors at Fukushima Daiichi, all while continuing to provide the Tokyo metropolis with stable electricity.

MOSCOW -- Speaking at Russia's giant yearly parade of high-stepping cadets and heavy weaponry through Red Square, the newly inaugurated president, Vladimir V. Putin, said on Wednesday that the country had ''a great moral right'' to the respect of other nations, particularly on matters of global security. Russian leaders often use May 9 -- the anniversary of the defeat of Nazi Germany -- as a geopolitical bully pulpit. For the last two years, President Dmitri A. Medvedev went out of his way to celebrate the alliance of Russia and the West against the Nazis.

MANFREDI--Ray (Renato) Victor Woodrow, 25 April 1917-7 May 2012. Graduate of Theodore Roosevelt High School (1936) and LL.B, St. John's University (1943). Retired attorney of Bronx County bar and longtime resident of Fordham Hill Apartments. Seventh and last child of Fortunata Moraca Mogavero (1881-1979) of Baucina, Palermo, Sicily and dott Camillo Manfredi (1877-1937) of Conflenti, Catanzaro, Calabria. Husband of Mary Elizabeth Hegarty of Boston, Massachusetts (1916-2004). Survived by son Victor Manfredi (Cambridge, Massachusetts), by cousins Teresina and Orazio Manfredi (Santu Mangu, Catanzaro, Calabria), Olga Sacco (Ottawa, Ontario) and prof dott Giuseppe Palminteri (Palermo) as well as by many younger collaterals in North America and Italy. Public commemorations, in the Bronx and Santu Mangu, to be arranged later this year.

Because of editing errors, an article in some editions on April 30 about New York City private schools that sued parents over tuition erroneously included one school among those that filed lawsuits and referred imprecisely to a case filed by another school. Léman Manhattan Preparatory School has not taken such legal action against parents. And while York Preparatory School has sued parents over tuition, those cases do not involve parents who withdrew their children from school. (The issue of students having been withdrawn is included in lawsuits filed against parents by Mandell, Friends of Seminary, and the Little Red School House and Elisabeth Irwin High School.)

Tom Hanks is in negotiations to make his Broadway debut next year playing the Daily News columnist Mike McAlary in a new bio-drama by Nora Ephron, Mr. Hanks's spokeswoman confirmed on Wednesday. Mr. McAlary, a hard-charging journalist who became one of the most popular tabloid newspaper writers in recent city history, died from colon cancer in 1998, at 41. He covered crime and cops and the major police department corruption scandals of the 1980s and 90s, perhaps most famously the Abner Louima brutality case, which won him the 1998 Pulitzer Prize for commentary. Ms. Ephron draws on all of this in her play, titled ''Lucky Guy,'' which is said to be a multicharacter work as opposed to a one-man show. Ms. Ephron did not immediately return a phone message on Wednesday morning, and the producers, Sonia Friedman and Colin Callender (a former president of HBO Films), declined to comment through a spokesman.

De GEORGE--Florence A.,Passed away peacefully the morning of Thursday May 3, 2012, at her home in Jupiter, Florida. She would have been 92 on July 2. Florence was born in New York City to Peter Paul Efel and Eugenia Budsalowska Efel. After her mother and father separated, Florence spent a good deal of her early years growing up on a Pennsylvania farm owned by her grandmother Aniela Budsalowska, with her mother, brother Peter P. Efel and sister Eugenia M. Efel. In addition to English, the children spoke Polish and Russian in the home, the native languages of their grandmother and mother. After graduating from high school and completing two years of college, Florence was among the first group of women volunteers to join the Women's Army Corps (WAC) after the outbreak of WWII. Florence was passionate about helping those affected by the War in Europe. Her great love for this country in part came from her parents and grandmother, who were naturalized citizens. Florence had family in the areas of Europe affected by the War and wanted to help; however, the limited role that women could play in the Army at that time was disappointing and she eventually resigned. In 1943, Florence met her husband to be, U.S. Navy Lieutenant (jg) Lawrence J. De George. Three months later, on December 18, 1943, they married in a military ceremony in Boston, just prior to Lawrence reporting for duty aboard a US Navy Destroyer guarding convoys in the North Atlantic. After the end of World War II, Florence dedicated herself to raising her two sons and focused on her passions: the arts, particularly music and dance; and later, commercial interior design. Throughout the 1950's and 1960's she produced, directed and choreographed productions for community theaters and local schools. Energetic and self-starting, she was always looking for a new challenge. Florence taught herself interior design and by 1988 completed several large commercial projects, which she designed and decorated. Two of these projects included the Amphenol Corporate building in Wallingford, Connecticut, and the seventh floor of the Seagram's Building on Park Avenue in New York City. Additionally, for seven years from 1986 to 1993, she served as an Amphenol Corporation director and member of the audit committee until the sale of the company in 1993. For the past twenty-one years, Florence and her late husband, Lawrence, were dedicated to helping children and have left a philanthropic legacy which will continue to make a difference in the lives of thousands of children for years to come. Florence and Lawrence loved all children but especially those in need. In 1991, Florence and her husband founded the Lawrence J. and Florence A. De George Charitable Trust. Florence stated, when interviewed about the Charitable Trust, My husband and I have always believed that every child deserves the best chance at life. The mission of our charitable trust has always been to support seriously ill and at risk children who struggle each day and need our help. Since 1991, Florence and her late husband dedicated themselves to fulfilling that mission. The charitable trust has donated well over one hundred million dollars under their direction. Among their many projects and donations, their charitable legacy includes two Florence A. De George Boys & Girls Clubs in Palm Beach and Broward counties; the Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation Islet Transplantation Research Project at Harvard Medical School; and Camp Boggy Creek in Eustis, Florida. To date, Camp Boggy Creek, which they cofounded with Paul Newman and General Norman H. Schwarzkopf, has provided an exciting, medically-sound camp experience for more than 50,000 chronic and terminally-ill youth. After her husband's death in April 2009, Florence continued the charitable trust legacy with several multiyear, multimillion-dollar grants to the American Heart Association (AHA) Research Grant; major funding for the new administrative and welcome center at Camp Boggy Creek and in January 2011, the ten million-dollar grant to fund the creation of a three-story, 75,000 square-foot Children's and Women's Healthcare Services facility, named the Florence A. De George Pavilion at Jupiter Medical Center. Florence loved her family and is preceded in death by her husband of 65 years, Lawrence J. De George. Florence is survived by her sons: Lawrence F. De George and wife Suzanne of Jupiter, Florida, and Peter R. De George of Jupiter, Florida; three grandchildren: Peter M. De George, Michael L. De George, both of Jupiter, Florida, and Brandi M. Martelli of Cheshire, Connecticut; three great-grandchildren: Brooke De George, Payton De George and Savanna Martelli. Florence was a devout Catholic. There will be a private family service. In lieu of flowers, the family requests contributions be made to: Florence A. DeGeorge Boys and Girls Club of Palm Beach; Camp Boggy Creek or Jupiter Medical Center's Foundation for the Florence A. De George Pavilion. The Boys & Girls Clubs of Palm Beach County, Inc., 800 Northpoint Parkway - Suite 204 West Palm Beach, FL 33407-1946. Camp Boggy Creek, 30500 Brantley Branch Road, Eustis, Florida 32736. Jupiter Medical Center Foundation, 1210 South Old Dixie Highway, Jupiter, Florida 33458. For the Florence A. De George Pavilion.

WASHINGTON -- Before President Obama left the White House on Tuesday morning to fly to an event in Albany, several aides intercepted him in the Oval Office. Within minutes it was decided: the president would endorse same-sex marriage on Wednesday, completing a wrenching personal transformation on the issue. As described by several aides, that quick decision and his subsequent announcement in a hastily scheduled network television interview were thrust on the White House by 48 hours of frenzied will-he-or-won't-he speculation after Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. all but forced the president's hand by embracing the idea of same-sex unions in a Sunday talk show interview.
