KATZ--Dr. Sidney, MD. Friends and colleagues at the Columbia University Stroud Center for Study of Quality of Life mourn and honor the life of Dr. Sidney Katz, MD, who passed away at home on Friday, May 4, aged 88. He was buried on Sunday, May 6 in Cleveland, the city of his birth. He founded and co-directed this Center and the Professorship named for him. Among his many honors, he was Professor Emeritus of Geriatric Medicine at Columbia University, a member of the National Institute of Medicine, and a decorated volunteer physician in the Korean war. He received many honors, including the Pollack and Kent awards from the Gerontological Society of America. He developed the most widely cited measure of health in aging, and chaired a national committee that pioneered standards of quality in nursing homes. Motivating his deeply intellectual scientific accomplishments was an intense and warm engagement with people in his personal and collegial circles. Dr. Katz is survived by his wife of 66 years, Beverly, in Byron Center, MI.

WHITNEY--Edward Farley, died on May 6, 2012 in Portsmouth, New Hampshire at the age of 96. Born on August 12, 1915 in Locust, New Jersey, he graduated with honors in 1938 from Harvard University where he was captain of the rugby team. A resident of Dublin, New Hampshire for over 60 years, he served as selectman for many years and was active in the life of the town. He was predeceased by his much-loved wife, Millicent Bonner Bowring Whitney on December 25, 1987, and is survived by his children, Cynthia Farley of Lee, NH, Edward Bonner of New York City, Amy Susan of Lambertville, NJ, Richard Duane of Lee, NH, and James Warren of Bowdoinham, ME, and by ten grandchildren and six great- grandchildren. A gentle, kind and generous man, he will be much missed. A funeral service will be held at 3pm on May 13, 2012 at the Dublin Community Cemetery, followed by a reception at the Dublin School.
LESCHER--Mary Cantwell. 5/10/30 - 2/1/00 Missed and celebrated today and every day.

SILVERMAN--Dr. Joseph. NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital and Columbia University Medical Center mourn the loss of Joseph Silverman, M.D., who served the hospital as Attending Pediatrician and the College of Physicians and Surgeons' Department of Pediatrics as Clinical Professor during his entire professional career of more than 40 years. Dr. Silverman completed his residency in pediatrics at Babies Hospital (now Morgan Stanley Children's Hospital of NewYork-Presbyterian) in the late 1950's. He was one of the original leaders of NewYork-Presbyterian's Society of Practitioners and served on several important hospital committees. A wonderful physician and exemplary human being, he is remembered with respect and affection by his colleagues, friends, and the countless individuals whose lives he touched during his distinguished career. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Dr. Silverman's family and especially to his sister, Ethel Siris, M.D., of NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital/Columbia University Medical Center. Steven J. Corwin, M.D. CEO NY-Presbyterian Hospital Lee Goldman, M.D. Dean of the Faculties of Health Sciences and Medicine Columbia University Medical Center

SAN FRANCISCO -- California and Quebec moved to knit together their fledgling carbon markets on Wednesday as California proposed a new regulation allowing cross-border trading of the permits that industries must acquire to cover their emissions of greenhouse gases. It is the first cross-border carbon trading system created since 2005, when the European Union introduced such a trading network to help it meet emissions limits set by the Kyoto Protocol, a treaty that went into effect that year.

Seventeen-seventy-six will never lose its place in the history books, but its claim to the record books may have been undermined by a decision not to build a sculptural cladding for the mast atop 1 World Trade Center. The mast was to elevate an otherwise 1,368-foot skyscraper into a 1,776-foot structure whose defining measurement was meant to express American spirit and resolve in the face of the terrorist attack of Sept. 11, 2001.
International GROUP SEES SIGN OF CLEANUP

Pity the poor translator. He (or more often she) works in the same solitary fashion as the novelist, poet, playwright or essayist but must be content with reflected glory: at best, his or her name in small type on the cover of a book, or, just as likely, relegated in smaller type to an interior page. Which is why an event like the Translation Slam on Thursday night, which was part of this year's PEN World Voices literary festival, must be a translator's delight, a rare opportunity to stand in the spotlight. The event, at the Bowery Poetry Club, was modeled on the poetry slams that have become popular in recent years, reaching even the White House. A pair of translators are given the same text three days in advance and asked to create their own versions in another language, which they read to an audience that can be appreciative, or not. It's part intellectual puzzle, part spectacle.

A music review on Tuesday about a performance of ''Il Ritorno d'Ulisse in Patria'' (''The Return of Ulysses to His Homeland'') by Monteverdi, at Yale, misidentified the teacher of the course Analyzing, Directing and Performing Early Opera, in which the class assignment is to put on a fully staged production of a Baroque work -- in this case the Monteverdi opera that was reviewed. The class that did the production was taught by Grant Herreid and Toni Dorfman -- not by Ellen Rosand, who also teaches at Yale and is executive director of the Yale Baroque Opera Project.

Q. My iPod syncs only new audio and video podcasts when I connect it to the computer and iTunes. Sometimes, I'll listen to the first part of a show or accidentally start it before I transfer it to the iPod. Because it's not ''new'' anymore, it doesn't sync. How do I ''unplay'' a podcast so it copies to the iPod? A. Even if you have listened to part or all of an audio or video podcast in iTunes, you can reset the file back to its original status. Just right-click, or control-click on a Mac, on the title of the episode in the iTunes window and select ''Mark as Unplayed'' or ''Mark as Unwatched'' from the contextual menu.

Doris instilled in her family a strong commitment to philanthropy. Her legacy lives on through the generosity and leadership of Ronda and Gerald. We extend our deepest sympathies to the entire family. Jerry W. Levin, President Alisa R. Doctoroff, Chair of the Board, John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

In a signal to Wall Street that the continuing phone-hacking scandal in Britain has not had a significant impact on its bottom line, News Corporation on Wednesday reported a 47 percent increase in profit and said it would buy back an additional $5 billion worth of stock. News Corporation said its net income, driven largely by its strong cable television division, was $937 million in the third quarter, which ended March 31, or 38 cents a share, compared with $639 million, or 24 cents a share, in the period a year earlier.

MITCHELL--Elizabeth Alaire (76) passed away on April 13th at her home in Abiquiu, New Mexico surrounded by family and friends. Alaire spent most of her career in education as a teacher and as the Supervisor of the Editorial Unit of The Division of Curriculum and Instruction of the NYC Board of Education. After retiring, she wrote for The Electric School Bus TV series and NFTE. Concurrently, Alaire pursued her love of the theater, writing and directing plays in small theater groups, including an all female cast in WAITING FOR GODOT. But her most lasting legacy may be in her interaction with people. She listened, understood and cared. And, in doing so, she touched the hearts of all who met her. She is survived by her brother, Leland Buttle, her daughter, Alexis and her husband, Alex. Alaire/BryceCanyon/ Alex/4ever.

HONG KONG - Bankers in Hong Kong, the world's biggest market for initial public offerings, could face as much as two years in prison and fines of more than $100,000 if false or misleading information is included in the listing documents filed by companies they bring to market, according to a proposal by a Hong Kong regulator. On Wednesday, the Hong Kong Securities and Futures Commission announced the proposed penalties as part of a regulatory overhaul that follows a series of accounting failures, fraud and other corporate scandals here in recent years, mainly involving companies from mainland China.

Because of an editing error, an On Baseball column in some editions on Wednesday, about Josh Hamilton's four-homer game for the Texas Rangers, erroneously attributed a distinction to his 18 total bases in the game. He and Joe Adcock of the 1954 Milwaukee Braves are one behind Shawn Green, who set the major league record of 19 in 2002 with the Los Angeles Dodgers. Hamilton did not tie the major league record held by Adcock. And an accompanying chart listing other players who have hit four home runs in a game misidentified, in some copies, the Chicago team that Pat Seerey played for when he did it in 1948. It was the White Sox, not the Cubs.

SCENIC vistas and room to roam provide the serenity that retirees like Jim and Ava Higgins thrive on. The view from their one-acre property overlooks the town of Libby, Mont., with the craggy peaks of the Cabinet Mountains in the background. ''We see grizzly bears, mountain lions, the whole nine yards,'' Mr. Higgins said of visiting the federally designated wilderness area nearby. But as idyllic as the setting has been for them for the last 10 years, the Higginses lately have thought about moving out.
LONDON - In the battle over banker bonuses, score one for the bankers. A court here ruled on Wednesday that 104 investment bankers in London were entitled to $66 million in bonuses, plus interest.

GOULD--Honorable Bruce J.,83. Never out of love from the first evening walk with his wife to be, Karolyn, of 53 years. Experienced his greatest sense of contentment when simply in the same room as his wife, children and grandchildren. Innovative policy maker and judge. Relentless advocate dedicated to a life of public service, particularly to improving and safeguarding the housing of New Yorkers. His family's loss will be eased by the legacy of his significant contributions to improve the lives of others and by the love he shared with family and his remarkable world of friends. Predeceased by his wife. Survived by his four children, and their spouses: Sarah Kagan and her husband Stewart, Tom and his wife Maura, Roger and his wife Cathy Wagner, Melinda Konopko and her husband Elliot and nine grandchildren--Andrew, Joan, Ruth, Leo, Penelope, Aviva, Adam, Charlotte and Oliver. He is also survived by his brother Arnold and his wife Pearl and his sister-in-law, Barbara Elliot. Funeral will be at Riverside Memorial (76th and Amsterdam) on Friday, May 11 at 11 am. Donations: Karolyn and Bruce Gould Literacy Fund InwoodHouse.com

PEARL--Lee, 94, Palm Beach Florida, died peacefully at home May 5th. WWII Veteran and Founder and President of Chemical Testing Corporation in Stamford, CT. Loving father of Nancy Matles (Roger) Holly P Pressman (Peter Goldman), Douglas Pearl and Shelley Pearl. Grandfather of Ned, William, Meghan and Melissa. He is survived by his beloved Eleanor Shaw. You will always be in our hearts. Private Service. Family will be sitting Shiva at Matles residence--2 Heirloom Lane, Rye Brook, NY Thursday 4-9 pm, Friday 1-6pm, Saturday 7-9pm and Sunday 2-6pm.

8:30 P.M. (13) FAUST Des McAnuff, the artistic director of the Stratford Shakespeare Festival, whose revival of ''Jesus Christ Superstar'' is now on Broadway, makes his Metropolitan Opera debut with Gounod's ''Faust,'' updated to the 20th century. Jonas Kaufmann stars as a nuclear scientist, despairing of the effects of his life's work, who makes a contract with the Devil. Marina Poplavskaya, above with Mr. Kaufmann, is Marguerite, Faust's love interest and eventual victim, and René Pape reprises his role as Méphistophélès. Yannick Nézet-Séguin conducted this ''Great Performances at the Met'' presentation, which was shown live in movie theaters on Dec. 10. ''It is better if a production does not look too deeply for elements of existential despair that are simply not in the piece, and that seems the problem with the new 'Faust,' '' Anthony Tommasini wrote in The New York Times, adding that this co-production with the English National Opera, ''though rich with ideas and theatrically daring, is finally rather clinical and oppressive.'' 7:45 A.M. (IFC) AWAY FROM HER (2007) Fiona and Grant, a long-married couple played by Julie Christie and Gordon Pinsent, confront Alzheimer's disease in the feature directorial debut of Sarah Polley, who earned an Oscar nomination for her screenplay, based on an Alice Munro short story. ''There is, in Ms. Munro's mature work, a flinty wisdom about heterosexual love, a skepticism about romantic ideals that does not altogether deny their power or necessity,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The Times. ''Ms. Polley, rather remarkably for someone still in her 20s, shows an intuitive grasp of this wisdom and a welcome, unsentimental interest in the puzzles and pleasures of a long, imperfect marriage.'' He added, ''I can't remember the last time the movies yielded up a love story so painful, so tender and so true.''

The Noticed column last Thursday, about Web sites that help strangers locate each other after brief public flirtations, contained two images that were published in error. The correct logo and sample screen image for Bump.com can be seen at nytimes.com/fashion; the ones that were published were from www.bu.mp, a cellphone data-sharing app.

In a signal to Wall Street that the continuing phone-hacking scandal in Britain has not had a significant impact on its bottom line, News Corporation on Wednesday reported a 47 percent increase in profit and said it would buy back an additional $5 billion worth of stock. News Corporation said its net income, driven largely by its strong cable television division, was $937 million in the third quarter, which ended March 31, or 38 cents a share, compared with $639 million, or 24 cents a share, in the period a year earlier.

MORRIS--Arthur C. and Madeleine F. Aged 88 and 89, they passed away on May 3rd, 2012, succumbing to the elements after a minor car accident in the Catskills. Learning that numerous 911 calls failed due to poor cellular coverage worsened the loss. Arthur, originally from Cambridge (OH) was always a gentleman whose quiet disposition belied a dry sense of humor. He graduated from Juilliard; a pianist and organist, he taught music and was a church organist on Long Island. Madeleine, born in Bellegarde, France, endured Nazi occupation and was named one of the Just for her actions during the war. She immigrated to the USA; widowed at 30 and with two children, she earned a Ph.D. in French Literature at Columbia University. She was a pioneer as one of the first women to become a professor at Brown University, and later taught at Queens College as well as the CUNY Graduate Center. She was an energetic leader with a passion for life, and remarried in 1963. Arthur and Madeleine were inseparable, even in death, just shy of their 50th anniversary. Arthur is survived by his niece Emily and nephew Carl. Madeleine is survived by her sister Dr. Colette Jeantet, two sons Ronald and Robert, a grandson Jeantet and a great-granddaughter, Lyra. A memorial service will be held at Noon on Saturday, May 12th at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, on 73rd Street. In lieu of flowers, please make a donation to Doctors Without Borders in their names.

On the music charts this week, Carrie Underwood has a hit new album, the Beastie Boys return to the Top 20 and Gotye hits No. 1 on multiple singles charts. Ms. Underwood's ''Blown Away'' (Arista Nashville) opens at with 267,000 sales in its first week, according to Nielsen SoundScan. As Billboard noted, that is the best week for a country album since the release of Lady Antebellum's ''Own the Night'' in October, and the second-biggest opening week for any album this year, after Madonna's ''MDNA,'' which had 358,000 in March.

The Koss Striva Pro headphones are a great idea, but it will take some work to make them a great product. The idea is this: Why not make a wireless headphone that connects by Wi-Fi instead Bluetooth? It means a connection with better range and better fidelity. You can even listen without a computer, all you need is a network. Brilliant!

MOMS carry a heavy load. (Just ask Ann Romney.) An easy, roomy tote is all but de rigueur. And because Mother's Day is coming, here are a bunch of smart summer carryalls that caught our eye. More totes online at nytimes.com/fashion. Clockwise from top left: Anya Hindmarch canvas fruit and vegetable tote bag, $295 at Saks Fifth Avenue, saks.com; Sophie Hulme embroidered leather tote, $585 at Dagny + Barstow, 264 Bowery, (212) 675-2346; Emilio Pucci printed canvas and leather tote, $490 at net-a-porter.com; Anya Hindmarch rubber and leather tote, $495 at Anya Hindmarch, 29 East 60th Street, (212) 750-3974.

Husband and Best Friend Forever to Carol Art. Father to Jeffrey (Martha) and Don. Predeceased by his son Douglas. Grandfather to Megan. Brother to Harold (Betty), Robert (Mary). Brother-in-law to Shirley and Judy Dreyfus. Uncle to many nieces and nephews. Memorial Service Saturday, May 12, 2012, 5:30pm at Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West 64th St., New York City. FIERSTEIN--Jacqueline H. Mother of attorney Ronald Fierstein and writer/actor Harvey Fierstein, died on May 5 in her Brooklyn home at the age of 90. Mrs. Fierstein has been recognized for her charitable works for Hadassah, God's Love We Deliver and Cancer Care. She held a MLS and taught at Jackie Robinson J.H.S. An avid theater and museum attendee, Jackie instilled the importance of art in her two sons. Jackie is survived by her sons, daughter-in-law Dorothea W. Regal, grandsons Bradley and Matthew, her brother Irwin Gilbert and his family. Donations can be made to Hadassah, God's Love or any endeavor vital to the arts.

An article in some editions on Tuesday about Rangers defenseman Anton Stralman, who scored a first-period goal in Game 5 of an N.H.L. playoff series on Monday, misstated the team's shooting advantage over the Washington Capitals in that period. The Rangers outshot the Capitals by 17-4, not by 17-6.

The Board of Directors, Staff and Volunteers of Ronald McDonald House New York mourn the passing of Lila Ruth Fink, mother of longtime friend and supporter of our organization, Laurence D. Fink. PUSHING FOR CHANGE In a letter to Yahoo's board on Wednesday, Daniel S. Loeb, manger of the hedge fund Third Point, called again for the company's chief executive, Scott Thompson, to be fired. Mr. Loeb suggested that either the company's chief financial officer, Tim Morse, above, or its global media head, Ross Levinsohn, should serve as chief executive on an interim basis. MICHAEL J. de la MERCED

The Salt Water Fuel Cell Monster Truck ($26, owirobots.com) is a labor-intensive snap-together model truck with an innovative DIY battery - a tiny fuel cell, the same technology that some automakers like Honda hope will provide the green future of personal transportation. Inside the box you'll find a tiny electric motor, stamp-sized sheets of magnesium for power and about a hundred snap-together parts. Because each part is molded at once, it must be carefully trimmed, a tedious job that requires some extra tools (we used nail clippers). Also not in the box: some salt, water, a screwdriver and, for me, reading glasses in order to help me working my way through the 26 pages of instructions.

PARKER--Sheryl (also known as, Sheryl Parker Zinberg) died peacefully in her home on Monday May 7, 2012, after a valiant fight with cancer. She will be missed for her great courage, intelligence, and generosity by her loving sister, Marian Schwartz, daughter, Louise (Stuart McMuldroch) and son James (Christan), nephews Robert (Ellen Brown) and Andy Schwartz, her niece Meli, and step-children Adele, David, and Helene Zinberg, together with many loving family and friends. She was the beloved wife of Arthur Parker (d. 1976) and Eugene Zinberg (d. 2004). Sheryl was a life long advocate for the poor and civil rights. She had a passion for world travel, culture, and politics. She is remembered for her dedication to the League of Women Voters where she was Vice-President and to the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services (JBFCS) where she worked in social services until her retirement in 1991. Services will be on Thursday May 10, 11am at the Riverside, Great Neck. In lieu of flowers, please send donations in her memory to the Hospice Care Network or the JBFCS.

The suits at the World Wide Wicket Company are closing up shop. The Broadway revival of Frank Loesser's 1961 musical ''How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying'' will close after its performance on Sunday, May 20, the show's producers announced on Tuesday. It will have played 30 previews and 473 regular performances at the Al Hirschfeld Theater. Nominated in 2011 for a Tony Award for best musical revival, the show has been struggling at the box office in recent weeks despite the star power of its leading man, the pop singer Nick Jonas, in the role of the executive J. Pierrepont Finch. Last week, the show took in just $367,605 at the box office, or about 26 percent of its potential gross at the Hirschfeld. It recouped its $9 million initial investment in December.

Since Adam Yauch of the Beastie Boys died on Friday, a great deal of attention has been paid to the group's innovative use of sampling, as well as to the legal issues that have surrounded sampling for decades. And, in an unfortunate coincidence, on Thursday, the day before Mr. Yauch's death, a lawsuit was filed against the group in federal court, raising those same legal issues. The suit argues that several songs by the 1980s group Trouble Funk were used on the 1989 Beastie Boys' album, ''Paul's Boutique,'' and also on the group's 1986 debut, ''Licensed to Ill,'' without permission.
7:46 p.m. | Updated For weeks, as an accelerating wave of partner defections crippled Dewey & LeBoeuf, the law firm's head of litigation, Jeffrey L. Kessler, insisted that the firm could stay afloat.

KATZENBACH--Nicholas deB. A Vera Institute of Justice trustee from 1969 to 1983 and subsequently honorary trustee until his death, Mr. Katzenbach was best known to the public for personally facing down the Alabama governor in the fight for desegregation. His lifelong bravery and commitment to equal rights were demonstrated less publicly when he helped plan and became the first board chair of the Brooklyn-based Addiction Research and Treatment Corporation, which Vera helped create in 1969. The Vera Institute was honored to have Mr. Katzenbach deliver its first Justice Address in 2007 and joins the larger social-justice community in mourning his death.

It took nearly a decade of parenting before I saw this holiday as having anything to do with me. My children brought home the kind of things children do, and I cherished every handprint. But my biggest concern was my own mom. My family is big on small celebrations, and it was the day when I made the kind of curly-ribboned fuss over her that she regularly made over me. Even after my children arrived, to me, it was her day.

FIVE years after he bought the Elsa Schiaparelli brand in 2007, Diego della Valle, the chief executive of Tod's, will push forward a revival of a style he calls ''inimitable'' and ''modern,'' and will do so with a model spokeswoman whom he believes represents the spirit of that legendary designer. ''I chose Farida Khelfa for her strong passion for the Schiaparelli brand and for her modern and provocative elegance,'' Mr. della Valle said. ''She reminds me of Elsa in her charm and her distinct taste and style.''
ADELMAN--Walter Brian. Born in Brooklyn, NY, December 30, 1934, died April 17, 2012. Sheridan Oregon. Buried Havurah Shalom Portland Oregon. www.wayworld.com/ walteradelman.

OBITUARIES An obituary on Wednesday about the violinist Roman Totenberg repeated an error from a 1935 Times report on a concert in Washington at which Mr. Totenberg made his United States debut. He performed Beethoven's Violin Concerto in D Major -- not in D Minor. (There is no such Beethoven violin concerto.) And the obituary misstated the surname of the pianist in the Alma Trio, which also included Mr. Totenberg and the cellist Gabor Rejto. He was Adolph Baller, not Bailer.

A COOL thing about Feminin Rascal, a new accessories-only e-commerce site, is that hard-to-find European goods can be delivered to your door in a matter of hours. For her first foray into the fashion biz, the owner, Estee Lieberman, who has a background in finance, secured the sort of covetable items you usually see only in spreads in Italian Vogue. There is a finely edited selection of fringe leather bags from Sara Battaglia, whose sister, Giovanna, serves as inspiration; sexy modern shoes from the French label Aperlai; and hand-finished multicolor scarves from the British designer Jane Carr. The accessories on the site (femininrascal.com) are generally pricey, but Pourchet handbags and Maison Boinet belts are steals. And for New York City shoppers, same-day delivery is free.

They may not be the luckiest people in the world, but Brooklyn people who want to see Barbra Streisand struck a jackpot of sorts Wednesday: the singer confirmed that she is returning to her home turf, to perform for the first time since she graduated from Erasmus Hall High School as a fiercely ambitious teenager and became, well, Barbra Streisand. ''Brooklyn to me means the Loew's Kings, Erasmus, the yeshiva I went to, the Dodgers, Prospect Park, great Chinese food,'' Ms. Streisand said in a statement announcing the concert, which is set for October 11. ''I'm so glad I came from Brooklyn - it's down to earth. I guess you can come home again.''
Because of an editing error, an article last Thursday about the artist Rita Ackermann misstated the title of her recent video series. It is ''Warfilms,'' not ''Warfilm.''
GANS--Jamie. Thinking of you and hoping you have finally found some peace. Love and miss you, Mona, Felix, Andy and Sarah

NBC ended the suspense early about the future of the last ''Law & Order'' series standing. The long-running ''S.V.U.'' edition will be back for a 14th season, the network announced Wednesday. The news is certainly good for Dick Wolf, who created the now storied ''Law & Order'' franchise in 1990. It is especially good because NBC has also ordered a new series from Mr. Wolf, ''Chicago Fire,'' a drama about a firehouse in inner-city Chicago.

WASHINGTON -- Russia's newly inaugurated president, Vladimir V. Putin, will not attend a summit meeting of world leaders in Maryland next week, the White House said on Wednesday, postponing until June the much-anticipated first meeting of President Obama and Mr. Putin as the leaders of their respective countries. The surprising White House announcement, which came after a telephone call between the men, serves to underscore what appears to be a difficult start to their relationship.
Q. I have heard you can view live TV with Windows 7. How hard is this to set up?

Uploading albums of photos on Facebook is a convenient way to share multiple pictures of an event with friends. If the page for the photos is set to Album view, comments from friends on the entire album appear below the thumbnails, but you must click on each image to see the specific comments for that picture. If you would rather see a list of the comments for the all the photos in the album in a list, click the Comment view icon (just to the left of the Add Photos button in the upper right corner of the page) to see a list of larger thumbnails of the photos that have individual comments from friends. Click the Album view icon (to the left of Comment view) to return to the full album of pictures.

4:43 p.m. | Updated Just weeks after hundreds of independent filmmakers protested a scheduling change for two award-winning independent film series on PBS, the broadcaster said Wednesday that it would move both series, ''Independent Lens'' and ''POV,'' to a Monday night slot and begin promotional efforts to recover viewers who were lost this season. The average number of viewers for new episodes of ''Independent Lens'' dropped 39 percent from October 2011 through March, after the show was bumped from the Tuesday night schedule (new episodes of ''POV,'' which were also moved, begin June 21.)

To the Editor: Re ''Ban on Gay Marriage Passes in North Carolina'' (news article, May 9): When I was a middle school student in the 1990s, a constant source of fear was the realization that I would never have what my parents had, or what all my friends' parents had. Gay marriage in New York State was still illegal, and when parents arrived together to pick their children up from school, I always saw something I could never accomplish. Banning gay marriage, as North Carolina voters did on Tuesday, means that for many children, this fear will persist: in churches, in schools and at home. This vote should be a call to action for any American who cares about keeping justice safe. PETER FULHAM Washington, May 9, 2012

JAFFE--Seymour, passed away May 5, 2012. Predeceased by wife of 55 years, Lenora. Survived by daughters, Cynthia J. Sanders and Deena L. Jaffe, son-in-law Bruce Sanders, granddaughter Megans Rickets (Joshua). Great-grandson Aryu Rickets, sister Beatrice Schmetz, brothers Marvin Jaffe (Anna) and Ira Jaffe (Shirley).

For nearly 50 years, the large school building on Avenue X in Gravesend, Brooklyn, has been known as John Dewey High School, after the man who has been called ''the father of progressive education.'' The name is on the building and the sign out front. It is what you hear on the school's answering machine. That era is coming to an end.

JEFFERY--Reuben, Jr. of Southport, CT beloved husband of the late Ann Thomas Jeffery, passed away peacefully in his home Saturday, May 5, 2012. Born January 31, 1923 in Syracuse, NY, the son of late Marie and Reuben Jeffery. He served in Japan with the U.S. Army 11th Airborne Division leaving the service at the end of the war as a Captain. Graduated from Yale, B.E. 1944 and Harvard Business School, M.B.A. 1949, with High Distinction and as a Baker Scholar. Thirty-five year career as an accounts manager, Polymer Products Department, E.I. DuPont de Nemours & Co. He is survived by his two children; Reuben Jeffery III of New York, NY and Martha Ann Jeffery of Bridgeport, CT; three grandchildren, Jocelyn Ann Jeffery, Reuben Jeffery IV and Robert Walker Jeffery; and his sister Jean Jeffery Greene of Syracuse, NY. He was predeceased by his brother, John Jeffery. A memorial service will be held Friday, May 18th 2012 at 11:00AM at Greenfield Hill Congregational Church, 1045 Old Academy Road, Fairfield, CT. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory can be made to Greenfield Hill Congregational Church.

SHUCHAT--Miriam. SAR mourns the loss of Miriam Shuchat, beloved mother of Bryna Landes and Board Member, Josh Landes, grandmother of SAR students Arielle, Daniel and Eli. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jack Bendheim, President

In an unusual move that may prompt millions of women to rethink their use of popular bone-building drugs, the Food and Drug Administration published an analysis that suggested caution about long-term use of the drugs, but fell short of issuing specific recommendations. The F.D.A. review, published in The New England Journal of Medicine online on Wednesday, was prompted by a growing debate over how long women should continue using the drugs, known as bisphosphonates, which are sold as generic versions of brands like Fosamax and Boniva, as well as Novartis's Reclast.

LOS ANGELES - In France, the pursuit of Roman Polanski by American authorities who remain intent on bringing him to trial for a decades-old sex offense has raised comparisons to the Dreyfus Affair. And those comparisons will surely be revived by Mr. Polanski's next film project: A political thriller to be called ''D,'' based on the story of Capt. Alfred Dreyfus. Dreyfus, a Jewish officer in the French Army, was tried for treason in 1894 for supposedly passing secrets to the Germans. He was convicted, sentenced to life in prison, and sent to Devil's Island, off South America. But an impassioned public defense by Émile Zola, and years of advocacy by others, ultimately led to his exoneration.

SCIENCE TIMES An article on Tuesday about the death of Vladimir Lenin, the subject this year at the University of Maryland's annual historical clinicopathological conference, misstated Lenin's age when he was shot twice in an assassination attempt. He was 48, not 38.

KINBERG--Rose M. ('Babe') 94, died peacefully at home in NYC, May 8. Beloved wife of the late Jack H., mother of Judy, Ronnie and wife Geri, grandmother of Michelle and Chris, Lee and Rose. Private burial. Donations: Carnegie East House, 1844 2nd Ave, New York, NY 10128, Attn C. Baksh appreciated. Memorial at CEH TBA.

DANCE--W. David, retired Vice Chairman of the General Electric Company's Board of Directors, passed away peacefully in Naples, FL, on May 2, 2012. He was 94. Born in Amherst, Nova Scotia, May 13, 1917, the son of Walter and Gertrude Dance, he grew up in Nahant, MA and was a longtime resident of Darien and New Canaan, CT. Predeceased by his wife of sixty-five years, Jane (Clune), and son Peter, he is survived by three children, Susan Deetsch, Louisville, KY; Robert Dance, Norfolk, CT and New York; and Richard Dance, West Chester, PA; seven grandchildren and eleven great-grandchildren. Dance graduated from Dartmouth College in 1940, and was a member of the Amos Tuck School of Business class of 1941. He served in the Army until 1945 attaining the rank of captain. Dance then began a thirty one year career with General Electric, including three years as President of Hotpoint, before retiring in 1979 as Vice Chairman of GE, and Chairman of the Board of GE Capital. He served on advisory committees for national energy programs for both Presidents Carter and Reagan. Dance served as Chairman of the Board of Overseers at the Tuck School, and as a director of A & P, Kollmorgen, Itek, Acme-Cleveland and Schering-Plough. He was a founder and director of the Citizens National Bank, Naples, FL, later absorbed into AmSouth (now RegionsFinancial). An avid golfer, Dance was a member of the Wee Burn Country Club, Darien, the Blind Brook Club, Purchase, NY, and the Royal Poinciana, Pelican Bay and Moorings clubs, Naples. Dance supported Habitat for Humanity, providing funding for fifteen houses in the Naples area, as well as Avow Hospice, the Tuck School and the Hood Museum at Dartmouth. Funeral Mass, St. Ann Catholic Church in Naples, FL, Saturday, May 12, 10am. Interment, Wednesday, May 16 at 11:30am, Lakeview Cemetery, New Canaan, CT. Memorial contributions to Avow Hospice, 1095 Whippoorwill Lane, Naples, FL 34105.

FIELDING--Florence, of Forest Hills, NY, died peacefully on her 104th birthday. Mother of Roberta Weissman; grandmother of Liz Priven and Susan Weissman. Graveside service Friday at Mount Ararat Cemetery 12:30pm.

THE fashionable Swedish fragrance house Byredo, with its enigmatic modern scents and distinctively minimal packaging, has collaborated with the design firm M/M (Paris) on a limited edition of handmade silk scarves to accompany its latest perfume, Seven Veils. Inspired by the dance of the seven veils, the biblical tale of Salome, the spicy sherry-color fragrance builds on a warm Indian sandalwood and vanilla base with a Tahitian vanilla flower heart and carrot and pimento berry top notes. Seven variations of the multicolor snakeskin-print scarves play on the seductive theme. Byredo Seven Veils perfume and scarf kit, $430; perfume alone, $220; at Barneys New York.

LUCAS HUGH, a line of workout attire from London, is technologically advanced and flattering. The woman behind the chic line is Anjhe Mules, a onetime intern at Alexander McQueen, where she designed swimwear. Her high-performance pieces are constructed with the same glue-seam technology used in the Speedo LZR Racer Michael Phelps wore in the Beijing Olympics. There are featherweight stretch leggings with a built-in support system (extra fabric, a bit like Spanx, slims and supports the bum), mesh-paneled swimsuits and sports bras in the glossy Olympics-inspired red and blue hues of the British flag. Other leggings and cycling shorts come in an abstract print based on pencil and ink drawings by the Russian artist Anna Sudbina. Much of the line is at Net-a-Porter, and you can also find Lucas Hugh, $110 to $595, at Kirna Zabête and Bergdorf Goodman.

During a soccer game two years ago, Megan Wirtz, a goalie for her high school team, was bending down to pick up a ball when an opposing player mistakenly kicked her in the face. Her face swollen and bleeding, Megan was taken to an emergency room and stitched up. No one realized she had suffered a severe concussion until three weeks later, when a player ran into her during another game and she fell to the ground, suffering a seizure on the field. Doctors believe she experienced what's known as second impact syndrome, a sequence of events in which a child or teenager sustains a hit before a concussion fully heals, which can cause the brain to bleed or swell, even if the second impact is a moderate one.

The silence has been broken: ''Chaplin,'' a new musical about the life of the comic performer and cinema pioneer Charlie Chaplin, has found a Broadway home. The production, which features music and lyrics by Christopher Curtis and a book by Mr. Curtis and Thomas Meehan (''Annie,'' ''The Producers'' and ''Hairspray''), will be presented at the Barrymore Theater, where it will begin previews on Aug. 21 and have its opening night on Sept. 10, its press representatives said on Thursday. ''Chaplin'' will be directed and choreographed by Warren Carlyle, who had those duties on ''Hugh Jackman, Back on Broadway'' and also choreographed the recent Broadway revival of ''Follies.'' The musical, which chronicles Chaplin's upbringing, professional breakthroughs and personal and political scandals, was presented in 2010 at the La Jolla Playhouse in San Diego. Titled ''Limelight: The Story of Charlie Chaplin,'' that production was not praised as universally as, say, ''Modern Times'' or ''The Great Dictator.'' In a review for The Los Angeles Times, Charles McNulty wrote that that incarnation of the musical ''doesn't rise to the challenge with anything resembling bold invention.'' But the San Diego Theater Critics Circle named ''Limelight'' its best new musical of 2010.

He enjoyed a rich and fulfilling life with his late wife Elaine Brody Silverberg and will be missed and long remembered by his step daughter, Sue Shapiro; his sister, Dorothy Silverberg; his brother, Benjamin Silverberg; his sister-in-law, Sheila Brody Kamerman; his nieces and nephews; his long-time friend, Marian Green, and his many colleagues at Wakefern/Shop- Rite. David was predeceased by his beloved brother Burt I. Sherman. Funeral services will be held at 9:30am on Friday, May 11th at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue. The period of mourning will be observed at the home of the deceased. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Bar Ilan University in Israel or the Elaine Brody Travel Fellowship at New York Univ.

COLUMBIA, S.C. -- When Command Sgt. Maj. Teresa L. King was named the first female commandant of the Army's elite drill sergeant school in 2009, proponents of gender equality in the military hailed the news as a watershed. But it did not take long for the grumbling to start. Students who flunked out of the school complained that she set unfair standards. Some of her own instructors said she rigidly enforced old-fashioned rules. Traditionalists across the service asked: how could a woman with no experience in combat manage the Army's only school for training the trainers who prepare recruits for war?

It is springtime in New York, and festivalitis has struck again. A fistful of festivals dedicated to new music have just finished, are happening now or are coming up. Two take place this weekend: the Queens New Music Festival in Long Island City and Look & Listen at the Pratt Manhattan Gallery in Chelsea.

''Forbidden Broadway,'' the long-running satirical revue of the artistic highs and overacting lows of New York theater, ended in March 2009 with more than 9,750 performances to its credit, after creator Gerard Alessandrini decided that ''Shrek the Musical,'' ''Guys and Dolls'' and other Broadway fare at the time weren't worth spoofing. But with critically derided shows like ''Ghost the Musical'' and ''Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark'' now on the boards, Mr. Alessandrini couldn't resist a comeback. A 21st edition of ''Forbidden Broadway'' is now in the works, Mr. Alessandrini said on Thursday, with preview performances scheduled to begin on July 17 at the show's old home, the 47th Street Theater, and an opening night planned for late summer. He will once again write and direct the revue, which first ran off Broadway in 1982 and received a special Tony Award in 2006; various editions have been performed in dozens of American cities as well as in London, Tokyo and Sydney. Casting for the new production will be announced later.

FRANKFURT - When Next Alternative, a Canadian start-up, wanted to raise money a few years ago, it opted for a listing on a new offshoot of the Frankfurt Stock Exchange. As part of the bourse's so-called First Quotation Board, the six-month-old start-up could tap investors for capital without the higher costs, stricter disclosure requirements and other regulatory hurdles of an offering on the main exchange. Now, Next Alternative has to find another home. The owner of the stock exchange, Deutsche Börse, is closing the unregulated market in December after a number of dubious parties used it to defraud investors. The situation has left hundreds of small companies, including Next Alternative, scrambling to qualify for the next level of the market or face delisting.

KATZENBACH--Nicholas deB. The partners of Cravath, Swaine & Moore LLP mourn the passing of their friend, colleague and client, Nicholas deB. Katzenbach. Mr. Katzenbach served as Senior Vice President and General Counsel of IBM during the critical years of IBM's successful defense of one of the most significant antitrust cases ever brought. His extraordinary leadership of that effort followed one of the most distinguished careers in public service, which included serving as the Attorney General of the United States during the height of the Civil Rights movement and as the Under Secretary of State during the Vietnam conflict. Despite his extraordinary accomplishments, Nick was a humble, self-effacing man with a wonderful sense of humor. Our country has lost a great man whose lifelong bravery and commitment to social justice helped shape this country's political history. Our sincere condolences are offered to Nick's wife, Lydia, to his children and grandchildren.

The best thing about ''Small, Beautifully Moving Parts'' is its admission that a positive pregnancy test is not always cause for giddy celebration; the worst thing is that, even at a lean 73 minutes, this flimsy road movie feels at least 43 minutes too long. Falling squarely into the much-ado-about-nothing category, Annie J. Howell and Lisa Robinson's debut feature hovers over Sarah (Anna Margaret Hollyman), a bland Los Angeles technophile who relates more willingly to wires and processors than to the fetus in her womb. Deciding that this is clearly the fault of her long-estranged mother (the marvelous Mary Beth Peil), currently residing off the grid in the Arizona desert, Sarah sets out for an uninvited reunion. Detours to a nightmarish baby shower, a Skype-obsessed father and a Vegas masseuse prove depressingly uninvigorating to both Sarah's maternal instincts and the film around her.

LIFLAND--William Thomas, 83, a leading antitrust lawyer and retired partner in the New York law firm Cahill Gordon & Reindel LLP, died peacefully on May 3, 2012 at his home near Princeton, NJ, after a long illness. To all who knew him, Bill Lifland was a gentleman and a scholar, a dry wit and a man of utmost integrity. The elder son of I. Charles and Carol Francks Lifland, he graduated from Yale College (49) and Harvard Law School ('52), where he was president of the Harvard Law Review. After law school, he served two years in the Air Force General Counsel's Office and a year as law clerk to U.S. Supreme Court Justice John Marshall Harlan II. He joined Cahill in 1955, practicing there until his retirement in 2002. A preeminent antitrust practitioner, he advised a diverse array of clients on all aspects of trade and competition law. He published two books on antitrust law, and wrote the New York Law Journal's monthly "Antitrust" column for 33 years. He taught antitrust law at Fordham Law School from 1981 to 2004, and served more than 30 years as an antitrust instructor for the Practicing Law Institute. In 1997 the New York State Bar Association Antitrust Section awarded him its Distinguished Service Award, and in 2007 the Section renamed the award the William T. Lifland Service Award in his honor. At home in Princeton, he enjoyed making furniture, tinkering with electronics, and developing and printing his own photographs. He was an avid reader and loved the theatre, concerts, and opera. He enjoyed playing tennis, bicycling, and traveling. A longtime member of Trinity Church, Princeton, he was a chair of the Outreach Committee and member of the Ushers' Guild. He is survived by his wife of 57 years, the former Nancy Moffat; their daughter, Carol and husband Daniel Giesberg of Los Angeles, CA; and sons, Charles and wife Alison of Pasadena, CA, Kerin of Grass Valley, CA, and David and wife Catherine Radmer of Wayland, MA; his brother, the Hon. John C. Lifland and wife Jean of Sea Girt, NJ; eleven grandchildren; and many nieces, nephews, and cousins. Interment will be private and a memorial service will be held in the fall. In lieu of flowers, the family invites your contributions to The Hospice Memorial Fund, Princeton Healthcare System Foundation, 253 Witherspoon Street, Suite 1, Princeton, NJ 08540. To extend condolences and comments please visit: TheKimbleFuneralHome.com.

DANCE--W. David, retired Vice Chairman of the General Electric Company's Board of Directors, passed away peacefully in Naples, FL, on May 2, 2012. He was 94. Born in Amherst, Nova Scotia, May 13, 1917, the son of Walter and Gertrude Dance, he grew up in Nahant, MA and was a longtime resident of Darien and New Canaan, CT. Predeceased by his wife of sixty-five years, Jane (Clune), and son Peter, he is survived by three children, Susan Deetsch, Louisville, KY; Robert Dance, Norfolk, CT and New York; and Richard Dance, West Chester, PA; seven grandchildren and eleven great-grandchildren. Dance graduated from Dartmouth College in 1940, and was a member of the Amos Tuck School of Business class of 1941. He served in the Army until 1945 attaining the rank of captain. Dance then began a thirty one year career with General Electric, including three years as President of Hotpoint, before retiring in 1979 as Vice Chairman of GE, and Chairman of the Board of GE Capital. He served on advisory committees for national energy programs for both Presidents Carter and Reagan. Dance served as Chairman of the Board of Overseers at the Tuck School, and as a director of A & P, Kollmorgen, Itek, Acme-Cleveland and Schering-Plough. He was a founder and director of the Citizens National Bank, Naples, FL, later absorbed into AmSouth (now RegionsFinancial). An avid golfer, Dance was a member of the Wee Burn Country Club, Darien, the Blind Brook Club, Purchase, NY, and the Royal Poinciana, Pelican Bay and Moorings clubs, Naples. Dance supported Habitat for Humanity, providing funding for fifteen houses in the Naples area, as well as Avow Hospice, the Tuck School and the Hood Museum at Dartmouth. Funeral Mass, St. Ann Catholic Church in Naples, FL, Saturday, May 12, 10am. Interment, Wednesday, May 16 at 11:30am, Lakeview Cemetery, New Canaan, CT. Memorial contributions to Avow Hospice, 1095 Whippoorwill Lane, Naples, FL 34105.

Mort Lindsey, who led Merv Griffin's television orchestra, accompanied Barbra Streisand on the piano in Central Park and played with Judy Garland in her celebrated comeback concert at Carnegie Hall, died on May 4 at his home in Malibu, Calif. He was 89. The cause was complications of a broken hip, his son Steve said.

An article on Thursday about President Obama's decision to declare his support for same-sex marriage described incorrectly in some editions a transcript circulated within the White House of Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.'s earlier remarks on the subject. The transcript, of a taping on Friday for broadcast on NBC's ''Meet the Press'' on Sunday, had the vice president's remarks on gay marriage highlighted in yellow. It was not the case, as a White House official said, that the vice president's office did not call the comments to anyone's attention.

PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla. - Ian Poulter is from England, but he looked at home Thursday at T.P.C. Sawgrass, shooting a seven-under-par 65 to take the early lead in the first round of the Players Championship. Poulter said the main reason was that he finally had a place to call home.

FORSYTHE--Warren, age 83, died on May 7, 2012. A graduate of St. Lawrence University and Yale Law School, Warren's career in the field of trust and estate law earned him a reputation for wise, thorough and effective advice to generations of clients. A loving and devoted husband and brother, he is survived by his wife Elizabeth, of Manhattan, and sister Jean Grayson, of Madrid, New York. He also will be warmly remembered by the many young people he mentored.

After three seasons on ABC ''Cougar Town'' is shifting to TBS, the comedy-centric cable channel that has been trying to promote a slate of original sitcoms. New episodes of ''Cougar Town'' will start showing on TBS in early 2013, the channel said in a news release Thursday. There will be 15 made, a TBS spokeswoman said. Older episodes will also be shown on the channel starting early next year.

CLARK--Msgr. Eugene V.,The Trustees of the Homeland Foundation, Inc. express great sympathy and affection for Msgr. Eugene V. Clark who died on April 11, 2012 in East Hampton, NY. Msgr. Clark was a guiding force and inspiration for the Homeland Foundation and was, along with Fr. Raphael Camano, its spiritual leader. He was a brilliant speaker, a knowledgeable connoisseur of religious art, had a keen whit, and was very devout. He was the creator of, and motivating influence, behind the Patrons of the Arts at the Vatican Museums, establishing its first United States Chapter in New York City, and counseled the members in their restoration of numerous works of art in Vatican Museums. This included the Raphael Tapestry "Healing the Lame Man," a 1 B.C. Roman Mosaic, the Fra Angelico frescoes in the Chapel of Nicholas V in Pontifical Palace in the Vatican, and the restoration of the Casina of Pope Pius IV in the Vatican Gardens near St. Peter's Basilica. He also was responsible for hundreds of persons being able to view Michelangelo's work in the Sistine Chapel, assisting many to ascend the scaffolding during the cleaning of the Chapel ceiling and "Last Judgment." His caring ways and leadership will be missed by Homeland, his family, and all of the persons and organizations with which he was involved during his lifetime. E. Lisk Wyckoff, Jr., President William J. Ayres, Vice Pres. David Dangremond, Vice Pres. Rev. John Kamas, Vice Pres. Carl Schmitt Elizabeth Wyckoff, Secretary Mrs. Lucy Flemming-McGrath, Trustee Emeritus

When Luli (Chloë Grace Moretz), the 13-year-old heroine of ''Hick,'' a botched coming-of-age story, decides to leave her Nebraska home for a glamorous life in Las Vegas, she takes off down the road, skipping. That's after she's practiced her Clint Eastwood moves in the mirror with her gun (a birthday present): ''You feel lucky, punk?'' Well, uh, do you? Directed by Derick Martini and adapted by Mr. Martini and Andrea Portes from her novel of the same title, ''Hick'' sends its young heroine -- more literary creation than credible teenager -- into the big, bad American heartland. It's a place of dank pool halls, one-street towns and shabby motels, a mythopoetic jumble of dangers and snares taken from other, better movies and books.

GELLER--Bertram, born June 18, 1918. Survived by his wife Lois of 64 years and by his son Sam, daughter Janet, grandchildren Grace and Emily, and daughter in law, Donna. He died peacefully on May 10 in his New York apartment. Bert Geller was successful in his business as a furrier and was successful in his avocation of art. Bert was in the fur business, the Geller Brothers, with his beloved brother Marty Geller who pre-deceased him. After retiring, he took up painting and decorated his home in Florida with his art work, as well as the homes of his family. Painting was a great joy in his life and is a talent he passed on to his granddaughter, Emily. Bert was also a life- long athlete, and played handball, tennis and golf. Bert continued to play golf and bridge up until a few weeks before his death. Bert was devoted to his wife, his children and grandchildren, but particularly to his daughter Janet who has cerebral palsy. Janet continues to have a wonderful life provided by the Crystal Run Village Foundation of Middletown, New York. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that memorials be made to Crystal Run. A private burial service was held at Mt Hebron cemetery on Friday, May 11th.

The high price of oil is not the only effect of commodity inflation hitting the streets of New York. A surge in the value of copper, iron and other metals has fueled a wave of thefts from sidewalks, roadways and rail yards in the last few months. On Wednesday alone, the New York police arrested three men for stealing hunks of cast iron - grates made to protect tree roots and manhole covers weighing as much as 300 pounds. The arrests followed reports of the disappearance of dozens of the grates and covers across the city and came on top of a continuing spree of thefts of copper wire from utility cables.

More than 700 scholars, writers, publishers, artists and others sent a letter to the New York Public Library on Wednesday protesting the $300 million restructuring of the 42nd Street flagship building and calling for a public discussion of the plan. The signers include the writers Salman Rushdie and Jonathan Lethem, the cartoonist Art Spiegelman and the historian Natalie Zemon Davis.

An article on Thursday about a White House announcement on Wednesday that President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia had decided not to attend a summit meeting of world leaders in Maryland next week misstated, in some editions, the circumstances under which Mr. Putin became Russia's prime minister after his first two terms as president ended in 2008. He was appointed by his successor, Dmitri A. Medvedev; he was not elected to the position.

WASHINGTON -- A few hours before President Obama offered his historic endorsement of same-sex marriage on Wednesday, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. apologized to the president in the Oval Office for forcing Mr. Obama's hand by airing his own views three days earlier, several people briefed on the exchange said on Thursday. Mr. Biden declared in an interview on Sunday that he was ''absolutely comfortable'' with same-sex marriage, a position that went considerably further than the president's ''evolving'' views on the matter and scrambled the White House's carefully laid plans for confronting one of the most sensitive social issues in the election.

An article on Wednesday about the growing acceptance of gay characters in television entertainment misstated the reaction of Bill O'Reilly, the Fox News host, when Chaz Bono became the first openly transgender contestant on ABC's ''Dancing With the Stars.'' Mr. O'Reilly interviewed a psychiatrist who was critical of the inclusion of Mr. Bono on the program, but Mr. O'Reilly expressed support for Mr. Bono; he did not complain about Mr. Bono's participation. The article also misidentified the gay character in the ''Modern Family'' series on ABC who had a disdain for public displays of affection. The character is Mitchell Pritchett, not Cameron Tucker.

Coty on Thursday raised its takeover bid for Avon Products to $10.7 billion and unveiled a potent new weapon: Warren E. Buffett. Among Coty's newest backers is Berkshire Hathaway, the conglomerate that Mr. Buffett runs and one of the best-regarded companies in the country.

BEIJING -- China escalated its quarrel with the Philippines over an island in the South China Sea on Thursday, halting Philippine bananas at customs for longer inspections and starting an official media campaign that suggested that any claims on the island represented an infringement of Chinese sovereignty. So far, China has not brought the United States into this renewed round of tension with the Philippines, but in the past few weeks the Chinese have said that the Philippines was daring to challenge China around an island in the South China Sea because of its alliance with Washington.

KATZENBACH--Nicholas deB. The partners of Cravath, Swaine & Moore LLP mourn the passing of their friend, colleague and client, Nicholas deB. Katzenbach. Mr. Katzenbach served as Senior Vice President and General Counsel of IBM during the critical years of IBM's successful defense of one of the most significant antitrust cases ever brought. His extraordinary leadership of that effort followed one of the most distinguished careers in public service, which included serving as the Attorney General of the United States during the height of the Civil Rights movement and as the Under Secretary of State during the Vietnam conflict. Despite his extraordinary accomplishments, Nick was a humble, self-effacing man with a wonderful sense of humor. Our country has lost a great man whose lifelong bravery and commitment to social justice helped shape this country's political history. Our sincere condolences are offered to Nick's wife, Lydia, to his children and grandchildren.

GOLAMBOS--Anne Keiko, passed away in New York on Tuesday from malaria complications after a trip to Ghana, Africa. She was born on October 6, 1980 in Rockville Center, NY. She attended the preparatory division of the Manhattan School of Music for piano while in high school, Binghamton University in New York and Christchurch College at the University of Oxford. She recently received her M.S. from the Swedish Institute of Acupuncture in New York. As a student, she was invited to speak at the international Asian Medical Conference in Bhutan in 2009. She founded the Global Clinic which has provided Asian medicine and acupuncture treatment to over a thousand Mayans in Guatemala. Global Clinic had plans to expand this program to other people and countries in need. Anne Keiko traveled extensively looking to appreciate and respect the differences in people to help enrich her own life and the lives of the people that she touched.

An art review last Friday about ''Lucio Fontana: Ambienti Spaziali,'' at the Gagosian Gallery on West 24th Street in Manhattan, referred incompletely to the six walk-in environments in the exhibition. Four are examples of ''Ambienti Spaziali,'' or ''Spatial Environments.'' The review also misstated the history of the display of Fontana's neon works in the United States. The exhibition is not the first time one has been shown here.

RAPP--Lillian, Ehrich, on May 10, 2012. Wife of the late Frank M. Rapp. Mother of Salena (Allen) Kern and Michael (Mary). Sister of Herbert Ehrich and the late Fred Ehrich. Services handled by Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 908-964-1500.

An article on Thursday about a system of carbon trading permits between Canada and California misstated its status in some copies. The system, and a California law to establish it, have been proposed; they have not been established. The error was repeated in the headline in some copies.

PEARCE--Judith Handler, 87, on May 9, after nine years with breast cancer. A resident of Manhattan and East Hampton, she was the beloved wife of Dr. Eli Pearce for 32 years. Mother of John Herfort (and Didi), the late David Herfort, the late Stephen Herfort, Michael Ruby (and Louisa) and Elizabeth Ruby Lyden (and John). Stepmother of Russell Pearce (and Michele) and Debra Pearce-McCall (and Scott). Grandmother of Karl, Grace and Clara Lyden; Charlotte, Emily and Natalie Ruby; Jamie Herfort; Seth and Jacob Pearce; and Kyle and Alexander Pearce-McCall. Sister of Antonia Handler Chayes. Special friend of Susan Ei. Judith was born in Manhattan, grew up in Woodmere, received a B.A. from Smith College, an M.A. in American History from Columbia and an M.S.W. from Rutgers. In her long career as a social worker, she helped Holocaust survivors, welfare recipients, minority schoolchildren, ex-addicts, foster-care families and the elderly. Funeral at Frank E. Campbell (81st and Madison) at 10am, Sunday, May 13. Interment at Mount Pleasant Cemetery, Hawthorne, N.Y., 10532. Shiva on Sunday after 5pm and Monday after 4pm at 2 Fifth Ave., Apt. 14M. In lieu of flowers, please contribute to the re-election of Barack Obama or the charity of your choice.

DILLON--Robert E.,Jr., 80, who retired as Executive Vice President of Sony North America in 1996 and was immersed in community activities for many years, passed away at his Westfield, NJ, home on Wednesday, May 9, 2012. He is survived by his wife of 58 years, Alice Sullivan Dillon, and their seven children, Marion Morris, Brooklin, ME; Dan Dillon, Leesburg, VA; Robert Dillon, III, Livingston, NJ; Andrew Dillon, Blue Hill, ME; Julia Dillon, Westfield; Joan Sloyan, Asheboro, NC; and David Dillon, Brooklin, ME; and 20 grandchildren. Also surviving is his brother James Dillon of Naples, FL. Son of Marion McNulty and Robert Dillon of Buffalo, NY, he graduated from Amherst College in 1953 and the Harvard Business School with an MBA in 1955. After U.S. Army service overseas, he worked for Lake Erie Engineering, Electro Dynamics, Mobil and ADT as a financial executive before joining Sony in 1973, the start of a 23-year career with the electronics and entertainment company. He also served on the UNUM Board of Directors and as a trustee of the College of Mount St. Vincent in New York. Notable as a family man, Roman Catholic and energetic volunteer in health care, the arts, education and community charities, including the Overlook Hospital in Summit, NJ, the Kessler Foundation supporting rehabilitation research and employment programs for people with disabilities, the United Fund of Westfield, the Westfield Foundation, Westfield Senior Citizen Housing, New Jersey Connect in developing affordable housing for physically disabled people, The Visual Arts Center of New Jersey, the United Way of Bergen County, and the Boy Scouts of Bergen County. He was honored with numerous awards recognizing decades of service and leadership. Not simply a parishioner of Holy Trinity Catholic Church of Westfield, he served his church in many volunteer capacities, including as a trustee. He was inducted into the Knights of Malta in 1994. The Dillons also maintain a home in Cape Elizabeth, ME. A funeral mass will be celebrated at The Catholic Church of the Holy Trinity, Westfield, NJ at 10am on Tuesday, May 15th. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that memorial donations be made to The Westfield Foundation (PO Box 2295, Westfield, NJ 07091), or to the charity of your choice.

An architecture review on Wednesday about a new visitor center and gateway at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden included an outdated reference to other entrances. One of the ''creaking turnstiles,'' on Eastern Parkway, was replaced by a new gate in 2006; it is not the case that the turnstiles ''have long served as the only public entrances'' to the garden. The review also misidentified the garden's employees who will care for the plants and grasses on the new center's roof. They are gardeners, not botanists.

KEYNAN--Professor Alex. We mourn the passing of Professor Alex Keynan, our dear friend and colleague of many years. Alex was a renowned microbiologist, an emeritus professor at the Hebrew University, a pioneer in the development of basic scientific research in Israel and a seminal figure in the development of Israel's policy on science. Among his many accomplishments were the establishment of the Israel Science Foundation, the Batsheva de Rothschild Foundation and the American Foundation for Basic Research in Israel. American Foundation for Basic Research in Israel

KATZENBACH--Nicholas. The Board of Directors of Americans for Oxford (AFO) and the entire Oxford community mourn the passing of Nicholas Katzenbach. A loyal and devoted Oxonian throughout his life, Nick's link to Oxford began when he won the Rhodes Scholarship in 1947. He succeeded as a scholar, soldier, lawyer, teacher and public servant. His work on behalf of civil rights exemplifies all that Oxford hopes its graduates will embody: courage, wisdom and moral fortitude. Nick's service to Oxford took many forms, including a successful tenure as Chairman of AFO. We extend our sincere condolences to Lydia and the Katzenbach family. Paul M. Dodyk, Chairman, Americans for Oxford; Michael G. Cunningham, Exec. Director, Oxford NA Office.

Brian Harman would usually not be happy with a one-over-par 73 to open the Players Championship. This time, he will take it. Harman, a 25-year-old rookie, entered Thursday as the first alternate, but a last-second withdrawal by the tour veteran D. A. Points caused so much confusion that Harman barely got a spot. ''I had no idea what was going to happen,'' Harman said. ''I'd be lying if I said I wasn't a little shook up by what happened.'' Points arrived at the No. 1 tee with his playing partners, Carl Pettersson and Robert Garrigus. Next to hit after Pettersson, Points told the starter that he was withdrawing with a back injury. By the time Harman learned a spot was available, he and his caddie, John Davenport, were playing table tennis in the clubhouse, while Pettersson and Garrigus were on the second hole. Harman arrived at the course at 7 a.m. and let officials know that he was there in case of a withdrawal. Davenport went to the first tee at 7:15 a.m. to remind officials that Harman was there. ''It happened very quickly -- we didn't have time to react,'' said Mark Russell, the tour's vice president for rules and competition. ''Very unusual situation. I mean, I've never seen anything like it really.'' Tour officials concluded that Harman had done nothing wrong and let him tee off from No. 1 at 12:20 p.m. as a single. On Friday, Harman will replace Paul Casey (shoulder injury) and will tee off at 2 p.m. with Bud Cauley and Ryan Moore. ''I thought it was the fair thing to do,'' Harman said.

An article on Thursday about a Securities and Exchange Commission investigation into possible accounting fraud at a Chinese client of the Shanghai affiliate of Deloitte misstated, in some copies, a provision of the Sarbanes-Oxley law that requires auditors of foreign companies whose securities are registered in the United States to provide audit work papers when requested by the S.E.C. It is Section 102-e, not Section 106. The error also appeared in a quotation attributed to Lauren Mistretta, a spokeswoman for Deloitte Touche Tohmatsu. Ms. Mistretta correctly referred to Section 102-e; she did not say ''Section 106.''
SILVERBERG--David M. Our cherished uncle. We will never forget his intellect, sense of humor, and enduring love and dedication to his family. Ina, Stan, Barrett and Darren; Kay, Iver, Ben and Nina.

FINK--Lila Ruth. The Board of Directors, Staff and Volunteers of Ronald McDonald House New York mourn the passing of Lila Ruth Fink, mother of longtime friend and supporter of our organization, Laurence D. Fink. We extend our deepest condolences to his entire family. Respectfully, Stanley B. Shopkorn Chairman of the Board William T. Sullivan President & Chief Executive Officer Ronald McDonald House New York

The athletic directors of the Ivy League have turned down a proposal by its coaches for a postseason conference tournament in men's and women's basketball, the league said Thursday. ''After careful consideration of these proposals, the athletics directors decided that our current method of determining the Ivy League champion and our automatic bid recipient to the N.C.A.A. championship is the best model moving forward,'' Robin Harris, the Ivy League's executive director, said in a statement.

Sometimes during lengthy floor debates on bills, interesting things happen in the witching hours. Such was the case late Wednesday, when Representative John Lewis of Georgia pushed back with a fiery speech directed at an amendment offered by Representative Paul C. Broun of Georgia that would have barred the Justice Department from using money to enforce a part of the Voting Rights Act.

7 P.M. (HBO) ONE DAY (2011) Anne Hathaway and Jim Sturgess (above) portray Emma and Dex -- she's bookish, serious and from a family of modest means; he's dashing, irresponsible and wealthy -- who meet, as drunken university graduates, on St. Swithin's Day in 1988 and proceed to reunite on that date, July 15, each year. Rafe Spall and Romola Garai play the characters who would seem to be Emma and Dex's perfect matches. Ken Stott and Patricia Clarkson are Dex's parents. Lone Scherfig, ''a veteran of the Danish Dogme 95 movement, whose previous English-language films are 'Wilbur Wants to Kill Himself' and 'An Education,' can be a wonderfully centrifugal director, wandering away from the center of a conventional narrative toward its scruffy margins, where the interesting stuff happens,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. ''Her eccentric eye and offbeat rhythm sustain 'One Day' through its stretches of banality and mitigate some of its flaws. Among these are a superficial sense of history -- remember how girls used to wear their hair? remember nuclear disarmament? -- and, more seriously, a late, disastrous dive into the deep end of weepitude.'' 7:45 P.M. (Bravo) THE SILENCE OF THE LAMBS (1991) Just in time for dinner -- fava beans and a nice Chianti, perhaps? -- the network offers back-to-back screenings of this Jonathan Demme thriller about Clarice Starling (Jodie Foster), an F.B.I. trainee who enlists the help of Hannibal Lecter (Anthony Hopkins, above), a sociopath with a taste for human flesh, in tracking a serial killer. The film won Oscars for best actor, best actress, best screenplay based on previously published material, best director and best picture.

Having developed the brand of its Audience Network around shows like ''Damages'' and ''Friday Night Lights,'' which it has shared with or inherited from other broadcasters, the satellite television provider DirecTV said on Thursday that it had ordered its first original scripted series, one that rests on the slender shoulders of the actress Thandie Newton. Ms. Newton, who has appeared in films including ''Crash,'' ''Beloved'' and ''Mission: Impossible 2,'' will star in the new series, called ''Rogue.'' DirecTV said in a news release that the series would focus on Ms. Newton's character, a ''morally and emotionally conflicted cop'' named Grace, who is wrestling with the possibility that she may have contributed to the death of her son while she conducts an illicit affair with a high-ranking criminal who may have also been involved. ''Rogue'' is planned to start production in August and make its debut on the Audience Network in the summer of 2013.

Alas, the Tea Party movement won't be setting up shop in Zurich anytime soon. Representative Michele Bachmann has asked the Swiss government to withdraw her dual citizenship, saying she's all American.
Fletcher-Sinclair Mansion 2 East 79th Street, Manhattan

JPMorgan Chase, which emerged from the financial crisis as the nation's biggest bank, disclosed on Thursday that it had lost more than $2 billion in trading, a surprising stumble that promises to escalate the debate over whether regulations need to rein in trading by banks. Jamie Dimon, the chief executive of JPMorgan, blamed ''errors, sloppiness and bad judgment'' for the loss, which stemmed from a hedging strategy that backfired.

FITZSIMONS--Genevieve T.,(July 2, 1916 - May 8, 2012) beloved wife of the late Bernard J. Fitzsimons, passed away quietly at her home on Tuesday, May 8, 2012. Beloved Sister, Mother, Grandmother, Great-Grandmother, Aunt, and Friend, Genevieve was the best a person could be. She is survived by her sister, Mary English, by her four sons: Richard (Kathleen), Bernard (Nila), Michael (Mary Ellen) and Dennis (Ann); grandchildren Ryan, Brendan, Sean, Michael, Maureen, Joseph, Matthew, Christine and Jeanne; great-grandchildren Fiona, Conner and Kennedy and many nieces and nephews. Genevieve is predeceased by her beloved granddaughter, Kimberly Anne. She is remembered fondly by all and will be sorely missed. Visitation will take place at Conway Funeral Home, 82-19 Northern Boulevard, Jackson Heights, NY (718 639-3220) on Friday, May 11 from 4:00 PM to 9:00 PM. Mass of Christian Burial will take place at 9:45 AM at St. Joan of Arc Church, 82-00 35th Avenue, Jackson Heights, NY. Interment will take place at Calvary Cemetery for members of the immediate family. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Scholarship Fund at St. Joan of Arc School, 35-27 82nd Street, Jackson Heights, NY 11372.

KINBERG--Rose M. ('Babe') 94, died peacefully at home in NYC, May 8. Beloved wife of the late Jack H., mother of Judy, Ronnie and wife Geri, grandmother of Michelle and Chris, Lee and Rose. Private burial. Donations: Carnegie East House, 1844 2nd Ave, New York, NY 10128, Attn C. Baksh appreciated. Memorial at CEH TBA.

A bond offering by Dewey & LeBoeuf did not disclose the extensive guarantees that it gave to partners, an omission that could subject the law firm to litigation, securities lawyers say. In March 2010, Dewey raised $125 million in a private bond offering, an unusual move by a law firm. The offering document, which was obtained by DealBook, paints a rosy picture of Dewey, even as cracks in the firm's finances were starting to show.

It didn't take long for bank reformers to say we told you so. JPMorgan Chase's $2 billion trading loss, which was disclosed on Thursday, could give supporters of tighter industry regulation a huge new piece of ammunition as they fight a last-ditch battle with the banks over new federal rules that may redefine how banks do business.

SESSLER--Beverly. The congregation of Westchester Reform Temple mourns the death of its devoted member and extends sympathy to her bereaved family. Lisa Messinger, President Jonathan Blake, Rabbi Jill Abramson, Cantor

BARZ--Edward I.,on May 9, 2012, in Newburyport, MA, of esophageal cancer. He was born in Brooklyn on November 20, 1930, and lived in Brooklyn and Montclair, NJ. He was a graduate of Poly Prep and Brown University. He was a retired Lt.Commander in the Navy Reserve and has been vice president and national director of media research at Foote, Con & Belding and executive vice president of Simmons Market Research Bureau. His first wife, Dierdre Merrill, died in 1998. He is survived by his wife, Janet K. Marcus, two daughters, Pamela of Londonderry, NH, and Jennifer Barz-Snell of Salem, MA, a stepson, Adam Marcus, of Boston and six grandchildren. A memorial celebration will be held at a later date. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Dana Farber Cancer Center or the Hospice of the North Shore in Danvers.

NEW RULES The Commodity Futures Trading Commission, led by Gary Gensler, below, unanimously approved a rule that imposes new standards for giant exchanges like the CME Group. The rule, in addition to mandating new risk controls and other safeguards for futures marketplaces, for the first time sets standards for exchanges to offer swaps contracts. But the agency postponed voting on one of the most contentious aspects of the exchange rule and softened other provisions, eliciting criticism from some consumer advocates. BEN PROTESS
