When reports emerged in the first week of April that a JPMorgan Chase trader in London was making bets so big they were distorting a little-known market in credit derivatives, an embedded regulator approached executives. The senior supervisor of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, one of roughly 40 Fed officials who work inside the bank, was told that senior management was not overly concerned about the reports, according to a person briefed on the matter.

Loretta Lynn, one of the top country singers of the late 1960s and early '70s, announced on Thursday night in Nashville that Zooey Deschanel, star of the Fox show ''New Girl,'' will play Ms. Lynn on Broadway in ''Coal Miner's Daughter,'' a musical based on Ms. Lynn's 1976 autobiography and its 1980 film adaptation that detailed her rise from an impoverished childhood in Kentucky to country music legend. The announcement was similar to a 1979 appearance at the Grand Ole Opry, where Ms. Lynn announced that the actress Sissy Spacek would portray her in the film. Ms. Spacek went on to win an Academy Award for her performance in the movie, which also starred Tommy Lee Jones as ''Doo'' Lynn, the man Ms. Lynn married at 13; Beverly D'Angelo as Patsy Cline; and Levon Helm, the former Band member who died last month, as her father.

6:41 p.m. | Updated A Senate Judiciary subcommittee on antitrust issues will be holding hearings on the Universal Music Group's proposed $1.9 billion takeover of EMI's recorded-music division, which puts out work by the Beatles, the Beach Boys, Pink Floyd and many others. The hearings could begin as early as next month, but a spokeswoman for Senator Herb Kohl, the Democrat of Wisconsin who is the chairman of the committee, said late Friday that no date had been set.

Ultra-Orthodox Jews in the New York region have been grappling with how to address child sex abuse in their communities. On Thursday, The New York Times published an article describing how ultra-Orthodox Jews who come forward with claims of abuse often encounter intense intimidation from their neighbors and from rabbinical authorities aimed at pressuring them to drop their cases. On Friday, a second article examined the record of the Brooklyn district attorney, Charles J. Hynes, in prosecuting these cases. Mr. Hynes has adopted a policy of not publicizing accusations of child sex abuse involving the ultra-Orthodox in Brooklyn. Readers responded to these articles in comments on nytimes.com; a selection of them, some edited for length, is below. On Intimidation

Although banks are now required to have customers actively ''opt in'' to receive overdraft coverage of debit card purchases and A.T.M. withdrawals, many consumers are unsure whether they have agreed to such coverage, according to a new report from an arm of the Pew Charitable Trusts. Ninety percent of Americans have a checking account, making it the most widely used financial-services product. But many accountholders are confused about how bank overdraft policies work, the report found.

A critic's notebook article on Friday about the choreography of Marius Petipa and 20th-century revisions of it misspelled the given name of a dance historian who helped stage ''Giselle'' last year for Pacific Northwest Ballet, a version that used three 19th-century sources, including Petipa. She is Marian Smith, not Marion.

Medical costs continue to loom large over retirement, a report from Fidelity Investments says. A 65-year-old couple retiring this year without any employer-based health coverage would need an estimated $240,000 to cover medical costs through retirement, according to Fidelity's latest estimate. That's a 4 percent increase from last year's figure. (The number has increased by 50 percent since 2002, when Fidelity first calculated the cost at $160,000.)

LONDONER--David J.,75 years old, on Friday, May 11, 2012 following a year's encounter with cancer. He is survived by Clara, his wife of 45 years, their sons and daughters-in-law David-Marc and Snezhana, John and Ranakdevi, and his two granddaughters Sasha and Roxanna. The closeness and love of his family were his greatest joy and proudest accomplishments. He was the total New Yorker: Brooklyn-born, Stuyvesant High School, Columbia University and over 40 years on Wall Street. In finance all his professional life, he was a Chartered Financial Analyst and became one of the more highly regarded media and entertainment analysts, mostly with Wertheim & Co. and its successor, Schroders. After retiring, he became a board member of several publicly traded companies in the U.S. and Great Britain. Memorial service Monday, May 14,2012 at 11:45am, "The Riverside", 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions in David's memory may be made to SmarterMedicalCare.org, 185 Bayview Drive, San Rafael, CA 94901, which produces free educational materials for cancer patients and their families.

An art review and a headline on Friday about a fair at the Fletcher-Sinclair Mansion in Manhattan misstated its name. And the error was repeated in an accompanying picture caption. The fair is the AOA Tribal Art Fair (which has art from Africa, Oceania and the Americas), not Tribal Art New York. (A different fair, the NYC Tribal Art Show 2012, is taking place at the Bohemian National Hall, also in Manhattan.)

When will Wall Street stop springing these types of nasty surprises? Every big bank has risk controls. Teams of executives are assigned to manage and review trades to ensure the bank's safety and health.

Days before revelations of JPMorgan Chase's $2 billion trading loss rocked Wall Street, the company's always-confident chief executive, Jamie Dimon, was his usual exuberant self. When the bosses of six of the largest banks gathered at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York in downtown Manhattan to meet with a top Fed governor, the others used the underground garage and avoided the cameras. Mr. Dimon came and went through the front door, and even chatted with a CNBC reporter.

PEARCE--Judith Handler, 87, on May 9, after nine years with breast cancer. A resident of Manhattan and East Hampton, she was the beloved wife of Dr. Eli Pearce for 32 years. Mother of John Herfort (and Didi), the late David Herfort, the late Stephen Herfort, Michael Ruby (and Louisa) and Elizabeth Ruby Lyden (and John). Stepmother of Russell Pearce (and Michele) and Debra Pearce-McCall (and Scott). Grandmother of Karl, Grace and Clara Lyden; Charlotte, Emily and Natalie Ruby; Jamie Herfort; Seth and Jacob Pearce; and Kyle and Alexander Pearce-McCall. Sister of Antonia Handler Chayes. Special friend of Susan Ei. Judith was born in Manhattan, grew up in Woodmere, received a B.A. from Smith College, an M.A. in American History from Columbia and an M.S.W. from Rutgers. In her long career as a social worker, she helped Holocaust survivors, welfare recipients, minority schoolchildren, ex-addicts, foster-care families and the elderly. Funeral at Frank E. Campbell (81st and Madison) at 10am, Sunday, May 13. Interment at Mount Pleasant Cemetery, Hawthorne, N.Y., 10532. Shiva on Sunday after 5pm and Monday after 4pm at 2 Fifth Ave., Apt. 14M. In lieu of flowers, please contribute to the re-election of Barack Obama or the charity of your choice.

A film review on Friday about ''Small, Beautifully Moving Parts'' misidentified the city where the character Sarah lives. While she visits her sister in Los Angeles and travels to Nevada and Arizona, she is from New York, not from Los Angeles.

Britney Spears is likely to be named a judge on Season 2 of ''The X Factor'' on Monday as the show's creator, Simon Cowell, reveals changes to the singing competition. The Associated Press and other news organizations reported this week that Ms. Spears had signed a contract to join the show's panel of judges. The network that telecasts ''The X Factor,'' Fox, declined to comment on Friday.

DILLON--Robert E.,Jr., 80, who retired as Executive Vice President of Sony North America in 1996 and was immersed in community activities for many years, passed away at his Westfield, NJ, home on Wednesday, May 9, 2012. He is survived by his wife of 58 years, Alice Sullivan Dillon, and their seven children, Marion Morris, Brooklin, ME; Dan Dillon, Leesburg, VA; Robert Dillon, III, Livingston, NJ; Andrew Dillon, Blue Hill, ME; Julia Dillon, Westfield; Joan Sloyan, Asheboro, NC; and David Dillon, Brooklin, ME; and 20 grandchildren. Also surviving is his brother James Dillon of Naples, FL. Son of Marion McNulty and Robert Dillon of Buffalo, NY, he graduated from Amherst College in 1953 and the Harvard Business School with an MBA in 1955. After U.S. Army service overseas, he worked for Lake Erie Engineering, Electro Dynamics, Mobil and ADT as a financial executive before joining Sony in 1973, the start of a 23-year career with the electronics and entertainment company. He also served on the UNUM Board of Directors and as a trustee of the College of Mount St. Vincent in New York. Notable as a family man, Roman Catholic and energetic volunteer in health care, the arts, education and community charities, including the Overlook Hospital in Summit, NJ, the Kessler Foundation supporting rehabilitation research and employment programs for people with disabilities, the United Fund of Westfield, the Westfield Foundation, Westfield Senior Citizen Housing, New Jersey Connect in developing affordable housing for physically disabled people, The Visual Arts Center of New Jersey, the United Way of Bergen County, and the Boy Scouts of Bergen County. He was honored with numerous awards recognizing decades of service and leadership. Not simply a parishioner of Holy Trinity Catholic Church of Westfield, he served his church in many volunteer capacities, including as a trustee. He was inducted into the Knights of Malta in 1994. The Dillons also maintain a home in Cape Elizabeth, ME. A funeral mass will be celebrated at The Catholic Church of the Holy Trinity, Westfield, NJ at 10am on Tuesday, May 15th. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that memorial donations be made to The Westfield Foundation (PO Box 2295, Westfield, NJ 07091), or to the charity of your choice.

Preseason expectations have a way of not panning out. Baseball pundits, for instance, expected the Yankees to be in the mix in the American League East and the crosstown Mets to be firmly in last place. Five weeks into season, only one of those predictions has come true. The Yankees are in the mix, 2.5 games behind the Rays and the surprising Orioles entering Friday's games, despite shaky starting pitching. The Mets are far from last: they were five games above .500, despite a far weaker lineup and a raft of injuries.

FELDMAN--Claire. May 12, 1922 - November 3, 1996 Dear Claire, despite the many years that you have been gone, the special memories have made living bearable. As my best friend, mentor with qualities of sensitivity and ethics; you will be forever cherished and missed. Love, Miriam

ING Direct - the online bank that is now officially part of Capital One - is offering mobile check deposit, joining a growing list of banks offering the service. You might think that a bank without any branches would be first to offer so-called remote deposit capture, which allows someone to deposit a paper check in an account by snapping a photo with a phone and uploading it electronically. But ING is behind some brick-and-mortar banks, including Chase and Citibank, in offering the service.
Because of an editing error, a recipe on Page 51 this weekend with the Eat column erroneously includes an ingredient among those needed to make a cosmopolitan. No soda should be used.

SERO CUADRAT--Felisa. February 11, 1921-May 8, 2012. Beloved mother and grandmother. The Minoves-Triquell family in Andorra thanks friends and family in the United States/Canada for their kind words of comfort.

The role of the hilarious gorgon Lady Bracknell in Oscar Wilde's ''Importance of Being Earnest'' is sometimes played by a man (Brian Bedford was nominated for a Tony award a year ago for doing just that). But there are already plenty of changes afoot in David Hyde Pierce's gangster-laden, Prohibition-era interpretation of the comedy, slated for the Williamstown Theater Festival this summer. So in this case the Lady will be a lady: Tyne Daly (''Master Class,'' ''Gypsy'') will do the honors, the festival is scheduled to announce on Friday as part of a flurry of casting news. Brandon Victor Dixon (''The Scottsboro Boys''), Lili Taylor (''Landscape of the Body'') and Finn Wittrock (now on Broadway in ''Death of a Salesman'') are among the actors who have recently signed on for the festival's 58th season.

PESSAR--Patricia R, of Woodbridge, CT, died May 10, 2012 in New Haven, CT. Beloved wife of Gilbert M. Joseph, loving mother of Matthew Eric Pessar Joseph, dearest sister of Linda Pessar Cowan. Professor of American Studies and Anthropology at Yale University. Memorial contributions may be made to The New Haven - Leon Sister City Project, 608 Whitney Ave., New Haven, CT. 06511. To sign a memorial book please visit: www.wellerfuneralhome.com.

TRUONG--Tran Dinh, Vietnamese Businessman and Philanthropist. Tran Dinh Truong was born on January 5, 1932 in Ky-Anh, a town on the north central coast of Vietnam. At the end of 1958, knowing he had to seek a better life for himself, penniless, Mr. Tran fled the north by swimming across the Ben-Hai River, which was the demarcation line between the northern and southern part of the country by the Geneva Accords in 1954. Upon arriving in the south, he was immediately captured and placed in a prison camp for fugitives and deserters by the Army of the Republic of Vietnam. While there, Mr. Tran stood out and caught the attention of a visiting priest who was in need of a driver and asked if Tran could drive. As it turned out, Father Khai was a special personal priest to the President, Ngo Dinh Diem and the rest is history. Mr. Tran was a devout Catholic with strong entrepreneurial spirits and a keen business sense; after working two years as a driver for Father Khai and winning over his admiration and respect, Mr. Tran sought a loan from his mentor and began buying and selling army supplies and uniforms. During this time he also met and married Nguyen Kim Sang, a recently crowned Miss Saigon and together they worked and built up a successful business which led them to Hiroshima, Japan in 1967 to buy their first cargo ship the Soe-Maru which later Tran changed the name to Sao Mai. By the early 1970s, their company Vishipco Lines was the largest shipping company in South Vietnam with a fleet of 24 ships. It was in April of 1975 when Mr. Tran fled his home once again during the last days of the fall of Saigon. Mr. Tran and his family were relocated and welcomed along with some other 150,000 Vietnamese refugees into the United States at Fort Chaffee, Arkansas. For the second time in his life he was seeking a better way of living and when the family arrived in Times Square in their beat-up station wagon, Tran looked around and declared that, "This is America!" Poor English did not stop him and soon Mr. Tran found a suitable life in real estate with his purchase of the Hotel Opera on West 76th Street bought with the gold the family was carrying on their backs. Tran loved New York City and when the opportunity arose to purchase a second building located in Times Square in 1977, he jumped right on it against his lawyers' wishes. "The Great White Way" became his place of residence as he struggled through the tumultuous years in Times Square before it became the Crossroads of the World. From then on he began to build his real estate portfolio with historical buildings in New York City, Buffalo, New York and the Philadelphia area. Mr. Tran may be remembered and honored most for ordering one of his ships, the Truong Xuan, to carry over 3000 Vietnamese refugees out of Saigon on April 30, 1975. Those refugees eventually reached Hong Kong safely and have made their lives all over the world. In 1984, Tran's answer to the poverty and famine he was witnessing out of Ethiopia was to donate two helicopters for the use of relief and transport of food and medicine to the villages. He also sent heavy construction equipment and trucks to his hometown in Vietnam for road repairs and made yearly contributions to churches and congregations in Vietnam, and all across the United States where large populations of Vietnamese Catholics worship. Mr. Tran also generously donated $2 million dollars of his personal funds to the American Red Cross Disaster Relief Fund after the September 11 attacks on the World Trade Center. It was a repayment to show his patriotism to the country that had rescued him and his family. Tran never forgot his humble beginnings both in his birth country and in the country that adopted him and his family. Tran Dinh Truong passed away on May 6, 2012 in his beloved Times Square home. He had suffered a stroke in late 2008 and never fully recovered. For the third and final time in his life, Tran has fled to a better place. He is a great loss to the Vietnamese community worldwide; as for his children, they will always miss the way their father used to sign off on his writings to them while they were away at school - his favorite song by Billy Joel, " I love you 'Just The Way You Are.' " He is survived by his wife of 52 years, Nguyen Kim Sang, and their four children, Teresa Yokoi of Westport, Connecticut and her husband Katsuhiko; Monica Tran of New York City and her husband Paul Carden; Joseph Tran of Dallas, Texas and his wife June Von Hoven; Victoria Tran of New York City and her fiance Brian McConville; his grandchildren Jessica, Jacob, Noah, Luc and Emmi. Family will receive friends on Saturday and Sunday 1-5pm at Frank E. Campbell 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. Mass of Christian Burial Monday 10am Holy Cross R.C. Church, 329 West 42nd St.

KATZENBACH--Nicholas. The Bard College Board of Trustees mourns the passing of Nicholas Katzenbach, honorary doctor of laws, class of 2000, a man of great intellect, honor, and compassion, and husband of long-time Bard trustee Lydia Katzenbach. We send our deepest condolences to Lydia, his children, Christopher, John '72, Mimi, and Anne deBelleville Katzenbach '83, and his six grandchildren, including Wolcott '08 and Phoebe '09. David E. Schwab II, Chair Emeritus Charles P. Stevenson Jr., Chair Leon Botstein, President

Financial pressures may force New York City Ballet to reduce its Saratoga season to one week instead of two, which would be the second downsizing in five years, officials said on Thursday. The company has been taking up residence in Saratoga for part of the summer for more than four decades. Its host, the Saratoga Performing Arts Center, said it can no longer afford the company's fee, which has been rising and will exceed $1.8 million next summer. Even with the fee, City Ballet loses $600,000 to $800,000 a season, said its executive director, Katherine E. Brown.

8 P.M. (HBO) HARRY POTTER AND THE DEATHLY HALLOWS: PART 2 (2011) Childhood ends with tears, howls and smoke for Harry (Daniel Radcliffe), Ron (Rupert Grint) and Hermione (Emma Watson, above with, from left, Mr. Grint and Mr. Radcliffe) in the series's final installment, which follows the threesome, now adult wizards, in their final showdown with he who shall not be named -- but who has been for a while -- Lord Voldemort (Ralph Fiennes). Writing in The New York Times, Manohla Dargis said that Mr. Fiennes and a certain albino dragon make the movie soar, as do Michael Gambon's brief turn as Dumbledore and Maggie Smith's ''visibly delighted marshaling of an army of stone soldiers'' as McGonagall. Finally too, Ms. Dargis said, there is Alan Rickman, ''who as Snape, Harry's longtime nemesis, lifts the movie to its expressive high point.'' That Snape ''has become such a brilliant screen character is due to Mr. Rickman, who helped elevate a child's tale of good and evil into a story of human struggle,'' she added. Part 1 leads in at 5:30. 10:30 A.M. (13) RELIGION & ETHICS NEWSWEEKLY Lucky Severson interviews Mark I. Pinsky, the author of ''Amazing Gifts: Stories of Faith, Disability and Inclusion,'' about integrating the severely handicapped into congregations.

An article on Monday about the online music distribution company TuneCore misstated the fees associated with TuneCore's music publishing service, which registers songwriters' work around the world and recovers any royalties owed. The company charges songwriters a $50 one-time fee plus 10 percent of all recovered royalties; it does not charge an annual fee.

An article last Saturday about an announcement by the Roman Catholic archbishop of Philadelphia that five priests under investigation for sexual abuse would be removed from the ministry included several errors. The priests' removal did not mean they were ''defrocked;'' they are still priests. (The error also appeared in the headline.) Three other priests who were exonerated will return to their parishes at some point, but not ''immediately.'' And while it is indeed the case that priests found unsuitable for ministry are ''not allowed to wear a collar,'' the archbishop, Charles J. Chaput, did not address that issue during a news conference.
The ArcelorMittal Orbit, a 375-foot tower designed by Anish Kapoor and Cecil Balmond for the Olympic Park in London, was officially unveiled on Friday.

HIRSCHHORN--Fred, Jr. The Board of Directors and employees of Fiduciary Trust Company International mourn the loss of Fred Hirschhorn, Jr. Fred's contribution to our organization spans over two decades. He served on Fiduciary Trust's Board of Directors until 1991, and then as an Honorary Director until 1992. During that time, he also served as Chairman of our Board's Audit Committee and as a member of the Directors' Executive Committee. Fred's influence on Fiduciary Trust is immeasurable: his financial expertise, integrity and perspective were respected and admired. The entire firm benefited from Fred's dedication and wise counsel. Our thoughts and prayers are with his family, including his wife, Joan, and his daughters, Elizabeth H. Wilson, Joan H. Bright and Eleanor Hirsch- horn who herself currently serves on Fiduciary Trust's Board of Directors with the same distinction and dedication that her father did.

An article on Friday about an escalation in the quarrel between China and the Philippines over an island in the South China Sea misstated, in some editions, the day on which anti-Chinese rallies were planned in the Philippines. They were held on Friday; they were not scheduled for today.

Motherhood, apple pie - and political attacks. With Mother's Day approaching on Sunday, a ''super PAC'' backing Mitt Romney's presidential campaign has decided to revive the criticism that a Democratic strategist leveled against Mr. Romney's wife last month.

The longtime president and chief executive of the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and Museum announced on Friday that he will retire at the end of 2013, and the museum's board of trustees has begun a search for a successor. The official, Terry Stewart, 66, has been in charge of the Cleveland institution since 1999. In recent years he has overseen a $35 million capital plan, which included an overhaul of the museum and the construction of a new library and archives about two miles away. He was also instrumental in bringing the annual induction ceremony back to Cleveland every three years and has been credited with tightening the museum's ties with the city and its residents.

A theater review in some editions on Friday about ''Up to You,'' a production for young people at Tada! Theater in Manhattan, using information from the program, misspelled the surname of the actress who plays Wendy. She is Alex Getlin, not Gettlin.

Suddenly, there it is. Everywhere. Almost overnight, it seems, 1 World Trade Center has inserted itself into the skyline, visible from places where the sky had seemed more empty than open since 2001. Its advent has inverted the ''phantom limb'' phenomenon; that period following the Sept. 11 attacks when the image of the World Trade Center's twin towers persisted. ''You feel it, but it's not there; you look to where you feel it should be,'' Ric Burns, a documentary filmmaker, said at the time.
An article on Friday about several music festivals in New York misstated the size of the budget of the River to River Festival. It is $2 million, not $5 million.

A Pop entry in the Week Ahead column on Page 6 this weekend includes outdated information about one of the headliners scheduled to perform at the Bamboozle Festival in Asbury Park, N.J., next Saturday. After the section had gone to press, My Chemical Romance replaced Blink-182, whose drummer, Travis Barker, had an emergency tonsillectomy.

RUZIKA--Richard M.,53, of Greenwich, CT passed away on Monday, May 7, 2012 at a Stamford hospital following a stroke on April 22, three days after surgery on his left knee. Rich was born on April 16, 1959 in Brooklyn, New York, the son of Frank and Miriam and brother to Keith and Frank, who predeceased him. He studied at West Hempstead High School and Columbia University, where he graduated in 1981 with a bachelor's degree in economics. Following college, Rich signed with the Dallas Cowboys of the National Football League for a brief period. In 1982, Rich joined Goldman Sachs in New York and went on to serve the firm with distinction for nearly three decades. He began his career as a silver and gold trader on the floor of COMEX, moving to the floor of NYMEX in 1984 as one of the original people in the firm's energy platform. He was a member of the board of NYMEX for nine years. Rich moved to the firm's trading floor in 1990, becoming head of Natural Gas Trading in 1996 and in 1998, he relocated to Baltimore as one of the founding members of Goldman Sachs' electricity business. Rich was named head of Commodities in 2000 where he developed the firm's AssetCo business and was later appointed co-head of Global Macro Trading and then co-head of the Global Special Situations Group. He was named a managing director in 1996 and a partner in 1998. Rich retired from Goldman Sachs in April 2011 as head of the Global Special Situations Group and a member of the Management Committee, the Securities Division Executive Committee and the Firmwide Risk Committee. Following his retirement from Goldman Sachs, Rich was planning to start a hedge fund with his longtime friend Joe Howley and former Goldman Sachs partner Lance Bakrow. In 1983, Rich married Ruthanne (nee Millnamow), daughter of James and Marion, who survives him, along with their children Craig, 18, and Caitlin, 17. Their marriage of almost 30 years, was built upon a friendship that started when they were youngsters, grew as they began dating in their teens and only deepened over the years. Their relationship was based upon mutual respect and a shared sense of family. Most of all, it was filled with passion and joy. Those who know Rich also know that beyond his professional success, he was most proud of his role as devoted husband and father.

Eduardo Saverin, one of the founders of Facebook, officially defriended the United States in September, giving up his American citizenship for the more tax-friendly residency status of Singapore. Mr. Saverin, who was born in Brazil and has lived in Singapore since 2010, plans to remain in the Asian island nation indefinitely. Singapore has a maximum personal income tax rate of 20 percent and no taxes on capital gains. He gained American citizenship in 1998.

Mitt Romney's commencement address Saturday at Liberty University, the evangelical institution in Virginia founded by Jerry Falwell, comes on the heels of President's Obama's announcement Wednesday that he supports same-sex marriage. But in a conference call with reporters Friday, Romney campaign aides said the candidate was focused on giving an address for graduates and their parents, ''not a policy speech,'' and that Mr. Romney would not overtly wade into the issue of same-sex marriage.

CHAMBERLAIN--William Ellsworth passed away Saturday, May 5 in Palo Alto, California at the age of 91. Known as "Bill," he was born August 16, 1920 in Providence, Rhode Island to William Chamberlain, Sr. and Kathryne Walsh. Bill had resided with his family in Palo Alto for the last forty years. After losing his mother at the age of three, Bill and his older sister Bernadette were raised by their maternal aunt, Julia Walsh, and their paternal grandparents, Catherine and Frank Chamberlain, who later moved them to Hartford, Connecticut. Bill graduated from Bulkeley High School in Hartford in 1938 and worked at Pratt & Whitney before enlisting in the Army in 1943. During World War II, he trained and served as a B-29 navigator in the U.S. Army Air Corps stationed at Harvard Air Force Base in Nebraska. After the war ended, he attended Brown University on the GI Bill, graduating in 1949 with a B.S. in Electrical Engineering. Bill went to work for the Electric Boat Division of General Dynamics in its nuclear submarine program, where he worked with USN Admiral Hyman Rickover in the development and construction of the USS Nautilus, the world's first nuclear-powered submarine. As part of the submarine program at EBD, Bill also did post-graduate work at Yale and MIT. His experience with nuclear power took him from General Dynamics to the Atomics Division of AMF Corporation in New York City. At the time AMF Atomics was involved in the U.S. Government's "Atoms for Peace" program that supplied nuclear equipment and information to schools, hospitals and research institutions within the U.S. and throughout the world. It was in 1957 that he met Bernadette Mitchel in New York City, and they were married the following spring. Bernadette's family was from San Francisco and Teaneck, New Jersey. Their early years were spent in New York City, where their children Claire and John were born. In 1963 Bill moved from AMF to the Utah Construction & Mining Company in San Francisco, where as Vice President he oversaw several projects including the construction of the BART trans-bay tube and the San Luis Rey Reservoir. Bill and Bernadette lived in San Francisco and welcomed a third child, Paul, later that year. It was in 1968 when Bill chose to leave the corporate world and begin his own venture in real estate development. He founded Transcentury Properties and developed sites in Northern California, the most noteworthy being the construction of Bodega Harbour, a community located along the Pacific Coast just south of Bodega Bay. In 1972 he and his family moved to Palo Alto. Bill remained active at Transcentury through 1980, and he continued his interest in real estate investing and development until his death. His wife Bernadette sadly preceded him in death in 1992. In 2005 after a long courtship, Bill married Claire Carew, formerly of San Francisco, and later adopted her children, Rodrigo and Maria. Throughout his remarkable life, Bill was an exceptional father and grandfather, a terrific listener who provided the rare combination of endless encouragement tempered by wise counsel, a wonderfully kind man with a twinkle in his eye and a light, yet ever present sense of humor. He was an avid reader of history, a keen fan of the World Series, and a man with an enormous interest in the well-being of others. He was immensely proud of his children and grandchildren, always encouraging them to pursue their interests with passion and to strive for excellence, all the while leading by example. He never stopped "growing young." Bill was so much for so long and to so many, yet above all else was known as the truest of gentlemen. Bill is survived by his wife Claire, his five children Claire, John, Paul, Rodrigo and Maria Chamberlain, his daughters-in-law Rebecca Schwartz Chamberlain and Martha Witbeck Chamberlain, and his ten grandchildren Carl, William and Jack Eckert; Laura, Sarah and Kathryne Chamberlain; and Eliza, William, Maggie and Grace Chamberlain. No words adequately express how much we will miss his voice and smile, yet no amount of time shall steal them from us. He is beloved in so many ways. Family and friends are invited to share in a celebration of Bill's life at St. Albert the Great Church in Palo Alto, California on August 18, 2012. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests that contributions honoring Bill's memory may be made to: Stanford Cardiovascular Institute, 2700 Sand Hill Road, Menlo Park, CA 94025.

Because of an editing error, an obituary last Sunday about the violinist Zvi Zeitlin referred imprecisely to Dubrovna, the village where he was born. While it was in Soviet territory when Mr. Zeitlin was born, in February 1922, it was not ''in the Soviet Union,'' which was not established until December of that year.

An August film listing in last Sunday's special Summer Movies section misstated Sylvester Stallone's role in ''The Expendables 2.'' Mr. Stallone stars in the action movie and helped write it, but he did not direct it.

John and Helen Taylor, the Australian hypermilers who made news in the United States in 2009 by averaging 67.9 miles per gallon in a tour of the 48 contiguous states, recently added another record to their considerable tally. The couple drove 1,626.1 miles in a 2012 Volkswagen Passat TDI SE from Houston to Sterling, Va., breaking the Guinness record for the longest drive in a passenger car on a single tank of diesel fuel. They departed May 3 and passed through nine states, averaging 84.1 miles per gallon during the excursion, and finished on May 5. By Wednesday the Taylors were on a plane, en route to their home in Australia.

A review last Sunday about the 2012 Ford Focus Electric erroneously attributed a distinction to the car. While it is the first all-electric production car from a Detroit automaker in the 21st century, it is not the first from an American company. (The Tesla Roadster was the first.)

GELLER--Bertram, born June 18, 1918. Survived by his wife Lois of 64 years and by his son Sam, daughter Janet, grandchildren Grace and Emily, and daughter in law, Donna. He died peacefully on May 10 in his New York apartment. Bert Geller was successful in his business as a furrier and was successful in his avocation of art. Bert was in the fur business, the Geller Brothers, with his beloved brother Marty Geller who pre-deceased him. After retiring, he took up painting and decorated his home in Florida with his art work, as well as the homes of his family. Painting was a great joy in his life and is a talent he passed on to his granddaughter, Emily. Bert was also a life- long athlete, and played handball, tennis and golf. Bert continued to play golf and bridge up until a few weeks before his death. Bert was devoted to his wife, his children and grandchildren, but particularly to his daughter Janet who has cerebral palsy. Janet continues to have a wonderful life provided by the Crystal Run Village Foundation of Middletown, New York. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that memorials be made to Crystal Run. A private burial service was held at Mt Hebron cemetery on Friday, May 11th.

An article on April 15 about the writer Robert Caro and his multivolume biography of President Lyndon B. Johnson described incorrectly how Caro first found out about an account that Luis Salas, a Texas election official at the time, gave about Johnson's disputed victory in the Senate election in 1948. Caro talked to Salas about an interview Salas had given James Mangan of The Associated Press in 1977 in which he said that Johnson ''did not win that election. It was stolen for him.'' And Caro drew on a handwritten memoir Salas gave him, in which he also described the cheating. Caro did not first learn of Salas's account when he ''uncovered'' the memoir. (In his book ''Means of Ascent,'' Caro credited Salas's interview with The A.P. and wrote about Salas's views in detail.)

The landmark decision that outlawed segregation, Brown v. Board of Education, was handed down 58 years ago this week. In its wake, school systems undertook desegregation efforts that peaked in the 1980s. Since then, schools across the country have been going through a process of de facto resegregation. In New York, efforts over the years to reduce the segregation of schools have had little effect. FORD FESSENDEN

Everyone has an ''if only I could go back and tell my younger self'' moment. Some would undo regrettable career, romance, even fashion choices. I would teach my younger self how to make a decent drink. My first ''job'' in journalism was during graduate school, as an intern at a prominent magazine in New York. It was the early 1990s, and in a world before blogs, iPad mags and on-demand publishing, magazines were print-only and powerful. I loved being a part of it.

MARY CHASE was wise about the comforting appeal that a divorce from reality offers. Her play ''HARVEY,'' about a man and his tall, invisible rabbit friend, won a Pulitzer Prize in 1944 and ran in its original Broadway production for more than four years. Now Roundabout Theater Company is reviving Chase's comedy in the first Broadway production of the 2012-13 season. When a show opens amid the feverish fuss about Tony Awards for the prior season, as ''Harvey'' is doing, its performances are often forgotten a year later. But the Roundabout has assembled a cast as likely to be memorable as any, led by Jim Parsons, the two-time Emmy Award winner for his portrayal of Sheldon Cooper, the charming nerd of a theoretical physicist on the CBS comedy ''The Big Bang Theory.'' He plays the rabbit-friendly Elwood P. Dowd, a role memorably played by James Stewart in the 1950 film version and the 1970 Broadway revival. Scott Ellis directs a cast that also includes Jessica Hecht, Charles Kimbrough, Larry Bryggman and Carol Kane. Previews begin Friday at Studio 54, 254 West 54th Street, Manhattan, (212) 719-1300, roundabouttheatre.org; $37 to $127.

DOES it say something about the state of the American musical theater that the animating incident in the most accomplished new Broadway show of the season is the repairing of a vacuum cleaner? It almost makes you nostalgic for those dark days when the talk of the Rialto was the spectacle of a chandelier plummeting toward the stage, or a helicopter landing on it. The fixing of the Hoover occurs in the first act of the musical ''Once,'' which transferred from New York Theater Workshop to Broadway this spring and racked up 11 Tony nominations, the biggest haul of any show this season. The musical depicts the hesitant blooming of love between a Dublin street singer who works in his father's vacuum-repair shop and a Czech immigrant who befriends him and encourages him to chase his dreams of becoming a guitar hero.

KATZENBACH--Nicholas deB. A Vera Institute of Justice trustee from 1969 to 1983 and subsequently honorary trustee until his death, Mr. Katzenbach was best known to the public for personally facing down the Alabama governor in the fight for desegregation. His lifelong bravery and commitment to equal rights were demonstrated less publicly when he helped plan and became the first board chair of the Brooklyn-based Addiction Research and Treatment Corporation, which Vera helped create in 1969. The Vera Institute was honored to have Mr. Katzenbach deliver its first Justice Address in 2007 and joins the larger social-justice community in mourning his death.

As an obstetrician for high-risk pregnancies who has cared for women with substance-abuse problems, I found the story of Amanda Kimbrough all too familiar. On a practical level, criminalizing any aspect of women's behavior during pregnancy has the exact opposite effect of what is intended: it alienates the very women who are most likely to benefit from prenatal care. Instead of protecting fetuses, this practice demonizes their mothers and sends them into hiding. Frequently this results in increased, rather than decreased, drug use. Which leads me to wonder if the purpose of these laws is really to protect fetuses. HYTHAM M. IMSEIS, M.D.,Charlotte, N.C.

THE artist MARK DION is part archaeologist, part hoarder, part historian, and he is bringing his angle of vision to the Explorers Club in Manhattan, calling attention to the 1908-9 scientific expedition to northern China led by Sterling Clark. He founded the Sterling and Francine Clark Art Institute in Williamstown, Mass., which commissioned the installation ''Phantoms of the Clark Expedition.'' It focuses on the history of exploration and Clark's investigation of China. Through Aug. 3, 46 East 70th Street, clarkart.edu; free. Industrial films don't get a lot of love or respect. Even so, the documentary filmmaker CAROLINE MARTEL is exploring the genre in an exhibition that opens Thursday at the Museum of the Moving Image. ''Industry/Cinema: An Installation by Caroline Martel'' juxtaposes industrial images with those from important films made between 1903 and 1991. Visitors can listen to the soundtrack of a Truffaut film one minute, an AT&T promotional film the next. Through Aug. 12, 36th Avenue at 37th Street, Astoria, Queens,(718) 777-6888,movingimage.us; free with museum admission.

A Pop entry in the Week Ahead column on Page 6 this weekend includes outdated information about one of the headliners scheduled to perform at the Bamboozle Festival in Asbury Park, N.J., this coming Saturday. After the section had gone to press, My Chemical Romance replaced Blink-182, whose drummer, Travis Barker, had an emergency tonsillectomy.

KEYNAN--Professor Alex. We mourn the passing of Professor Alex Keynan, our dear friend and colleague of many years. Alex was a renowned microbiologist, an emeritus professor at the Hebrew University, a pioneer in the development of basic scientific research in Israel and a seminal figure in the development of Israel's policy on science. Among his many accomplishments were the establishment of the Israel Science Foundation, the Batsheva de Rothschild Foundation and the American Foundation for Basic Research in Israel. American Foundation for Basic Research in Israel

DOBBS--Ernest, 71, formerly of New York City and Alabama, on April 13 in Hawaii where he made his home. Survived by Daniel Char and many friends. He was founder and Executive Director of AIDS Project Hawaii.

Michael Aubrey was home in Shreveport, La., last Tuesday night, studying for final exams, when his brother-in-law - a fan of the Texas Rangers - told him in a text message that Josh Hamilton had just hit his third home run. ''I know a guy who did four,'' the message said. It was referring to Aubrey, who took a study break and watched Hamilton match his own greatest feat. Last May 14, while playing for the Washington Nationals' Class AAA affiliate in Syracuse, Aubrey hit four home runs against the Durham Bulls. He was the last player in organized baseball to hit four home runs in a game before Hamilton erupted in Baltimore.

SLATER--Annelore (Anne). April 14, 1918 - May 5, 2012. Devoted wife and partner to late internationalist Joseph E. Slater, long-term President of the Aspen Institute. An advocate for social justice and the arts, Anne was opinionated but open-minded. Her gregariousness and sense of humor made her the friend of many and the life of every gathering. She outlived the Depression, Holocaust, Cold War and daily side of bacon. Mother of Bonnie (late) and Sandra, four grandchildren (plus countless others who called her grandma) and three great-grandchildren, all who carry on her fight for social justice and curiosity. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to scholarship fund at 1001 Emerson St., Palo Alto, CA 94301.

LEE--Kie-Hong Daniel, passed away on April 29, 2012, in Seoul, Korea. Born on April 13, 1922, Kie-Hong Lee studied at Hiroshima Imperial Normal College, Seoul National University, Amherst College, Princeton University and Columbia University. A prominent economist, Kie-Hong Lee was the primary architect of Korea's first 5-year economic plan after the Korean War, laying the path for Korea to grow from a stagnant, tradition-oriented, agricultural society into a modern, dynamic, economic powerhouse. Among his many contributions to Korea's development, the reforestation of the peninsula following its devastation from Japanese occupation, World War II, and the Korean War is probably the most beautiful and lasting. Mr. Lee was the first Korean citizen to work as part of the professional staff at the United Nations, ECAFE, beginning in 1958. On May 16, 1961, when a coup d'etat in South Korea deposed the popularly elected government in South Korea, Mr. Lee was in Washington, D.C. to discuss Korea's economic development plans with Walt W. Rostow, Deputy Special Assistant to the President for National Security Affairs, and McGeorge Bundy, National Security Advisor. Mr. Lee declined an offer of refuge from the US government, and returned to the post-coup Korea to continue his work as an economist with the new government, quickly rising to the position of Assistant Minister, Economic Planning Board. Over the course of his long career, Mr. Lee worked as an economist at The World Bank, Managing Director of Korea-US Economic Council, Managing Director of Korea Trade Association, and publisher of Business Korea and Korea Business World magazines. A strong advocate of advanced education for women, Mr. Lee was a former president of the Amherst College Alumni Association in Korea. He was also president of the Seoul Rotary Club. In 1989 he became one of the founding members of the Committee of 300 Free Thinkers, an outspoken group of former Korean government ministers and influential leaders in fields of economics, education, law, finance and industry dedicated to maintaining the development of the Republic by publishing loyal critiques of unwise government policies, while espousing values of truth, intellectual freedom, market economics, and integrity in leadership. Mr. Lee is survived by his wife Young-Ja, four children, Margaret, Thai, Celeste, and Changsuk, sons-in-law Al Njoo and Kevin C. McCann, daughter-in-law Young Wook Kang, and grandchildren Albert Njoo, Andrew Njoo, Daniel Njoo, Victor Leo, Hanah Lee, Noel McCann, Saymin Lee, Minjoon Lee, and Andy Whang.

BRODY--Arthur. Entrepreneur, businessman, philanthropist. A resident of Rancho Santa Fe, passed away Thursday morning, May 10th following a brief illness. He was a month shy of his 92nd birthday and was a vital presence in the business and philanthropic life of the San Diego community. Arthur was born in Newark, New Jersey, the son of pharmacy owners who had a small lending library in their store and who instilled in him a life-long passion for the written word. He studied electrical engineering at Columbia University and New York Technical Institute and it was during his college years that his talent for entrepreneurial enterprise emerged. Wanting to provide waterproof protection for textbooks, Arthur developed a way to turn clear photographic film into a protective cover; by the time he left school he had eight employees turning out his invention. From 1943-46, Arthur served as a commissioned officer in the Signal Corp of the United States Army. He taught the Theory of Frequency Modulation at the Army signal school in Fort Monmouth, New Jersey and also served in the European theater of operations. Following his army service, Arthur returned to his pursuit of business, founding the Brodart Company which grew to be the major manufacturer and distributor of library and school supplies and equipment in the country. He was granted a number of patents for library and office products and systems and his expertise in all things relating to educational and library tools made him a sought after member of boards and commissions of library organizations, including the Center of the Book at the Library of Congress. During this time Arthur and his wife, Sophie, were active with civic and philanthropic organizations and he became a member of the Young Presidents Organization, serving as the Chairman of the New Jersey Chapter in 1962 and 1963. He was one of eight founding members of the World Presidents Organization. Arthur became a private pilot and an avid yachtsman. Over the years he owned many boats and he loved to be out on the water cruising the inland waterways of the East coast from Maine to the Bahamas and, later, the southern California coast. In 1982 the Brodys relocated to Rancho Santa Fe. Arthur continued with numerous business pursuits even as he greatly expanded his involvement in civic and philanthropic organizations. He served on the boards of the San Diego Public Library, the Sanford-Burnham Institute, the UCSD Foundation, Rady School of Management, the San Diego Symphony, and Seacrest Retirement Village. He was the founding President of the UCSD Library Board and also served as President of the Jewish Community Foundation. One of his proudest involvements was helping to establish the Student Foundation at UCSD and he often followed the students' leads in selecting promising investments. It was as the President of the Sophie and Arthur Brody Foundation that Arthur addressed issues that were most important to him. His generosity was boundless, he had a huge heart, and he contributed generously to local, national and international charities. Aside from the organizations mentioned above, each of which was a major beneficiary of Arthur's largess, the Brody Foundation was a significant donor to Congregation Beth Israel, the Salk Institute for Biological Studies, the Moores Cancer Center, the United Jewish Federation, and the American Joint Distribution Committee. Arthur was an extraordinary man with a great sense of humor and inexhaustible strength. He continued to be interested and engaged in his businesses and philanthropies until his final days. He was a loyal friend and will be missed by the many individuals for whom his presence was so vital. He was predeceased by his beloved wife of 60 years, Sophie. For the last seven years Arthur was blessed by the loving companionship of Phyllis Cohn. He is survived by his daughter Janice Brody (Bruce Rule), his son, Donald Brody (Toby Mickelson), and his five grandsons, Cameron, Pokey, Evan, Harris (Johanna) and Alex (Natalie). Services will be held at 1:00pm on Monday, May 14th at Congregation Beth Israel, 9001 Towne Center Drive, San Diego, 92122. Contributions in celebration of Arthur Brody's life may be made to the Sanford-Burnham Institute, the Jewish Community Foundation, the San Diego Symphony, or the Salk Institute for Biological Studies.

Anna Wintour, top left, the editor of Vogue, has reinvented the fashion world's 64-year-old party of the year, the Metropolitan Museum of Art's Costume Institute benefit. It is now a celebrity gala. But forget the famous. Just look at the clothes of the 800 invitation-only guests. This year's exhibition, the reason for the gala, contrasts two Italian designers, Elsa Schiaparelli of the 1930s, and the realist Miuccia Prada, top right, of the present. But the guests had their own ideas of fashion, shown here, and the leg was the highlight. A few guests wore Schiaparelli and Prada. What Ms. Prada, dressed in a brocade pantsuit, thought of the 19th-century ball gowns with their yard-long trains is a mystery.

WELCH--Joseph F.,77, Chairman of The Bachman Company, passed away on May 5. He is survived by his wife of 50 years, Marcia, and five daughters: Winifred, wife of Sam E. Kinney, Jr.; Lorraine; Suzanne, wife of Scott R. Carpenter; Lucinda; and Elizabeth, wife of Darrell L. Gustafson. He is also survived by nine grandchildren. Welch graduated from Lehigh University and Cornell's Johnson Graduate School of Management.
An article last Sunday about eyelash extensions misidentified the blog for which Tracy Quan writes about pop culture. It is The Daily Beast, not The Huffington Post.

AARON--Stephen Arnold, 76, of Northampton, MA, passed away peacefully on Sunday at his home. Stephen will be remembered for his ardent, ebullient and sensitive nature and his devotion to both his family and friends, who will keenly feel his loss. Survived by his loving wife, Linda; his three stepchildren and his five step-grandchildren. Burial will be private. Donations in Stephen's memory may be made to The Juilliard School, 60 Lincoln Center Plaza, NY, NY 10023-6588 c/o Development and Public Affairs (Drama Division).

Last month, Philip Humber of the Chicago White Sox pitched the 21st perfect game in the major leagues. Last week, Josh Hamilton, the Texas Rangers outfielder, became the 16th major leaguer to hit four home runs in a game. But a case can be made that Humber was actually the 19th to toss a perfect game and Hamilton the 14th to achieve a four-homer game, at least in baseball's modern era.

BORNIA--Dr. Maria. Passed away on May 4th at her home in Chicago. She was 69. At her request, no service will be held. Maria was born in 1942 to Dr. Manuel Bornia and Ligia Vidal de Bornia in Santiago, Dominican Republic. In 1966, she graduated from medical school in Santo Domingo, and then moved to the United States for her medical training. She became one of the first female nephrologists in the country. Dr. Bornia maintained a private practice for 30 years, was awarded the prestigious Apple Award, and held administrative and medical appointments at Christ Hospital, Cornell Medical Center, Meadowlands Hospital, and Palisades Medical Center in New Jersey. She retired in 2008, and moved to Chicago to be with her family. In Chicago, Maria or "Nana," dedicated her time to family. Her beloved grandchildren brought her, in her own words, "the greatest joy of her lifetime." Maria is survived by her daughter, Ligia Mendez Goodwillie, her son-in-law, Patrick Goodwillie, and two grandchildren. She is also survived by her sister, Eunice Bornia, and her brother, Dr. Manuel Bornia. She is predeceased by her husband, Luis Mendez and beloved daughter, Rose Marie Mendez. Maria will be remembered for her love of life, warmth and generosity, and her disarming smile.

Las Vegas has its share of drag shows, but a few cross-dressing entertainers have decided to trade their stilettos for bowling shoes. Drink & Drag (drinkanddrag.com) opened this month downtown, on Fremont Street, offering 12 bowling lanes, 5 pool tables and a gaming room with 12 video game stations, an air-hockey table and darts. Oh, and the staff of the 22,000-square-foot space is made up of drag queens, who twice an hour drop their service duties, climb onto the pool tables and strut down the alleys, performing lip-syncing routines to recorded music.

SILVERBERG--David, died on May 9th at the age of 91 at his home, after a long illness. He enjoyed a rich and fulfilling life with his late wife Elaine Brody Silverberg and will be missed and long remembered by his step daughter, Sue Shapiro; his sister, Dorothy Silverberg; his brother, Benjamin Silverberg; his sister-in-law, Sheila Brody Kamerman; his nieces and nephews; his long-time friend, Marian Green, and his many colleagues at Wakefern/Shop- Rite. David was predeceased by his beloved brother Burt I. Sherman. Funeral services were held on Friday. The period of mourning will be observed at the home of the deceased. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Bar Ilan University in Israel or the Elaine Brody Travel Fellowship at New York Univ.

HIRSCHHORN--Fred Jr. Fred Hirschhorn Jr.,died on Sunday, May 6, 2012. He was 92 years old, born in New York City on May 28, 1919. He was the husband of Joan Morgenthau Hirschhorn and son of Fred Hirschhorn and Hannah deRothschild Scharps Hirschhorn. His father was the Founder and CEO of General Cigar Co. He attended Ethical Culture Fieldston in New York City, and was a graduate of Phillips Exeter and Yale University. Upon graduation, he was commissioned in the Navy and ordered to join the USS Rowan serving in the North Atlantic, African, Sicilian, and Italian invasions, and was a survivor of the sinking of the Rowan. Subsequently, he served on the USS Cushing in the Pacific and was present in Tokyo before the signing of the Armistice. He received an Individual Presidential Citation in 1945. He joined Abraham & Straus in 1946, where he remained until 1960, when he became a Partner at Joseph Walker & Sons. In 1962, he became a venture capitalist founding Frontier Capital of New York and Anchorage Properties Limited. He was a member of Delta Kappa Epsilon, Yale Athletic Association, and Riverside Yacht Club. He was a Director of Fiduciary Trust International. In 1957, he married Joan E. Morgenthau, MD, with whom he had three children, Elizabeth H. Wilson, Joan H. Bright, and Elinor H. Hirschhorn, two sons-in-law, and seven grandchildren. He lived in Old Greenwich, CT until 2007 when he moved to Edgehill Retirement Community in Stamford, CT. Memorial service at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue between 65th and 66th Street, New York, NY will be on Thursday, May 17 at 3:30pm with a reception to follow. Burial will be private. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that contributions be made to Thirteen/WNET, 825 Eighth Avenue, New York, NY 10019.

THERE'S acting, and then there's acting. This season some of the most unforgettable performances on Broadway were not just exercises in trading dialogue or sharing a song. They were true workouts -- emotionally explosive or physically rigorous tests of stamina (sometimes both) delivered eight times a week under some pretty hot lights. In honor of Mark Rylance's standard-setting (and Tony-winning) performance as Rooster Byron in last year's ''Jerusalem'' -- in which he raged, brayed, danced and performed a headstand during its 180 minutes -- we single out this season's energizers and offer a prize of our own. Only some are nominated for Tonys, but win or lose they will always have the Rooster to call their own.

Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation is the main target of a series of investigations into the operations of Britain's newspapers. Separate police inquiries cover, among other things, phone and e-mail hacking, bribery and obstruction of justice. Ofcom, the British broadcast regulator, is looking into the company's stake in a lucrative cable company. A judicial inquiry on media ethics heard testimony last week from Rebekah Brooks and Andy Coulson, two former high-ranking employees, both closely connected to the British prime minister. Here is a guide to the major characters in the drama.
International IN MEXICO, SUSPICIONS

HIRSCHHORN--Fred, Jr. The Board of Directors and employees of Fiduciary Trust Company International mourn the loss of Fred Hirschhorn, Jr. Fred's contribution to our organization spans over two decades. He served on Fiduciary Trust's Board of Directors until 1991, and then as an Honorary Director until 1992. During that time, he also served as Chairman of our Board's Audit Committee and as a member of the Directors' Executive Committee. Fred's influence on Fiduciary Trust is immeasurable: his financial expertise, integrity and perspective were respected and admired. The entire firm benefited from Fred's dedication and wise counsel. Our thoughts and prayers are with his family, including his wife, Joan, and his daughters, Elizabeth H. Wilson, Joan H. Bright and Elinor Hirschhorn who herself currently serves on Fiduciary Trust's Board of Directors with the same distinction and dedication that her father did.

A restaurant review in some editions on April 29 about Kyma Greek Cuisine in Somerville, N.J., whose owner and executive chef is Xristos Stamataros, referred incorrectly to the ownership of a diner on Route 1 in Princeton. Mr. Stamataros's father, Michael Stamataros, is a co-owner of the Princetonian Diner with his brother, Milton Stamataros, and their cousin Michael Petinos; Michael Stamataros is not ''the longtime owner.''

That's the number of times Mike Nichols has won a Tony Award for best director of a play, making him the all-time leader in that category. Mr. Nichols, who is up for a sixth, for his direction of ''Death of a Salesman,'' at this year's ceremony on June 10, won for ''Barefoot in the Park'' (1964), a two-for-one with ''Luv'' and ''The Odd Couple'' (1965), ''Plaza Suite'' (1968), ''The Prisoner of Second Avenue'' (1972) and ''The Real Thing'' (1984).

Mark Attanasio is an investor, and his intuition has served him well in business and as the owner of the Milwaukee Brewers. His asset-management firm is growing, and although his baseball team is not winning - for now - it is stable. The Brewers, who open a two-game series with the Mets at Citi Field on Monday, have started sluggishly after reaching the National League Championship Series last October. Yet last week, Attanasio gave contract extensions to General Manager Doug Melvin and Manager Ron Roenicke. Melvin's new deal runs through 2015, when the club has an option on Roenicke.

If Paul Krugman sees a difference between Ben Bernanke's academic writing and his current posture, maybe that's because Bernanke is no longer an academic, free to lob rhetorical missiles toward policy makers, which happens to be precisely what Krugman is doing. On the other hand, Krugman is right to feel frustrated at the pace of economic recovery and question whether there isn't a way for policy makers to do more. Unfortunately for the country, with just six months before the presidential election, political concerns are now paramount among our nation's leaders, which reduces the likelihood of aggressive Fed action. In a way, the Krugman-vs.-Bernanke debate symbolizes one of the great narratives of President Obama's first term: What happens when bold ideas run smack into the responsibility -- and political considerations -- of actually governing and maintaining public support to continue doing so?

On his first game day as the president of the Los Angeles Dodgers, May 4 in Chicago, Stan Kasten basked in the scenery at Wrigley Field. He might have taken special pride in the flags flapping atop the center-field scoreboard. His new team was on top of the column on the left, representing the National League West, and his two former teams, the Washington Nationals and the Atlanta Braves, led the N.L. pack in the column on the right. The Braves of the 1990s and the Nationals of today were built largely through shrewd scouting and development, which Kasten hopes to nurture again with the controlling partner Mark Walter.

Electric Daisy Carnival focuses on electronic dance music. KATZENBACH--Nicholas deB. The partners of Cravath, Swaine & Moore LLP mourn the passing of their friend, colleague and client, Nicholas deB. Katzenbach. Mr. Katzenbach served as Senior Vice President and General Counsel of IBM during the critical years of IBM's successful defense of one of the most significant antitrust cases ever brought. His extraordinary leadership of that effort followed one of the most distinguished careers in public service, which included serving as the Attorney General of the United States during the height of the Civil Rights movement and as the Under Secretary of State during the Vietnam conflict. Despite his extraordinary accomplishments, Nick was a humble, self-effacing man with a wonderful sense of humor. Our country has lost a great man whose lifelong bravery and commitment to social justice helped shape this country's political history. Our sincere condolences are offered to Nick's wife, Lydia, to his children and grandchildren.

TRAN--Truong Dinh, Vietnamese Businessman and Philanthropist. Tran Dinh Truong was born on January 5, 1932 in Ky-Anh, a town on the north central coast of Vietnam. At the end of 1958, knowing he had to seek a better life for himself, penniless, Mr. Tran fled the north by swimming across the Ben-Hai River, which was the demarcation line between the northern and southern part of the country by the Geneva Accords in 1954. Upon arriving in the south, he was immediately captured and placed in a prison camp for fugitives and deserters by the Army of the Republic of Vietnam. While there, Mr. Tran stood out and caught the attention of a visiting priest who was in need of a driver and asked if Tran could drive. As it turned out, Father Khai was a special personal priest to the President, Ngo Dinh Diem and the rest is history. Mr. Tran was a devout Catholic with strong entrepreneurial spirits and a keen business sense; after working two years as a driver for Father Khai and winning over his admiration and respect, Mr. Tran sought a loan from his mentor and began buying and selling army supplies and uniforms. During this time he also met and married Nguyen Kim Sang, a recently crowned Miss Saigon and together they worked and built up a successful business which led them to Hiroshima, Japan in 1967 to buy their first cargo ship the Soe-Maru which later Tran changed the name to Sao Mai. By the early 1970s, their company Vishipco Lines was the largest shipping company in South Vietnam with a fleet of 24 ships. It was in April of 1975 when Mr. Tran fled his home once again during the last days of the fall of Saigon. Mr. Tran and his family were relocated and welcomed along with some other 150,000 Vietnamese refugees into the United States at Fort Chaffee, Arkansas. For the second time in his life he was seeking a better way of living and when the family arrived in Times Square in their beat-up station wagon, Tran looked around and declared that, "This is America!" Poor English did not stop him and soon Mr. Tran found a suitable life in real estate with his purchase of the Hotel Opera on West 76th Street bought with the gold the family was carrying on their backs. Tran loved New York City and when the opportunity arose to purchase a second building located in Times Square in 1977, he jumped right on it against his lawyers' wishes. "The Great White Way" became his place of residence as he struggled through the tumultuous years in Times Square before it became the Crossroads of the World. From then on he began to build his real estate portfolio with historical buildings in New York City, Buffalo, New York and the Philadelphia area. Mr. Tran may be remembered and honored most for ordering one of his ships, the Truong Xuan, to carry over 3000 Vietnamese refugees out of Saigon on April 30, 1975. Those refugees eventually reached Hong Kong safely and have made their lives all over the world. In 1984, Tran's answer to the poverty and famine he was witnessing out of Ethiopia was to donate two helicopters for the use of relief and transport of food and medicine to the villages. He also sent heavy construction equipment and trucks to his hometown in Vietnam for road repairs and made yearly contributions to churches and congregations in Vietnam, and all across the United States where large populations of Vietnamese Catholics worship. Mr. Tran also generously donated $2 million dollars of his personal funds to the American Red Cross Disaster Relief Fund after the September 11 attacks on the World Trade Center. It was a repayment to show his patriotism to the country that had rescued him and his family. Tran never forgot his humble beginnings both in his birth country and in the country that adopted him and his family. Tran Dinh Truong passed away on May 6, 2012 in his beloved Times Square home. He had suffered a stroke in late 2008 and never fully recovered. For the third and final time in his life, Tran has fled to a better place. He is a great loss to the Vietnamese community worldwide; as for his children, they will always miss the way their father used to sign off on his writings to them while they were away at school - his favorite song by Billy Joel, " I love you 'Just The Way You Are.' " He is survived by his wife of 52 years, Nguyen Kim Sang, and their four children, Teresa Yokoi of Westport, Connecticut and her husband Katsuhiko; Monica Tran of New York City and her husband Paul Carden; Joseph Tran of Dallas, Texas and his wife June Von Hoven; Victoria Tran of New York City and her fiance Brian McConville; his grandchildren Jessica, Jacob, Noah, Luc and Emmi. Family will receive friends on Saturday and Sunday 1-5pm at Frank E. Campbell 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. Mass of Christian Burial Monday 10am Holy Cross R.C. Church, 329 West 42nd St.

No. 3 Phoenix vs. No. 8 Los Angeles The Kings barely made the playoffs, but now they have become the team many thought they would be at the start of the season: an all-around juggernaut. Led by Jonathan Quick, the scuttling, crablike goalie with a .949 save percentage, they needed only nine games to become the first No. 8 seed to knock out the two top seeds. Dustin Brown has six goals and is plus 9 in those games, and also is neck and neck with the Rangers' Ryan Callahan in hits per game. The rest of the forwards include Anze Kopitar (10 points, plus 8), Mike Richards (8, plus 4) and Dustin Penner (7, plus 7). The defense is anchored by the Canadian Olympian Drew Doughty and Willie Mitchell, whose 3.4 blocked shots per game is the top average in the playoffs.

IF anyone has a right to feel on top of the world, it's Howard Stern -- especially inside his elegant, cumulus-high apartment on the West Side of Manhattan, dominated by a solariumlike living room with views on one side extending far up the Hudson and the other encompassing the entire bucolic breadth of Central Park. This is the aerie of a hugely successful man, which certainly describes Mr. Stern. Six years ago he cashed in decades of radio notoriety when he moved to the satellite-radio service Sirius (now Sirius XM) in one of the most lucrative deals in the history of show business, with an estimated worth in the hundreds of millions of dollars.

ONE SPECIAL DAY By Lola M. Schaefer. Illustrated by Jessica Meserve. 40 pp. Disney-Hyperion Books. $16.99. (Picture book; ages 2 to 5) Every mother of two remembers the moment she viewed her firstborn as a threat: couldn't this unpredictable elder child accidentally topple, drop or otherwise maim the newest addition to the family? Especially if he's like Spencer, an exuberant boy who gambols among an imagined menagerie in his expansive backyard jungle. Schaefer offers a fresh take on the ''getting a new sibling'' book, which doesn't introduce the enemy until the last pages. But those final spreads are so tenderly wrought they will bring tears to any hormonally challenged mother's eyes. Young readers still may not want Spencer's baby sibling, but they will definitely want his backyard.

SINCE its founding in May 2002 the New York film company FOCUS FEATURES, the art-house division of NBC Universal, has been the closest thing to a mainstream brand trustworthy enough that its logo in trailers incites curiosity and anticipation. Few if any of Focus's films, some produced by the company and others acquired for distribution, could be dismissed as popcorn. And its commitment to filmmakers like Ang Lee (''Brokeback Mountain,'' ''Lust, Caution,'' ''Taking Woodstock''), Joel and Ethan Coen (''Burn After Reading,'' ''A Serious Man'') and Sofia Coppola (''Lost in Translation,'' ''Somewhere'') indicate its seriousness of artistic purpose. Ten of its most important films are being shown at the Museum of Modern Art's 10th anniversary celebration, which began May 3 and continues through next Sunday. Probably the most crucial, shown May 6, was the gay cowboy love story ''Brokeback Mountain,'' which cost $14 million to make and grossed $83 million in the United States. But there are still screenings of ''Lost in Translation'' (this Sunday), Lisa Cholodenko's ''Kids Are All Right'' (Friday), Michel Gondry's mind-twisting ''Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind'' (Saturday) and David Cronenberg's ''Eastern Promises'' (next Sunday). All are worthy. Information: (212) 708-9400, moma.org.

ALLEN--Ivan G.,81, of Ft. Lauderdale, FL, passed May 7, 2012. He was born in Detroit, MI where he studied at the Servero School of Ballet. At the age of 22 he joined the American Ballet Theatre after which he traveled with the company to the west coast. He became a principal dancer with the company and traveled throughout Europe as well as performing at the Bolshoi Theatre in Moscow and also performed in the Capitals of South America. He remained with the company until he made his debut with the Metropolitan Opera in 1964, making his debut in Jules Massenet's Manon on November 18, 1964. Marielle Anzelone, a botanist and urban ecologist, is tracking the progress of spring in a patch of woods on Staten Island. Her last dispatch found the season in full swing. Previous articles in the series are at nytimes.com/cityroom. A thunderstorm rolled through the night before our weekly visit to Corson's Brook Woods. More than half an inch of rain fell on Staten Island, though still not enough to bring precipitation totals to normal levels. The forest soaked it up, parched from the unusually dry winter.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''A Perfect Game and Now a 4-Homer Game,'' May 9: I hope baseball fans realize that they have a chance to see a hitter who may be right up there with Babe Ruth, Ted Williams, Stan Musial and Shoeless Joe Jackson. He is Josh Hamilton, who amazed everyone last week with his four-homer game for the Texas Rangers.

KARPAS--Irving D. Jr.,87, of Manhattan and Ridgefield, CT, died at his home in Connecticut on May 12th after a long illness. He was the son of Irving D. and Janet Karpas, and is survived by his loving wife of 45 years, Suzanne Toor Karpas, and his eight adoring children, Michele Kennedy, Matthew Karpas, Jennifer Chernus, Patricia Karpas, Bruce Karpas, Steven Karpas, Debra Geller and Peter Karpas. He was also the beloved grandfather of 14 grandchildren and two greatgrandchildren. Irving attended Union College in Schenectady, NY and was a Navy veteran of World War II. He was formerly a senior partner of Herzfeld & Stern, a securities brokerage firm in New York. Irving and Suzanne continued a longstanding family tradition of philanthropy started by Irving's late father, Irving D. Karpas Sr., who in 1925 established the Karpas Pavillion at Beth Israel Hospital. For over 30 years, Irving and Suzanne have been steadfast supporters of countless programs at Beth Israel Medical Center including The Karpas Health Information Center, which they founded in 1981 to provide free critical health information to the local community. They have supported numerous clinical care and research initiatives, and have been deeply involved with the Phillips Beth Israel School of Nursing, where Irving served as Chairman of the Board of Trustees. Suzanne and Irving also established "Isabel's Suite" in honor of their granddaughter, a family-centered program that is part of the neonatal intensive care unit, at St. Lukes Roosevelt Hospital. Irving's philanthropy also extended to Hebrew Union College and Rockefeller University. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Karpas Health Information Center or Phillips Beth Israel School of Nursing. A memorial service will be held at Temple Rodeph Shalom (7 West 83rd Street) in New York City at 10am on Wednesday, May 16.

He is survived by his sisters, Cheryl, Jackie and Valerie, his protegee, Lee Ann, and many friends. Patrick's courage to change the things he could became his strength and serenity. IN a historic interview last week, President Obama announced his support for same-sex marriage. As he discussed his journey toward that position, the president sounded many familiar themes, like the importance of distinguishing between civil and religious marriage and of living up to American ideals of fairness. At the core of his narrative, however, was a relatively novel element -- an affirmation of gay couples as parents. The president repeatedly attributed his ''evolution'' to his contact not only with gay couples but also with their children. He described thinking about staff members ''who are incredibly committed, in monogamous relationships, same-sex relationships, who are raising kids together.'' He discussed meeting same-sex couples and seeing ''how caring they are, how much love they have in their hearts -- how they're taking care of their kids.''

A subheading with an obituary last Sunday about Phoebe Jacobs, a publicist for Louis Armstrong and other jazz stars, referred incorrectly to one aspect of her career. While she worked at a number of nightclubs, she was never a ''club owner.''

Hotels and resorts have long offered programs for children, but some now promise a lot more than a trip to the kiddie pool. Here's one case where, as far as the city is concerned, crime can pay. Among the 840,000 archival images placed online recently by the city's Department of Records are 1,326 police evidence photographs mostly taken from 1915 to 1920. The Municipal Archives gallery provides free research online and at a new visitors' center at 31 Chambers Street behind City Hall, but a digital file or 8-by-10 print will cost $45. The crime scene photos are part of what Eileen Flannelly, a deputy records commissioner, describes as ''the largest collection of criminal justice evidence in the world.''

A report on April 29 in the In Transit column about plans to ease the demand on Heathrow during the Olympic Games, using information from the airport, misstated the average number of takeoffs and landings it handles daily. It is 1,305, not 13,070.

Last season the Oklahoma City Thunder became the youngest team in N.B.A. history to reach the conference finals. The Thunder lost to the Dallas Mavericks, 4-1, in that series, but Oklahoma City exacted revenge by sweeping the defending champions in the first round of this year's playoffs. That the Thunder have improved so quickly - in 2008-9, Oklahoma City was arguably one of the three worst teams in the league - is a credit to the blueprint drawn up by General Manager Sam Presti when he was hired five years ago.

SASSOON--Vidal. American Friends of The Hebrew University and The Hebrew University of Jerusalem are profoundly saddened by the passing of our cherished friend Vidal Sassoon, a brilliant businessman and visionary who founded The Vidal Sassoon International Center for the Study of Antisemitism at Hebrew University. Vidal Sassoon maintained a lifelong dedication to Israel, actively seeking to eradicate antisemitism worldwide. At The Hebrew University, through the Center bearing his name, Vidal Sassoon helped to advance the highest levels of scholarship, research, and outreach. Vidal Sassoon received an honorary doctorate from Hebrew University. A Benefactor of the University, he was awarded the Magnes Award in recognition of his humanitarianism. He served as an Honorary Governor of the University's International Board of Governors, as an Honorary Vice President of national AFHU and as President Emeritus of AFHU's Western Region. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife Ronnie and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. In lieu of flowers, the family has requested that memorial donations be sent to American Friends of The Hebrew University in support of The Vidal Sassoon International Center for the Study of Antisemitism--AFHU, 11500 W. Olympic Boulevard, Suite 512, Los Angeles, CA 90064, or online at www.afhu.org. The Hebrew University of Jerusalem Professor Menahem Ben-Sasson, President Michael I. Federmann, Chairman, International Board of Governors American Friends of The Hebrew University George A. Schieren Chairman Martin E. Karlinsky President Peter T. Willner National Executive Director
