IMMIGRATION is an issue everywhere in the country, but Arizona may be the epicenter, and its schools are among the places where the various positions have their most practical effects. ''PRECIOUS KNOWLEDGE,'' Thursday on PBS's ''Independent Lens'' series (check local listings), takes a look at how a Mexican-American studies program in Tucson was affected by state legislation to abolish such initiatives. Latino students have a high dropout rate, and Tucson, the film says, has 32,500 of them. Its Mexican-American studies program was begun in part to combat the dropout problem.

An article on April 29 about the French filmmaker Jacques Rivette, best known for ''Céline and Julie Go Boating,'' misidentified the literary form of Henry James's ''Other House,'' which was adapted for part of the movie. It is a novel, not a novella.

MARCUS--Leon Charles, died April 30th due to complications from a 40-year battle with cancer. He was 75. Born August 27, 1936, in Maplewood, NJ, he was the eldest of four children of Herman and Sylvia Marcus. Leon graduated high school at the age of 16, finished Lafayette College at 19 and then went on to Columbia Law School. He was told that he was the youngest person ever admitted to the bar. Leon began his career in bankruptcy law, when corporate law firms deemed that practice area second class. Leon became one of the most notable personalities of the bankruptcy bar. Leon soon built one of the preeminent small bankruptcy firms in New York City. Among his high profile cases were the Pan Am, US Steel, Braniff Airlines, and REA Express to name a few. Leon was an avid sailor, fisherman and tennis player. A perpetual student of life, he devoured books on American history. He married five times, had five children, and was legal guardian to one other. He always loved being around his children and often said they were his greatest accomplishment in life. In 1969 Leon was first diagnosed with cancer and then again in 1977. Told he would not survive the year, he said he wanted to be able to enjoy his last days with his family doing what he loved. Leon bought a sailboat named it "Endgame" and with his family sailed for six months throughout the eastern Atlantic. Shortly after his return, his cancer was diagnosed as "in remission." Then in 1987, his cancer returned, and was an on-again off-again battle the remainder of his life. In 2002 he moved with his youngest daughter Sarah to Nova Scotia, where he lived for several years before moving back to the states to be with his daughter Kati and her family. Leon is survived by his five children: Brad Marcus of Connecticut, Eric Marcus of Florida, Spencer Marcus of New Jersey, Kati Biren of Minnesota and Sarah Marcus of Canada. His three siblings: Mary Ann Hamburger of New Jersey, Michael Marcus of New Jersey, Barbara Marcus of New Jersey. His grandchildren: Rachel, Madison, Jordana, Sophia, Asher, Ellis, and Lilah, expected first week of May. We miss him.

Louis H. Pollak, a federal judge and former dean of two prestigious law schools who played a significant role in major civil rights cases before the Supreme Court, including the landmark Brown v. Board of Education desegregation case, died on Tuesday at his home in Philadelphia. He was 89. The cause was congestive heart failure, his wife, Katherine, said.

A PENTHOUSE owned by Oprah Winfrey at 207 East 57th Street that sold for $7.75 million was the biggest sale of the week, according to city records.The three-bedroom condominium, which has a 750-square-foot terrace, was bought by a hedge fund manager from London.The sale was also a stroke of fortune for Nesrin Anjollie Feradov, a broker for the boutique firm SKNY Realty who represented the buyer.Ms. Feradov's story of how she completed the deal for the apartment would have fit right in on Ms. Winfrey's former television show.Ms. Feradov left a career in finance for the real estate world two years ago. But she hit a rough patch, she said: ''I personally had like five dollars in my bank account.''Then, a former client from her old job put her in touch with a financier from London who was looking for a home in Manhattan.When the financier, Mark Hillery, came to town with his wife to view apartments, Ms.Feradov decided she couldn't let him see that she was struggling. She hired a big S.U.V. from a car service, wore her finest Gucci shoes and whisked him to a $22 million penthouse in a Chelsea building designed by Jean Nouvel. Mr. Hillery wanted the penthouse, but by the time he reached a decision it had been bought by someone else. ''I was devastated,''Ms. Feradov said.Come Monday, her head cleared, she asked Mr. Hillery if she could show him more apartments.Once he saw Ms. Winfrey's penthouse at Place 57, as the 38-story building is called,he was sold. Ms. Feradov 's 2.5 percent commission worked out to a net payday of nearly$200,000.''If Oprah only knew that because of her apartment a single mom who has always struggled to make ends meet can not only pay her rent but her child's tuition,'' Ms. Feradov said. ''She, and my client, created a miracle in my life.''Big Ticket includes closed sales from the previous week, ending Wednesday. MARC SANTORA

FORSYTHE--Warren, age 83, died on May 7, 2012. A graduate of St. Lawrence University and Yale Law School, Warren's career in the field of trust and estate law earned him a reputation for wise, thorough and effective advice to generations of clients. A loving and devoted husband and brother, he is survived by his wife Elizabeth, of Manhattan, and sister Jean Grayson, of Madrid, New York. He also will be warmly remembered by the many young people he mentored.

Last year nearly 800,000 Australians traveled to the United States, an 81 percent increase over 2006. At a time when overall tourism to the United States has dipped, the percentage of Australians coming here is growing faster than any other market, according to Australia's Department of Resources, Energy and Tourism. This surge is starting to change the composition of popular tourist markets like New York City, where, since 2006, Australians have climbed from the 12th to sixth largest group of visitors, and have become the third biggest spenders, second only to the British and Brazilians.

TO describe CHRISTINE BREWER'S recital on Sunday at Alice Tully Hall as a rare New York appearance by this great American soprano may be an overstatement. But not by much. Wagner fans were disappointed when Ms. Brewer withdrew from singing Brünnhilde in the final presentation of Otto Schenk's production of the ''Ring'' at the Met in 2009. Her Met career has amounted to two performances in the lead role of Strauss's ''Ariadne auf Naxos.'' At 56 she sounds in her prime, her enormous yet plush and lyrically pliant voice ideal for Wagner and Strauss soprano roles. But Ms. Brewer seems to prefer recitals and concerts with orchestras over opera. Her last appearance in New York was as a soloist in the Boston Symphony Orchestra's performance of Beethoven's ''Missa Solemnis'' at Carnegie Hall in March. For this recital she is joined by the exceptional pianist Craig Rutenberg. The Mother's Day program is enticing, with excerpts from Virgil Thomson's ''Mother of Us All'' and works by Barber, Ives, Youmans, Arlen and more. 5 p.m., Lincoln Center, (212) 721-6500, lincolncenter.org; $45 to $77.

TRAN--Truong Dinh. Vietnamese businessman Tran Dinh Truong passed away at his home and business, Hotel Carter, on Sunday, May 6, 2012. He was 80 years old. The son of Mr. Tran Toi Lac and Mrs. Le Thi Tu, Mr. Tran was born and raised in Vietnam and was the principal owner of Vishipco Line, the largest shipping company in South Vietnam during the 1970s. He left Vietnam with his families on April 30, 1975, the day Saigon fell to the Communists, boarding one of his eleven ships with only two gold filled suitcases and an American dream. The journey was long, but the Tran families eventually landed in New York City, where Mr. Tran began his new career in hospitality, first with the Hotel Opera on the Upper West Side, and then Hotel Carter in Midtown Manhattan, a purchase which also included Hotel Lafayette, in Buffalo, New York and Hotel Kenmore in Manhattan. Through the years, there were many other real estate holdings, but his greatest accomplishment was his humanitarian work, which included a personal contribution of $2 million dollars to The American Red Cross Disaster Relief Fund after the September 11, 2001 terrorist attacks. In May 2004, Mr. Tran was awarded a Golden Torch Award by the Vietnamese American National Gala in Washington, D.C. Mr. Tran was also on the Board of Directors of The United Way of New York City. He is survived by sixteen children: Nam Tran, Bac Tran, Thu Tran, Suzen Tran, Caroline Tran, Stephanie Tran, Teresa Yokoi, Monica Tran, Joseph Tran, Victoria Tran, Trang Tran, Margaret Tran, Christine Tran, Madalena Tran, Anthony Tran, Laura Tran, their mothers, and 15 grandchildren. A mass will be held at Holy Cross Church, 329 West 42nd Street on May 14, 2012 at 10am. The funeral will be at Trinity Cemetery, 770 Riverside Drive on May 16, 2012 at 10am.

BOGOMOLNAYA--Alla, 55, of Lyndhurst, OH, on May 11, 2012, from colon cancer. Devoted teacher; beloved wife of Mikhail Sapozhnik; cherished and adored mother of Eugene and Ellen Weinstein of New York, NY.

Ray Lucas does not blame the N.F.L. for his addiction to prescription painkillers, and he does not blame football. After contemplating suicide, he got help, and he said he wants to throw a lifeline to others. Lucas, a former Rutgers, Jets and Dolphins quarterback, now an SNY football analyst, is working with Reckitt Benckiser Pharmaceuticals to inform the public about treatment options. In his case, he took Suboxone, an opioid that managed his withdrawal symptoms and eventually allowed him to subdue his addiction. Lucas, 39, answered questions recently via e-mail. Q.

THERE is an ongoing debate in this country about the rich: who they are, what their social role may be, whether they are good or bad. Well, consider the following. A recent study found that 10 percent of people who work on Wall Street are ''clinical psychopaths,'' exhibiting a lack of interest in and empathy for others and an ''unparalleled capacity for lying, fabrication, and manipulation.'' (The proportion at large is 1 percent.) Another study concluded that the rich are more likely to lie, cheat and break the law. The only thing that puzzles me about these claims is that anyone would find them surprising. Wall Street is capitalism in its purest form, and capitalism is predicated on bad behavior. This should hardly be news. The English writer Bernard Mandeville asserted nearly as much three centuries ago in a satirical-poem-cum-philosophical-treatise called ''The Fable of the Bees.''

PUEBLO GARZÓN, a pint-size village tucked within the farmlands of southeastern Uruguay, was all but abandoned after its train station closed half a century ago. So when the Argentine chef Francis Mallmann opened a five-room hotel and restaurant there in 2003, a few skeptical eyebrows were raised. But once the wood-grilling expert persuaded his European and American friends to make the trip inland -- Garzón is about 40 miles northeast of Punta del Este, the glamorous seaside resort -- word began to spread about the town's old-time charms: gauchos riding on horseback along tidy gravel streets, residents greeting one another by name, and children playing in a flower-filled central plaza. Now Mr. Mallmann has company. Along with the arrival of travelers in search of epicurean fare came a smattering of new restaurants, boutiques and high-end establishments, including a winery, bringing new life into this quiet corner of the Uruguayan countryside. PAOLA SINGER

LEE--Kie-Hong Daniel, passed away on April 29, 2012, in Seoul, Korea. Born on April 13, 1922, Kie-Hong Lee studied at Hiroshima Imperial Normal College, Seoul National University, Amherst College, Princeton University and Columbia University. A prominent economist, Kie-Hong Lee was the primary architect of Korea's first 5-year economic plan after the Korean War, laying the path for Korea to grow from a stagnant, tradition-oriented, agricultural society into a modern, dynamic, economic powerhouse. Among his many contributions to Korea's development, the reforestation of the peninsula following its devastation from Japanese occupation, World War II, and the Korean War is probably the most beautiful and lasting. Mr. Lee was the first Korean citizen to work as part of the professional staff at the United Nations, ECAFE, beginning in 1958. On May 16, 1961, when a coup d'etat in South Korea deposed the popularly elected government in South Korea, Mr. Lee was in Washington, D.C. to discuss Korea's economic development plans with Walt W. Rostow, Deputy Special Assistant to the President for National Security Affairs, and McGeorge Bundy, National Security Advisor. Mr. Lee declined an offer of refuge from the US government, and returned to the post-coup Korea to continue his work as an economist with the new government, quickly rising to the position of Assistant Minister, Economic Planning Board. Over the course of his long career, Mr. Lee worked as an economist at The World Bank, Managing Director of Korea-US Economic Council, Managing Director of Korea Trade Association, and publisher of Business Korea and Korea Business World magazines. A strong advocate of advanced education for women, Mr. Lee was a former president of the Amherst College Alumni Association in Korea. He was also president of the Seoul Rotary Club. In 1989 he became one of the founding members of the Committee of 300 Free Thinkers, an outspoken group of former Korean government ministers and influential leaders in fields of economics, education, law, finance and industry dedicated to maintaining the development of the Republic by publishing loyal critiques of unwise government policies, while espousing values of truth, intellectual freedom, market economics, and integrity in leadership. Mr. Lee is survived by his wife Young-Ja, four children, Margaret, Thai, Celeste, and Changsuk, sons-in-law Al Njoo and Kevin C. McCann, daughter-in-law Young Wook Kang, and grandchildren Albert Njoo, Andrew Njoo, Daniel Njoo, Victor Leo, Hanah Lee, Noel McCann, Saymin Lee, Minjoon Lee, and Andy Whang.

Published in 1970, the novel revolves around the advertising artist Si Morley, who is recruited by the government to join a secretive operation. The project takes him back in time to the New York of 1882. JACOB--Joel. February 3, 1917-May 3, 2012. Survived by his wife of 36 years Barbara, children Deborah Jacob (Dow Timmon), Paul Jacob (Rosemary Cooke) stepchildren Karen Lichtig, Lisa Lichtig (Patrick Hanaway) and five grandsons, Richard Cohen (Lucia Gervino), William Cohen, Daniel Jacob, Wilkin Hanaway, Devin Hanaway, and four great-granddaughters, Hailey Cohen, Ella Cohen, Marlena Cohen, Piper Cohen. He is predeceased by his first wife Betty. She was a famous sculptor. Joel was a third generation Detroiter, who attended and graduated from University of Michigan law school. He served honorably in the US Army JAG during WWII. Joel was a key contributor to the success of M. Jacob and Sons, a 126 year old family owned packaging business started by Joel's grandfather, Max Jacob. Joel was the chairman of the M. Jacob and Sons Board of Directors for 30 years from 1976 until 2006 and was their legal counsel for many years longer. He was a founding partner of Hertzberg, Jacob & Weingarten a prominent corporate and bankruptcy law firm in Detroit. Jacob & Weingarten is the successor law firm, currently in business. Florine Mark was Joel's best friend for many years. Joel was always a champion for women and, although he always appeared to be a 'tough guy' he really was a 'softy' at heart. Joel marched to his own drummer-singing in his rich baritone. Duroy Burnett cared for Joel for many years. He was Joel's close friend and caring companion. Sandra Reynolds took special care of Joel at night during the last couple of months. Joel will forever be missed and forever remembered in our hearts.

CLARK--Msgr. Eugene V.,The Trustees of the Homeland Foundation, Inc. express great sympathy and affection for Msgr. Eugene V. Clark who died on April 11, 2012 in East Hampton, NY. Msgr. Clark was a guiding force and inspiration for the Homeland Foundation and was, along with Fr. Raphael Camano, its spiritual leader. He was a brilliant speaker, a knowledgeable connoisseur of religious art, had a keen whit, and was very devout. He was the creator of, and motivating influence, behind the Patrons of the Arts at the Vatican Museums, establishing its first United States Chapter in New York City, and counseled the members in their restoration of numerous works of art in Vatican Museums. This included the Raphael Tapestry "Healing the Lame Man," a 1 B.C. Roman Mosaic, the Fra Angelico frescoes in the Chapel of Nicholas V in Pontifical Palace in the Vatican, and the restoration of the Casina of Pope Pius IV in the Vatican Gardens near St. Peter's Basilica. He also was responsible for hundreds of persons being able to view Michelangelo's work in the Sistine Chapel, assisting many to ascend the scaffolding during the cleaning of the Chapel ceiling and "Last Judgment." His caring ways and leadership will be missed by Homeland, his family, and all of the persons and organizations with which he was involved during his lifetime. E. Lisk Wyckoff, Jr., President William J. Ayres, Vice Pres. David Dangremond, Vice Pres. Rev. John Kamas, Vice Pres. Carl Schmitt Elizabeth Wyckoff, Secretary Mrs. Lucy Flemming-McGrath, Trustee Emeritus

9 P.M. (ABC) DESPERATE HOUSEWIVES The ladies who scheme and lunch wrap up loose ends as the series comes to a close. Bree's lawyer, Trip (Scott Bakula), begs her to tell him what really happened the night of Alejandro's murder when it looks as if she were about to be convicted. Gaby (Eva Longoria) tries to come up with a way to take the burden off Bree (Marcia Cross, above with Mr. Bakula). Susan (Teri Hatcher) works to conceal the sale of her house until she can break the news to her neighbors; Katherine Mayfair (Dana Delany) returns to Wisteria Lane with a job offer for Lynette (Felicity Huffman) -- one that could end her chances of reconciliation with Tom (Doug Savant). Renee (Vanessa Williams) reaches the end of her rope when Ben (Charles Mesure) is arrested before their wedding. And all the women agree to take care of Mrs. McCluskey (Kathryn Joosten) when she decides to die at home. 7 A.M. (Starz) EASY A (2010) Emma Stone plays Olive, a good girl who pretends to be bad to raise her social standing in high school, as well as that of some persecuted class virgins, in this satire directed by Will Gluck. But when her faked promiscuity generates an unexpected chain reaction, she sews a capital A on her clothes and parades around the school in suggestive outfits. Amanda Bynes is the leader of the Christian club, who denounces Olive as a slut. Penn Badgley is Olive's prince-in-waiting. ''Whatever else it accomplishes, the sassy high school comedy 'Easy A' commands attention for the irresistible presence'' of Ms. Stone, Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times.

FROM most choreographers a dance advertised as ''a psychedelia-inspired kaleidoscope'' and ''catharsis'' would go a long way toward prompting me not to see it. But LUCIANA ACHUGAR is not most choreographers. There is something fantastically witchy and singular about her performances; she has a rare ability to create worlds of abandon for her audiences without losing her own head, so that her dances are as smart as they are sensual. This Uruguayan choreographer, long based in New York, is a great collapser of space: between the audience and the artists, the intellect and the physical. Earthy, often awkward movements, repeated again and again, become ritualistic. The female body (Ms. Achugar often works with women, playing with stereotypes even as she explodes them) courts forces both sexual and sinister.

Last month, Philip Humber of the Chicago White Sox pitched the 21st perfect game in the major leagues. Last week, Josh Hamilton, the Texas Rangers outfielder, became the 16th major leaguer to hit four home runs in a game. But a case can be made that Humber was actually the 19th to toss a perfect game and Hamilton the 14th to achieve a four-homer game, at least in baseball's modern era.

WHEN most families fight, as most families do, you might hear about it over the back fence or see a stray post on Facebook. When the Wainwrights get into it, the spat often shows up in a full-blown song, which begets other songs. That kind of thing will happen when one of America's most bracing folk writers, Loudon Wainwright III, marries another folk luminary, Kate McGarrigle of the McGarrigle Sisters, and they have two musically gifted children, Rufus and Martha. Factor in a serious relationship, which has long ended, with another member of the folk pantheon -- with Suzzy Roche of the Roches, that produced yet another musical offspring, Lucy Wainwright Roche -- and cue decades of songs, many of them about a complicated life in a family of musical royalty. Some of those songs have titles that don't scan well in a family newspaper, including Loudon's ditty about a fight for position at the breast of Rufus's mother and Martha's profane rocket aimed at her father's shortcomings. Back and forth it goes, with Rufus's ''Dinner at Eight'' revealing that supper at the Wainwrights was sometimes more dark indie movie than sitcom. But as a clan they never let a song get in the way of firmer, more durable ties. On Friday many members of the family will gather at Town Hall to mark the recent release of Loudon Wainwright's album ''Older Than My Old Man Now'' (2nd Story Sound Records), a bracing look back that includes references to -- and performances by -- various Wainwrights, Roches and McGarrigles. Even the departed are represented, with a spoken recitation of a meditation on family written by Loudon's father, a columnist for Life magazine, along with the only song Loudon Wainwright ever wrote with McGarrigle, who died in 2010.

BENSON--Joyce M. 83, of Stuart, FL, died April 19, 2012 at Martin Hospital South in Stuart. Born in Winnetka, IL, she resided in Stuart for the past 16 years, moving to this area from Mamaroneck, NY. Joyce was a graduate of Salem College in Winston-Salem, NC. Joyce earned a Silver Life Master level of bridge (ACBL). She was a member of Khatib Bridge Education Center, Mariner Sands Golf & Country Club, past chair of Women's Volunteers at Winged Foot Golf Club in Mamaroneck. women's coordinator for the 1984 U.S. Open, member of the Junior League. Vitetta of Stuart; half sister, Patricia Monteith of Cincinnati, OH; nine grandchildren; and one great-grandchild. She was preceded in death by her daughter, Linda J. Benson.

''Are your eyes more deep-set now than they used to be?''Dr. Robert Lesser asked the middle-aged woman in his office. She was surprised by the odd question from this eye doctor she just met. Why would he ask me that? she wondered ''No,'' the woman told him, ''I don't think so.'' A HISTORY OF EYE PROBLEMS

Once Elsa Schiaparelli got going, she didn't quit. She was enormously innovative from the start of her career, in 1927, as visitors to the new Schiaparelli-Prada exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art will readily see. She created severely chic suits as well as witty party clothes and accessories for at least two generations of irreverent women. On Monday, as designers around town were fitting actresses for clothes to wear to the Costume Institute gala, Diego Della Valle announced that he would revive the Schiaparelli name. This wasn't exactly news - he has owned the name since 2006 - but the exhibition offered a fresh hook.

COOPER--Lucy, who for years split her time between Brooklyn and W. Palm Beach, died peacefully at age 90 on May 6, 2012. Born on December 11, 1921, Lucy was married for 42 years to the love of her life, Jack Cooper, who pre-deceased her in 1985. After graduating magna cum laude and Phi Beta Kappa from Hunter College and receiving master's degrees from Columbia University and Pratt Institute, she worked for many years as a high school librarian. Lucy's passion for travel sparked family trips worldwide, and her endless curiosity had her engaged in an ongoing study of chemistry at the time of her death. She is survived by daughters Betsy (Sean) and Kathy (Tom); grandchildren Josh (Amy), Jo (David) and Gabe; and great-grandchildren Juniper and Quentin. Donations may be made to the Brooklyn Botanic Gardens.

CASALS--Elena "Mimi". On March 17th, 2012, Cuban songwriter and poet, Elena Casals, "Mimi", sailed on at the age 85. She was born on January 28th, 1927 in Pinar del Rio, Cuba where she wrote her first songs and poems at the age of 15. The passionate boleros of Elena Casals have been recorded by Latin music legends Olga Guillot, Roberto Ledesma, Lucho Gatica, Grisel Sanchez and many more in a career that has spanned over 70 years. In 1965, along with Jose Carbo Menendez and Concha Valdez Miranda she became a founding member of La Sociedad de Autores y Compositores Cubanos en el Exilio. She also collaborated with her son, songwriter/music producer Desmond Child (Bon Jovi, Cher, Ricky Martin, Katy Perry) writing Spanish lyrics to his songs and proudly attended his induction into the Songwriters Hall Of Fame in 2008 where she took a bow herself. Her life's work, "Mis Cajas De Carton/My Cardboard Boxes" - Las Poesias y Boleros de Elena Casals" will be published this year. She is adored and missed by her sons Desmond Child and Fred Barrett and grandchildren; Freddy, Marylou and Natalya Barrett and Roman and Nyro Child.... especially today on Mother's Day. For more information: ElenaCasals.com/ DesmondChild.com.

BEFORE you dismiss a candle as too obvious for a Mother's Day gift, consider this: Good candles, ones that smell luxurious and come in beguiling pots or canisters, are neither too cheap (some, like Fornasetti's limited edition Cammei Oro, can cost hundreds of dollars) nor too expensive (Carrière Frères Industrie's are all less than $50). Their fragrances can be layered, delicate, even appetizing concoctions that blend, say, tulips, chimney smoke, dried vines and a brick wall (see Tisane by Tatine's St. John's Wood). Packaged in Bakelite (James de Givenchy for Taffin), blue glass (Cire Trudon) or porcelain (Juliska), their cups are worth cleaning and keeping for use as a flower vase, desk accessory or button jar. As presents, candles might at first seem impersonal, but give your sister the signature scent of her favorite SoulCycle classes (Jonathan Adler's special edition grapefruit candle), or your brother one that matches his surf wax (Ted Shred's), and neither would accuse you of being inconsiderate. In fact, because smell is so closely linked to memory, candles can be quite sentimental -- take the one that burned at the hotel where you honeymooned, for example; the one that scented the now-closed but much-missed boutique in NoLIta where you bought the wedges you wore to your first job interview; the one that smells like home. To prove that candles are, indeed, great and giftworthy for Mother's Day and beyond, we collected the very best scents in the very best-looking vessels. Get a whiff! JANE HERMAN

STICHTER--John A. Kane Lodge No. 454 F. & A. M. announces with profound sorrow the death of our esteemed Brother and Past Master, Right Worshipful John A. Stichter on April 30. He was a 50 year member and served as our Master in 1972 and in 1985. John was the President of the Kane Lodge Foundation for over twenty five years, served the Lodge in numerous other capacities and was a mentor to many of us. A memorial service will be held at Kane Lodge on Tuesday, June 5, 2012 at 5:30pm for his family, friends and Brothers. As one of the pillars of Kane Lodge, he shall be greatly missed and warmly remembered. Paul D. Reitz, Secretary Murat Dogruer, Master

LYNCHBURG, Va. -- Mitt Romney traveled to Liberty University, the spiritual heart of the conservative movement, on Saturday, seeking to quell concerns about him among evangelical voters by offering a forceful defense of faith and Christian values in public life. At a graduation speech at the college, founded by the evangelical leader Jerry Falwell, Mr. Romney made the case that he is bound theologically and politically to the same belief and value system as Christian conservatives, though he never explicitly mentioned his Mormon faith.

TOBIN--Austin J.,Jr. 84, of Southbury, CT., a legend in the municipal bond world, died May 9th after an illness of several months. A lieutenant in the Marines in World War II and a captain during the Korean Conflict, he graduated from Dartmouth College and Columbia Law School. He was Republican finance chairman during Nelson Rockefeller's successful bid for governor of New York. He was a life-long student of history and government and a connoisseur of art and literature. During his Municipal Bond career, he was bond counsel for Wood, King and Dawson, and an underwriter for W.H. Morton. He developed a "range of yield curve" model that revolutionized pricing in the municipal bond industry. His company, Delphis Hanover Corporation, served many state and local governments nation-wide, and numerous investors. He is mourned by his wife, Nancy Becklean Tobin, his children with former wife Elizabeth Stephens Tobin, Austin III and wife Rita, Farley and husband Alton Parks, John and former wife Nancy Feinberg, his grandchildren, Jacob, Austin IV, Nina and sister, Stacy Carmichael. He is also mourned by his stepchildren, Jennifer Conn Bonnar, Richard, Elizabeth, Robert Conn and colleagues, David Abel and Tom Lanctot. He was the son of Geraldine T. Farley and Austin J. Tobin, Executive Director of the Port Authority of NY/NJ for 30 years. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent in his memory to the Southbury Public Library.

WINK--Walter, 76, of New York City and Sandisfield, MA, died on May 10th. He was professor of Biblical Interpretation at Auburn Theological Seminary from 1976-2005. He earned Master of Divinity and Ph.D. degrees from Union Theological Seminary. He pioneered a method of Bible study first presented in a controversial and widely influential book, The Bible in Human Transformation. He is internationally renowned for his work on power structures and non-violence, coining the phrase "the myth of redemptive violence." He is author of over a dozen books, including the award-winning "Powers" trilogy. He is survived by his wife June, brother Dick, three children, two-stepchildren and eight grandchildren.
DOWNEY--Nicholas, 61, gentle Welsh. Intellect, musician, May 4, 2012. Survived by loving wife Marilyn, friends and family in the US, Wales and else where. Memorial: Saturday, June 2, 4-6pm.

The Outer Critics Circle, a group of theater writers outside of New York, said on Sunday that the new Broadway musical ''Once'' and the new play ''One Man, Two Guvnors'' received three top awards each in the group's 62nd annual competition honoring Broadway and Off Broadway productions. ''Once'' won for best musical, director of a musical (John Tiffany) and book (Enda Walsh); ''One Man'' won for best play, director of a play (Nicholas Hytner) and actor in a play (James Corden). The drama ''Sons of the Prophet'' won for Off Broadway play and ''Queen of the Mist'' won for Off Broadway musical, while this season's Broadway productions of ''Death of a Salesman'' and ''Follies'' won for best play revival and musical revival. ''Follies,'' which closed in January, also won for best actor in a musical (Danny Burstein); the top awards for actresses went to Audra McDonald (as Bess in the musical revival of ''The Gershwins' Porgy and Bess'') and Tracie Bennett (as Judy Garland in ''End of the Rainbow''). Recipients of featured acting awards were James Earl Jones (''Gore Vidal's The Best Man''), Spencer Kayden (''Don't Dress for Dinner''), and Michael McGrath and Judy Kaye (both for ''Nice Work If You Can Get It'').

Imagine if you had a superpower that would allow you to peer into the future of the Internet? It's a pretty nerdy power compared to Spider-Man's web-slinging, but you could use this superhuman ability to see what would be popular soon, and in some instances, change the future. Facebook actually has this power. Because it connects Facebook users to more than nine million apps and services through Facebook Connect, the Open Graph developer platform, and the hundreds of millions of like buttons that perforate Web pages across the Internet, the company can see what people are using. Facebook is more tapped into the pulse of people online than any company on the planet.

Microsoft rolled out a new version of its Bing search engine with new features aimed at weaving together the experience of Internet search and social networking. There is, however, one eyebrow-raising new Bing feature Microsoft was testing that it decided not to release to the public. Last week, when Microsoft gave me early access to the new version of Bing, I noticed a message in the search bar of the product that indicated I could share all of the search terms I entered on Bing with friends in my Facebook social network.

HIRSCHHORN--Fred Jr. Fred Hirschhorn Jr.,died on Sunday, May 6, 2012. He was 92 years old, born in New York City on May 28, 1919. He was the husband of Joan Morgenthau Hirschhorn and son of Fred Hirschhorn and Hannah deRothschild Scharps Hirschhorn. His father was the Founder and CEO of General Cigar Co. He attended Ethical Culture Fieldston in New York City, and was a graduate of Phillips Exeter and Yale University. Upon graduation, he was commissioned in the Navy and ordered to join the USS Rowan serving in the North Atlantic, African, Sicilian, and Italian invasions, and was a survivor of the sinking of the Rowan. Subsequently, he served on the USS Cushing in the Pacific and was present in Tokyo before the signing of the Armistice. He received an Individual Presidential Citation in 1945. He joined Abraham & Straus in 1946, where he remained until 1960, when he became a Partner at Joseph Walker & Sons. In 1962, he became a venture capitalist founding Frontier Capital of New York and Anchorage Properties Limited. He was a member of Delta Kappa Epsilon, Yale Athletic Association, and Riverside Yacht Club. He was a Director of Fiduciary Trust International. In 1957, he married Joan E. Morgenthau, MD, with whom he had three children, Elizabeth H. Wilson, Joan H. Bright, and Elinor H. Hirschhorn, two sons-in-law, and seven grandchildren. He lived in Old Greenwich, CT until 2007 when he moved to Edgehill Retirement Community in Stamford, CT. Memorial service at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue between 65th and 66th Street, New York, NY will be on Thursday, May 17 at 3:30pm with a reception to follow. Burial will be private. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that contributions be made to Thirteen/WNET, 825 Eighth Avenue, New York, NY 10019.

Updated 5:15 p.m. | Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, in a commencement address at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill on Sunday, delivered a spirited defense of the right of gays and lesbians to marry, just days after North Carolina passed an amendment that banned the practice. ''Each and every generation has removed some barrier to full participation in the American dream,'' the mayor said. ''I would argue last week's referendum banning same-sex marriage shows just how much more work needs to be done to ensure freedom and equality for all people.'' Mr. Bloomberg has become a vocal supporter of same-sex marriage, which was legalized by the New York State Legislature last year, and he chairs a group, ''Mayors for the Freedom to Marry,'' that supports ''ending marriage discrimination at all levels of government.''

The mortgage unit of Ally Financial plans to put itself into bankruptcy, according to people briefed on the matter, allowing the bank to effectively remove the biggest obstacle to its turnaround efforts. The division, known as Residential Capital or ResCap, was expected to file for Chapter 11 as soon as late Sunday evening, these people added. ResCap's board was met late Sunday to authorize the move.

An obituary on April 20 about Stanley R. Resor, who was secretary of the Army from 1965 to 1971, referred incorrectly to an action taken in 1974 by his successor, Howard H. Callaway, in the case of Lt. William Calley, convicted of murder for his role in the My Lai massacre. Mr. Callaway reduced Lieutenant Calley's sentence to 10 years from 20 years, and Lieutenant Calley was paroled later that year; Mr. Callaway did not pardon him.

Every year, the newest golf drivers attract all the publicity. Any trip to a golf retailer will prove that driver sales run the show. The displays of new drivers overwhelm the sales racks, beckoning to us with their gaudy promises of 5, 10 or 20 extra yards. But as more and more people fixate on the big dog in the golf bag - and as equipment rules officials work harder to keep drivers honest and conforming to the rules - those using the other metal woods have been benefiting from the nonattention. I speak of fairway woods - those handy tools that in recent years have been overshadowed by the hybrid explosion and the driver distance grab.

When JPMorgan Chaserevealed its $2 billion loss last week, it looked as though the big Wall Street banks were up to their old tricks, using their government-backed funds to make risky trades in a misguided effort to improve their profits. But even banks that focus mainly on good, old-fashioned lending do their fair share of high-stakes trading.

A report in the National Briefing column on Tuesday about a federal appeals court ruling that said Rhode Island must surrender to federal authorities a man accused of murder misstated the given name of the inmate. He is Jason W. Pleau, not David.

Who could have thought a hoodie could mean so much? Over the last two days, there has been a great deal of mudslinging and hand-wringing about the significance of what Mark Zuckerberg, 27, the chief of executive of Facebook, wore when he went courting would-be investors in New York.

Almost nobody likes to hear that they should practice their putting more, even if it is undoubtedly true. If you're lucky enough to be near a practice facility that has a putting green, there might be a line of people waiting for a stall to whack away with the irons and woods, but the practice putting and chipping area will probably be deserted. Putting is, admittedly, too simple: roll that little ball over into that little hole. People don't feel they have to waste their precious, limited practice time perfecting something so elementary. But P.G.A. teaching professionals who have spent their entire careers trying to get golfers to play better overwhelming insist that the easiest and most time-efficient way to score lower is to work on the putting stroke. This advice usually goes unheeded because most golfers think they are far better at putting than they really are.

BRODY--Arthur. Entrepreneur, businessman, philanthropist. A resident of Rancho Santa Fe, passed away Thursday morning, May 10th following a brief illness. He was a month shy of his 92nd birthday and was a vital presence in the business and philanthropic life of the San Diego community. Arthur was born in Newark, New Jersey, the son of pharmacy owners who had a small lending library in their store and who instilled in him a life-long passion for the written word. He studied electrical engineering at Columbia University and New York Technical Institute and it was during his college years that his talent for entrepreneurial enterprise emerged. Wanting to provide waterproof protection for textbooks, Arthur developed a way to turn clear photographic film into a protective cover; by the time he left school he had eight employees turning out his invention. From 1943-46, Arthur served as a commissioned officer in the Signal Corp of the United States Army. He taught the Theory of Frequency Modulation at the Army signal school in Fort Monmouth, New Jersey and also served in the European theater of operations. Following his army service, Arthur returned to his pursuit of business, founding the Brodart Company which grew to be the major manufacturer and distributor of library and school supplies and equipment in the country. He was granted a number of patents for library and office products and systems and his expertise in all things relating to educational and library tools made him a sought after member of boards and commissions of library organizations, including the Center of the Book at the Library of Congress. During this time Arthur and his wife, Sophie, were active with civic and philanthropic organizations and he became a member of the Young Presidents Organization, serving as the Chairman of the New Jersey Chapter in 1962 and 1963. He was one of eight founding members of the World Presidents Organization. Arthur became a private pilot and an avid yachtsman. Over the years he owned many boats and he loved to be out on the water cruising the inland waterways of the East coast from Maine to the Bahamas and, later, the southern California coast. In 1982 the Brodys relocated to Rancho Santa Fe. Arthur continued with numerous business pursuits even as he greatly expanded his involvement in civic and philanthropic organizations. He served on the boards of the San Diego Public Library, the Sanford-Burnham Institute, the UCSD Foundation, Rady School of Management, the San Diego Symphony, and Seacrest Retirement Village. He was the founding President of the UCSD Library Board and also served as President of the Jewish Community Foundation. One of his proudest involvements was helping to establish the Student Foundation at UCSD and he often followed the students' leads in selecting promising investments. It was as the President of the Sophie and Arthur Brody Foundation that Arthur addressed issues that were most important to him. His generosity was boundless, he had a huge heart, and he contributed generously to local, national and international charities. Aside from the organizations mentioned above, each of which was a major beneficiary of Arthur's largess, the Brody Foundation was a significant donor to Congregation Beth Israel, the Salk Institute for Biological Studies, the Moores Cancer Center, the United Jewish Federation, and the American Joint Distribution Committee. Arthur was an extraordinary man with a great sense of humor and inexhaustible strength. He continued to be interested and engaged in his businesses and philanthropies until his final days. He was a loyal friend and will be missed by the many individuals for whom his presence was so vital. He was predeceased by his beloved wife of 60 years, Sophie. For the last seven years Arthur was blessed by the loving companionship of Phyllis Cohn. He is survived by his daughter Janice Brody (Bruce Rule), his son, Donald Brody (Toby Mickelson), and his five grandsons, Cameron, Pokey, Evan, Harris (Johanna) and Alex (Natalie). Services will be held at 1:00pm on Monday, May 14th at Congregation Beth Israel, 9001 Towne Center Drive, San Diego, 92122. Contributions in celebration of Arthur Brody's life may be made to the Sanford-Burnham Institute, the Jewish Community Foundation, the San Diego Symphony, or the Salk Institute for Biological Studies.

BOGOMOLNAYA--Alla, 55, of Lyndhurst, OH, on May 11, 2012, from colon cancer. Devoted teacher; beloved wife of Mikhail Sapozhnik; cherished and adored mother of Eugene and Ellen Weinstein of New York, NY.

An article on April 14 about the economic problems in California, as measured between east and west instead of the state's usual north-south divide, referred incorrectly to data looking at the gap between the per capita income in the San Francisco Bay Area compared with the Inland Empire. The article erroneously used dollar figures -- saying that the gap between the two communities grew to more than $40,000, and that it was $26,000 four decades ago -- rather than using the per capita income index used by the researchers. (By 2009, the San Francisco Bay Area per capita income was 86 percent higher than the Inland Empire, a gap that had grown since 1969, when the per capita income was 41 percent higher than in the Inland Empire.)

TRAN--Truong Dinh. Vietnamese businessman Tran Dinh Truong passed away at his home and business, Hotel Carter, on Sunday, May 6, 2012. He was 80 years old. The son of Mr. Tran Toi Lac and Mrs. Le Thi Tu, Mr. Tran was born and raised in Vietnam and was the principal owner of Vishipco Line, the largest shipping company in South Vietnam during the 1970s. He left Vietnam with his families on April 30, 1975, the day Saigon fell to the Communists, boarding one of his eleven ships with only two gold filled suitcases and an American dream. The journey was long, but the Tran families eventually landed in New York City, where Mr. Tran began his new career in hospitality, first with the Hotel Opera on the Upper West Side, and then Hotel Carter in Midtown Manhattan, a purchase which also included Hotel Lafayette, in Buffalo, New York and Hotel Kenmore in Manhattan. Through the years, there were many other real estate holdings, but his greatest accomplishment was his humanitarian work, which included a personal contribution of $2 million dollars to The American Red Cross Disaster Relief Fund after the September 11, 2001 terrorist attacks. In May 2004, Mr. Tran was awarded a Golden Torch Award by the Vietnamese American National Gala in Washington, D.C. Mr. Tran was also on the Board of Directors of The United Way of New York City. He is survived by sixteen children: Nam Tran, Bac Tran, Thu Tran, Suzen Tran, Caroline Tran, Stephanie Tran, Teresa Yokoi, Monica Tran, Joseph Tran, Victoria Tran, Trang Tran, Margaret Tran, Christine Tran, Madalena Tran, Anthony Tran, Laura Tran, their mothers, and 15 grandchildren. A mass will be held at Holy Cross Church, 329 West 42nd Street on May 14, 2012 at 10am. The funeral will be at Trinity Cemetery, 770 Riverside Drive on May 16, 2012 at 10am.

An article on Thursday about a New York City health department campaign to encourage hospitals to stop giving out free baby formula in order to help promote breast-feeding misstated a recommendation of the American Academy of Pediatrics. It recommends continuing breast-feeding beyond six months, while introducing other food, for a year or more -- not continuing for ''up to'' a year, while introducing other food.

JEFFERY--Reuben Jr.,of Southport, CT beloved husband of the late Ann Thomas Jeffery, passed away peacefully in his home Saturday, May 5, 2012. Born January 31, 1923 in Syracuse, NY, the son of late Marie and Reuben Jeffery. He served in Japan with the U.S. Army 11th Airborne Division leaving the service at the end of the war as a Captain. Graduated from Yale, B.E. 1944 and Harvard Business School, M.B.A. 1949, with High Distinction and as a Baker Scholar. Thirty-five year career as an accounts manager, Polymer Products Department, E.I. DuPont de Nemours & Co. He is survived by his two children; Reuben Jeffery III of New York, NY and Martha Ann Jeffery of Bridgeport, CT; three grandchildren, Jocelyn Ann Jeffery, Reuben Jeffery IV and Robert Walker Jeffery; and his sister Jean Jeffery Greene of Syracuse, NY. He was predeceased by his brother, John Jeffery. A memorial service will be held Friday, May 18th 2012 at 11:00AM at Greenfield Hill Congregational Church, 1045 Old Academy Road, Fairfield, CT. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory can be made to Greenfield Hill Congregational Church.

The British period drama ''Downton Abbey'' may be a hit for PBS, but how much box-office allure will one of its stars have on Broadway? That proposition will be tested this fall: Dan Stevens, who stars on ''Downton Abbey'' as Matthew Crawley, the reluctant heir, will play the far more callow character Morris Townsend in a revival of ''The Heiress.'' He will star opposite the previously announced Jessica Chastain as Catherine Sloper, the title role, and David Strathairn as Catherine's father, who regards Morris as a gold digger. Mr. Stevens has acted extensively in British theater, including in the lead role of the tutor Septimus in the 2009 West End revival of Tom Stoppard's ''Arcadia.'' ''The Heiress'' role will be his Broadway debut. Performances are set to begin in October.

There was a time, in mid-2000, when Google generated a paltry 1 percent of search. In the four-week period ending on April 28, Google had almost two-thirds of all search share, and together with Yahoo and Bing, accounted for 94 percent of all activity. Microsoft has spent years revamping its search business (it replaced Windows Live Search and MSN search with Bing in June 2009). Last week it announced a partnership with Facebook, to incorporate the ''likes'' and activities of a user's friends alongside search results on Bing. Any challenge is still a daunting task. Even if counting Bing and Yahoo together (since Bing powers Yahoo search) all Bing-related search accounts for slightly less than half of Google's share, with 30 percent.

An article on Tuesday about a Texas landowner, Julia Trigg Crawford, and her objection to TransCanada's effort to appropriate some of her property for the Keystone XL pipeline, described incorrectly ''diluted bitumen,'' the material that would be carried by the pipe. Bitumen is very dense crude oil diluted with liquid natural gas; it is not very dense crude mixed with sand and water.

An article on Thursday about efforts by professional sports to prevent athletes from having their finances derailed after retirement misstated part of the name of a company that consults on sudden wealth and financial windfalls. It is the Sudden Money Institute, not the Sudden Wealth Institute.

Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about a veto by Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey of an online health-insurance marketplace misstated, in some copies, the title of a lawmaker who criticized the governor's action. The lawmaker, Louis Greenwald of Camden, is an assemblyman, not a senator. (As the article correctly noted, Mr. Greenwald is the leader of the Democratic majority in the Assembly.)

Jay-Z may have one of the most successful and lucrative careers in hip-hop, a talented and renowned wife, a much cooed-over baby girl and part ownership in the soon-to-be Brooklyn Nets basketball franchise. But does he have his own two-day music festival? Well, he'll soon have that, too. On Monday, it is expected to be announced that Jay-Z will be the curator of and headlining performer at the first Budweiser Made in America music festival, a two-day event that will bring as many as 28 musical acts to Fairmount Park in Philadelphia on Sept. 1 and Sept. 2. (Sorry, Brooklyn, but hasn't Jay-Z done enough for you already?) The festival, which will be produced by Live Nation, is to be formally unveiled at a Monday morning news conference with Jay-Z and Mayor Michael A. Nutter of Philadelphia and will assemble an eclectic lineup of ''rock, hip-hop, R&B, Latin and dance'' musicians, according to a news release from its organizers. No other acts chosen by Jay-Z were immediately announced, but when you have Kanye West on speed dial and share a home with Beyoncé, presumably opportunities are rife.

Add public broadcasters to the media outlets aiming for the 50-plus crowd: a Web site called Next Avenue will go live on Tuesday, a year after first planned, with original and aggregated journalism directed at baby boomers. Under the slogan ''where grown-ups keep growing,'' Next Avenue will pull together content, including video, from existing public television series, government agencies and a long list of contributors from inside and outside public television.

Sometimes, artists' homes are turned into museums after they die. Perhaps fittingly in the case of Mike Kelley, the anarchic Detroit-born artist who committed suicide in January, a museum of sorts dedicated to his memory will now be built as an almost precise replica of his childhood suburban ranch home - down to the dimensions of the walls and the white siding. The project, ''Mobile Homestead,'' had been in the planning stages for several years, and a small piece of the home, a trailer-house-size recreation of part of its facade, made a kind of ancestral journey - on wheels, towed behind a truck - in 2010 from downtown Detroit back to the suburb of Westland where the former Kelley family home still stands. (Three videos that Mr. Kelley made documenting that journey and other parts of the project will be shown as part of the Whitney Biennial beginning May 16.)
An article on Thursday about fitness programs in retirement communities misstated the name of one such community in some references. It is Orchard Cove, in Canton, Mass. -- not Orchard Grove.

LEINER--Henrietta Chafets, 98. Neuroscientist, computer pioneer and beloved wife of the late Alan Leiner. Born in New York, she died on May 12, 2012 in Palo Alto, CA. Her remarkable career began with mathematical work for the United States government during WWII. Her scientific legacy includes her significant discovery of the cognitive capability of the human cerebellum. She is survived by her admiring and loving family: her sister, children, cousin, nieces, nephews, grandchildren and great-grandchildren. A memorial celebration will be held at a later date.

8 P.M. (HBO) THE WEIGHT OF THE NATION More than two-thirds of the adults in the United States and one-third of children are overweight, leading to an increase of deaths from heart disease, Type 2 diabetes, cancer, stroke and kidney disease. This four-part documentary -- a collaboration among HBO, the Institute of Medicine, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, and the National Institutes of Health -- is at the center of a public health campaign that includes a book, a social media component and a nationwide outreach to more than 40,000 community organizations. This first installment, ''Consequences'' (above, a scene from the film), explores the health effects of being overweight. Part 2, ''Choices,'' at 9:10, investigates the science of weight loss and offers diet and exercise tips that will help people find success. Parts 3 and 4 will be broadcast on Tuesday, starting at 8. 2 P.M. (AMC) CINDERELLA MAN (2005) In this biopic from Ron Howard, Russell Crowe, right, portrays James J. Braddock, the Depression-era heavyweight boxing champion with a 75-inch reach, who on June 13, 1935, fought the fight of his life against Max Baer (Craig Bierko), a k a the Livermore Larruper, whose reach was 81 inches. But it's the face-off between Braddock and his manager, Joe Gould (Paul Giamatti), that gives the film its bite. One of its satisfactions is that the story that unfolds inside the ring is not the same one the filmmakers seem keen to sell, Manohla Dargis said in The New York Times. ''Their Cinderella Man is the decent little guy who affirms what movie people call the triumph of the human spirit,'' she wrote. ''The story Mr. Crowe tells, with Mr. Giamatti as a gleeful Mephistopheles, is that of a man who, having sampled the blood of others, clearly enjoyed the taste.''

Davis, shoulders a large chunk of the blame for its stunning fall. Yet amid the recriminations, two sharply divergent views of Mr. Davis have emerged.

KARPAS--Irving D.,Jr. It is with profound sadness that the entire Beth Israel Medical Center community joins with the leadership of its parent company, Continuum Health Partners, in acknowledging the passing of our dear friend, devoted colleague, generous benefactor and one of the outstanding leaders in the history of the hospital, Irving D. Karpas, Jr. Irv, as he was affectionately known to many of us, joined the Beth Israel Board of Trustees in 1972, following in the footsteps of his late father, Irving D. Karpas, Sr. Irv's tenure on the Board coincided with the most prolific period of growth and expansion in the hospital's illustrious history. He served with great distinction in numerous roles during his years of dedicated service on the Board, most notably as the longtime Chairman of the Phillips Beth Israel School of Nursing. With his beloved wife Suzanne Toor Karpas, who later joined Irv on the Beth Israel Board, they generously supported many facilities, programs and services at Beth Israel. The Karpas name is linked in perpetuity to Beth Israel through the naming of the Karpas Medical Pavilion, the Karpas Health Information Center and numerous initiatives at the School of Nursing, among many others. He will forever be remembered for his quiet demeanor, steady leadership and extraordinary commitment to the mission of the hospital. And he will be greatly missed by all who knew him, worked with him, and admired him. To Suzanne, their children Michelle, Matthew, Jennifer, Patricia, Bruce, Steven, Debra and Peter, the entire Karpas family and all of his loved ones, we extend most heartfelt condolences. Steven Hochberg Chairman, Board of Trustees Continuum Morton P. Hyman Founding Chairman Emeritus Stanley Brezenoff President and CEO Robert G. Newman, MD President Emeritus Harris M. Nagler, MD President, Beth Israel Anne Moses Director Karpas Health Information Center Beth Israel

KERN--Estelle, on May 12, 2012. Wife of the late Harold Kern. Mother of Emily, Allen (Salena) and Donald. Grandmother of Adam and Jonathan. Services were held at Riverside Cemetery, Saddle Brook, NJ on Sunday. Services were handled by Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 908-964-1500.

KARPAS--Irving D. Jr.,87, of Manhattan and Ridgefield, CT, died at his home in Connecticut on May 12th after a long illness. He was the son of Irving D. and Janet Karpas, and is survived by his loving wife of 45 years, Suzanne Toor Karpas, and his eight adoring children, Michele Kennedy, Matthew Karpas, Jennifer Chernus, Patricia Karpas, Bruce Karpas, Steven Karpas, Debra Geller and Peter Karpas. He was also the beloved grandfather of 14 grandchildren and two greatgrandchildren. Irving attended Union College in Schenectady, NY and was a Navy veteran of World War II. He was formerly a senior partner of Herzfeld & Stern, a securities brokerage firm in New York. Irving and Suzanne continued a longstanding family tradition of philanthropy started by Irving's late father, Irving D. Karpas Sr., who in 1925 established the Karpas Pavillion at Beth Israel Hospital. For over 30 years, Irving and Suzanne have been steadfast supporters of countless programs at Beth Israel Medical Center including The Karpas Health Information Center, which they founded in 1981 to provide free critical health information to the local community. They have supported numerous clinical care and research initiatives, and have been deeply involved with the Phillips Beth Israel School of Nursing, where Irving served as Chairman of the Board of Trustees. Suzanne and Irving also established "Isabel's Suite" in honor of their granddaughter, a family-centered program that is part of the neonatal intensive care unit, at St. Lukes Roosevelt Hospital. Irving's philanthropy also extended to Hebrew Union College and Rockefeller University. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Karpas Health Information Center or Phillips Beth Israel School of Nursing. A memorial service will be held at Temple Rodeph Shalom (7 West 83rd Street) in New York City at 10am on Wednesday, May 16.

Tim Burton's tepidly reviewed ''Dark Shadows'' wilted under the holdover heat of ''Marvel's The Avengers,'' which took in an astounding $103.2 million at North American theaters in its second weekend. That No. 1 total pushed the domestic gross for ''The Avengers'' (Disney) to about $373.2 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box office data. ''Dark Shadows,'' a $150 million horror comedy starring Johnny Depp, was a distant second, with about $28.8 million in ticket sales. Based on the 1960s-era vampire soap opera, ''Dark Shadows'' (Warner Brothers) looked solid on paper despite Hollywood's mixed success at adapting TV shows for the big screen: Mr. Burton and Mr. Depp have a track record for delivering hits, including the 2010 smash ''Alice in Wonderland.'' But ''Dark Shadows'' was wobbly even without ''The Avengers'' tidal wave. Warner's marketing campaign, while visually stunning, had a hard time clearly positioning Mr. Burton's offbeat movie (is it a comedy? a campy horror movie? an ''Addams Family'' update?), and some analysts worry that audiences are becoming blasé about Mr. Depp's eccentric characters. Word of mouth was also chilly, with audiences giving ''Dark Shadows'' a B-minus in exit polls.

Henrik Lundqvist of the Rangers and Martin Brodeur of the Devils have faced each other 43 times in the regular season and the playoffs. Lundqvist has nearly a two-to-one edge in regular-season victories and the goaltenders have split eight playoff matchups. But Lundqvist's .469 winning peercentage in the playoffs over all is far inferior to Brodeur's .557, not to mention Brodeur's 3-0 advantage in Stanley Cup championships.

There is nothing a presidential campaign likes less than to be forced to answer for someone else's actions. And yetPresident Obama andMitt Romney are likely to face that challenge repeatedly during this election season as their allies and adversaries in Congress pursue agendas that do not always make things easy on the campaign trail.

The continuing lawsuit between Oracle and Google has raised a lot of thorny questions about patent violations, copyright violations and what constitutes a fair use of software. One other large question is not in the lawsuit itself: Why did Oracle bring this lawsuit in the first place? The answer is that most likely, Oracle is making a claim on the future.

KARPAS--Irving D.,Jr. The leadership, faculty, students and alumni of the Phillips Beth Israel School of Nursing (PBISN) are deeply saddened to acknowledge the passing of Irving D. Karpas, Jr., former Chairman of the School. Mr. Karpas provided outstanding leadership during both difficult and prosperous times, and forever will be remembered by many of us for his unyielding advocacy and support. Today, our School stands as one of the finest examples of nursing education due, in large part, to his tremendous efforts on our behalf. With his devoted wife, Suzanne Toor Karpas, they also provided extraordinary philanthropic support to help fund the education of those in need and to ensure that the PBISN always had the tools and the means to provide both the highest quality education and the highest quality student life. Our deepest sympathies are extended to Suzanne, the entire Karpas family, and to all whose lives were touched by this wonderful man. Janet Green Ruth Nerken Co-Chairs, Trustee Committee Janet Mackin, RN, EdD Dean
BILLER--Murray; August 26, 1928 - April 14, 2012. Retired attorney, beloved husband, father and grandfather. Donations in his memory may be made to the American Heart Association.

CATAPANO--Josephine. We mourn the loss of our cherished Jo who died on May 14, 2012. Born December 29, 1918, with roots in Brooklyn, NY, Jo graduated from Hunter High School and then Hunter College. Known by many as a "nose" and the first American woman perfumer of note, Jo designed Estee Lauder's Youth Dew and JHL, Guy Laroche's Fidji, Norell's Norell, and Shiseido's Zen, among others. Jo was a long time executive at International Flavors & Fragrances and her accolades include her 1980 Cosmetic Career Women's Award as well as her 1993 Lifetime Achievement Award from the American Society of Perfumers. Her family remembers her as a devoted, spirited, loving, sister, aunt, and great-aunt who enjoyed her life and lived it to the fullest. Jo was a caring and loving sister to brothers Patrick and John, who both predeceased her. She is mourned by many, including her sister, Carmella; her sister-in-law, Rosemarie; her nephews and nieces, Robert, William, Thomas, Lisa, Russell, Laura, and Gina; and the many great and great-great- nephews and nieces in her family, along with the millions that will be adorned by her creations for generations to come. Jo, you enriched our lives in countless ways, and will continue to do so with your sweet scents that charm and enchant so many. Your perfumes serve as a lasting legacy for the tremendous spirit that created them. Visiting Hours on Tuesday 2-4pm and 7-9pm at Edwin L. Bennett Funeral Homes, 824 Scarsdale Avenue Scarsdale, NY 10583 (914)725-1137. Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday 10:30am Immaculate Heart of Mary Church Scarsdale, NY.

BIEDLER--June L. The staff of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center mourns the death of June L. Biedler, Ph.D. Dr. Biedler, recognized for her groundbreaking work in cancer biology, particularly her discovery of the role of gene amplification in drug resistance, worked at the Center for 35 years until her retirement in 1994. She began her career at our institution when she joined the laboratory of Joseph A. Burchenal, M.D., a pioneer in the field of cancer chemotherapy. She was later appointed Chairman of the Cell Biology and Genetics Program in the Sloan-Kettering Institute, a position she held until her retirement. Dr. Biedler's research on drug resistance influenced the development of new strategies for cancer therapy, including combination therapies to more effectively treat the disease. Thousands of patients have benefited from her work and countless more will benefit in the future. We extend our sincere condolences to her family. Craig B. Thompson, President Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center Thomas J. Kelly, Director Sloan-Kettering Institute

Broadway plays are often limping at the box office in May, filling seats with Tony Award voters (who don't pay for tickets) before the annual ceremony, on June 10 this year. Several plays close right afterward, because of a lack of awards or because their star actors want to return to Hollywood (or go on vacation). But this month has been notably good for many plays, including some without stars. Last week 10 of the 14 plays on Broadway grossed more than 40 percent of the maximum possible amount - an indication that they broke even or turned a profit. ''Death of a Salesman,'' starring Philip Seymour Hoffman and Andrew Garfield, grossed by far the most, $934,861 - a total aided by top ticket prices of $425, the sort of premium pricing that usually only hit musicals can charge safely. Another revival, ''Gore Vidal's The Best Man,'' starring James Earl Jones, grossed $737,996 (with a top ticket of $225), while a third revival - ''A Streetcar Named Desire'' with Blair Underwood - took in $446,069 (with a $197.50 top ticket).

In its first paper, the group, called the Henry Jackson Initiative for Inclusive Capitalism, suggests companies should stop reporting earnings quarterly, to encourage investors to think over the longer term.

WHITE--Barbara D'Arcy. A design legend and our dear friend for over 45 years, Barbara was a larger than life personality who uniquely touched our lives and brightened our world. We will forever cherish the memories of our travels together to the Near and Far East where she would immerse herself in the local culture and customs, meticulously chronicling each experience and design detail. We will always remember sharing the Fourth of July fireworks in East Hampton, her wildly red hair, huge smile, oversized glasses and, above all, her infinite passion for life. A truly unforgettable woman who we were privileged to know, we will profoundly miss her. Our hearts go out to her beloved Kirk and Barbara's entire family. All our love, Lynn and Peter Tishman

An obituary on May 8 about Carl J. Bernadotte, who lost his title as a Swedish prince when he married a commoner, referred incorrectly to the landlord from whom he and his wife rented an apartment in Manhattan. The landlord, who was not named in the obituary, was a woman (Rose Cumming, a well-known interior designer), not a man.

An article on Friday about the possibility that the European Union might ease the insurance-coverage provision contained in its planned embargo of Iranian oil misstated Iran's daily oil production. It is approximately 3.6 million barrels a day, according to the Energy Information Administration of the United States, not 2.2 million barrels, which is the amount of Iran's estimated daily exports. (As stated in the article, most of Iran's exports go to Asia.)

DRILLINGS--Irving, was born in Rzeszow, Poland in 1924. He survived the Nazi concentration camps and came to the United States in 1946, where he founded Arlette Fashions, a manufacturer of women's coats. He was a former member of the Board of Directors of Burlington Coat Factory. He is survived by his wife of 57 years Arlette, his daughter Fern (and Richard Bregman), his son Gary (and Nancy) and his grandchildren David, Michael and Jonathan. He was an avid reader of the New York Times and known for his sense of humor and engaging personality.

ROTHSCHILD--Christine E. (November 15, 1937 - May 12, 2012), passed away quietly at her home on Saturday, May 12, 2012, after a short illness. Beloved by Eric, her husband of fifty years, she will be missed and remembered by him and also by her sons Adam and Alan, her daughters-in-law Kathy and Sayada, and her grandchildren Ellen, William, Jaan and Gemma. Christine was a graduate and class officer of Simmons College in Boston. In her professional life, Christine served as a supervising public health nurse for the Westchester County Department of Health. Upon retirement, she volunteered with adults learning to read. She loved classical music and for many years she sang with the Hoff-Barthelson Festival Chorus. Her most notable trait, though, was her enduring love and dedication to her family. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Literacy Volunteers of Westchester County.

An article on Thursday about the intimidation some ultra-Orthodox Jews encounter in their community when they come forward with allegations of child sexual abuse misspelled the surname of a rabbi who is executive vice president of Agudath Israel of America, a powerful ultra-Orthodox organization. He is Rabbi Chaim Dovid Zwiebel, not Zweibel. (The error was repeated in an article on Friday about the Brooklyn district attorney, who must decide how to handle such cases.)

In the years leading up to JPMorgan Chase's $2 billion trading loss, risk managers and some senior investment bankers raised concerns that the bank was making increasingly large investments involving complex trades that were hard to understand. But even as the size of the bets climbed steadily, these former employees say, their concerns about the dangers were ignored or dismissed. An increased appetite for such trades had the approval of the upper echelons of the bank, including Jamie Dimon, the chief executive, current and former employees said.

KARPAS--Irving D.,Jr. The Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion family mourns the death of Irving D. Karpas, Jr., business leader and philanthropist. His devotion to the College-Institute spanned 35 years. He served as a New York Overseer and then as a member of the Board of Governors during the growth and expansion of both the New York and Jerusalem campuses. He was dedicated to perpetuating the values, teachings and ethics of Judaism and his deep devotion to his family was manifested in all his endeavors. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his dear wife, Suzanne, their children and grandchildren. May the family find comfort together with all those who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi David Ellenson, President Irwin Engelman, Chairman of the Board of Governors

Facebook is planning to increase the price for its eagerly awaited initial public offering to a level that could value the company as much as $104 billion. Because of high investor demand, the social network behemoth will seek a price in the range of $34 to $38 a share, up from an earlier $28 to $35 a share, people with knowledge of the matter said on Monday evening because the discussions were private. In Asia alone, Facebook's offering is more than 25 times oversubscribed, said a person briefed on the matter.

Recently my wife and I went on an epic hunt to uncover everything possible about baby formula. We scoured more Web sites than I'd like to admit to and learned about all the options: powder, liquid, milk-based, soy, D.H.A.- and A.R.A.-fortified. (I'm still not clear on what A.R.A. is, exactly.) Then we learned that none of it actually matters. Since the Infant Formula Act of 1980, the F.D.A. makes sure that all formula is pretty much the same, no matter which one you buy. Despite knowing this, I still insist on paying twice as much for Enfamil, which its maker claims is ''scientifically designed.'' (Aren't they all?) I splurge because Mead Johnson is a 107-year-old company that has been promoting a single baby-formula brand for more than 50 years. I figure that it's less likely to squander its name by skirting the rules or engaging in shoddy manufacturing than a company with less to lose. This peace of mind costs me about $7 per day.
International GANGSTER'S VATICAN TOMB

Australian triathlete Brad Kahlefeldt is hospitalized in San Diego with a suspected case of tuberculosis, which jeopardizes his training and possibly his chance of competing in the London Olympics. Kahlefeldt, 31, fell ill while competing in the world championship series race at Mission Beach on Sunday when he experienced chest pains. He finished the race, placing 24th. He mentioned his chest pains to Triathlon Australia officials after the race, and was taken to the hospital.

Updated, 5:57 p.m. | As newspapers large and small struggle to survive financially in an increasingly digitized marketplace, more and more of them are looking for ways to charge their online readers. In New York, The Wall Street Journal, The New York Times and Newsday have, with varying degrees of success, tried paid digital subscriptions. One much smaller New York newspaper, though, has had a functional pay wall in place since 2003.

The City Room column on Thursday, about Barbra Streisand's plan to perform in Brooklyn for the first time since she graduated from Erasmus Hall High School, misspelled her father's given name and also referred incorrectly to another student of the high school. Mr. Streisand was Emanuel, not Emmanuel. And the other student, the chess champion Bobby Fischer, dropped out of Erasmus Hall; he did not graduate.

Five years ago, on a muggy August morning in Hicksville, N.Y., Ann Kornhauser was out walking her golden retriever when bones in her left foot suddenly cracked. Ms. Kornhauser, then in her late 50s, soon learned why: doctors discovered a rare tumor in her foot. They amputated half of it. The prosthetic foot she received afterward left her in constant pain; she often cried in her car after trips to the grocery store because she dreaded carrying the bags into the house. Her prosthetist offered a solution. Artificial limbs had greatly improved, he said, and she could benefit from one of the new high-tech models -- but it would fit only if her left leg was amputated below the knee.

There is no good time for a presidential candidate to face what Mitt Romney faced last week, when The Washington Post reported that he had tormented a fellow student while at prep school in the 1960s.
