A Moody's Investors Service analyst said on Monday that JPMorgan Chase's big trading loss underscores the rating agency's deliberations over whether to cut the credit ratings of 17 global banks. The analyst, Peter Nerby, who is involved in the Moody's review of bank ratings, said the fact that an institution with a ''deserved reputation'' as a skilled risk manager could lose $2 billion because of weak internal controls showed that the big banks were carrying risks that were not fully apparent in their current ratings.

Conflicting signs are emerging in Washington over whether JPMorgan Chase's surprise trading loss will spur tighter regulation on Wall Street. One of the banking industry's main regulators appeared to indicate that it would oppose new efforts to rein in risky Wall Street activities, while other regulators emphasized caution. Still, a Congressional committee announced plans on Monday to hold a hearing on the financial regulatory overhaul that will look at the JPMorgan loss. Wall Street's representatives, fearing that the entire banking industry might pay for JPMorgan's sins, are trying to contain the fallout in Washington, people close to the matter said.

MITCHELL--Elaine, teacher, poet and vibrant participator in life, passed away on May 12, 2012. She was born in New York on July 22, 1924. Her husband, and the love of her life, Ruben Mitchell, predeceased her in 1984. Elaine graduated from Hunter College with a Bachelors Degree and earned her Masters at the University of California at Berkeley. She taught high school English in the public school system in the Bronx, finishing her career as an Assistant Principal. At 87, Elaine was still feisty, irreverent, curious and forever learning. A life-long lover of literature, she wrote beautifully; rewarding her readers with poems of wit and sparkle. She never stopped trying, doing, giving and enjoying. Elaine was always animated, interested and interesting. She was devoted to her friends and family. She leaves a step-son, Swami Paramananda Saraswati and many nieces and nephews. Her verve will be missed by all who knew her.

''If I go there will be trouble, and if I stay it will be double.'' That dilemma, grittily framed by the British rock band the Clash, could serve as a warning to JPMorgan Chase as it considers what to do with the soured bet that has already produced $2 billion of losses.

A national survey of more than 12,000 students in grades 5 to 10 has found that television viewing is associated not only with unhealthy snacking while watching, but also with unhealthy eating at all times. Researchers asked the children how much TV they watched; how often they snacked while watching; how often they ate fruits, vegetables and candy and drank soda; and how often they skipped breakfast.

I used to run with a guy who was unhappy with the way his performance had deteriorated over the years. In his early 20s, he said, he had been super-fast. A couple of decades later and about 20 pounds heavier, he had lost that amazing speed. ''Too many miles on the tires,'' he would say. His idea was that if you start racing when you are young, you will be worse in middle age than if you started fresh when you were older.

An obituary on May 3 about Earl Rose, who was the Dallas County medical examiner when President John F. Kennedy was assassinated, misstated where Dr. Rose completed a residency in forensic pathology. It was the Medical College of Virginia (now part of Virginia Commonwealth University), not the University of Virginia.

As far back as I can remember, I have been more at home in water than on land. My father taught me to swim at age 3, and I've been an enthusiast ever since. While most of my aquatic adventures have been relatively tame, a few have been remarkable. I've swum with piranhas in the Amazon, sharks and penguins in the Galápagos, schools of tropical fish off Papua New Guinea, an octopus at the Great Barrier Reef, and sea lions off the coast of Mexico.

KARPAS--Irving D.,Jr. The Rockefeller University community deeply mourns the passing of our cherished friend and generous benefactor Irving D. Karpas, Jr. A member of The Rockefeller University Council for twenty-six years, Irv was a devoted partner in our efforts to further scientific knowledge for the benefit of human health. He and his beloved wife, Suzanne, supported a number of initiatives at the University, including research related to coronary heart disease and cancer. Beyond Rockefeller, Irv championed countless causes throughout New York City to help improve healthcare and advance clinical research. We celebrate a life well lived, and we extend our heartfelt sympathy to Suzanne and the entire Karpas family. Russell L. Carson, Chair David Rockefeller, Honorary Chairman Marc Tessier-Lavigne, President Marnie Imhoff, Vice President
LEVITT--Robert, Hackensack, NJ, May 13. Military: Lt. Cdr., U.S. Navy, WWII. Textile broker, Burlington Ind. Survived by wife Bernice, children, Susan, Debra, Helaine; grandchildren, Zoe, Nick.

WASHINGTON -- Most Americans suspect that President Obama was motivated by politics, not policy, when he declared his support for same-sex marriage, according to a new poll released on Monday, suggesting that the unplanned way it was announced shaped public attitudes. Sixty-seven percent of those surveyed by The New York Times and CBS News since the announcement said they thought that Mr. Obama had made it ''mostly for political reasons,'' while 24 percent said it was ''mostly because he thinks it is right.'' Independents were more likely to attribute it to politics, with nearly half of Democrats agreeing.

Hannah, the spunky central character in the edgy new HBO series ''Girls,'' is a creative and endearingly naïve 24-year-old bumbling fearlessly through postcollege life. She works for years at an unpaid internship that never turns into a job and pretends to be far more sophisticated about sex than she actually is. She's a loyal friend, but whatever you do, don't ask her about human papillomavirus, or HPV. She's clueless. The much-discussed third episode of the series, which aired in late April, was rife with misinformation about HPV, a reflection of the real confusion felt by twentysomethings - or perhaps just by the show's writer, Lena Dunham, who plays Hannah.
It's a pretzel palace of incredible complexity. GOV. JERRY BROWN,

WEDEMEYER--Richard Alan. The Jim Henson Legacy mourns the loss of our dear friend, colleague and co-founder of the Jim Henson Legacy. Richard's (Dick) guidance, vision and wisdom was, and will continue to be, our inspiration. The Trustees of the Jim Henson Legacy

Coty said on Monday that it was abandoning its pursuit of Avon Products, citing Avon's ''unwillingness to engage in discussions.'' On Thursday, Coty, which had been making overtures to the rival beauty products company since last year, raised its unsolicited offer to $10.7 billion. That was up from an offer of $10 billion made in March and disclosed on April 2 that was rebuffed. But Coty also set a deadline of Monday for Avon to enter into negotiations.

Ron Paul just called it quits - sort of. In an e-mail to supporters, Mr. Paul said he would no longer actively campaign in states that have not yet held Republican presidential primaries. To do so, he said, ''would take many tens of millions of dollars we simply do not have.''

GOLUB--Ellen. We mourn the loss of Ellen Golub. She was the adored daughter of Florence and Carl, wonderful sister to Arianne and Rob and loving aunt to Katie, Amanda and Henry. She was an inspiration to all who knew her and we will forever feel her presence. Robin & Scott Gottlieb

SCHWIMMER--Jules Stanley. December 6, 1929 May 13, 2012. We mourn the passing of Jules Stanley Schwimmer, loving husband, father, father-in-law, grandfather, friend. Born on New York's Lower East Side, graduate of City College, President of Jules Schwimmer Associates, devoted Board Member (and past President) of Green Chimneys Children's Services. A man who was never at a loss for words, he delighted in having an audience for his stories, jokes, and poems. Survived by his wife of 61 years Barbara, daughters Linda Stern and Susan Schwimmer (Harry Sunshine), grandchildren Benjamin and Daniel Stern, Reuven, Hannah, and Gil Sunshine, and brother Louis. Services: Tuesday, May 15th Riverside Memorial Chapel, Mount Vernon 12:00pm. Donations in his honor to Friends of Green Chimneys, 400 Doansburg Rd., Box 719, Brewster, NY 10509-0719.

As Yahoo's latest chief executive and newest board members settle into their roles, they will be confronted with the same problem that has bedeviled their predecessors: how to fix one of Silicon Valley's most crisis-plagued companies. The turnaround effort will be led for now by Ross B. Levinsohn, whose roots lie in media, advertising and deal-making.

BUCHOLT--Pearl (Schneiweis) died May 12, age 93. She is mourned by Joe, her husband of 70 years, and their children, Geraldine Levey and Carl Bucholt, and son-in-law Franklin Levey. Pearl was a one-and-only: charming, intelligent, persistent, selfless, principled; an artist, a dancer, a worker, an intellect, a reader, a hostess, a gardener; a progressive, an atheist, an advocate of women's and civil rights, a traveler, a film buff, a snorkeler. Pearl was a life member of the Art Student's League, received a Certificate from the New School of Social Research, an award winner at the Richter Art Show, a Board member of the Lake Waubeeka (CT) Assn. She made a lasting impression on her grandchildren Robyn Laveman, Daniel Bucholt, Wendy Levey, and Maya Bucholt, their spouses: Michael, Sarah, and Ignacio, and her five great-grandchildren. "We grew up in the comforting cloud of our grandmothers unconditional love, light, laughter, hugs, kisses, joy, cooking, encouragement, optimism, acceptance, strength, humor, grace and goodness. She danced with us, swam with us, drew and painted with us, traveled with us, gardened with us, shared old stories with us, passed traditions down to us, and smiled every time she saw us. We love you bubbe (and we were listening all along.)" Robyn, Daniel, Wendy and Maya. A memorial service will be held at the Jewish Community Center, 334 Amsterdam Avenue, on June 2nd at 1pm.

An article on April 28 about a city crackdown on illegal hotels misstated the name of one hotel and the amenities it offered. When the city shut down a hotel on West 173rd Street in Washington Heights in 2011, it was known as Eden House -- not Pied-A-Terre, which was the name of a hotel previously operated at the property by a tenant. And while Pied-A-Terre had offered access to barbecue equipment, the Eden House was not doing so when it was shut down, according to the property owner.

Benjamin Millepied's company, L.A. Dance Project, will make its first appearance on the East Coast with October performances at Montclair State University's Peak Performances series, it was announced on Wednesday. Also on the bill are a new chamber opera about the African-American artist Clementine Hunter, created in part by Robert Wilson; a new and so-far untitled work by Laurie Anderson and the Kronos Quartet; performances by South Africa's Via Katlehong dance group, the Richard Alston Dance Company and the Jasmin Vardimon Company; and the first presentation of ''Dog Days,'' a mix of ''opera, musical theater and rock-infused concert music'' set in an imaginary ''war-torn United States,'' Peak Performances said. ''Dog Days'' is the work of David T. Little, Royce Vavrek, Robert Woodruff, Judy Budnitz and Alan Pierson. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

DUTKA--Charlotte S.,of Carlsbad, CA, formerly Pound Ridge and Scarsdale, NY. Died on May 12 at the age of 91. Hunter College class president, renowned kindergarten teacher, tennis buff, compassionate matriarch, inspiration to family and countless friends. Loving wife of Leonard, mother of Elaine, Mark, and Richard, sister of Marvin and Lillian, doting grandmother of Annie and Zoe. "Chuckie" was energetic, witty and generous, living fully and forcefully until the end. Her "transition" is our loss. Donations to Rick Dutka Memorial Fund c/o The Tides Foundation 415-561-6400; Southern Poverty Law Center 334-956-8200; The ALS Assn. 888-949-2577. Services Friday, May 18, 11am at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave., New York City. Interment immediately following at Mt. Pleasant Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY.

During the Eastern Conference finals between the Rangers and the Devils, The New York Times will revisit some of the memorable characters of the 1994 conference finals between the teams. On May 15, 1994, the Rangers and the Devils met at Madison Square Garden in Game 1. After the Devils' Claude Lemieux tied the score, 3-3, with 43 seconds left in regulation, Stephane Richer scored the winning goal in the second overtime for the Devils. Now 45, Richer spoke by telephone from Montpellier, Quebec, where he owns a golf course. Q.

Joyce Redman, a distinguished Irish-born actress widely acclaimed for her intelligent stage presence in Shakespearean drama and French comedy, though probably best known to American audiences for her silent improvisation with a lobster, an oyster, a pear and Albert Finney in the exuberantly lascivious eating scene in the 1963 film ''Tom Jones,'' died on Wednesday in Kent, England. She was 96. Her son, the actor Crispin Redman, told the BBC that Ms. Redman died of pneumonia after a brief illness.

LINCOLN, Neb. - Republicans have long salivated over the prospect of capturing Nebraska's open Senate seat, a triumph that would increase their odds of winning a majority in the Senate and taking full control of Congress. But the party's effort to defeat Bob Kerrey, the native son and former senator who returned here from New York to bolster Democrats' hopes, is taking a back seat to a fiercely competitive Republican primary fight that features a familiar tug-of-war between establishment and insurgent candidates that has become a growing theme in Republican contests across the country.

A theater review on Saturday about ''Sophie Gets the Horns,'' at the Incubator Arts Project at St. Mark's Church on East 10th Street in Manhattan, referred incorrectly to the character played by Adriano Shaplin. The character is a male student, not a female student.

From the Department of Ewwwwwww: Amy Winehouse and Pete Doherty were never the best influences on each other, and their latest and presumably final collaboration - a painting made using their blood - has proved another disappointment, yielding only about half the price it was expected to draw at an auction in London, The Guardian reported. Before her death last July, Ms. Winehouse, a soul singer who struggled with drugs and alcohol, had had a relationship with Mr. Doherty, a fellow musician and troubled soul. During their time together they worked on a painting called ''Ladylike,'' for which Ms. Winehouse contributed a minimalist self-portrait and which uses an artistic technique Mr. Doherty calls ''arterial splatter'': illustrations made with blood from a syringe or a sliced-open fingertip.

''Jimmy Kimmel Live'' will produce a week of shows at the Brooklyn Academy of Music in October, reports Bill Carter in the Media Decoder. Guests will include people with Brooklyn connections, and the show will venture into the neighborhoods of the borough. Mr. Kimmel was born in Mill Basin in 1967, and lived in Brooklyn during his early childhood. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Television viewers tuned in to say goodbye to the residents of Wisteria Lane on Sunday as the series finale of ''Desperate Housewives'' on ABC was the most-watched program of the night. The two-hour show added more viewers every half hour and finished with an average of 11.1 million and a 19 percent bump in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic compared to last week, according to Nielsen. While far below the 24 million viewer average of the show's water cooler-fueled first season, the finale was easily the best ratings performance for the series since March 2011. Elsewhere, ''Survivor: One World'' helped CBS secure second place with an average of 10.2 million viewers for the two-hour finale and another 8 million for the reunion episode that followed.

NEAMAN--Robert Gordon, age 68, died on May 2nd, 2012, surrounded by family and friends. The cause was lung cancer. Born October 17th, 1943 in Washington D.C., he lived in Mamaroneck, NY and Lee, MA, and worked at Educage and then White Plains High School. Bob was an avid music lover, photographer, and, most of all, proud grandfather. He is survived by his wife Christiane Neaman, daughters Julia Klagsbrun and Alexis Roberts, and five grandchildren, all of Katonah, NY. Services will be private.

Probiotics - live micro-organisms that offer some benefit to their host - significantly reduce the risk for diarrhea caused by taking antibiotics, a review of 82 trials has concluded. Most of the studies tested species of Lactobacillus, found in yogurt, cheese and other foods. Others tested combinations of Lactobacillus with other probiotic organisms.

8 P.M. (HBO) THE WEIGHT OF THE NATION More than two-thirds of the adults in the United States and one-third of children are overweight, leading to an increase in deaths from heart disease, Type 2 diabetes, cancer, stroke and kidney disease. This four-part documentary -- a collaboration by HBO, the Institute of Medicine, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and the National Institutes of Health -- is at the center of a public health campaign that includes a book, a social media component and an effort to reach more than 40,000 community groups. Part 3, ''Children in Crisis,'' looks at the struggle of overweight children and at their medical issues; above, a middle school gym class in Austin, Tex. It also examines school lunch standards and the debate over the definition of good nutrition among food and beverage makers, researchers and the government. The conclusion, ''Challenges,'' at 9:10, explores factors behind the obesity epidemic, including subsidized agriculture, evolutionary biology, racial and socioeconomic disparities, physical inactivity and the strong influence of the food and beverage industry. ''It wouldn't surprise me if people look back on the early part of the 21st century and call this the obesity era,'' says Dr. Thomas Farley, the New York City health commissioner. 9 A.M. (Sundance) ENCOUNTERS AT THE END OF THE WORLD (2008) For this documentary Werner Herzog traveled to Antarctica, where he met scientists and journeymen at the American outpost McMurdo Station and the penguins, seals, clams and jellyfish that surround them on what might as well be another planet. ''Few filmmakers make the end of days seem as hauntingly beautiful as Werner Herzog does, or as inexorable,'' Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. One of the film's beauties, Ms. Dargis said, ''is that all the furry and floating animals are no more wondrous than the bipeds tramping through and around McMurdo: the linguist turned philosopher, the banker turned bus driver, and the female adventurer who, for drama and odd entertainment, likes to have herself zipped up in a carryall bag. (She's her own baggage.) Mr. Herzog opens his mind, heart and eyes to all these wayfarers who -- despite the persistent strain of melancholy that touches each and every person who appears on camera -- seem eerily at peace at the bottom of the world.'' The film received an Oscar nomination for best documentary feature.

An obituary on Saturday about the pilot and flying instructor Evelyn B. Johnson misstated the year of her birth. She was born on Nov. 4, 1909, not 1908. (As correctly noted in the obituary and the headline, she was 102 when she died.)

Because of an editing error, a picture caption on Wednesday with an article about a record fine for illegal advertising signs that were removed from the SoHo-Cast Iron Historic District misidentified the location of two ''grandfathered'' ads that were shown. The Aldo and Burberry ads pictured were on Houston Street, between Crosby and Lafayette Streets, not at 598 Broadway, where the illegal signs had been taken down. (The block with the ''grandfathered'' ads was added to the historic district; the block on which 598 Broadway stands had always been part of that district.)

Slip on your dancing shoes, Ellen DeGeneres, because you have something to celebrate. On Tuesday it was announced that Ms. DeGeneres, the comedian and highly animated daytime talk-show host, would be the recipient of the 15th annual Mark Twain Prize for American Humor. The award, given by the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington to ''people who have had an impact on American society in ways similar to'' Mark Twain, the arts organization said in a news release, will be presented to Ms. DeGeneres at a ceremony on Oct. 22 that will be recorded for a later broadcast. David M. Rubenstein, the Kennedy Center chairman, said in a statement that Ms. DeGeneres was being honored for ''her special brand of humor'' that ''has allowed us to find hilarity in the mundane and has kept us laughing for years.'' Noting some of the esteemed comedians who have previously won the Mark Twain Prize, Ms. DeGeneres said in a statement: ''To get the same award that has been given to people like Bill Cosby, Tina Fey and Will Ferrell, it really makes me wonder why didn't I get this sooner?''

JEFFERY--Reuben Jr.,of Southport, CT beloved husband of the late Ann Thomas Jeffery, passed away peacefully in his home Saturday, May 5, 2012. Born January 31, 1923 in Syracuse, NY, the son of late Marie and Reuben Jeffery. He served in Japan with the U.S. Army 11th Airborne Division leaving the service at the end of the war as a Captain. Graduated from Yale, B.E. 1944 and Harvard Business School, M.B.A. 1949, with High Distinction and as a Baker Scholar. Thirty-five year career as an accounts manager, Polymer Products Department, E.I. DuPont de Nemours & Co. He is survived by his two children; Reuben Jeffery III of New York, NY and Martha Ann Jeffery of Bridgeport, CT; three grandchildren, Jocelyn Ann Jeffery, Reuben Jeffery IV and Robert Walker Jeffery; and his sister Jean Jeffery Greene of Syracuse, NY. He was predeceased by his brother, John Jeffery. A memorial service will be held Friday, May 18th 2012 at 11:00AM at Greenfield Hill Congregational Church, 1045 Old Academy Road, Fairfield, CT. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory can be made to Greenfield Hill Congregational Church.

Knoedler & Company and its former president, Ann Freedman, filed motions in federal court in Manhattan this week to dismiss a $17 million lawsuit from a customer who says the now-defunct Knoedler Gallery sold him a fake Jackson Pollock painting. The gallery and Ms. Freedman maintain that the work, dubbed ''Silver Pollock'' and now owned by Pierre Lagrange, a London collector, is authentic. The motions include affidavits by two experts who continue to support its authenticity and dismiss a forensic analysis that concluded the paint used was invented after Pollock's death. The gallery also argues that in any case ''sophisticated'' buyers have an obligation to do their own research.

President Obama remains a millionaire with assets that could reach around $8 million, thanks to proceeds from his two best-selling books and investments made possible by them, according to financial disclosure forms made public by the White House on Tuesday. The disclosures require only that Mr. Obama and his wife, Michelle, list the value of their assets in wide ranges. So the first family's assets, according to the disclosure, are valued between $2.6 million and $8.3 million. The president lists royalties from his memoir ''Dreams From My Father'' as between $100,000 and $1 million.

HITTING the road this summer? Better get booking. As the busy summer car-rental season begins, prices are expected to climb. ''In early June through the end of August, these rates will spike,'' said Neil Abrams, president of Abrams Consulting Group, which tracks the car rental industry. Last July, for example, the average rate for a weekly airport rental of a compact car booked seven days ahead was $369.62, or 56 percent more than the $236.73 charged in March, according to the Abrams Travel Data Index. Here are some tips to keep costs down.

HARD ROAD Shares in Avon Products, the troubled cosmetics maker, plunged 9.7 percent on Tuesday, after Coty withdrew its $10.7 billion takeover offer. At $18.71, Avon's stock is near a 52-week low. Avon's board may not have relished the idea of selling the company to a smaller rival, especially one that was prepared to sell itself to Avon only months before. But the evaporation of a deal means a lot of hard work may be ahead.

On the way, she'd listen to ''Take Care,'' the Drake album that had just come out.

We are beginning to see more national surveys now, including this week's New York Times/CBS News poll, which show Mitt Romney with a slight lead over President Obama in the general election matchup. To be sure, there are also a number of polls that put Mr. Obama slightly ahead. But his lead does seem to have narrowed - from about three or four points in an average of national polls a month or two ago to more like a point or so in surveys today. Has something fundamental changed in the race?

THERE'S a scene early on in ''Middle of Nowhere,'' one of this year's Sundance prize-winning films, when a young married couple bicker briefly in the visiting area of a prison: the room is pallid, even clammy, but the actors' faces are vibrant and vulnerable, held full-frame. It's a triumphant, even signature moment for the film's cinematographer, Bradford Young. ''I'm big on faces,'' Mr. Young said, his own collapsing into a sweet, easy grin. ''I like to fill the frame with heads. I use faces as landscapes, as architecture. That always feels like the right place to start.''

WHEN ''My Name Is Rachel Corrie'' was postponed and then pulled from the New York Theater Workshop in March 2006, the ensuing furor raged chiefly between critics of the play's unequivocal sympathy for the Palestinian cause and those, like Tony Kushner and Harold Pinter, who worried that the workshop had bowed to political censorship. But one kind of voice was conspicuously absent from the standoff over ''Corrie,'' a British play about an American activist killed in the Gaza Strip by an Israeli military bulldozer in 2003: that of Palestinians.

The curtain has come down on a lawsuit filed against the organizers of the Tony Awards and CBS by Bret Michaels, who said he had been injured by a piece of scenery in the awards show but has reached a settlement in the case, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Michaels, the frontman of the rock group Poison, was performing in the opening number of the 2009 Tony Awards show at Radio City Music Hall when a descending backdrop hit him on the head as he was leaving the stage. Mr. Michaels, who broke his nose and received three stitches in his lip, filed suit against the producers of the Tonys show, saying he was not warned about the set change in the opening number and that his injury contributed to a brain hemorrhage he was treated for in 2010. His lawsuit also named CBS, which shows the Tonys ceremony, saying the network did not have to broadcast his accident, which became a widely circulated video clip on the Internet.

Major League Baseball will announce on Wednesday that next year's All-Star Game will be held at Citi Field, according to a person with knowledge of the decision. The Mets were expected to be awarded the game after the Yankees hosted it in 2008, the last year the old Yankee Stadium and Shea Stadium were open. This will be the second time the Mets will act as hosts of the game; the first was in 1964, the year Shea Stadium opened.

BY all outward appearances this should be the happiest year of Steve Kazee's career. In January this 36-year-old actor finished an acclaimed Off Broadway run of the new musical ''Once,'' playing a bereft Dublin guitarist who falls for a Czech pianist. Now the show is on Broadway, and he has just received his first nomination for a best actor Tony Award. Virtually overnight Mr. Kazee (pronounced kuh-ZEE) has reached starry heights: Anna Wintour invited him to this month's Costume Institute Gala, where he was seated beside Mary-Kate Olsen and cut a dashing figure for the paparazzi in a Calvin Klein tux.

Lady Gaga is too risqué for Indonesia. The national police denied her a permit on Tuesday for a concert that was to have been held in early June after Islamic hard-liners mounted protests, complaining that her sexy clothes and suggestive dance moves will corrupt the youth, The Associated Press and Reuters reported. Boy Rafli Amar, a spokesman for the national police, told The Associated Press that the permit for the June 3 ''Born This Way Ball'' had been denied because the police in Jakarta could not guarantee the safety of the crowd. Some of the militant groups had threatened to use physical force to stop the show.

When life went sour, they turned to sweets. Denise Cumming, a stay-at home mom, became a gluten-free baker to satisfy a daughter with celiac disease. And Zachary Schmahl, a young entrepreneur, turned a baking hobby into a business when his marketing job disappeared in the recession. Both are opening shops this week. Ms. Cumming, 45, who is self-taught, named her bakery Pip's Place after her daughter, who is nicknamed Pippi. The Upper East Side shop has few seats and an open kitchen, where Ms. Cumming bakes cakes, above, as well as muffins, cookies and squares. In place of wheat flour, she uses white and brown rice flour and teff, a type of grain, as well as potato and corn starches, with excellent results. It took her four years of experimenting to come up with a satisfactory blend.

ISASI-DIAZ--Dr. Ada Maria, died on May 13, 2012 at age 69 after having received the Holy Sacraments. Ada Maria was born in La Habana, Cuba, on March 22, 1943, the daughter of Josefina Diaz de Isasi and Domingo G. Isasi-Battle (RIP 2005). She lived her youth in Cuba, studying in La Habana where she graduated from Merici Academy in 1960. She moved to the United States in 1960 with her family, and soon after entered the Ursuline novitiate in Santa Rosa, California. After finishing studies at New Rochelle College, NY, Ada was sent to Lima, Peru by the order to work among the poor in the "barriada de Miramar". There she became passionate in caring for the dispossessed and building the "kin-dom" of God. After leaving the convent in 1969, she lived with her family in the United States. Realizing that she had a continued calling to be an educator and a voice for the underprivileged, Ada Maria moved in 1975 to Rochester, New York where she served in two inner city parishes and became involved in the Women's Ordination Conference (WOC). Ada Maria earned a Masters of Divinity and a Doctorate in Theology from Union Theological Seminary, in New York City in 1990. At Union, she started her lifelong engagement and leadership in the community of Liberation Theologians. Continuing her commitment to women's issues, she coined the term Mujerista theology to make explicit the Latina voice in Feminist Liberation Theology. In 1991, Ada Maria became a professor of Ethics and Theology at Drew University, Madison, NJ from where she retired in 2009. Students were very fond of her and described her as someone who was a demanding teacher, fair, honest and passionate. While at Drew University, she co-founded the Hispanic Theological Institute for training of Hispanic Theologians.She was a prolific writer, completing eight books, and many scholarly articles.' Her seminal work was Mujerista Theology: a Theology for the 21st Century. She is survived and remembered by her mother, sisters, and brother, brothers-in-law and sisters-in-law, her nieces, nephews, great-nieces and great-nephews, friends and the community of women she mentored and inspired. Visiting hours will be held at Caballero-Rivero-Woodlawn, 8200 SW 40th Street, Miami, FL from 6:00pm until 9:00pm on May 18, 2012. A Mass of the Resurrection will be held at St. Thomas the Apostle Church, 7377 SW 64th Street, Miami, FL at 2:00pm on May 19, 2012; followed by the interment at Our Lady of Mercy Cemetery, 11411 NW 25th St, Miami, FL. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to either: Mary's Pence, 275 East 4th Street, #

An article on Sunday about college students' debt, and an accompanying chart, misstated the percentage of bachelor's degree recipients who had borrowed money for their education from the government, private lenders, or with the help of family members. The article stated that the percentage had increased to 94 percent from 45 percent in 1993, based on data from the Department of Education, whose officials reviewed The Times's methodology before publication. While the percentage of students borrowing for college has indeed increased significantly, the 94 percent figure reflected an inaccurate interpretation of the data, which came from a survey of 2007-2008 graduates. That survey showed that 66 percent of bachelor's degree recipients borrowed from the government or private lenders; an additional percentage of graduates had family members who borrowed on their behalf or who lent them money, meaning that the total percentage with college borrowing increased to more than 66 percent. But the precise figure isn't known because the department survey did not address borrowing involving family members. (The earlier survey, of 1992-1993 graduates, found that just 45 percent of graduates had borrowed from all sources, including from family members.)

State Senator Deb Fischer of Nebraska surged past the state's attorney general, Jon Bruning, on Tuesday to capture the Republican nomination for the closely watched contest for the Senate seat being vacated next year by Ben Nelson, a moderate Democrat. Ms. Fischer, a 61-year-old rancher who has not sought statewide office before now, upended expectations in Washington and scrambled the calculations of both parties. For months, the race was seen as a two-man contest between Mr. Bruning, 43, and Don Stenberg, the state treasurer who was endorsed by Senator Jim DeMint, a Tea Party kingmaker from South Carolina, and the conservative Club for Growth.

BYRNE--Patrick Dixon Bice. October 3, 1981-May 11, 2012. The world lost an unbelievably special soul whose life was taken away unexpectedly. Patrick is the adored son of Peggy Bice and J. Dixon Byrne; beloved stepson of Valerie DiFebo; precious brother of Molly Byrne, Bryan DiFebo Byrne, and Maggie and Alex Taylor; admired uncle of Andrew, Grace and Katherine Taylor; cherished grandson of Margaret S. Bice and the late James D. and Norma M. Byrne; treasured grand-nephew of Jack Byrne. Originally from Manhasset and Sea Cliff, NY; recently a resident of New Fairfield, CT. Patrick was an avid fisherman, accomplished musician, talented artist, lover of nature and his dog, Toby. The size of his heart was only surpassed by the love he had for his family and friends. His uncanny ability to comfort the hearts of others will never be matched. Patrick will be loved and held close to our hearts forever. Services will be conducted at Fairchild & Son Funeral Home in Manhasset, NY, Wednesday May 16, 2-5 and 7-9. The funeral mass will be held Thursday, May 17 at 10am, at St. Mary's RC Church in Manhasset, NY.

One problem with Treece, Kan., is that the ground keeps caving in. It has happened more than a hundred times over the last century. On most occasions, the subsidences -- that's what the scientists call them -- are small, like when a sofa-size crater opened up on 10th Street last year. Other times, they are much worse. In 1966, a 300-foot-wide, 200-foot-deep abyss swallowed up the road out on the edge of town. Somehow no one died. I first visited Treece in 2010. From the airport in Kansas City, it's a half-day's drive down Highway 69, the industrial sprawl giving way to fields of sunflowers and prairie grass. Then you enter a dust bowl, land so flat it's more like a dustpan -- so flat, in fact, that in 2003 researchers discovered that the entire state is flatter than an actual pancake, which the team purchased from one of the IHOPs that dot the landscape. Getting nearer to Treece, there are junk shops and single-wide trailers selling kittens and breeze-box Baptist churches with signs announcing, ''Hell Awaits.''

IN person Matt D'Elia is a considerate conversationalist, a generous listener who makes his points enthusiastically but leaves plenty of space for a reporter's responses and rebuttals. He is, in other words, nothing like the boorish, professed philosopher he portrays in the film ''American Animal,'' a dark chamber comedy he also wrote and directed. The movie, which opens on Friday in New York, is his debut feature. It focuses on a manic young man named Jimmy who faces a terminal disease not with the usual nobility of the cinematically ill, but with an overbearing devotion to raw hedonism and self-interest. ''Jimmy is pure id,'' Mr. D'Elia said recently. ''He's a dog with thumbs.''

The Global Update on Tuesday, about a study that concluded that performing more Caesarean deliveries in poor countries would save many mothers' lives and prevent many fistulas, described incorrectly an obstetric fistula. It is internal tearing that occurs in prolonged or obstructed labor after blood flow to vaginal tissue is interrupted, causing it to die -- not a vaginal tear in the delivery process that is so severe it reaches the rectum.

If you like black-and-white photography and Leica cameras, and have around $8,000 to spare, you might be interested to know that the German optics maker has introduced the newest addition to its M line of cameras: the M Monochrom. The mirrorless Monochrom has a dedicated 18-megapixel image sensor that lacks a color filter array, so you can only shoot 35-millimeter black-and-white photos. But if your inner Scrooge is asking why you should spend eight grand when you can remove color after the fact, one reason is the camera's dedicated sensor, which allows the M Monochrom to pick up more light. That, and the lack of a low-pass filter, helps churn out visibly crisper images than you're bound to get through post-processing.

ONE prescription for avoiding another real estate bubble is that banks tighten up mortgage requirements. Now, a new Federal Reserve report indicates that lenders have indeed been doing just that. A majority of banks are less likely to offer loans to people with a FICO credit score of 620 and a 10 percent down payment than they were in 2006, according to the report. Lenders were also less likely to do so even for those with a score of 720.

SLOAN--Hilda Sault. October 9, 1920 - May 15, 2012. Devoted wife of the late Paul Sault and the late Irving Sloan, beloved mother and mother-in-law of Barbara and Michael Peterman (Cleveland, Ohio), grandmother of Lauren DeMinico (Michael), and great-grandmother of Ellie and Samantha DeMinico. Hilda was an energetic and inspirational woman who was ahead of her time. She made her mark in a man's world before it was commonplace to do so, first in business as an executive with National Silver Company during World War II and later as the founder and organizer of the Women's Division of United Cerebral Palsy (UCP). Hilda served with great distinction as President of the New York UCP Women's Division and subsequently for many years as Chair of the National UCP Women's Committee as well as a trustee and vice president for National UCP. Beginning in the 1950's she was appointed to serve on the President's Committee for the Employment of the Handicapped by Presidents Eisenhower, Kennedy, Johnson and Nixon. Among her proudest accomplishments were the establishment of the national, annual UCP Telethons and the UCP/NYC Thrift Shop which raised millions of dollars for cerebral palsy. Partnering with her second husband, Irving Sloan, they opened six Sloan Fitness Centers throughout New York and Connecticut with equipment modified for use by individuals with physical disabilities. She was also active with Irving at the Southbury Training School in Danbury, Connecticut. Private graveside services will be held on Thursday, May 17. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the New York or Cleveland offices of United Cerebral Palsy. Hilda will be fondly remembered by her family and many friends for her love of life, kindness, sophistication, warmth and generosity.

An article on Saturday about proposed revisions pertaining to drug and alcohol addiction in the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, which have provoked controversy similar to that raised about earlier proposals regarding other disorders described in the manual, misstated, in some editions, one of those disorders. It is bipolar disorder, not bipolar personality disorder.

IT has happened to everyone. You are standing in the kitchen and you see something out of the corner of an eye. Was it a mouse scurrying across the floor, or worse, a cockroach dashing along the counter? Do you start feeling itchy every time an advertisement for a bedbug removal service comes on television?

ALEXANDRA CASSANITI, known for her surfer-girl neoprene swimsuits and gauzy cheesecloth tank tops and T-shirts, is now the ''creative curator'' of the Surf Lodge in Montauk, N.Y. For summer, Ms. Cassaniti has fitted out the beachside hot spot with some of her favorite eco-conscious brands, like Fresco towels and Coola sun-care products, all available for guests to purchase. And the swimwear and bags in her new Summer Bummer line, including this bandanna-print backpack made from waterproofed canvas, will be sold at the Surf Bazaar shop in the hotel. Even if you're not hitting the Hamptons, you can stock up on her assorted beach gear at summerbummer.com. Cotton canvas book bag with leather straps, $225 at summerbummer.com.

To the Editor: In her review of ''The Beginner's Goodbye'' (May 6), Julia Glass captured my recent feelings about Anne Tyler's novels: that the characters are too removed from the larger world and that things are a bit too easy for them. After years of finding Tyler's works lovely, funny, insightful about the details of relationships and always reliable as good books to take on vacation, I began to wonder why, for example, her characters never use obscenities or how they could stalk someone, leave a marriage or temporarily abandon their children without, seemingly, any real repercussions.

IT may be that the house of the future is an apartment -- at 420 square feet, a very small apartment -- in a century-old tenement building on Sullivan Street. Shiny and white, it has movable walls that allow it to morph from one room into six, as well as expandable furniture and filtered, or ''country,'' air, as the owner, Graham Hill, put it recently while showing off the apartment's convertible tricks like a modern-day Bernadette Castro, dressed neatly in a black merino wool polo shirt, black pants and black Vans. This laboratory, as Mr. Hill calls it, for small-space, sustainable and -- it must be stressed -- high-end living is the first tangible product from his fledgling company, LifeEdited. It comes with an awkward manifesto that nonetheless manages to gather an armful of social and economic trends and philosophies, including happiness research, the booming field of collaborative consumption (which uses new technology to share resources like cars, toys and books, on the Zipcar model) and data on the proven efficiencies of cities.

PRESERVATION groups are circling the deliciously decorated Con Ed powerhouse at 11th Avenue and 59th Street, as the 1904 structure, designed by Stanford White, nudges up for a third time to landmark designation. At the same time, a similar grand structure sits alone without fuss or bother, just working hard in elegant industrial simplicity. Few today notice the giant 1902 powerhouse at the foot of East 74th Street, or have heard of George H. Pegram, the engineer who designed it, but on the day he was buried, thousands of New Yorkers stopped in their tracks, literally.

Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, the private equity giant, is in talks to buy a stake in a money manager that focuses on hedge funds, people briefed on the matter said. A deal with the money manager, Prisma Capital Partners, which oversees nearly $8 billion in hedge fund investments, would accelerate K.K.R.'s evolution from a buyout shop to a large asset manager. The fund-of-funds business is one where K.K.R.'s chief rival, the Blackstone Group, has been expanding.

LOS ANGELES -- In his seven years as host of ''The Late Late Show'' on CBS, Craig Ferguson has had many an unusual broadcast, whether it was an episode partly lighted by flashlight when his studio lost power or an evening dedicated to the BBC science-fiction series ''Doctor Who.'' But until now Mr. Ferguson had never taken his show to Scotland, his home country. Following in the tradition of a series of ''Late Late Show'' episodes filmed in Paris last year, Mr. Ferguson traveled to Scotland in March, taking along his robot sidekick, Geoff Peterson, a team of celebrity pals like Mila Kunis, Rashida Jones, Michael Clarke Duncan and David Sedaris, and, wisest of all, some cameras to film his journeys there.

GROWING up in Chicago, I remember hearing stories of the architectural feats required to build the Sears (now Willis) Tower and the John Hancock Center, two of the tallest buildings in the world. Huge X-shaped braces, for example, were needed to absorb the biting winds that blew in from Lake Michigan.

IN the mid-1990s, Dana Fuchs arrived in New York from Florida -- alone, broke and hoping to find success as a singer and musician. She worked odd jobs, became a secretary, and in 2003 took over the role of Janis Joplin in the off-Broadway musical ''Love, Janis.'' Her throaty alto soon led to voiceover jobs for MTV. She landed in a one-bedroom rental in a fifth-floor walk-up on the Upper West Side.

The painter Anh Duong, 51, was born in Bordeaux, France, and grew up outside Paris. She moved to New York City in the late '80s and now lives in Greenwich Village and East Hampton, N.Y. BEE-SHYUAN CHANG WEDNESDAY, MAY 9

I was lucky enough to spend a few summers on Fire Island in the late '70s, and -- with no cars, no school, no schedule, no shoes -- it was a pretty happy place to be a kid. Most days, after a swim in the bay, I'd walk the narrow, sunny lanes and fill buckets with fat blueberries. Once a week, a club in one of the villages opened its doors early for the elementary-school set: for an hour or so, we got hopped up on soda and boogied to the Bee Gees and Donna Summer. For us, the living was easy, but this was not equally true for our mothers, many of whom were recently divorced or separated. They'd cluster together, our newly single moms, on one or another's deck and commiserate over white-wine spritzers, Dubonnet spritzers, Lillet spritzers. Melissa Manchester's rendition of ''Don't Cry Out Loud'' was a big hit back then, and to my considerable annoyance, my mother and her friends listened to it over and over, as if it gave voice to their collective grief.

Earlier this year, I announced an essay contest for teenagers about bullying. Some 1,200 essays later, we have our grand prize winner. Before I get to her story, let me share a sampling of the entrants who wrote poignantly and powerfully about the suffocating ostracism of school corridors and cafeterias.
HOME By Toni Morrison

PREPARE to turn heads on the holiday weekend in a sleek maillot, this season's freshest look for swimwear. ''As much as I think bikinis can be very tasteful, a well-cut one-piece has so much more impact,'' said Christene Barberich, the editor of the popular fashion site Refinery29. Modern with retro touches, this spring's one-piece styles have elegant silhouettes, with single shoulder straps, plunging necklines and punchy floral and animal prints. Ms. Barberich also loves the way a one-piece looks off the beach. ''There's nothing cooler than wearing a maillot under a high-waist pair of white wide-leg pants,'' she said. Clockwise from far left: Laura Urbinati one-shoulder swimsuit, $242 at Creatures of Comfort, 205 Mulberry Street; creaturesofcomfort.us; Zimmermann high-neck one-piece with plunging back, $230 at Zimmermann, 87 Mercer Street, (212) 226-6440; Roksanda

IF you're late to book your country house in Litchfield County this summer, do not despair. There are still plenty of houses available. Just don't expect a place with a pool -- most in Litchfield have already been snapped up. Agents throughout the bucolic northwest corner say that summer rentals have been moving at a steady pace. But because so many more homeowners are offering their houses for all or part of the season, supply remains plentiful in many towns.

Coty has selected underwriters for an initial public offering, according to people briefed on the matter, only two days after withdrawing a $10.7 billion takeover bid for Avon Products. Any offering is likely to value Coty at about $7 billion to $8 billion, and could raise as much as $1 billion.

TAKING A CALMER VIEW The $2 billion trading loss at JPMorgan Chase has led to worries about the bank's risk management, the danger of high-stakes trading by Wall Street and the shape of future financial regulation. But one prominent Republican lawmaker has posed a drastically different question: Why all the fuss?

The days grow long now, stretching into evenings purple and warm. We bank fires in the grill set up in the yard, out in the park, down by the beach, on a fire escape perched high over New York's fragrant streets. We cook steaks. Why not salad too? I set out to talk to Alan Ashkinaze about that. Ashkinaze is the longtime chef de cuisine for Laurent Manrique, the charming Frenchman who came to Peacock Alley at the Waldorf-Astoria in the 1990s, courted fame at Aqua in San Francisco and later returned to Manhattan to open Millesime in the Carlton Hotel. Manrique is a celebrity chef of a sort, Gallic and handsome, often on the road. Ashkinaze is the one who makes his food. He has done so on and off for the better part of 20 years.

That's a wrap - in this case, probably a neon-pink taffeta wrap - for the Broadway musical ''Priscilla Queen of the Desert,'' press representatives for the production said on Wednesday. The musical, adapted from Stephan Elliott's 1994 comedy ''The Adventures of Priscilla, Queen of the Desert,'' about a team of drag performers journeying through remote Australia in a camping (and camp) bus, will play its final show at the Palace Theater on June 24. The musical, which is directed by Simon Phillips and features a book by Mr. Elliott and Allan Scott as well as a score of disco-friendly pop hits, opened in March 2011 and won the Tony Award that year for its costume design by Tim Chappel and Lizzy Gardiner. Tony Sheldon, who played the role of the transsexual Bernadette - on Broadway as well as previous productions in Australia, Toronto and London's West End - was also nominated for leading actor in a musical. ''Priscilla'' will have played 23 previews and 526 performances at its closing. A spokesman for the show said that it would not recoup its capitalization costs, which totaled $15 million for the Broadway run and a pre-Broadway tryout in Toronto. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Leslie Rodriquez was 2 years old on Sept. 11, 2001, when she was sent home from day care in the swirl of the day's catastrophic events. In the decade since, that day meant little more to her than a hazy historical reference. ''In fourth or fifth grades, we would have a moment of silence,'' she said. ''And then move on with the rest of our day.''
FINNEGAN--Lawrence J.,Jr. Dearest Larry, you remain in our hearts!

WHEN Giulia Campeol was growing up in a small town near Venice, she wore hand-stitched slippers, or friulanas, as they are known in northern Italy. Now, working as a fashion buyer in Rome, she has reimagined her childhood shoes, sometimes called gondolier's slippers, with a contemporary twist. Her Allagiulia collection is made by local craftsmen from felt and bicycle-tire rubber with white hand-stitching (the traditional mode). For the uppers, Ms. Campeol searches vintage markets to find bandannas and soft cotton dishcloths. With slippers now so popular as summer footwear, a casual weekend pair, like these in striped canvas, will add an air of old Italy to summer in the city. Allagiulia slippers, $135 to $145 at John Derian,

11:39 a.m. | Updated Alas, there will be no joyous reconciliation for the band that sang of evil women, war pigs, the hand of doom and killing yourself to live. Bill Ward, the original drummer for the heavy-metal group Black Sabbath, said he would not join his former bandmates Ozzy Osbourne, Tony Iommi and Geezer Butler for any of the reassembled act's three scheduled performances this year because he was disappointed with the amount of involvement he was offered, The Guardian reported.

AMID thousands of bound plays, signed first editions of matinee idol biographies and a wall of how-to tomes for actors, producers and the rest, there is one piece of theatrical memorabilia at the Drama Book Shop that isn't for sale. Safely locked in a glass case next to a 31-volume, 1930 limited edition of the works of George Bernard Shaw, the store, in Midtown Manhattan, proudly displays its own Tony Award. Allen Hubby, who owns the store with his aunt Rozanne Seelen, first feared they had been pranked. ''I thought someone was kidding me: a bookstore wins a Tony?'' he said. But for the drama devotees who flock to this shop, the honorary award for ''Excellence in the Theater'' was, if anything, long overdue.

A federal judge on Wednesday granted class-action status to a lawsuit challenging the New York Police Department's stop-and-frisk tactics, saying she was disturbed by the city's ''deeply troubling apathy towards New Yorkers' most fundamental constitutional rights.'' The decision by the judge, Shira A. Scheindlin, of Federal District Court, (see also below) provides possible legal recourse for hundreds of thousands of people who have been caught up in the department's increasingly vigorous stop-and-frisk practice, which critics say unjustly ensnares blacks and Latinos.

WITH the median price of an apartment in Manhattan topping $1,000 a square foot, homeownership is often far out of reach. But there are options for those who cannot afford the market rate, including co-op apartments for buyers who earn a certain percentage of the area median income, or A.M.I. These buildings are scattered all over the city. Some date to the 1950s; others are brand-new and still looking for buyers. Some are limited to those who earn less than the median income -- 60 or 80 percent, for example (the median for a family of four in New York City is $83,000). Others have apartments for those earning a bit more than that sum. Many new developments try to bring in owners from different economic backgrounds, and are likely to include market-rate units as well.

California HOLLYWOOD BOWL June 22-Sept. 30. Along with their fine al fresco opera offerings (''Don Giovanni'' will rear its stone head a few times this season), the Hollywood Bowl delights in pairing pop figures with classical power for bombastic, cinematic evenings; this year Barry Manilow takes three spins with the Los Angeles Philharmonic (July 2-4), as does the Brian Setzer Orchestra with the Hollywood Bowl Orchestra (Sept. 14-16). Glen Campbell delivers what is said to be the final Los Angeles performance of his storied career, and Wilco closes the season; hollywoodbowl.com.

The Devils have claimed Game 2 of the Eastern Conference finals, and now it looks as if this renewal of the Battle of the Hudson may be a drawn-out affair after all. All the ballyhoo about the Rangers' superior shot-blocking, goaltending and conditioning after their Game 1 victory meant nothing at Madison Square Garden on Wednesday night, not after David Clarkson's tip-in goal at 2 minutes 31 seconds of the third period broke a tie and the Devils hung on for a 3-2 victory that evened the series at a game apiece.

An article on Tuesday about genetic illnesses that affect children conceived with donated sperm erroneously included fragile X syndrome among those illnesses. (Although a sperm donor who is a carrier of the fragile X permutation may pass it along to his daughters, the disease, which affects twice as many boys as girls, is almost always inherited from the mother.) The article also misidentified a consequence of a heart defect known as hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, or HCM. Among young athletes, the defect is a leading cause of sudden cardiac death -- not myocardial infarction, or heart attack.

IF one motto could be said to have guided all those responsible for the waves of development sustained by Downtown Brooklyn over the years, it might have been ''Think no small thoughts.'' The first land rush came in the early 1800s, after Robert Fulton's regular ferry service eased the link to Manhattan. Country lanes were transformed into lively blocks of city dwellings.

BLUMBERG--Harold, of West Milford, NJ, died Tuesday. Husband of Mayrose, father of Barbara and Howard, grandfather of Amanda, brother of Bertram and his wife Ann. Harold was a civil engineer. Memorial donations may be made to Cooper Union.

When the Cedar Lake Contemporary Ballet company was founded in 2003 by the Walmart heiress Nancy Laurie, the news was greeted with a profound shrug by the dance world. The troupe's first two years didn't do much to dispel the idea that it was a rich woman's whim: there was no headquarters and few performances, and reports of an oddly corporate environment with dissatisfied collaborators. Nearly 10 years later the 16-member Cedar Lake, which has opened at the Joyce Theater for a two-week run, has become a New York success story, possibly the country's most innovative contemporary ballet troupe with an A-list repertory and an accent on creation that few companies worldwide can match.

An Op-Ed essay on May 10 about the debate over extending the low interest rate on a federal student loan program incorrectly stated that college loans cannot be discharged in bankruptcy, unlike nearly every other type of debt. In fact, such loans can be discharged in rare cases, when borrowers are able to show that repaying would cause undue hardship.

(SNY) 50 GREATEST METS In celebration of the Mets' 50th anniversary, SNY counts down the team's 50 greatest players as voted on by the play-by-play announcers Gary Cohen and Howie Rose; the broadcaster Ralph Kiner; John Harper, a columnist for The Daily News; and Steve Hirdt, executive vice president of the Elias Sports Bureau. (Flix) MOSTLY MARTHA (2002) Martha (Martina Gedeck), a single, workaholic chef in an upscale restaurant in Hamburg, Germany, finds her carefully organized life thrown into disarray when she must care for her dead sister's 8-year-old daughter (Maxime Foerste). Enter Mario, the likable Italian sous-chef (Sergio Castellitto) who is capable of charming everyone but Martha. ''The movie succeeds because the writer and director, Sandra Nettelbeck, seems as obsessive as her titular heroine,'' Elvis Mitchell wrote in The New York Times. ''The final confection is extremely enjoyable, though a few degrees shy of perfection.''

A picture caption last Thursday with the On Location column, about a modernist house in Los Angeles, misidentified a reproduction of a chair designed by Arne Jacobsen. Arkansas ARKANSAS SHAKESPEARE THEATER Conway, June 7-July 1. Whether you prefer your summer Shakespeare outside or indoors, this festival can accommodate you. ''Twelfth Night'' will be presented on the green at the Village at Hendrix in Conway and at Wildwood Park for the Arts in Little Rock. At the indoor Reynolds Performance Hall in Conway, you can catch ''Richard III'' or ''The Tempest.'' Shakespeare plays are big business come summer, but this Arkansas company, like many theaters focused on Shakespeare, branches out: The indoor stage will also feature the Huck Finn musical ''Big River''; (866) 810-0012, arkshakes.com.

WERTHEIM--Denise Pauline, passed away after a year long courageous battle with esophageal cancer at Mt. Sinai Hospital, Manhattan on Thursday, May 10, 2012, at age 53. Denise was born in New York City on Independence Day, 1958, the beloved daughter of Jack and Elise Wertheim, who predeceased her. Denise is survived by her father, his wife Jill, sister Alison, brother Mark, Uncle Mickey, niece Sarah and cousin Jason, all of whom gave Denise devoted love and comfort during her final months. After attending Edgemont High School, Scarsdale, Denise graduated from Ithaca College with a BA degree in journalism. She worked in the financial industry for 20 years, ten of them as a trader on Wall Street. September 11, 2001, hit her hard, and after losing close friends she decided to make a change and relocated to Santa Monica, CA. There, she devoted many years to teaching drama, music and dance to teens, touching the lives of many young people and serving on the board of Kids on Stage. Denise was devoted to animals, including her cats Rory and Mysti and Tibetan Terriers, Topaz and Ruby, who were with her during her last days. We will never forget Denise's brave fight against her devastating illness nor the pain she endured. Now that her suffering has ended, may Denise rest in peace. Gifts in her honor can be given to the Los Angeles SPCA at www.spcala.com and the Esophageal Cancer Awareness Association at www.ecaware.org.

LINCOLN CENTER last Thursday was filled with stars like Natalie Portman and Drew Barrymore and socialites like Julia Koch, all dressed to the hilt as the New York City Ballet opened its spring season. But true fashion lovers probably found their gaze fixed not on the lobby but on the stage, as they sought out the evening's most exciting designs. In an usually fashion-focused gala the Rodarte designers, the sisters Kate and Laura Mulleavy, created the costumes for the premiere of a new ballet by Benjamin Millepied (Ms. Portman's husband), ''Two Hearts,'' and Gilles Mendel of J. Mendel supplied the designs for Peter Martins's latest work, ''Mes Oiseaux.'' And in perhaps the most significant move, the classic costumes for Balanchine's ''Symphony in C'' were revamped with crystals by Swarovski.

SLOAN--Hilda Sault. The Board of Directors and families of United Cerebral Palsy of New York City mourn the loss of our longtime benefactor Hilda Sault Sloan. We shall miss her leadership and vision. A member of the board for 58 years, many of them as secretary, Hilda was also a past president of Women's Division, traveling the country extensively to create UCP women's auxiliaries. With her late husband (and former board member) Irving Sloan, she founded and supported three UCP of NYC Sloan Fitness Centers. We extend our condolences to her daughter and son-in-law, Barbara (Sault) and Michael Peterman, her granddaughter, Lauren Deminico (Michael), and her great-granddaughters Ellie and Samantha. To read more about her contributions to UCP of NYC please visit: ucpnyc.org. Gary Geresi, PresidentEdward R. Matthews, CEO
