An article on Wednesday in the Square Feet pages, about aircraft maintenance facilities in Arizona, misstated the surname of the chief executive of Ascent Aviation Services. He is David Querio, not Quiero.

The British actor Alan Rickman has agreed to play Hilly Kristal, the founder of the famous East Village punk-rock club CBGB, in a biographical film to be shot this summer, the producers said on Wednesday. The project has been in development for several years, but the filmmakers -- Jody Savin and Randall Miller - say they are finally set to begin filming on June 25, with Mr. Rickman taking on the part of the iconoclastic bearded, flannel-wearing bar owner who played a key role in the birth of punk and new wave music in the 1970s, providing the scarred stage where the Ramones, Television, Talking Heads, Blondie and other seminal groups got their starts.

NEW YORK likes to think of itself as being the classical music capital of the world. Yet every so often it falls off the flight path of certain eminent musicians. Cecilia Bartoli, Carlos Kleiber, Birgit Nilsson and Brigitte Fassbaender are just a few of the great artists who have skipped New York for long stretches. The same goes for the superb Nina Stemme, widely considered the world's reigning dramatic soprano. When the Swedish Ms. Stemme (pronounced (STEH-muh) made her Metropolitan Opera debut, as Senta in Wagner's ''Fliegende Holländer'' in 2000, Anthony Tommasini praised her ''cool, radiant and often penetrating sound'' in The New York Times and called her portrayal ''lustrous and winning.'' But she has logged a mere 11 New York appearances in all, having returned to the Met in 2010 for five performances of Strauss's ''Ariadne auf Naxos''. And she won't resurface there until the 2016-17 season, when she will star in both Strauss's ''Elektra'' and a new Willy Decker production of Wagner's ''Tristan und Isolde.''

GROWING up, Eileen Wolter, now 40 and a blogger about stay-at-home motherhood in Summit, N.J., was one of those rare teenagers without complexion concerns. ''I had really good skin,'' she said. ''And I just used Ivory bar soap.'' But in recent years, that skin has gone from picture-perfect to problematic. ''I've got uneven skin that's also oily with constant blackheads and cystic acne bumps on my chin,'' Ms. Wolter said. And her once-simple regimen now involves a complicated product list: face brush, acne cover-up, face mask, cortisone shots and prescription acne gel, as well as cleansers and lotions to treat both acne and aging.

BEIRUT, Lebanon -- President Bashar al-Assad of Syria said in an interview broadcast Wednesday that he faced no real domestic opposition in the 15-month-old uprising against him, the violence in his country is entirely the work of foreign-backed terrorists, and the boycott of parliamentary elections last week was a fiction. The interview, conducted on Tuesday by Russiya 24, a Russia state television station, was Mr. Assad's first since December. It suggested he had hardened longstanding views about his adversaries in the face of escalating international pressure. He also was dismissive of a question over why the political reforms sought by opponents was so slow in Syria.

An article on Wednesday about Uncle Dick's Home, the orphanage in the Philippines opened by the father of Jets quarterback Tim Tebow, misstated the given name of the country's president. He is Benigno S. Aquino III, not Bengino.

With strong ticket sales, eight Tony Award nominations and good reviews and word of mouth among theater-goers, the new Disney musical ''Newsies'' will plunge ahead with an open-ended run on Broadway rather than close Aug. 19, the producers of the show said on Wednesday. The August closing date had been something of a spurious notion ever since ''Newsies'' - about a group of New York City newspaper hawkers on strike against a media baron at the turn of the 20th century - started setting box-office records in April at the Nederlander Theater. Yet Disney Theatrical Productions has tried to manage expectations about the musical from the get-go since it was not developed to be a big Broadway show. It was intended to be a licensable title for regional theaters and schools until several critics raved about its debut last fall at Paper Mill Playhouse in Millburn, N.J.; that production transferred largely intact to Broadway.

Everett Lilly, who was largely credited, along with his brother Burt and their band mates Don Stover and Tex Logan, with introducing bluegrass music to New England, died on Tuesday at his home in Clear Creek, W.Va. He was 87. Mr. Lilly had been found to have an aneurysm and probably died of a heart attack, his son Daniel said.

Arizona GRAND CANYON MUSIC FESTIVAL Aug. 24-Sept. 8. This small festival tempts the eyes and ears with concerts amid spectacular scenery. The lineup in the Shrine of the Ages, near the south rim of the canyon, includes the dynamic string quartet Ethel; (800) 997-8285, grandcanyonmusicfest.org.

MALLOY--Edward J. On behalf of the Rudin family and the employees of Rudin Management Co., we mourn the loss of our dear friend and associate, Ed Malloy, whose wisdom, powers of persuasion, no-nonsense attitude and tireless efforts on behalf of the building trades not only made the unions stronger but also promoted rational development and the growth of our city and state. Ed was a valued partner of the real estate industry and a friend who could always be trusted to tell you exactly what he thought. We will greatly miss Ed and all his sage advice. We send our sincere condolences to his wonderful wife, Marilyn, his daughters, Theresa and Anne, and the entire Malloy family. Jack Rudin, Chairman, Rudin Management Co.

Betty White's age - she is 90 and still going strong - was the topic of much discussion Wednesday at the Sheraton New York in Midtown Manhattan, where Ms. White was the target of a Friars Club roast. The comedian Jeff Ross called Ms. White the ''ghost of honor'' and said the event was organized as a lunch ''because we didn't think she'd make it till dinner.''

With Facebook, Mark Zuckerberg has created a seemingly perfect home on the Web, one where people feel comfortable chatting with friends, playing games, sharing photos and videos, listening to music and revealing the most intimate details of their lives. The $100 billion question is whether Facebook will be a perfect home for advertisers, as well.

James Abdnor, a South Dakota Republican farmer who liked to say that he got off his tractor and went to Washington, where he served four terms in Congress and one in the Senate after defeating the Democratic incumbent, George S. McGovern, in 1980, died on Wednesday in Sioux Falls, S.D. He was 89. His death was announced by his family.

During his appearance at the 92nd Street Y on Sunday night, John Irving said he thought he was finished with the theme of ''intolerance of our sexual differences'' after ''The World According to Garp.'' But his new novel, ''In One Person,'' from which he read two extended scenes, features a bisexual narrator named Billy Dean, and Mr. Irving's bibliography makes it clear that he has always been drawn to the experience of unconventional sexuality. When he was an adolescent, Mr. Irving said, he ''imagined having sex with just about everyone.'' That included friends, mothers of friends and wrestlers he admired. His heterosexuality eventually asserted itself, but he said, ''I didn't forget what it felt like to be attracted to everyone.''

The trading losses suffered by JPMorgan Chase have surged in recent days, surpassing the bank's initial $2 billion estimate by at least $1 billion, according to people with knowledge of the losses. When Jamie Dimon, JPMorgan's chief executive, announced the losses last Thursday, he indicated they could double within the next few quarters. But that process has been compressed into four trading days as hedge funds and other investors take advantage of JPMorgan's distress, fueling faster deterioration in the underlying credit market positions held by the bank.
To the Editor: I really appreciated Bill Clinton's beautifully written review of Robert A. Caro's book ''The Passage of Power: The Years of Lyndon Johnson'' (May 6).

THE British writer Simon Gray died in 2008 after a long life of writing and smoking, smoking and writing. His prolific output included more than 30 plays as well as novels, screenplays and a series of memoirs collectively entitled ''The Smoking Diaries.'' But Gray never really made much of a mark in the United States. Only three of his plays made it to Broadway, the most celebrated being ''Butley,'' revived in 2006 with Nathan Lane in the lead. A new production of his popular 1984 play, ''THE COMMON PURSUIT,'' gives audiences a chance to reassess his talent. Originally directed by Harold Pinter, a longtime collaborator and friend, the play is a generational comedy-drama that follows the lives of a half-dozen Cambridge students through two decades as they move through the worlds of literary London. The title refers to the literary magazine founded by one of the characters at school, and is a homage to a volume of essays by the esteemed British critic F. R. Leavis. Moisés Kaufman (''Bengal Tiger at the Baghdad Zoo,'' ''33 Variations'') directs the new production for the Roundabout Theater Company. Opens Thursday, Laura Pels Theater, 111 West 46th Street, (212) 719-1300, roundabouttheatre.org; $71-$81.

The Scene City column on May 3, about an after-party following the White House Correspondents' Association dinner, described incorrectly the character played by Kerry Washington, a guest at the party, on the ABC show ''Scandal.'' She portrays an independent media relations consultant, not a Washington press aide.

BYRNE--Patrick Dixon Bice. October 3, 1981-May 11, 2012. The world lost an unbelievably special soul whose life was taken away unexpectedly. Patrick is the adored son of Peggy Bice and J. Dixon Byrne; beloved stepson of Valerie DiFebo; precious brother of Molly Byrne, Bryan DiFebo Byrne, and Maggie and Alex Taylor; admired uncle of Andrew, Grace and Katherine Taylor; cherished grandson of Margaret S. Bice and the late James D. and Norma M. Byrne; treasured grand-nephew of Jack Byrne. Originally from Manhasset and Sea Cliff, NY; recently a resident of New Fairfield, CT. Patrick was an avid fisherman, accomplished musician, talented artist, lover of nature and his dog, Toby. The size of his heart was only surpassed by the love he had for his family and friends. His uncanny ability to comfort the hearts of others will never be matched. Patrick will be loved and held close to our hearts forever. Services will be conducted at Fairchild & Son Funeral Home in Manhasset, NY, Wednesday May 16, 2-5 and 7-9. The funeral mass will be held Thursday, May 17 at 10am, at St. Mary's RC Church in Manhasset, NY.

Sure, that sun feels good now. But at the hot, bright height of summer, its rays can be as unflattering to your look as they are unkind to your skin. (As anyone in Hollywood can tell you, stars always act like that.) Herewith, a few ways to get your beach look together -- and avoid the glare.

The Broadway revival of Arthur Miller's ''Death of a Salesman,'' starring Philip Seymour Hoffman, will recoup its $3.1 million capitalization this week, just 14 weeks into its run, the producers said on Wednesday. That is a notably swift achievement for a show that has seven performances a week instead of the standard eight. Those missing performances translated into more than $1 million in unrealized revenue, based on an analysis of the ticket sale grosses for the show; it grossed $9.8 million in its first 13 weeks. The producers have been able to charge a top price of $425 for the best seats in the theater, an almost unheard-of amount for a play and almost as much as the hit musical ''Book of Mormon,'' where tickets top out at $477. ''Mormon'' and ''Salesman'' have a lead producer in common, Scott Rudin. ''Salesman'' has broken the box office record six times at its home, the Barrymore Theater. Only about 30 percent of Broadway shows recoup capitalization costs and turn a profit.

JENKS--Darrell Allan. On May 14, 2012 Darrell A. Jenks died at his residence in Baltimore, MD. Darrell Jenks, diplomat, retired last autumn after a thirty-year career that included two tours in Japan, most recently as Director of the FSI Japanese Language and Area Training Center in Yokohama. His colleagues admired him for his warm, lively and outgoing personality, as well as his conscientious leadership in the workplace. Darrell, a brilliant linguist, served the American people well. He spoke nine languages including Japanese, Korean and Chinese. In 2007, Darrell volunteered to serve in Maysan, Iraq, where largely self-taught he picked up the basics of his fourth super-hard language, Arabic. Darrell was fascinated by people and cultures, and formed lasting friendships everywhere he went. Even after retiring, and while fighting a terrible illness, Darrell continued working with his friends in Japan and the United States to organize celebrations of the 100th anniversary of Japan's donation of cherry trees to Washington, DC. Darrell is survived by his wife Thelma, daughter Desiree, son Christopher, parents George, and Zoya Jenks, and siblings Mark and Andrew. A Memorial Service will be held on May 19, 2012 at 2:00 pm at the Mitchell-Wiedefeld Funeral Home, Inc., 6500 York Road, Baltimore, MD 21212. In lieu of flowers, donations in his honor may be made to Alvin & Lois Lapidus Cancer Institute, (c/o The Darrell Jenks Memorial), Sinai Hospital of Baltimore, 2401 W. Belvedere Ave, Baltimore, MD 21215.

An article on May 3 about the White House public tour misidentified which of Woodrow Wilson's wives removed Theodore Roosevelt's hunting trophies from the house. She was Ellen Wilson, his first wife -- not Edith Wilson, whom he married after Ellen's death.

SEIDEMAN--Abby. The Board of Trustees, Associate Board of Trustees, League, Administration and staff of the Parker Jewish Institute for Health Care and Rehabilitation are deeply saddened by the passing of Abby, beloved daughter of Barbara and Peter Seideman, Vice Chairman of the Board. We offer our most heartfelt condolences to the entire Seideman family, and hope that loving memories and the warm wishes of family and friends help ease this most difficult time. Lenny Tanzer, Chairman of the Board Michael N. Rosenblut, President/CEO

The Securities and Exchange Commission and the Federal Bureau of Investigation are looking into JPMorgan Chase's trading debacle - and if you think anything is going to come of that, well, I'm pretty sure that JPMorgan has some derivatives it would love to sell you. A serious investigation is still necessary. The first lesson of the financial crisis is not that the capital markets were poorly regulated or that the banks were too leveraged or that the government needed better processes for taking over failing institutions.

WHITE--Abraham, of Forest Hills, NY on May 16th, 2012; born November 15th, 1916. Beloved husband of Evelyn, who predeceased him, loving father of Perrin and Marjorie and father-in-law of Marjorie Boeck, adoring grandfather of Joshua and Benjamin. Eminent physician and healer. His unshakeable optimism enriched our lives. Services Friday, May 18th, 11:30am at Schwartz Brothers, 114-03 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills. Memorial contributions to Children's Aid Society, http://www.childrensaidsociety.org/donate.

Adam Graves took 31 shots againstMartin Brodeur in the 1994 Eastern Conference finals against the Devils, and only two got through for goals. That degree of difficulty helps to inform Graves's frame of reference on the trans-Hudson rivalry, then and now. Q.You are one of only a handful of Rangers whose numbers hang from the rafters at Madison Square Garden, but that '94 series against the Devils was tough sledding for you and for everyone involved.

DEEP inside a nondescript building in SoHo, a two-story steel vault marked ''Fort Knox'' holds a huge arsenal of weapons that has armed action heroes and their adversaries, fake armies and feds, and Tony Soprano. The collection, of more than 5,000 firearms, includes sniper rifles, assault rifles, shotguns, revolvers, pistols, machine guns and even a 15th-century wheel lock, one of the world's first practical handguns. The deadly decorations hang on the vault's white walls, and each has, at one time or another, played a role in film or television.

MALLOY--Edward J.,Jr., on May 15. Son of the late Edward J., Sr. and Mae. Beloved husband of Marilyn (nee Lynett); cherished father of Theresa Torres Latini (Jack) and Anne Trekle (Donald); loving brother of John, Anne, Brennan and Delores Connolly and the late Gerald Malloy; grandfather of Vincent, Joseph, Edward, Lauren, Devon, James and Allison; great-grandfather of Keilly, Ethan, Collin, Christopher, Sophie and Yvonne. Past President of Steam Fitters Local Union 638, Past President of New York City Building and Construction Trades Council and President Emeritus New York State Building Trades Council. Family will receive friends Thursday 2-4 and 7-9pm at Frank E. Campbell "The Funeral Chapel," Madison Ave. at 81st St. Mass of Christian Burial Friday, 10am at St. Patrick's Cathedral. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to: St. Jude Children's Research.

MELTZER--Sally. The Board of Governors and members of Beach Point Club note with deep sorrow the passing of our fellow member, Sally Meltzer and extend sincere condolences to her family. Alan Fischer, President

It is perhaps the government's most powerful piece of evidence in its case against Rajat K. Gupta, the former Goldman Sachs director accused of leaking boardroom secrets. ''I heard yesterday from somebody who's on the board of Goldman Sachs that they are going to lose $2 per share,'' said Raj Rajaratnam, the now-imprisoned hedge fund manager, in a secretly recorded telephone conversation that he had with a colleague at his hedge fund Galleon Group in October 2008.

To the Editor: I was interested to read in William Poundstone's review of ''Turing's Cathedral,'' by George Dyson (May 6), about how my husband, Martin Davis, a distinguished mathematician and logician, and I expressed our opposition to that destructive force, the H-bomb, while Martin was a visiting member at the Institute for Advanced Study in 1952-54. As the review notes, I scrawled ''Stop the Bomb'' in the dust on the rear window of John von Neumann's black Cadillac. We also distributed leaflets against nuclear testing in institute mailboxes. This was a principled stand that my husband and I can be proud of.

My otherwise-sensible neighbors sent me an invitation to a funeral for their 12-year-old basset hound. They are going to bury the dog in the backyard and say a few words in its honor. They have no children, so this event is not to humor them. I had no relationship with the dog. What would make adults hold such a foolish affair? And how do I get out of it?H. L., Westport, Conn. As I type this, I am gazing at an 8-year-old poodle that means more to me than 97 percent of the people in my Rolodex. (And that's being generous to the Rolodex.) But you're right: a funeral for a dog is unusual. So why not be a mensch and go?

An article on Wednesday in the Square Feet pages, about the renovation of the Cross County Shopping Center in Yonkers, misstated the amount paid in lieu of property taxes by the shopping center in 2009, the first year of a 14-year agreement with the Yonkers Industrial Development Agency. It was $3.3 million, not $3,000. Because of an editing error, the article also misstated, in some editions, the cost of the renovation. It was $250 million, not $50 million. The error was repeated in a picture caption.

MELTZER--Sally, 81, of Scarsdale and New York City, passed away peacefully on Wednesday, May 16, 2012, as her heart finally succumbed to complications from scleroderma. A native New Yorker, Sally built a wonderful life for her family there and in Scarsdale, finding time to teach nursery school at Sarah Lawrence College, where she had graduated, and as a docent at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. She leaves Jay Meltzer, her loving husband of 58 years, her lovely daughter, Dr. Amy Meltzer (married to Dr. Scott Gitlin of Ann Arbor, MI), two fine sons, Mark of Portland, OR and Daniel of Seattle, WA, and two fabulous grandchildren, Andrew and Emily Gitlin. Funeral service on Friday May 18, at 9:45am at Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Road, Scarsdale, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Reading Reform are suggested.

Regina Spektor had warned me that she wouldn't let me hear her sing. Now we were sitting outside the L.A. studio of her producer, Mike Elizondo, where she'd been laying down initial tracks of piano and voice for her sixth solo record, ''What We Saw from the Cheap Seats.'' And still she wouldn't budge. ''Everybody who's ever made records feels that way,'' Spektor explained. ''You're in a room and you're working on it and it's just an engineer and a producer. And then someone comes over, and you play the song for them. The way you hear it in that instant is very different than how you've been listening to it. If you do it really early you interrupt the process with other frequencies. It's almost like a certain kind of coat of color. You can't take it off once you've listened to something with a stranger in the room. And at that point everybody's a stranger. It could be your mom.''

The Personal Best column on Tuesday, about the decline in performance as athletes age, described incompletely an achievement of Kozo Haraguchi, a runner who took up the sport late in life. Mr. Haraguchi, who became a sprinter at age 76, formerly held a world record in the 100-meter sprint among runners in his age group -- not among all runners.

People who bought a pair of Skechers toning shoes may not get the great legs and abdominal muscles that the advertisements promised - but now at least they can get their money back. Federal regulators announced on Wednesday that Skechers had agreed to pay $40 million to settle complaints that the company deceived consumers with claims that some of its sneakers - from the Shape-Ups, Resistance Runner, Toners and Tone-Ups lines, endorsed by celebrities like Kim Kardashian and Brooke Burke - could deliver toned legs, better buttocks and a slimmer body ''without setting a foot in a gym.''

The academics Chris Herbst and John Ifcher are challenging collective wisdom: parents, they say, really are happier than their non-parent counterparts. Mr. Herbst and Mr. Ifcher set out to assess the body of research that led to the generally accepted ''parental happiness gap,'' that is, the repeated findings showing that parents experience more depression and anxiety and are less happy in general (and in their marriages) than non-parents are. What they found suggests that the balance of happiness is shifting. Parents' happiness has held steady, while the absolute happiness of non-parents dropped from 1972 to 2008.

Carrie Underwood tops the Billboard album chart for a second time this week, but music sales were down all around. Ms. Underwood's latest release, ''Blown Away'' (Arista Nashville), held at No. 1 with 120,000 sales, down 55 percent from last week, according to data from Nielsen SoundScan. The top rungs of the chart are filled with other titles that have slipped. ''Now 42,'' a compilation, lost 31 percent of its sales, falling one spot to No. 4 with 65,000; Norah Jones's ''Little Broken Hearts'' (Blue Note), which opened last week at No. 2, lost 46 percent, dropping to No. 5 with 60,000. One Direction, Jack White, B.o.B, a ''Smash'' soundtrack -- all high-charting records in recent weeks -- also had substantial drops.

An article last Thursday about efforts by professional sports to prevent athletes from having their finances derailed after retirement misstated part of the title of a National Basketball Association official, Mike Bantom. He is senior vice president for player development, not for player and basketball development. It also misidentified the administrators of the Rookie Transition Program. It is run by the players union and the N.B.A., not the Career Development Program, a separate joint venture of the two.

The architect Frank Gehry has refined his design for a memorial to Dwight D. Eisenhower on the Washington Mall in response to concerns from the Eisenhower family and historians that a youthful statue failed to represent the former president's significant achievements. Mr. Gehry outlined his changes to the design on Tuesday in a letter that was presented at a meeting of the Eisenhower Memorial Commission.

You know how people who rudely check their phones every 42 seconds can drive you completely bonkers? Thanks to Sony they won't do that any longer. Instead they will drive you bonkers by checking their watches.

There is a touch of the unhinged in Jack Tanner, the hero of ''Man and Superman,'' as played by Max Gordon Moore in this sparkling revival of George Bernard Shaw's comedy at the Irish Repertory Theater. Wide-eyed, exasperated by human folly, Tanner speaks for Shaw himself. But Mr. Moore's agitation adds a vivid animus that this often talky play requires, and his performance illustrates what makes this staging, produced with Gingold Theatrical Group, so winning. The complete ''Man and Superman'' has four acts and can run more than five hours, given its characters' tendency toward protracted discussions about class, religion, the sexes and other topics (leavened, fortunately, by volleys of wit).

Tablets are easy to rest in your lap when you're sitting, but they become awkward to grip if you're standing or multitasking. I tend to hold my iPad by the flap of its cover, and I've noticed that the cover is starting to tear from the strain. Some covers alleviate this problem with built-in stands or handles, but they add bulk and weight to the device. You can get stands or grips separately, and there is a wide assortment out there to choose from, but then you have more tech junk cluttering your home.

Le Concert des Nations, conducted by Jordi Savall. Naïve OP 30513; CD. CRITICS throw around the word revelatory a bit too much. But Jordi Savall's recent recording of Vivaldi's ''Teuzzone'' richly deserves the adjective.

MALLOY--Ed. The Association for a Better New York offers condolences to the family of Ed Malloy. Ed's leadership on behalf of organized labor over the last four decades was a critical part of New York City's resurgence. Ed was a longtime member of ABNY's Steering Committee and we were proud to work closely with him. He will be greatly missed. William C. Rudin, Chairman Jennifer Hensley, Exec. Dir.
Photographers at a photo call of the jury at the 65th Cannesfestival, which startedWednesday. Jurors will choose winnersfrom the 22 films in competition. The festival ends on May 27.

KEND--Elaine. We mourn the loss of our beloved Elaine, who died suddenly in New York City on May 12, 2012. Born in Flushing, Queens in 1932 and a graduate of Barnard College, she lived a peripatetic adult life from Great Neck, NY to Boca Raton, FL and Manchester, VT as well as London and Rome. Her family remembers her as a devoted friend, mother, sister, sister-in-law, aunt and Granny. She is survived by her sons Robert and Peter; her four grandchildren, Sydney, Alyssa, Samuel and Eden; her sisters, Myrna and Dedee; her sister-in-law, Connie; her brothers-in-law Albert and Arthur; her nieces Leslie, Melissa, Donna, Stephanie; and her nephews Bill, Jeffrey, Ken, Jonathan and David. She was passionate about the arts, especially the contemporary arts, classical music and opera. She founded classical music festivals in Boca Raton, FL and Manchester, VT. She served on the Visiting Committee for the Arts at Williams College. She enriched the lives of all her knew her in countless ways with her wise counsel. We celebrate a life well lived and will forever feel her presence. Services will be private but donations in her memory can be made to the Eaglebrook School in Deerfield, MA.

ON a recent Saturday night, a lean young man with foppish hair was in the back seat of a black S.U.V., being driven from his Murray Hill apartment to STK Midtown, a steroidal steakhouse that brings the raucousness of the meatpacking district to Times Square. After a big greeting at the door and several rounds of complimentary drinks, the man, in a blue custom-made suit, continued down to West 16th Street. Stepping out at the Dream Downtown, he pushed past a crowd and, like a fighting cock let loose in an arena, crowed out ''Aalex Julian!'' to the head doorman (who did not seem pleased to see him) and tossed a pink paisley pocket square onto Mr. Julian's bald head. Mr. Julian removed it and stuffed it back into the young man's mouth, who then bit his finger.

MELTZER--Sally R. The congregation of Westchester Reform Temple mourns the death of its longtime, devoted member and extends sympathy to her bereaved family. Lisa Messinger, President Jonathan Blake, Rabbi Jill Abramson, Cantor

MALLOY--Edward J. Bradford Construction Corporation wish to express our deepest sympathy over the passing of Edward Malloy. We extend our condolences to his family and we join all New Yorkers in saying "We shall not see his like again". Sandra Wilkin, President

MALLOY--Edward J. The governors, members and staff of The Real Estate Board of New York mourn the passing of Edward J. Malloy, a giant in the New York labor movement. Ed, as President of the Building and Construction Trades Council, worked with our industry in promoting economic development and public infrastructure improvements. Ed supported measures to contain construction costs including the negotiation of the first of its kind project labor agreement for a major public works project in New York State in 1994. We express our sincere condolences to the entire Malloy family. Mary Ann Tighe, Chairman Steven Spinola, President

WING--Laurence C. Born in Brooklyn New York on June 26, 1914, passed from our sight on May 4, 2012 peacefully, in his sleep. He is survived by his son, Christopher, his wife Julia (Ware) and his two grandchildren, Rebecca L. and Deland L. His family spent summers in Brielle, sailing the boats he had built in the Manasquan River. When the war began, he was working for Federal Ship and volunteered for the Navy. After OCS, he was sent to California by the Navy for his experience in shipbuilding. With a passion for sailing that he had developed as a young boy, he opted to remain in California where he could sail year round. He obtained a General Contractor's license, built several houses, and worked in the aerospace industry in production control, where he was involved in the Apollo Project. An avid reader with wide-ranging interests, he was a great conversationalist and the fundamental source for our family's background and the history of the Wing & Son Piano Company. He could build anything and had an instinctive feel for how to make a boat sail fast. Happy sailing, Dad!

An article in some editions on Saturday about the Yankees' 6-2 victory over the Seattle Mariners the previous night described incorrectly, in some copies, the play that led to the Yankees' first run and the third out of the first inning. On Robinson Cano's single to right field with two outs and Curtis Granderson on second base, Seattle first baseman Justin Smoak, not pitcher Felix Hernandez, cut off Ichiro Suzuki's throw to the plate and threw out Cano, not Granderson, at second for the third out. (Granderson scored on the play.)

IF first impressions count for much, the Hudson House, in Nyack, made a fine one on a balmy night early this month. Set before me by our sweet-natured waiter, a flute of brisk prosecco arrived with a tiny orange nasturtium bobbing on top. ''You can eat that,'' he said, smiling. I did, at once, and a peppery snap of flower power turned an everyday aperitif into a charming opening act. Matt Hudson and Amy Lehman, who have owned the Hudson House for 22 years, gave it a face-lift and a tummy tuck over the winter: they replaced old wooden beams with steel and laid new oak floors; a fresh coat of gold-and-white pearlized paint on the ornate pressed-tin walls and ceiling gives the place a distinctive sheen, the decorative equivalent of a satin prom dress. A beautiful, muted wall-length mural of the Hudson River and white tablecloths lend a bit of formality.

Among the midsize, family-owned companies that power the German economy, it has long been an article of faith: credit comes from the friendly local banker, not from cold and distant capital markets. So Peter H. Leibold was breaking from the norm last year when he decided to finance the expansion of his company, which makes wood pellets for heating and energy generation, by selling corporate bonds. The company, German Pellets, raised more than 80 million euros ($102 million).

WASHINGTON -- American negotiators, heading into a crucial round of talks with Iran over its nuclear program next week in Baghdad, are allowing themselves a rare emotion after more than a decade of fruitless haggling with Tehran: hope. With signs that Iran is under more pressure than it has been in years to make a deal, senior Obama administration officials said the United States and five other major powers were prepared to offer a package of inducements to obtain a verifiable agreement to suspend its efforts to enrich uranium closer to weapons grade.

Two delegations of Japanese officials visited Palisades Park, N.J., this month with a request that took local administrators by surprise: The Japanese wanted a small monument removed from a public park. The monument, a brass plaque on a block of stone, was dedicated in 2010 to the memory of so-called comfort women, tens of thousands of women and girls, many Korean, who were forced into sexual slavery by Japanese soldiers during World War II.

WASHINGTON -- The lawyer Rusty Hardin, known equally for his legal acuity and showmanship, did his best to convince jurors on Thursday that Brian McNamee, the government's key witness in Roger Clemens's perjury case, was not to be trusted. Relentlessly, Hardin tried to chip away at the credibility of McNamee, the only government witness to claim firsthand knowledge of Clemens's use of steroids and human growth hormone, substances now banned by Major League Baseball.

Mitt Romney almost matched President Obama in fund-raising during April after securing his party's presidential nomination and joining forces with the Republican National Committee, the campaign will announce on Thursday. Mr. Romney and the R.N.C. raised $40.1 million in April, just shy of the $43.6 million that Mr. Obama and the Democratic National Committee raised for the month.

Antigovernment anger in Syria escalated on Friday over the harsh repression of students in Aleppo, the country's largest city, where activists reported what they called the most extensive protests there yet in the 15-month-old nationwide uprising against President Bashar al-Assad. Many thousands of demonstrators, including some government loyalists, participated in the protests, according to dispatches by activists and witnesses interviewed by telephone. Sympathy protests for victims of the crackdown on the students were also reported in several other Syrian cities in what organizers called ''the heroes of Aleppo University'' demonstrations, and in some cases they were broken up by security forces using live ammunition.

ALBANY -- The federal government paid New York State $700 million more in 2009 than the state needed to care for residents with developmental disabilities who lived in its institutions, according to the inspector general of the Department of Health and Human Services in Washington. The finding suggested that billions of dollars earmarked for institutional care in New York had been used for other purposes over the last several years. No penalty is recommended, however, because the payments were approved by federal regulators.

It was my first day of practice with Santo André and I sat quietly on the team bus, staring out the window as we rode to a practice center. I had no idea where we were going or what kind of soccer I was in store for. As the bus veered through the winding hills and favelas of São Paulo, one of Brazil's largest cities, I truly wondered what was ahead of me. Having graduated from Princeton in 2006, I was now in the second year of my quest to become a professional soccer player. I spent most of 2007 in San Francisco, playing in the United Soccer Leagues Premier Development League, a minor league circuit equivalent to Class AA baseball, and then working out for some lower-division clubs in England.

As Wal-Mart reported higher-than-expected first-quarter earnings on Thursday, it suggested in a regulatory filing that the scope of an internal investigation into bribery accusations had widened beyond the retailer's subsidiary in Mexico. The company reported that the audit committee of the Wal-Mart Stores board was examining possible violations of the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act and ''other alleged crimes or misconduct in connection with foreign subsidiaries, including Wal-Mart de México.'' It was the first public disclosure by the company that the internal inquiry could involve additional subsidiaries, though none was named.

The Royalty At every turn on ''Lovers'' (Victory), Nicole Boudreau, the frontwoman of the Royalty, has a whip-smart come-on, a delicately phrased look into her own psyche. ''Take me away with your old-school tunes/I'll be Aretha/Oh, Otis, make my heart swoon,'' she sings powerfully on ''Bartender.'' On ''How I Like 'Em,'' she tells us: ''Everyone warned me, I didn't listen/Just seems like the rebels are better at kissing.'' Ms. Boudreau is a chipper and sly songwriter, and she always sounds cheeky, like a flexible Dusty Springfield, putting her leaps ahead of more serious-minded white soul singers. Better still, she's backed by a collection of electric players: Jesus Apodaca on guitar, Will Daugherty on bass, Daniel Marin Jr. on keyboards and Joel Quintana on drums. Often reminiscent of the Gaslight Anthem, another group that meshes fervent soul, classic rock storytelling and impressive band dynamics, the Royalty is both ragged and hospital-corners tight. Its blend of the acumen of the Dap-Kings and the detached affect of the Strokes is invigorating and fresh, making for one of the year's most unexpected and enjoyable rock records.

Relatives who are a little too close; a suffocating sense of limits; secrets that, once shared, undo the precepts that defined a way of life: If these sound like elements in a family's deconstruction -- the stuff, say, of a Sam Shepard play -- they certainly could be. But Tom Dudzick's ''Miracle on South Division Street,'' at St. Luke's Theater, is a sprightly, gentle comedy, where revelations that might remake a family's sense of itself are each rolled out in service of laughter.

WASHINGTON -- It says something about American politics that it has come to this: For the record, Bill Clinton does not actually support Mitt Romney for president no matter how many times Mr. Romney, the presumptive Republican nominee, cites him in his speeches. And for that matter, just for clarity, Ronald Reagan certainly would not be supporting President Obama, either.

ATHENS -- Political and economic tremors rolled out of Greece and across Europe again on Thursday as the caretaker prime minister, Panagiotis Pikrammenos, appointed a temporary cabinet to manage the country's affairs until June 17, when the second general election in a little more than a month is held. An increasingly urgent question is whether Europe can afford to wait until that election, which is expected to determine the future of the troubled country in the euro zone and the broader stability of the bloc. Events may force European officials' hand much earlier.

We asked a group of critics and reporters who cover music for The Times about their go-to tunes for road trips. Here is a selection of their picks. JON CARAMANICA''We Got It 4 Cheap, Vol. 2,'' the 2005 mixtape from the hip-hop duo Clipse, is all forward motion, dark, anxiety-inducing verses atop surging, snarling beats. It makes you feel as if you're on the run -- as good a reason to be in the car as any.

The hand-painted Italian bicycles that flash across Silicon Valley on Saturday mornings have become the new Ferrari -- and only the cognoscenti could imagine that they cost more than $20,000.

AFTER 'BOOK' During the NBC presentation, Jennifer Salke, president of the NBC Entertainment division, lavished praise on Josh Gad, a star of a coming sitcom, ''1600 Penn.'' Mr. Gad, she said, ''stole the show'' on Broadway in the musical ''The Book of Mormon.''

BEATON--Daniel. On May 17, 2012. Born August 20, 1925 in Bronx, NY to the late Nathan and Ida and last resided at The Osborn in Rye, NY. Devoted husband of Shirley Ruth (nee Sobleman) for 65 years. He was the father of Dr. Howard (the late Bettye), Neal (Dr. Ann) and, Dianne (Brian Heaps); grandfather of Joshua (Beth Stevens), Audrey (Mike Margarite), Eric (Rachel), Jessica, Kevin (Elisha), Gregory, Rachel, Nathan and Andrew; and great-grandfather of Jacob and Olivia. Graduate of Townsend Harris High School at age 15, City College (B.S. Civil Engineering) at age 18 and NYU (M.S. Civil Engineering), with doctoral studies at Brooklyn Polytech. Served in U.S. Navy during World War II as a radar instructor. Spent most of his professional career as a partner in Rose, Beaton & Rose in White Plains and predecessor firms that he built to one of the largest architectural and engineering firms in the New York area, specializing in telecommunications buildings. Served as president of Sands Point School PTA, Community Synagogue in Port Washington and Community Synagogue of Rye and active in many charitable endeavors. Funeral services at Community Synagogue of Rye, 200 Forest Avenue, on May 20, 2012 at 11:00am. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to charity in his memory. May his memory forever be a blessing.

Too big to hedge. That may be the lesson of the debacle at JPMorgan Chase. And if regulators take the lesson to heart, they could close a gaping loophole in the Volcker Rule, which is supposed to ban speculative trading by banks that take insured deposits.

Taylor Swift, perhaps the biggest young country star in a generation, has said she will donate $4 million to the Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum in Nashville, The Associated Press reported. Museum officials said the gift is the largest they have received from a musician. They intend to use it to build an exhibition with classroom space, called the Taylor Swift Education Center, which is expected to open in 2014. The center will form part of a $75 million expansion project that will add 200,000 square feet to the museum.
