Set in a landmarked 1835 brick building that began as a purveyor of fire insurance to the shipping trade, the restaurant, at 5 Front Street, is owned by the group that brought Colonie to Brooklyn Heights last year. The chef, Sam Richman, honed his haute French technique at Jean Georges and Per Se but spent a month in Mexico on a culinary cram course before taking over the kitchen. Pacifico Clara beer ($6) makes its New York City debut on tap. About those skulls and skeletons on the walls: the Día de los Muertos motif of the Mexican artist José Guadalupe Posada has been customized in Dumbo-centric wallpaper. It works its intended macabre magic. IN THE SEATS In the slightly damp backyard -- the river birch trees were shedding -- three Brooklyn co-workers from Acquia, a software firm based in Boston with a Dumbo outpost, camped out at a silver table lighted by a hurricane candle and passing patches of blue sky on a rainless Wednesday evening: Lisa Rex, 38, a software designer from Cobble Hill; Ezra Gildesgame, 25, a software engineer and product manager from South Park Slope; and Ben Jeavons, 28, a senior software engineer from Park Slope. They were in the mood to dine Mexican and alfresco. ''We needed some fresh air and some fresh food,'' Mr. Jeavons said.

Mitt Romney's campaign claims to be outraged that President Obama would dare criticize its candidate's experience of running Bain Capital, a private-equity firm. Some Democratic politicians have also said the president went too far in tarring an important driver of economic growth. The financial price has been high: Mr. Romney's campaign is reaping unusually generous Wall Street contributions, while Mr. Obama's campaign is raising far less from the financial sector than it did four years ago. The Obama campaign, however, is right to make an issue of Mr. Romney's tenure at Bain. Mr. Romney argues that his experience in the private sector makes him the best choice to revive the economy, and voters need to understand the precise nature of that experience.

MANILA -- The chief justice of the Philippine Supreme Court, Renato C. Corona, testified in his impeachment trial Friday that he had $2.4 million in undeclared foreign currency deposits, a figure far lower than prosecutors have alleged. And he insisted that, under his interpretation of the law, he was not required to disclose the money. During detailed testimony about his finances -- punctuated by weeping, anecdotes about his family and breaks for medical checkups by nearby doctors -- Chief Justice Corona debated the legalities of reporting requirements for government officials.

MORRIS--Dorothy Edith, of Briarcliff Manor, NY died May 23, 2012. She was 80. Wife of the late Kenneth Baker Morris. Mother of Sandra and Laura Morris. Sister of William Kohler and Frances Kohler Chorsky. Visiting hours Friday (today) 2-4pm and 7-9pm at Beecher Funeral Home, Inc., Pleasantville, NY. Funeral service Saturday 11am, All Saints Episcopal Church, Briarcliff Manor, NY. Burial Dale Cemetery, Ossining, NY

Most good horror movies are rich with subtext. You could read ''Psycho''as an Oedipal parable, say, or George Romero's ''Dawn of the Dead'' as a sendup of voracious consumerism. ''Chernobyl Diaries''? You could conceivably consider it a warning about nuclear power, but it's really about the dangers of seeking adventure in a foreign country and trusting former Soviets. But please, don't give it that much thought. We've been on similar tours: ''Turistas'' tossed young people to their deaths in Brazil; ''Hostel'' tortured them in Slovakia. ''Chernobyl Diaries'' follows six travelers -- the sensitive Chris (the cherubic pop star Jesse McCartney); his girlfriend, Natalie (Olivia Taylor Dudley, unfocused); her sensible friend Amanda (Devin Kelley); Chris's impetuous brother, Paul (Jonathan Sadowski); and a couple they meet, the Norwegian Zoe (Ingrid Bolso Berdal, underused) and the hippie-ish Australian Michael (Nathan Phillips) -- on an ''extreme travel'' expedition in Ukraine to Pripyat, the dilapidated town beside the shuttered Chernobyl nuclear reactor.

After 33 years of long waits and false starts, the investigation of Etan Patz's disappearance and the prosecution of the man who says he killed him moved with rapid force on Friday. Crime scene investigators swarmed the basement where the suspect, Pedro Hernandez, says he killed the boy; Mr. Hernandez was arraigned after being placed on a suicide watch; and new details emerged of his chilling confession -- he told investigators he choked Etan moments after luring him to the basement.

A few months ago, I received a letter from someone whose business card, included in his envelope and containing only a small fraction of his résumé, described him as a trained lawyer, educator, speaker, boxing journalist and, perhaps most significant, a historian of Seagate. Occupying the western tip of Coney Island, in Brooklyn, Seagate is a neighborhood of about 800 or so mostly single-family homes, with two gated entry points. It is tempting to call it a gated community, though that distinction seems almost slanderous for a place few would reflexively see as a setting for the ''Real Housewives'' franchise. There are no Pilates studios or restaurants (or hardware stores or Duane Reades, for that matter) in Seagate. The neighborhood's commerce is limited to a beach club whose membership is open to anyone interested in seasonal cabana rentals and a roster of children's activities that include competitive pie-eating.

BEIJING -- As an English-speaking talk show host on China Central Television, Yang Rui likes to think of himself as a bridge between East and West. He has a soft spot for tweed newsboy caps and Sherlock Holmes-style pipes and takes pride in his communications degree from Cardiff University in Wales. He may exult in China's growing might, but made sure his son attended college in the United States. His program on the state-run CCTV, ''Dialogue,'' often includes both foreign and Chinese guests.

KABUL, Afghanistan -- President François Hollande of France made a visit to French troops in Kapisa Province on Friday, assuring them that their mission in Afghanistan would be over this year. The visit came less than a week after the new French president announced at a NATO summit meeting that France would pull its troops out of Afghanistan by the end of this year, two years ahead of the 2014 deadline previously agreed to by NATO and the United States for withdrawal.

Geographically speaking, Long Island begins just across the Brooklyn Bridge from Manhattan. And Brooklyn was the setting for a showcase of East End wines this month, along with a few from the Finger Lakes and the Hudson Valley. The annual large-scale tasting, called Brooklyn Uncorked, was sponsored by Edible Brooklyn and Edible Manhattan magazines, with the help of the Long Island Wine Council, a trade association.
THE OUTSOURCED SELF Intimate Life in Market Times

Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about a study on the coverage available from health insurance policies gave an outdated name for a research center where the study's lead author, Jon R. Gabel, works. He is a health researcher at NORC at the University of Chicago; it is no longer known as the National Opinion Research Center.

MOSCOW -- What began as a legislative debate over Ukraine's official language policy escalated into a fist-swinging, clothes-ripping brawl between screaming, sweaty lawmakers that reverberated around the Internet on Friday, embellishing the country's standing in the pantheon of parliamentary punchfests that are captured on camera. In what the BBC called the ''Rumble in the Rada,'' parliamentarians tumbled over their desks in the parliamentary chamber in Kiev, the capital, on Thursday night, trading blows, tearing shirts and choking one another as reporters and spectators in the balconies whistled and cheered. One deputy, thrown headfirst into a chair, turned and stumbled back into the melee. Another was flipped over a banister, feet flailing.

After the fireworks and decisive results of Games 7 and 8, the world chess championship match between Viswanathan Anand, the titleholder, and Boris Gelfand, lapsed back into relative calm as Games 9 and 10 were drawn on Wednesday and Thursday. The score in the best-of-12 match, which is being played in Moscow in the Tretyakov Gallery museum is tied at 5 points apiece. If the score is tied after the next two games, there will be a series of four rapid games to decide the title.

MUNICH -- When Germany wants to understand Greece and the crisis afflicting Europe it not only looks south to the Continent's periphery but also turns inward, to the former East Germany, still struggling more than two decades after German reunification. To an extent not often appreciated by outsiders, the lessons provided by that experience -- with the nation pouring $2 trillion or more into the east, by some estimates, to little immediate benefit -- color the outlook and decisions of policy makers and the attitudes of voters, a majority of whom would like to see Greece leave the euro zone, polls show.

When news broke last week that the billionaire investor Joe Ricketts had considered financing a $10 million advertising effort linking President Obama with the fiery race-based rhetoric of his former spiritual adviser, the Rev. Jeremiah A. Wright Jr., Mr. Ricketts quickly distanced himself from the proposal and Mitt Romney's campaign denounced it. But Mr. Ricketts is continuing to play a provocative role in the effort to defeat Mr. Obama.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala. -- A Birmingham police officer with almost three years on the force has been arrested after a series of arsons in abandoned houses in the city and a suburb this month. Fourteen houses were set ablaze in western Birmingham, and nine in the northern suburb of Warrior.
BRING UP THE BODIES By Hilary Mantel

JOHNSON--Ralph V. - On behalf of the Calvary Hospital and Calvary Fund Boards of Directors, Administration, and staff of Calvary Hospital, Inc., we mourn the passing of our longtime Board member, Ralph V. Johnson. Mr. Johnson served on the hospital Board of Directors since 1993. He gave generously of his time as a member of the Human Resources Committee and the Planning/Facility Committee. His commitment to the special mission of Calvary Hospital, and his dedication and leadership contributed enormously to the quality of care of Calvary's special patients. We will miss Ralph V. Johnson, both as a loyal Board member and a member of the Calvary Family. We extend our condolences to his family. Thomas J. Fahey, Jr., MD, Chairman, Calvary Hospital Board of Directors Steven J. Golub, Chairman of Calvary Fund Board of Directors Frank A. Calamari, President Chief Executive Officer Michael J. Brescia, MD, Executive Medical Director Robert Brescia, MD Director of Calvary Palliative Care Institute Christopher P. Comfort, MD Medical Director Richard J. Kutilek, Chief Operating Officer Andrew V. Greco Chief Financial Officer Vincent J. Spinelli, Executive VP, Calvary Fund

MEXICO CITY (AP) -- People suspected of being drug gang members opened fire on a hotel being used as a police dormitory and then attacked it with a car bomb on Thursday, wounding seven officers, Mexican officials said. The hotel is less than four miles from the border with the United States. A Tamaulipas State official said that the authorities thought the Zetas, one of Mexico's two most powerful criminal organizations, carried out the attack on the Hotel Santa Cecilia in Nuevo Laredo, a city across the border from Laredo, Tex.

BANGKOK -- Amid widespread anxiety in Thailand about his health, King Bhumibol Adulyadej made a rare visit outside his hospital suite on Friday in what senior Thai officials described as a demonstration of his improved fitness. It was the first time in two years that the king, who is 84, had traveled outside greater Bangkok, Thai television said. The king has suffered from a number of illnesses not completely explained by the palace.

SPEAKEASY-STYLE bars with secret entrances and Prohibition themes may be popular, but their illegality is only an illusion. That wasn't the case when 100 guests gathered in a Los Angeles loft for a party celebrating April 20, which has emerged as a national holiday for marijuana users.

J.R. Smith, the Knicks guard with a history of legal troubles, was arrested in Miami Beach on Thursday for failing to appear in court on a traffic matter. Smith, 26, was cited in May 2011 for operating a scooter without a valid driver's license and was ordered to stand trial on July 25. When he failed to show, a bench warrant was issued for his arrest.

On Sunday, because of Shavuot, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City. Other regulations will remain in effect. Alternate-side street-cleaning regulations also will be suspended on Monday because of Shavuot and Memorial Day.

BAKU, Azerbaijan -- About 50 antigovernment demonstrators were arrested Friday evening in Baku while trying to stage a flash rally in the city center, as opponents of President Ilham Aliyev sought to use the Eurovision Song Contest to draw international attention to human rights abuses. The Eurovision finale will be held in Baku on Saturday night, and a dress rehearsal was under way when plainclothes police officers began arresting protesters. The demonstrators said they were demanding the release of political prisoners. It was the third time this week that the police arrested protesters hoping to take advantage of the buzz around the Eurovision contest.

Watching the meter climb in New York City's yellow cabs could get a whole lot more stressful this summer after the Taxi and Limousine Commission raises basic fares for the first time since 2006. (The state added a fee of 50 cents per ride in 2009.) Drivers want a fare increase of about 16 percent. Taxi owners also want the commission to approve an increase in the amount that they can charge drivers to use their cabs. So there is talk that taxi fares could increase by 20 percent. Cabs in New York still wouldn't cost as much as in London or Tokyo, but that's not much consolation.

Scores of federal regulators are stationed inside JPMorgan Chase's Manhattan headquarters, but none of them were assigned to the powerful unit that recently disclosed a multibillion trading loss. Roughly 40 examiners from the Federal Reserve Bank of New York and 70 staff members from the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency are embedded in the nation's largest bank. They are typically assigned to the departments undertaking the greatest risks, like the structured products trading desk. Even as the chief investment office swelled in size and made increasingly large bets, regulators did not put any examiners in the unit's offices in London or New York, according to current and former regulators who spoke only on condition of anonymity.

The year 2012 looks a lot like 2008: high unemployment, a candidate named Obama promising to do something about high unemployment, and the Giants beating the Patriots in the Super Bowl. And one more thing: conservatives are still ridiculing liberation theology. With the complicity of clueless pundits and incurious journalists, they are reducing an important theological movement of the past 40 years to an abusive sound bite. In 2008, conservatives gleefully attacked the Rev. Jeremiah A. Wright Jr., Mr. Obama's home pastor in Chicago, for his provocative remarks in sermons, taken out of context, including his assertion that 9/11 was evidence that ''America's chickens are coming home to roost.'' They persuaded many that Mr. Wright was wielding something called ''liberation theology'' -- and that Candidate Obama had to answer for it.

MIAMI BEACH HIS has been just about the biggest name in Spanish-language pop music over the last decade, but the Colombian singer-songwriter Juanes is approaching a crossroads, and he knows it. Not only will he will turn 40 this summer, but for several years now he has been harboring reservations about the direction his career has taken.
THOSE WHO HAVE BORNE THE BATTLE A History of America's Wars and Those Who Fought Them

President Dilma Rousseff on Friday vetoed portions of Brazil's new Forest Code, a bill drafted to open big areas of protected forests to large-scale agriculture. The decision by Ms. Rousseff, which removes 12 articles from the bill, alters legislation sought by powerful agricultural groups. The bill had provoked outrage among environmentalists, some business leaders and cultural icons, especially over a provision that effectively granted amnesty to landowners who illegally deforested some areas. Responding to these concerns, Environment Minister Izabella Teixeira said the president's line-item vetoes ruled out amnesty. Still, Ms. Rousseff's action fell short of the expectations of environmental groups, which had wanted her to veto the entire bill. Details about the changes to the bill were sparse on Friday, with Brazil's powerful Agriculture and Livestock Confederation withholding comment. The official text of Ms. Rousseff's alterations, which include dozens of suggested changes to the bill in addition to the vetoed portions, is expected to be published on Monday.

A picture caption on Thursday with a dance review of Cedar Lake Contemporary Ballet, at the Joyce Theater in Manhattan, misidentified the dancer shown with Jubal Battisti. He is Oscar Ramos -- not Jon Bond, another member of the company.

LONDON -- Prime Minister David Cameron on Friday defended his handling of a contentious and ultimately doomed $12 billion bid by the media conglomerate owned by Rupert Murdoch to take control of Britain's most powerful and lucrative pay-television network, and offered new backing to an embattled cabinet minister who had pushed energetically for the bid's approval. On a day when Britain's newspapers splashed their front pages with accounts of earlier maneuvering to assure approval for the bid by Mr. Murdoch's News Corporation, Mr. Cameron appeared on a morning television show to offer a rebuttal of any wrongdoing on his part or by the minister, Jeremy Hunt, who lobbied for the Murdoch bid before Mr. Cameron appointed him to oversee the regulatory process involved.

CANNES, France -- The Austrian director Michael Haneke has made an art of exploiting audience discomfort. In a sense his new film, ''Amour,'' continues in that vein by staring down the least palatable of subjects: aging, sickness and death. But the universal specter of mortality has brought with it a tenderness seldom seen in Mr. Haneke's cool, analytical cinema, and the film remains the closest thing to a consensus favorite among critics at the Cannes Film Festival here. As the festival enters its final weekend, ''Amour'' also looks like a strong contender for a top prize at the awards ceremony on Sunday. (Mr. Haneke's previous film, ''The White Ribbon,'' took the Palme d'Or in 2009.)

Donna Summer, the pop singer and disco queen behind hits like ''I Feel Love'' and ''Hot Stuff,'' was remembered Wednesday at a funeral service for family members and close friends at Christ Presbyterian Church in Nashville, The Associated Press reported. Ms. Summer, who won five Grammy Awards during a career that spanned some 30 years, died of cancer on May 17 at her home in Naples, Fla. She was 63. Among those who paid tribute to Ms. Summer at the memorial service, The A.P. said, were the producer David Foster (he had worked with Ms. Summer since the early 1980s), who sang ''The Prayer'' with Natalie Grant. Giorgio Moroder, who produced songs for Ms. Summer like ''Love to Love You Baby'' was also in attendance, as was Tony Orlando. Ms. Summer's sisters, Linda Gaines Lotman, Mary Ellen Bernard, Dara Bernard and Jenette Yancey, performed ''We've Come This Far by Faith'' at the service.

His specter loomed over the coziest of breakfast nooks, in the bleakest crevices of parents' minds and in the fretful warnings that tumbled from their lips: Remember the boy who disappeared. On Thursday, New York City revisited the case that has gripped it since the boy, Etan Patz, went missing 33 years ago, as Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kellyannounced the arrest of Pedro Hernandez, 51, in the killing. The 6-year-old boy's disappearance in SoHo in 1979 focused national attention on missing children and set off a long quest for answers that seemed never to come.

AMERICAN fashion, like many Americans, is torn between the past and the future. While designers are swaddling and coddling customers in fondly retooled visions of yesteryear -- just pick a decade -- some designers are trying to take a blindfolded whack at the future. Some hit the piñata, and some hit the wall. If you were to pay a visit to Jack McCollough and Lazaro Hernandez, the two young men behind the fashion line Proenza Schouler, at the country house they share in the Berkshires in Western Massachusetts, you would assume they belonged to the yesteryear school. The house is a clapboard center-hall Colonial built in 1792 and sits on 100 acres of woods and pastures speckled with grazing cows and pigs from neighboring farms.

CLEVELAND -- In Florida, a state trooper pulled Jim Wilson off the highway, but instead of issuing a speeding ticket, asked a favor: Could he have a few Romney for President bumper stickers? In Michigan, a woman left a handwritten letter for Mitt Romney on Mr. Wilson's dashboard, recounting her husband's trouble finding work. ''We pray you can get us out of this mess,'' she wrote.

BEARDED, willowy and often dressed in white, Alexander Ebert, the frontman of the folk-rock act Edward Sharpe and the Magnetic Zeros, has a hippie leader vibe. It helps that his band's music feels like a community singalong, with group harmonies and whistling, snaps and hand claps as percussion. Mr. Ebert started the band in California with the singer Jade Castrinos; their romance was captured on their 2009 debut album, ''Up From Below,'' in tracks like the hit single ''Home.'' As they and their many bandmates spent the last few years on tour, building a fan base with their stirring live shows -- audience members dance ecstatically, Mr. Ebert joining in, until he beckons them to sit in a circle around him for a quiet song -- singles like ''Home'' and ''Janglin' '' had a steady presence on TV and on movie soundtracks. Now the band has grown enough to sell out large clubs like the 6,000-seat Greek Theater in Los Angeles.

WHEN economic waters are rough -- or perhaps just to shake things up in times of stagnation -- musical institutions try to redefine themselves, sharpen their sense of mission and do some image tweaking. That can be hard when your mission is already unusual and clearly defined. But the American Composers Orchestra, which has been putting a spotlight on (mostly contemporary) American music since 1977, has lately been reinventing itself as a hybrid performing ensemble and service organization. ''I think of the A.C.O. a little bit like the Bronx Zoo,'' Michael Geller, the orchestra's executive director, said recently. ''If you didn't know anything about zoos, and I asked you what its mission was, you would say, 'It looks like a place where grandparents take children to entertain themselves while they're getting to observe living creatures.' But of course their mission is not that. Their mission is environmental. It's about protecting species. It's about doing research. The zoo is the public face of it, and that's important. Clearly if it were just a research center, it wouldn't be the same.

Admit it, Victorian mystery fans. We've been spoiled by the rigorous scholarship of writers like Peter Ackroyd, lulled by the formal elegance of stylists like Anne Perry. In short, we've lost touch with the lurid traditions of the 19th-century potboiler. Consider THE YARD (Putnam, $26.95) a crude corrective to those literary leanings. This deliciously trashy first novel by Alex Grecian walks the genre back to the era of Jack the Ripper with its bloody tale of a serial killer who is systematically butchering detectives from Scotland Yard's recently formed Murder Squad. ''Jack was the first of a new breed,'' Sir Edward Bradford, the police commissioner who created this elite division, remarks. ''He opened a door to certain deranged possibilities and there will be more like him.''

10 P.M. (A&E) PAUL SIMON'S GRACELAND JOURNEY: UNDER AFRICAN SKIES (2012) The filmmaker Joe Berlinger celebrates the 25th anniversary of ''Graceland,'' a masterwork by Mr. Simon (above center), while examining that singer-songwriter's decision to travel to apartheid-era Johannesburg in 1985 to record South African musicians during a cultural boycott of that country. ''The film's happiest moment is its clip of a 'Saturday Night Live' performance of 'Diamonds on the Soles of Her Shoes,' by Mr. Simon with Ladysmith Black Mambazo, that preceded the album's release,'' Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times. ''This sparkling, buoyant performance reminds you that great music outlasts the politics of the moment.'' 11:10 A.M. (Sundance) FLIGHT OF THE RED BALLOON (2008) The Taiwanese master Hou Hsiao-hsien creates a love letter to Paris -- and to Albert Lamorisse's 1956 classic, ''The Red Balloon'' -- in this tale about Suzanne (Juliette Binoche, left), a puppeteer; her lonely 7-year-old son, Simon (Simon Iteanu); and Song (Song Fang), a Chinese film student hired to be his nanny. ''In the end what elevates Mr. Hou's films to the sublime -- and this one comes close at times -- are not the stories but their telling,'' Manohla Dargis wrote in The Times. ''In 'Flight of the Red Balloon' Mr. Hou plays with light and space on the small canvas that is Simon and Suzanne's apartment, moving the camera around as gracefully as if it were a brush (or a balloon).'' In ''The Pool'' (2008), at 1:10 p.m., Venkatesh (Venkatesh Chavan), an Indian teenager on the verge of manhood who ekes out a living cleaning hotel rooms and selling plastic bags on the street, becomes obsessed with the shimmering pool of a luxurious home, where no one seems to swim. Eventually he approaches the property's owner (Nana Patekar) and becomes his assistant; the rich man, in turn, promises to become Venkatesh's benefactor if he will move from Goa to Mumbai and go to school. ''Just when you expect the film to turn into a predictable, rose-colored valentine to opportunity and hope, it goes to a deeper, more ambiguous place,'' Stephen Holden wrote in The Times about this movie by Chris Smith, adapted from a short story by Randy Russell. ''Contemplating poverty from Venkatesh's perspective, it understands that his pursuit of upward mobility will require a terrifying leap of faith.''

As if we didn't have enough probably fictitious but possibly real beings to worry about. All over basic cable, people are searching for Bigfoot, hunting down ghosts, looking for extraterrestrials. Now, it turns out, we need to add mermaids to the list. At least we do if you take ''Mermaids: The Body Found'' seriously. Which you shouldn't. The film, Sunday night on Animal Planet and part of its Monster Week, is a fictional account built on a few strands of fact and made to look like an actual documentary. If you know those ground rules, it's a rather enjoyable and intriguing piece of work, in the same vein as ''The Blair Witch Project.''

When Barry Rigal read last Monday's column, he wrote to say it reminded him of this diagramed deal, which occurred during the World Transnational Mixed Teams Championship in Rhodes, Greece, in 1996. The details were sent to me by Rich Colker, who described it in that year's world championship book.

Nice, France IT was James, a thickset American interrogator nicknamed ''the Elephant,'' who first told Lakhdar Boumediene that investigators were certain of his innocence, that two years of questioning had shown he was no terrorist, but that it did not matter, Mr. Boumediene says.

The resignation of Gregory Jaczko, the embattled chairman of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, means the country is losing a strong advocate for public safety who was always willing to challenge the nuclear industry and its political backers in Congress. The White House's choice to replace him, Allison Macfarlane, has strong credentials as an expert on nuclear waste and weapons. She will need to be as independent and aggressive as Dr. Jaczko. Both industry and her fellow commissioners will have to be pushed to implement necessary improvements highlighted by the disaster at the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant in Japan.

The rain fell in sheets, cascading rapidly off the brim of Jeremy Hefner's royal blue hat, but he hardly seemed to notice. Hefner, the Mets' starter, cruised through the first two innings of his first major league start. He didn't ask to stop. The rain kept coming. The umpires called for a delay, which lasted 68 minutes. Hefner resumed but never revived the momentum he had built before the weather washed it all away.

An art review last Friday about the new home of the Barnes Foundation collection, in Philadelphia, referred incompletely to the design of the lighting system. It was done by Paul Marantz and his firm, Fisher Marantz Stone, not just by Mr. Marantz.
To the Editor: Re ''Gates Puts the Focus on Teaching,'' by Joe Nocera (column, May 22):

Too much dairy, too little fiber, and too few vegetables and fruits can contribute to constipation. In particular, P-letter fruits may help: prunes, pears, plums and peaches. Children may avoid defecation, ''withholding'' as pediatricians call it, to try to control their environment. Stressors include a new sibling or school, toilet training, moving homes, unfamiliar bathrooms. Stools that hurt to pass can also lead to withholding.

Latin jazz at its best enacts a kind of diplomacy, a dialogue between two separate but related parties. The trumpeter and conguero Jerry Gonzalez has long been an emissary in the field, equally fluent in hard bop and the music of the Afro-Caribbean diasporas, and given to reconciling the two. In recent years he has worked extensively with flamenco musicians, as a byproduct of his nearly decade-long residency in Madrid. But his signature group remains the Fort Apache Band, which he formed in the Bronx with his brother, the bassist Andy Gonzalez, more than 30 years ago.

AS a child, Kelly Slater surfed the modest swells near his home in Cocoa Beach, Fla. ''You wouldn't ever say we had world-class waves,'' he recalled. ''They don't have good shape and aren't especially great in any way.''

ROME -- After months out of the spotlight, former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi of Italy made a rare public appearance on Friday to call for an overhaul of the country's Constitution that would allow Italians to directly elect the nation's president, instead of letting Parliament make that choice, as is now the case. And Mr. Berlusconi, who stepped aside last November amid personal scandals and political instability, said he would be willing to try to fill those hypothetical presidential shoes, should his party ask him to.

SCHAJER--Morris, PhD, 66, of New York City, NY passed away May 23, 2012. He was born April 6, 1946 in Bagnoli, Italy, the son of the late Samuel Schajer, and Lola Schajer, who survives. He was a Doctor of Social Work in private practice. He is survived by his mother, Lola Schajer, his son Robert and his wife Nancy and their children Alexander and Cassandra, son David Schajer, brother Abraham and his wife Madeline and their children Jeffrey-Scott and Alison, sister Susan and her husband Jay and their children Fallon, Marc, and Andrew, brother Jeffrey and his wife Carol and their children Michael and Lena, sister Karen and her husband Barry and their children Matthew, Jennifer and Heather, and many dear friends and loved ones, including his aunts Sally and Rosa. A service will be held on Monday, May 28 at 9:30am, in New York City at Temple Emanu-El on 1 East 65th St., in the Bethel Chapel, followed by an entombment at 11:30am, at Mt. Lebanon Cemetery 7800 Myrtle Avenue in Queens. For more info go to jewish-funeral-home.com

SAN FRANCISCO -- A just-completed report from a presidential advisory committee urges President Obama to adopt new computer technologies to make better use of a huge swath of the radio spectrum now controlled by federal agencies. The shift, which could be accomplished by presidential signature -- and without Congressional involvement -- would relieve spectrum congestion caused by the popularity of smartphones, and generate far more revenue for the federal government than auctioning spectrum to wireless carriers, according to the authors of the report.

C. B. Bucknor, 50, was a physical therapist at what was then New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center when, on a whim, he used vacation time to attend umpire school in 1990. A career change ensued. Now, most of his Sundays involve ballgames and airline travel; he umpires 135 Major League games a season, not counting spring training and the playoffs. (He has worked the playoffs three times, but never a World Series, and his calls have sometimes been controversial.) In the off-season he spends time in his hometown, Savanna-la-Mar, Jamaica, where he helps run an annual ''Treat 54'' party (named for his uniform number) for local children. He lives in Prospect-Lefferts Gardens, Brooklyn, with his wife, who is a registered nurse, and their children, ages 9, 15 and 17; his mother lives upstairs. STRETCH AND DIP I get up by 8 or 9, and whether I'm at home or on the road, the first thing I do is exercise. You have to be in good shape for this job: We're on a four-man crew and rotate the bases with each game. When you're at home plate calling balls and strikes, besides having to constantly use your judgment, you're doing around 300 dips. It's tough on the knees. I spend an hour on stretching, push-ups, situps and dips. Before spring training, I run at least two miles a day in Prospect Park, but I'm not a treadmill guy.

CHICAGO -- As Dr. Danielle McCarthy listens to a man beg for a prescription for painkillers, she weighs her possible responses. A 31-year-old emergency room physician, she listens patiently as the man tells her that ''every morning I wake up in pain,'' describing the agony he continues to endure, three years after being injured in a car wreck.
AEROGRAMMES And Other Stories

This Memorial Day weekend, visitors to the Fire Island Pines will find the prominent waterfront site long occupied by the Pavilion, the island's legendary spot for dancing and trysting, to be little more than a forlorn lot containing sand, ashen debris and memories of giddier times. But the owners of the club, which was gutted by a fire in November, have vowed to rebuild the Pavilion, an emotional touchstone for generations of gay men who found liberation, and sometimes romance, on its cavernous dance floor. They have released plans for the new building, which they say will reopen in time for the 2013 season.

STORCH--George D. George D. Storch, 90 years old, on May 23, 2012. Born in Zamosc, Poland. Devoted son of the late Rabbi Sholom Storch and Rivka (Peltz) Storch. Beloved husband of Rose Storch. Loving father of Oliver(Geidy) Storch, and Vivian (John) Cannon. Adoring grandfather of Daniel, Benjamin, Phoebe and Zoe. Survivor of the Holocaust. Was able to save his parents, late siblings Chana Bruce, Miriam Lewent, Bella Chaim, Joseph and niece Florence Edelstein from Nazi capture by escaping to Russia and Kazakhstan. Decorated and twice wounded Lieutenant in the 1st. Polish Army under Marshal Konstantin Rokossovsky during WW II. Retired nightclub entrepreneur and real estate investor. A true Mensch, fluent in five languages, who's big smile and charisma enriched the lives of all he met. He will be truly missed. Donations in his memory may be made to the National Kidney Foundation.

The first modern fly-destruction device was invented in 1900 by Robert R. Montgomery, an entrepreneur based in Decatur, Ill. Montgomery was issued Patent No. 640,790 for the Fly-Killer, a ''cheap device of unusual elasticity and durability'' made of wire netting, ''preferably oblong,'' attached to a handle. The material of the handle remained unspecified, but the netting was crucial: it reduced wind drag, giving the swatter a ''whiplike swing.'' By 1901, Montgomery's invention was advertised in Ladies' Home Journal as a tool that ''kills without crushing'' and ''soils nothing,'' unlike, say, a rolled-up newspaper might. Montgomery sold the patent rights in 1903 to an industrialist named John L. Bennett, who later invented the beer can. Bennett improved the design -- stitching around the edge of the netting to keep it from fraying -- but left the name.

Pom Wonderful, the provocative purveyor of pomegranate juice, began a highly aggressive ad campaign Thursday to challenge a potentially damaging ruling by an administrative judge, who found that the company had greatly exaggerated the product's health benefits. The ruling Monday by Judge D. Michael Chappell came in response to a complaint by the Federal Trade Commission two years ago. He found that the company had insufficient evidence to support claims that its juice reduced the risks of heart disease, prostate cancer and impotence, and issued a cease-and-desist order that forbids the company from making the claims for 20 years.

The long march of Mets history resumes Sunday after a 16-year break, as Banner Day materializes anew before the club's 1:10 matinee game against the San Diego Padres. If precedent is a reliable indicator, paint will be spilled, linens will be ruined and at least a few people will have something clever to say. Stretching from the twilight of the Mets' Manhattan origins in September 1963 to the end of their Dallas Green period in August 1996, Banner Day was the quintessential Mets promotion, a tradition for a franchise that often seems uncomfortable acknowledging it has them.

In 2007, Noomi Rapace read for the part of Lisbeth Salander in the Swedish film version of ''The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo'' as a long-shot contender. Though she was a smart and seasoned actress who had worked in film as well as onstage, she was known mainly to Stockholm theatergoers. Her name barely surfaced in the lively public debate in Sweden over who should play Lisbeth, one of the most sought after film roles for a Swedish actress in recent memory. Moreover, the film's director, Niels Arden Oplev, feared that Rapace was too attractive to portray the androgynous Lisbeth. After working through a scene with her, though, he changed his mind. ''When she's Lisbeth and you put a camera on her, and she's just sitting there looking at you, you think, Oh, my God, what is she going to do?'' he says. ''There's an unpredictable, dark, dangerous energy that flows from her.'' Once he cast her, she gave herself over to the task of transforming into the alienated hacker-heroine of Stieg Larsson's ''Millennium'' trilogy, even as the novels' popularity began to snowball outside of Sweden. (The English translation of the first novel came out in 2008.) She trained with a Thai-boxing coach, submitted to multiple piercings and lopped off her hair. Then she shot the three films, one right after the other, over an 18-month period. When the first film opened, in February 2009, journalists from all over Europe descended on Stockholm to see it -- and to see her, the unknown actress charged with interpreting what had suddenly become one of the world's most popular characters.

People have snickered for years about ''Cats,'' suggesting that the reason the show became the second-longest-running hit in Broadway history (after ''The Phantom of the Opera'') was that the dance-driven extravaganza was an ideal attraction for tourists who did not speak English. But I suspect that some who dismiss this musical as mere spectacle have never actually seen or heard it. Maybe it is time they did. Certainly, they will see a capably performed ''Cats'' at the Gateway Playhouse, which previously presented the musical in 2004. It is directed and choreographed this time by Jacob Brent, who performed in ''Cats'' on Broadway, in London and in the DVD version. The current revival in Bellport is a smaller-scale but otherwise fairly faithful rendition of the show, which ran for 7,485 performances at the Winter Garden Theater beginning in 1982, a year after it opened in London.

So I guess you've heard about the recent initial public offering that didn't turn out the way it was supposed to. The company's Wall Street advisers misjudged the market, and, on its first day of trading, the stock went a little haywire. Then it slowly sank, dropping around 10 percent over the next month. No, I'm not talking about Facebook. I am referring to Splunk, an 8-year-old, money-losing data analytics company that went public five weeks ago. Splunk's investment bankers priced the stock at $17 a share. But it closed its first day of trading at $35.48 -- a gain of 109 percent -- before declining over the next month. (It has rebounded in the last week.)

Where are the start-up airlines? With the big carriers cutting routes and raising fares, this would seem an ideal time for a new airline to take them on with cut-rate prices and service to smaller airports eager for more flights. That is the path, after all, taken by two of the industry's success stories -- Southwest Airlines, back in 1971, and JetBlue Airways, in 2000.

International atomic inspectors in Iran have detected traces of uranium enriched to levels of purity higher than the Iranians have previously disclosed, according to a new report on Tehran's nuclear program made public on Friday. The report, by the International Atomic Energy Agency, an arm of the United Nations based in Vienna, said its inspectors had taken environmental samples at a uranium-enrichment plant in a mountain bunker and discovered purities up to 27 percent.

''I WANT the fabulous hat,'' Caroline Traugott said with a laugh. ''And whatever goes with it, who cares?'' When Ms. Traugott, a young mother from the neighborhood, came to Suzanne Couture Millinery on East 61st Street in late April to find a hat for the Central Park Conservancy's 30th annual Frederick Law Olmsted awards lunch, she brought six dresses with her. With the help of Suzanne Newman, the owner, she'd chosen a small headpiece -- a fascinator, strictly speaking -- with skinny blue and black feathers waving about like errant thoughts. The dress it suited best was, Ms. Traugott later confessed, ''a cheapie.'' But the dress was not the point.

All this season in New York, opera lovers and longtime admirers of the storied Cleveland Orchestra had been eagerly anticipating the concert performance of Strauss's ''Salome'' at Carnegie Hall that finally took place on Thursday night. This was a chance to hear Strauss's incandescent score played by that great orchestra from the stage of the acoustically glorious Carnegie Hall, with the stunning dramatic soprano Nina Stemme in the title role, and the powerhouse bass-baritone Eric Owens as Jochanaan. The performance delivered over all, and the ovation was tremendous. But the conducting of Franz Welser-Möst, while commanding, intelligent and organic, lacked the extra dimension of intensity and terror that make for a great ''Salome.''

A BREAKTHROUGH occurred last November on the CBS comedy ''The Big Bang Theory.'' Sheldon Cooper, the commitment-wary physicist, ramped up his courtship of Amy Fowler, the skittish neurobiologist. ''I present to you,'' he says, ''the Relationship Agreement.''

PALO ALTO, Calif. THE wedding of Mark Zuckerberg to Priscilla Chan last weekend here in the backyard of their $7 million home had all the staging of a carefully orchestrated celebrity event. A publicist for Facebook eagerly offered photos afterward of the beaming couple, who met at Harvard and have dated for much of the last nine years. Well-placed anonymous sources leaked to reporters the dinner menu, which included sushi and Mexican food, and the fact that Green Day's Billie Joe Armstrong performed.
THE LAST ENGLISHMAN The Double Life of Arthur Ransome

Could it happen now? Could someone sinister pluck a small child off that same street at that same hour on the same day, so that he vanished into the ether for 33 years? It was May 25, 1979, when the 6-year-old Etan Patz went missing on Prince Street in SoHo. The long cold case gained fresh traction on Thursday when the police said Pedro Hernandez confessed to strangling the child in the basement of the bodega where he worked. Etan was walking to the school bus stop, barely two blocks from his home, the first time he went by himself.

A Bronx jury awarded about $120 million on Friday to a woman who has been incapacitated since she was treated at three local hospitals in 2004. The award, by a State Supreme Court jury, was made in a lawsuit filed on behalf of Jacqueline Martin, now 45, by her mother. Ms. Martin suffered brain damage after a series of hospital visits in February 2004, the family's lawyer, Tom Moore, said.

What can you say about a 72-year-old man who died? More salient, what can you say about a 27-year-old novel that survives him? That it was a best seller. And brilliant in parts, but mostly not. That it loved Mozart and Bach. And Harvard. Also Harvard. Did I mention Harvard?

In the months leading up to North Carolina's vote this month to ban gay marriage, most of the state's business leaders were conspicuously silent. While some executives spoke out against it as individuals, not one Fortune 500 company based in North Carolina, including Bank of America, Duke Energy, VF Corporation and Lowe's, opposed it. But one company did: Replacements Limited, which sells silver, china and glassware, and is based in Greensboro. Its founder and chairman, Bob Page, is gay. The company lobbied legislators, contributed money to causes supporting gay marriage, rented a billboard along the interstate near its headquarters, and sold T-shirts at its showroom. Its experience may explain why no other for-profit company followed its example.

IF I could return to just one moment in New York's story, I would go back to the Roaring Twenties, with their radiant gatherings in Harlem and the rise of the Chrysler Building, when the city threw its most jubilant parade for Charles Lindbergh, the shy young pilot who, F. Scott Fitzgerald wrote, had seemingly nothing to do with his generation except allowing us to dream once more of our greatest possibilities. I would watch Babe Ruth round the bases with odd little steps, and at night I would visit the one place to be: the Casino, the elegant night spot in Central Park. Just inside and southwest of Inventors' Gate at Fifth Avenue and 72nd Street, where today's SummerStage concerts are held, the Casino on many nights had fancy cars three deep in a lot built for 300. Bewitching cocktail music and the fragrance of foods drifted to the treetops when even the stars seemed ordered by the maître d'.

NEWARK -- On May 25, 1994, the Devils stood on the verge of eliminating the Rangers in Game 6 of the Eastern Conference finals, but blew a 2-0 lead and lost the game and the series. So it was again in Game 6 on May 25, 2012. Martin Brodeur was the man in the Devils' net both games, living a bad dream and forced to relive it almost two decades later.

STEINBERG--Andrew, 53, of Chevy Chase, MD and Falls Village, CT, died at home in Chevy Chase on May 20 of uveal melanoma. A partner in the Washington, DC office of Jones Day, one of the nation's leading aviation regulatory lawyers; a man of extraordinary intellect, integrity and humility. Held both of the nation's two top aviation regulatory positions under President George W. Bush. Was a recognized authority on legal issues relating to modernizing air traffic control, aviation and aerospace regulation, aviation and climate change, foreign market access, computerized travel distribution. From 2006 until 2008, was Assistant Secretary of Transportation for Aviation and International Affairs; from 2003 to 2006 was Chief Counsel of the Federal Aviation Administration. He was Executive Vice President and General Counsel of Travelocity.com from inception of the company in 2000 until 2003. From 1996 to 2000 he was Executive Vice President and General Counsel of SABRE, which he guided through separation from American Airlines to a public company in 2000. From 1990 to 1996 held senior legal positions at American Airlines, as Associate General Counsel for employment and environmental and Senior Attorney for antitrust. Prior to 1990 Andy was an associate in the Los Angeles office of Gibson, Dunn, and Crutcher, practicing antitrust and commercial litigation. During his tenure at the U.S. Dept of Transportation, led the department's efforts to secure open skies agreement with the E.U. and helped negotiate agreement with China that doubled the number of routes between China and the U.S. With U.S. Depts. of State and Treasury, directed the Civil Aviation delegation of the first China-U.S. Strategic Economic Dialogue (SED) in 2006 led by then-Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson. He led the U.S. delegation in Montreal during the 2007 International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) Assembly, defending the U.S. position on aviation and climate change, for which he was later awarded the Stratospheric Ozone Protection Award (now known as the Montreal Protocol Award) from the Environmental Protection Agency. At the FAA, promoted the use of satellite based air traffic systems to modernize air traffic control and improve safety in the U.S. and abroad, and was instrumental in spearheading FAA's legal strategy in protracted labor negotiations with air traffic controllers. While at Travelocity, he had the unusual distinction of being awarded a citation from the F.B.I. for work pursuing information about the transactions of an infamous Travelocity customer, Muhammad Atta, a 9/11 hijacker who used Travelocity.com to make reservations for air and car travel in the months leading up to the attacks. That information later proved useful in leading to the arrests of Al-Qaida terrorists in Spain and Germany. Earlier in his career, he represented American Airlines in defeating claims of predatory pricing and monopolization by Continental Airlines and Northwest Airlines. Andy was born in Perth Amboy, NJ, grew up in Scarsdale and graduated from Edgemont High School. He earned his A.B. from Princeton in 1980, and J.D. from Harvard Law School in 1984, after teaching English in Japan through Princeton-in-Asia. He clerked for the Honorable Richard H. Gadbois, Jr., in the U.S. District Court in the Central District of California. Andy served as president of the International Aviation Club of Washington, D.C., on the governing committee of the ABA Air and Space Law Forum, on the Board of the Empower African Children Foundation, and volunteered for Boy Scout Troop 52 in Chevy Chase. Andy loved bicycling around Washington, DC and the country roads near his home in Falls Village. His main hobby was being with his family, sharing music, travel, and well-written comedy; a quick, wry wit, he was a well-qualified critic. A devoted husband and father, Andy leaves and will forever be mourned by his wife Roxann, daughter Madeline and son Malcolm, his brother and sister-in-law, Laurence and Wendy Steinberg, of Philadelphia; his nephew, Benjamin Steinberg, of New York City, and will be sorely missed by friends, colleagues, and admirers worldwide. He was buried in Falls Village, CT; a memorial service will be held in Washington DC at a later date. Memorial contributions to The Eye Cancer Research Foundation, PO Box 832, Philadelphia, PA 19105

As part of her Diamond Jubilee celebration, Queen Elizabeth II has established a Web site featuring the complete personal journals of Queen Victoria, the only other sovereign in British history to have celebrated 60 years on the throne. The project, undertaken in collaboration with the Bodleian Libraries at Oxford and ProQuest and available at www.queenvictoriasjournals.org, marks the first time that Queen Victoria's diaries have been published in their entirety, as well as what Queen Elizabeth, in a message on the site, called ''the first major public release of material from the Royal Archives.''
To the Editor: Re ''Bishops Sue Over Contraception Mandate'' (news article, May 22):

As someone who rides a bicycle in New York City, I am still waiting for the smartphone revolution. There are dozens of public-transit apps for smartphones, offering all kinds of novel services. The offerings for the city's bikers, by contrast, are pretty sparse.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg may rule New York City, but he is also expanding his empire in Westchester County. For a modest -- by billionaire standards -- $4.55 million, Mr. Bloomberg bought a 33-acre estate in North Salem last year, according to tax returns and public records reviewed on Friday. The new property is likely to be combined with an adjacent 20-acre estate that Mr. Bloomberg has owned in North Salem since 2001 for the use of his daughter, Georgina, an accomplished equestrienne.

NEWARK -- On May 25, 1994, the Devils stood on the verge of eliminating the Rangers in Game 6 of the Eastern Conference finals, but blew a 2-0 lead and lost the game and the series. So it was again in Game 6 on May 25, 2012. Martin Brodeur was the man in the Devils' net both games, living a bad dream and forced to relive it almost two decades later.

Mike Woodson will be the Knicks' coach next season, and he will almost certainly have Jeremy Lin running his offense. The team officially lifted Woodson's interim title on Friday and signed him to a multiyear contract -- his reward for salvaging a seemingly dismal season and guiding the Knicks to the playoffs. The decision to retain Woodson was made weeks ago and had been widely reported, although working out the contract took some time.

HOME, by Toni Morrison. (Knopf, $24.) A black Korean War veteran, discharged from an integrated Army into a segregated homeland, makes a reluctant journey back to Georgia in a novel engaged with themes that have long haunted Morrison. FARTHER AWAY, by Jonathan Franzen. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $26.) The theme of human struggle against the pulls of solipsism and narcissism illuminates every page of the novelist's essays.
Pedro Hernandez, who was arrested on Thursday and accused of killing Etan Patz in 1979, faces a charge typical of the most serious killings in New York State.

The likelihood that any of the children in the article will ''end up just fine'' without intervention is extremely low. That's the approach our society has taken for too long: do nothing, wait until they grow up and commit crimes, then imprison them. The researchers in this article should be commended for their pioneering work in addressing an important, understudied societal problem. ERX, New York, posted on nytimes.com
International FORMER MONGOLIAN LEADER

FOXBOROUGH, Mass. -- When the junior varsity boys' lacrosse team at Chaminade High School faced St. Anthony's High School on Long Island in New York on Tuesday, a dozen Division I men's lacrosse coaches were in the stands watching. Seven sophomores playing in the game had already made verbal commitments to top college lacrosse programs around the country, before even putting on a varsity uniform or taking the SAT.

One of my earliest memories that doesn't have to do with my tonsillectomy or the arrival of my baby brother -- and I am not equating the two -- is of seeing President Kennedy ride along East 161st Street in the Bronx in the back of an open limousine, moving up the hill that begins at Yankee Stadium and ends at the Concourse Plaza Hotel, next door to which my family lived. It was 1962. I was 6 and perched on my dad's shoulders. One Sunday some 40 years later, I opened this newspaper to find confirmation of that gauzy memory: a photograph, taken from the south side of 161st Street. Kennedy is in the foreground, beyond him a crowd of spectators. There's a man wearing eyeglasses, and on his shoulders a boy. Unmistakable. I put down the newspaper and phoned my dad, and within days had ordered a print for each of us.

BOSTON -- Watching the Philadelphia 76ers push the Boston Celtics to the limit in their Eastern Conference semifinal playoff series harks back to another team that defied the odds more than once: the 1999 Knicks. The similarities between the teams are more of a statistical nature than of a personnel one. But like the '99 Knicks, the 2012 Sixers entered the playoffs in a lockout-shortened season as the eighth seed and proceeded to upend the No. 1 seed in the first round.

THE 2012 Chevrolet Camaro ZL1 has a heavy load to bear. Its model designation, borrowing the General Motors option code for one of the most storied V-8 engines of the muscle car's glory days, sets lofty expectations among those who lived through Detroit's horsepower wars. In truth, by the time the original ZL1 engine arrived in a limited run of bare-bones Camaro coupes for the 1969 model year, the muscle car craze was already doomed. Still, the car was remarkable: what looked like a 6-cylinder brown bag from the outside, with nothing, save for the bulge of its cold-air ZL2 hood, to give it away, was actually powered by an all-aluminum brute rumored to produce as much as 500 horsepower.

MIAMI BEACH -- This small city is accustomed to big events. But every Urban Beach Week, residents and businesses take in a collective deep breath and do not exhale until it's over. Since 2001, hundreds of thousands of young hip-hop devotees from around the country have descended on the South Beach neighborhood for Memorial Day weekend to hear some of country's leading artists and D.J.'s. As the visitors converge, a reverse migration ensues: Rresidents, beaten down by the traffic and chaos of the event, hop in their cars en masse and head to the mainland for a few days.

The gentleman of the house answers the doorbell in his bathrobe. He recognizes the cleaning woman (''the cleaner,'' that is; we are in London), but has no idea what her name is. She is almost nine months pregnant and has brought along her daughter, who is almost 9, for the day. The lady of the house has disappeared. We are off and running. ''My Wonderful Day,'' one of Alan Ayckbourn's lesser-known but absolutely not-less-funny comedies, is the final production of the Two River Theater Company's 2011-12 season. Mr. Ayckbourn has sent American theatergoers marvelous plays, like ''Absurd Person Singular,'' ''House'' and ''Garden,'' over the decades. This one overflows with his sophisticated signature style but differs in a couple of important ways. A child is at its center, and one-third of the characters are not affluent, white, people-like-us Londoners.

An article on Thursday about complaints by the Commission Nationale de l'Informatique et des Libertés, a French data protection agency known as C.N.I.L., that Google has not been cooperative in an investigation of its new privacy policy included an inaccurate English translation from a C.N.I.L. news release, provided by the agency. The release said that Google's answers to a questionnaire about its policy had been ''incomplete or approximate,'' not ''incomplete or inaccurate.'' (The agency corrected its translation after the article was published.)

DYM--Judith, on May 22, 2012. Beloved wife of the late Robert, devoted mother of Kenneth, Andrew and Michael, mother-in-law of Sheila, Hallie and Elise. Adored grandmother of Brandon and Lonny, Matthew, Aaron, Jeremy and Naomi, Joshua and Shira, dear sister of Peter Wolfe. Service Friday, 12:30pm, at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ.

LONDON -- What can companies do when the legally impossible becomes reasonably probable? Under European Union law, Greece cannot leave the euro. That is the theory. But in practice, any protection the law offers investors could be difficult to enforce, according to lawyers trying to protect their corporate clients against the upheaval sure to follow if Greece were to default on its debts and adopt a new currency.

IT'S a busy time of year for bees. As the city's flowering plants and trees reveal their sweet nectar, colonies go into reproductive overdrive as they build armies large enough to take in the spring flow. And the urban beekeepers tending to these exploding colonies are scurrying to keep pace. The once-clandestine buzzing boxes on balconies and in community gardens, rooftop residences, schools and even hotels all over the city have been legal only for the past two years. The New York City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene puts the number of registered hives at 161 -- up from 4 in April 2010 -- but the actual number of hives may be three times as many.

INDIANAPOLIS -- As usual, thousands of race fans found seats, mostly in the shade, on a hazy Friday morning at Indianapolis Motor Speedway, parking their coolers to watch the final practice session before the Indianapolis 500 on Sunday. Dario Franchitti was the fastest. The 96th running of the race will look somewhat different. The cars have been redesigned, with wider side pods that swoop back to virtually enclose the rear wheels. They sound different, too, creating lower-pitched growls rather than primal whining.

A Russian ballerina has decided to make America her artistic home. Polina Semionova, currently a guest artist with American Ballet Theater, will join the company as a principal dancer in September, Kevin McKenzie, Ballet Theater's artistic director, announced. Ms. Semionova, who was born in Moscow and joined the Berlin State Ballet as a principal in 2002, first appeared with American Ballet Theater in 2011. She will perform with the company during its New York seasons, as well as on its national and international tours. Ms. Semionova, 27, is scheduled to perform with ABT at the Metropolitan Opera House in four more performances this season, including ''La Bayadère '' on Saturday, ''Apollo'' on June 13 and ''Swan Lake'' on June 26 and 29. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

TACOMA, Wash. WITH dozens of major car museums in the United States already vying for the attention of a select group of visitors, is it possible to create a new automotive showcase that will stand out from the crowd?

NEWARK -- Balloting for the Calder Trophy, awarded to the N.H.L.'s best rookie, ended at the conclusion of the regular season, which is a shame for a 22-year-old member of the Devils who has scored not one but two series-clinching goals this postseason. The latest stroke of opportunism by that rookie, Adam Henrique, set off a celebration that echoed throughout Prudential Center on Friday night and a euphoric scrum to the left of the Rangers' net, in which the puck that he nudged past Henrik Lundqvist at 1 minute 3 seconds of overtime had settled moments earlier, launching the Devils into the Stanley Cup finals with a 3-2 victory. ''There are still more things to accomplish,'' said Henrique, having shed his uniform (for a suit), but not his smile.

THE BIG PROFILE: SASHA ALEXANDER While portraying Dr. Maura Isles, the more bookish, less socially adept half of the TNT crime-solving duo ''Rizzoli and Isles,'' Sasha Alexander had a nonfelonious revelation. ''One day,'' she says, ''I was like, 'Oh, my gosh, I think I'm playing my mother.' '' Which, of course, she means as the highest compliment: ''She's a very attractive woman who was kind of a brainiac,'' Alexander says, ''a C.P.A., but a very math-and-science-oriented person -- in the body of a bombshell.''

COLUMBUS, Ga. -- Right on either side of Alabama, there are two places with the same name. Like the one over in Mississippi, this Columbus was founded in the 1820s and sits just a few minutes from countryside in almost any way you drive.

Prepaid debit cards are becoming increasingly common, and more traditional banks have begun offering them. But the cards, which offer convenience to customers who may not be able to qualify for a traditional checking account, also carry fees that can be significant. On Wednesday, in fact, the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau is proposing a rule that would require issuers to disclose the fees that come with prepaid debit cards. Until now, those cards escaped the regulations passed in the wake of the financial crisis affecting credit card and checking account fees.

NOT long ago, serving on the board of Facebook must have seemed awfully glamorous. Then Facebook went public and its stock fell flat. Now, with Facebook's share price down 16 percent since the initial offering on May 17, and the lawsuits starting to fly, a seat on the board might feel like an affliction. Among the early accusations -- which the company has denied -- is that Facebook misled investors about its prospects.

BOAZ WEINSTEIN didn't know it, but he had just hooked the London Whale. It was last November, and Mr. Weinstein, a wunderkind of the New York hedge fund world, had spied something strange across the Atlantic. In an obscure corner of the financial markets, prices seemed out of whack. It didn't make sense.

MIAMI -- Besieged by identity theft, Florida now faces a fast-spreading form of fraud so simple and lucrative that some violent criminals have traded their guns for laptops. And the target is the United States Treasury. With nothing more than ledgers of stolen identity information -- Social Security numbers and their corresponding names and birth dates -- criminals have electronically filed thousands of false tax returns with made-up incomes and withholding information and have received hundreds of millions of dollars in wrongful refunds, law enforcement officials say.

IF you own a Windows-based PC, you may like the operating system well enough. Or you may merely tolerate it, if you give it much thought at all. But whatever your feeling, ''love'' probably isn't the word that immediately comes to mind to describe it. I bring this up because Microsoft acts as if its customers have a strong affection for all things Windows. For the last seven years, it has tried to make Windows the anchor brand for software that is not an operating system.

Baltimore Matt Wieters made a comment this March that sounded so naïve, it was almost charming. It was spring training, when even the lowliest teams can be optimistic. But Wieters, the catcher for the Baltimore Orioles, seemed to push the limits of the plausible.

Everyone is talking about the chicken for two at NoMad, the new restaurant in the hotel of the same name. Daniel Humm runs the kitchen, and Will Guidara is in charge of the dining room. But before I was served the chicken, there was the snow pea salad: delicately crisp, brightly flavored and light as a spring breeze.

Little girls of ''Annie,'' beware: Broadway's new Miss Hannigan knows a thing or two about stealing scenes, no matter how cute the moppets are. Katie Finneran, the two-time Tony Award winner - most recently for playing a barfly in the 2010 revival of ''Promises, Promises'' - will play the alcoholic orphanage manager in the revival of the musical ''Annie'' that begins performances in October. Ms. Finneran confirmed the news in a telephone interview on Friday, after weeks when news outlets and theater blogs were floating her name and many others (Rosie O'Donnell, Jean Smart, even Elaine Stritch) in a fevered chase to name the actress playing one of the juiciest roles of the 2012-13 Broadway season.
