LIPPMAN--Bert J. 31 years ago today. Always in our hearts. We miss you everyday. Your legacy continues to grow. With all our love, Ruth, Jane, Robin, Chuck, Stefan, Bradley, Jessica, Lucy and Leo

Preparation for Oscar de la Renta's resort show began about a month ago, after the wrap-up of the bridal and fall collections. It all started with a book: Irving Penn's iconic ''Flowers,'' which has a large mauve and white tulip (among de la Renta's favorites) on its cover. For three weeks the house's design team went to the flower district and selected the best crop to be photographed and turned into textile prints. Backstage, in the corridor of the ODLR offices on the 25th floor of a 42nd Street building, are the fruits of these excursions: racks of pieces printed with colorful, overblown bearded iris and parrot tulips. They reveal a new direction for de la Renta's patterns - abstracts have been used in the past, but never so digitized. This season there will be a few surprises, but first the run of show needs to be solidified. In the office, three girls dressed in de la Renta looks sit in front of computers and work on last-minute changes to the list of what will be sent down the runway. A sheet is passed around. On it a de la Renta logo-ed sticky note stuck to the top reads ''Updated!'' in messy handwriting.

WONSIK--Richard J.,age 82, of Hilton Head Island, SC formerly of Cedar Grove, NJ, died Saturday, May 19, 2012. Survived by his wife of 55 years, Barbara J. Young and daughters, Susan J.W. Feist, Karen W. Lyman, Sally J. Younghans and five grandchildren. A private service for the family will be held at a later date.

If it keeps on raining, levee's going to break -- ''When the Levee Breaks,'' Led Zeppelin Newsprint sentimentalists are part of a shrinking club. Plenty of people care about news, but the fetishists who want it to be imprisoned on paper? We are like Shriners, once a proud, powerful bunch who now meet in little rooms and exchange secret handshakes.

The Big Deal column last Sunday, about the move toward ever-taller apartment buildings, misstated the role of Related Companies in a new high-rise at 1214 Fifth Avenue. It is the building's leasing agent and management company, not the developer.

The architect Greg Lynn, who is known for the organic, biomorphic forms (or blobs, as he famously christened them) that he creates using sophisticated computer technology, designs everything from buildings to flatware and furniture. This year he added jewelry to his list of accomplishments. After working with Lynn in 2009 on an installation for Swarovski Crystal Palace at Design Miami, Nadja Swarovski, the company's creative director, invited him to design a jewelry collection for Atelier Swarovski. Now in its 10th season, Atelier Swarovski features jewelry and accessories by some of the world's leading designers in fields that include fashion and architecture. Lynn was intrigued by the idea of designing jewelry because, he says, ''most people don't get to see what I do or wear what I do.'' But Nadja's invitation didn't come without its challenges. Lynn started by sending her sketches, creating a family of forms based on the shapes and colors of the crystals themselves, and then began to make digital models of the pieces. ''I'm never surprised by anything in terms of scale,'' Lynn explains, ''but the scale of the jewelry was really whacked on the first round. It looks much bigger on the screen in the computer models I made. It took three rounds to just get the scale right.'' Lynn made all the prototypes in his studio, keeping practical issues like the weight of an earring in mind as he worked.

Nike at one point chose to focus an entire advertising campaign on the popularity of home runs, declaring that ''chicks dig the long ball.'' But in an era of smaller sluggers and increasingly-dominant pitchers, Major League Baseball may want to rebrand to focus on strikeouts. In recent days, piling up bunches of strikeouts has been all the rage. From Max Scherzer of the Detroit Tigers striking out 15 batters in seven innings to Dan Haren of the Los Angeles Angels striking out a career-high 14 in a shutout Thursday, it is looking like another Year of the Pitcher.

Four years after the 2008 collapse, the finance industry has regained its dominant position in American politics. Perhaps the development of deepest significance is an absence: the failure of a powerful anti-Wall Street faction to emerge in either the House or the Senate. This is in contrast to the response to previous financial crises, when Congress enacted tough legislation. Look at the current political environment this way: if Mitt Romney's campaign and the Romney-supporting ''super PAC'' Restore Our Future were a public company, the financial services industry would have a controlling interest.

Roland Barthes, a prolific and eclectic writer who was one of the most celebrated French intellectuals to have emerged since Jean-Paul Sartre, died Tuesday in Paris from injuries suffered in an auto accident this month. He was 64 years old. . . . Susan Sontag, a friend and admirer of Mr. Barthes, once described him as ''the most consistently intelligent, important and useful literary critic to have emerged anywhere'' in the last quarter-century. . . . Mourning the fact that he was ''condemned to assertion,'' Mr. Barthes accepted the title of literary critic with great reluctance, preferring, he said, to share his pleasures rather than pass judgments. Nonetheless, he could be quite lacerating when he joined the fray. He asserted, for example, that ''writing is the destruction of every voice, of every point of view,'' and that contrary to creating something original, literature ''is a multidimensional space in which a variety of writings, none of them original, blend and crash.'' Still, he could write about the many-faceted joys of reading -- ''The Pleasure of the Text'' in 1976 -- and about his own hedonistic inclinations in the autobiographical ''Roland Barthes'' (1977). His most popular book was ''A Lover's Discourse''; it sold more than 60,000 copies in France. Mr. Barthes lived alone, in a sparsely furnished apartment in Paris, and shared a country home with his mother near Bayonne. Excerpted from the March 27, 1980, obituary in The Times by Tony Schwartz, published two days after Barthes's death.

EVEN if you can't sing, it's hard not to be jealous of the four young people in ''RENÉE FLEMING: A YOUNGARTS MASTERCLASS,'' showing at 6 p.m. on Monday evening on HBO. Who wouldn't want to be invited to watch Ms. Fleming rehearse, or to be welcomed into her home to talk music? The show is the first installment of a new season of the YoungArts series, which pairs aspiring singers, artists, playwrights and so on with someone at the top of the profession for mentoring. This isn't just a keep-up-the-good-work pep talk. In Monday's episode, Ms. Fleming has one young man sing with a cough drop balanced on his tongue, another while clenching a pencil between his teeth. The exercises are efforts to refine some aspect of the students' technique. Later the four get to watch Ms. Fleming rehearse at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center, which turns out to be a bit of a lesson for Ms. Fleming as well. ''I just thought, oh my God, I have to do everything right now,'' Ms. Fleming says afterward. ''I have to do the things that I asked them to do.'' Participants in future episodes include Patti LuPone, John Guare and Bobby McFerrin.

Thirteen Roman Catholic dioceses and some Catholic-related groups scattered lawsuits across a dozen federal courts last week claiming that President Obama was violating their religious freedom by including contraceptives in basic health care coverage for female employees. It was a dramatic stunt, full of indignation but built on air. Mr. Obama's contraception-coverage mandate specifically exempts houses of worship. If he had ordered all other organizations affiliated with a religion to pay for their employees' contraception coverage, that policy could probably be justified under Supreme Court precedent, including a 1990 opinion by Justice Antonin Scalia.

Opened in the summer of 1936, the hottest on record in the United States, the McCarren pool, on the Greenpoint-Williamsburg border in Brooklyn, was one of 11 unveiled across the five boroughs that sweltering season, a statement in concrete of the city's ability to do something big in the depths of the Great Depression. They were gargantuan, more like lakes than pools. McCarren's capacity said it all: 6,800 swimmers in a 55,440-square-foot basin. Now, after being shut for 28 years, the pool and its historic bathhouse are set to reopen at the end of June. The pool complex, which sits in McCarren Park, has undergone a $50 million restoration, and the enormous rectangular pool has been turned into a giant U, with the placement of a concrete beach along one side. Painters are applying a coat of cerulean blue, a hue evoking longings of escape -- from the heat, from work, from summer in the city. Grab your suit! LISA W. FODERARO
To the Sports Editor: Re ''Only One Chipper,'' May 20: Chipper Jones's father got one thing wrong: Larry is indeed a memorable name.

BASEBALL evokes the image of a father having a catch with his son. The grass is green, spring is in the air. Then you sign that professional contract. It's not that the original image gets erased when you become a pro. It just usually takes a little time away from home before you know yourself well enough to figure out how to embrace the picture as an adult -- or find a father figure who can complete the image for you.

TEHRAN -- Iran's nuclear chief, reversing the country's previous statements, said on state television on Sunday that the country would not halt its production of higher-grade uranium, suggesting that the Iranian government was veering back to a much harder line after talks in Baghdad with the West last week ended badly. The official, Fereydoon Abbasi, said there would be no suspension of enrichment by Iran, the central requirement of several United Nations Security Council resolutions. He specifically said that applied to uranium being enriched to 20 percent purity -- a steppingstone that puts it in fairly easy reach of producing highly enriched uranium that can be used for nuclear weapons.

When Doug Imbruce wanted to start an interactive video company in 2009, he had no luck finding investors in New York. So he moved to Silicon Valley -- where venture capitalists were receptive to his pitch -- and founded Qwiki. But in February, he decided that being so far away from the nation's big media companies was stifling his start-up's growth. So he moved back to New York, bringing the company with him. Qwiki, with 15 employees, now operates out of a SoHo loft space.

Lloyd Winslow Cheu and Dr. Douglas Nelson Mintz were married Saturday at Le Chateau, a restaurant in South Salem, N.Y. The Rev. M. Frances Sink, a Unitarian Universalist minister, officiated. Mr. Cheu (left), 46, is a kitchen designer working with private clients and developers in New York and Miami. He graduated from the University of Pennsylvania and received an M.B.A. from Northwestern.

Madison Square Park, between Fifth and Madison Avenues at 23rd Street, held its children's fair on May 19 with music, games, popcorn and cotton candy. The children, in their summery hats, resembled butterflies. They were the ideal foil for the thatched-roof children's playhouse surrounded by flowers seen later in the day at a benefit for grown-ups at Old Westbury Gardens, the former estate of the Phipps family on Long Island.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''The Collection of a Lifetime,'' May 22: I am making plans with my 10-year-old grandson to visit the Metropolitan Museum of Art to see Jefferson R. Burdick's amazing collection of ephemera. My grandson is collecting sports cards and has most of the walls in his bedroom covered with them.

STORCH--George D. George D. Storch, 90 years old, on May 23, 2012. Born in Zamosc, Poland. Devoted son of the late Rabbi Sholom Storch and Rivka (Peltz) Storch. Beloved husband of Rose Storch. Loving father of Oliver(Geidy) Storch, and Vivian (John) Cannon. Adoring grandfather of Daniel, Benjamin, Phoebe and Zoe. Survivor of the Holocaust. Was able to save his parents, late siblings Chana Bruce, Miriam Lewent, Bella Chaim, Joseph and niece Florence Edelstein from Nazi capture by escaping to Russia and Kazakhstan. Decorated and twice wounded Lieutenant in the 1st. Polish Army under Marshal Konstantin Rokossovsky during WW II. Retired nightclub entrepreneur and real estate investor. A true Mensch, fluent in five languages, who's big smile and charisma enriched the lives of all he met. He will be truly missed. Donations in his memory may be made to the National Kidney Foundation.

The I.R.S. is doing what they can to prevent this, but this is like a tsunami of fraud. Everywhere I go, every dinner, every function I attend, someone will come up to me and tell me they are a victim. WIFREDO A. FERER, a United States attorney, on identity-theft tax fraud. [20]
Manhattan

BAYLISS--William Heywang, died May 11, at age 88 in Chapel Hill, NC, after a fall. Born July 29, 1923 in Titusville, PA, he graduated from Harvard in 1948 and later earned an MBA from Columbia and a law degree from Duke. During WW II he served in the Army Air Corps as a B-25 pilot in the Pacific. After working at Upjohn Co. in Kalamazoo, MI, he moved to Chapel Hill where he practiced law as a partner at Bayliss, Hudson & Merritt. He is survived by Ann Palmer Bayliss, his wife of 55 years; sons George, Theodore and Mark; daughters-in-law Svea Herbst, Maura Landry and Christianne Edkins; and grandchildren Margaret, Andrew and Caroline. Funeral to be held in Chapel Hill on June 2 at 2pm at University Presbyterian Church.

Camille Madeleine Fléchet and Daniel Jason File were married Saturday in Paris at the City Hall for the Ninth Arrondissement. The arrondissement's deputy mayor, Xavier Laugaudin, officiated. The bride, 27, is a lawyer in international arbitration and litigation at the Paris office of the London law firm Allen & Overy. She received master's degrees in law from the University of Cologne, King's College London and Sorbonne University in Paris, where she also currently teaches a master's degree course in international arbitration.

BROKMAN--Leila. Beloved mother of Michael, Robert and David. Loving grandmother and great-grandmother. Lifetime member of The Pythian Sisters. Graveside services Tuesday 1:30pm at New Montefiore Cemetery.

HEINES--Muriel R, 96, a lifelong Brooklyn resident died on Friday, May 25, 2012. Survivors include her beloved daughter, Molly K. Heines and her husband Thomas J. Moloney; and her loving family, Robin Moloney and Richard Cook, and their children, Tommy and Patrick Cook. Reposing on Sunday and Monday from 2-5pm and 7-9pm at Greenwich Village Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker Street. Mass on Tuesday at 10am at St. Joseph's Church, Greenwich Village. Interment in Holy Cross Cemetery, Brooklyn. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to St. Joseph's Church, 371 Sixth Avenue, NY, NY 10014 or Battery Dance Company, 380 Broadway, 5th Floor, NY, NY 10013. green wichvillagefuneralhome.com

There was a time, not so long ago, when Memorial Day, and the knowledge that school would soon be ending, was the dock from which we looked out upon the sea of summer. From Memorial Day, to a child of the right age, September looked like some undiscoverable Indies, lying far beyond the visible horizon. And Memorial Day itself? It was the last and most solemn solemnity before the beautiful expanse of summer, a day when graves were being gardened everywhere and you could see from the flags among them who had died as veterans.

BULKLEY--Jonathan Duncan, a San Francisco resident for more than fifty years, and a prominent architect and founder of a real estate investment firm, died peacefully, after a yearlong illness on April 30, 2012, with his family at his side. Mr. Bulkley was born on August 5, 1930 in Port Chester, and grew up in North Salem, New York. He was the fifth child of Henry Duncan Bulkley and Wynanda Koechlin Boardman. Mr. Bulkley attended Deerfield Academy, and before entering Yale University he served in the United States Marine Corps Reserves. He graduated from Illinois Institute of Technology in 1957 where he studied architecture under Ludwig Mies van der Rohe. In 1960, Mr. Bulkley began practicing architecture in San Francisco. For over thirty years, he specialized in designing commercial and residential buildings in the San Francisco Bay Area. In 1980 he founded Round Hill Pacific, a successful family owned residential real estate firm with multi-state holdings. Mr. Bulkley was a life long collector and amassed a large collection of 19th century letterheads, advertising trade cards, and stamps. The Bulkley Collection of Commercial Stationery has recently been donated to the Huntington Library in San Marino, CA. Mr. Bulkley used his educational background and work expertise to help the community where he lived. In 1970, he became a founding member of PAR, San Francisco's largest member neighborhood organization dedicated to improving the quality of life and architecture in the Richmond District and served on the advisory board of San Francisco Planning & Urban Research. His family and friends fondly remember him for his keen intellect and sense of humor, and sage advice, Mr. Bulkley is survived by his wife, Lisa Baker Bulkley, his children, Honor Bulkley, Adrienne Bulkley and Suzanne Esser, all of the San Francisco Bay Area; Peter Bulkley of Ontario, Canada, Peter Esser of Oahu, Hawaii, Derick Bulkley of Cebu, Philippines, and seven grandchildren. A private memorial was held May 13th at the Presidio of San Francisco.
MANHATTAN VALLEY CONDO $699,000

LET'S say that, on a whim, you decide to form a baseball franchise made up of history's greatest anxiety sufferers -- a sort of neurotic all-star team, like the 2004 Red Sox, only too debilitated to make it out of the dugout. What would you call the team? Last Rosh Hashana, I asked a group of friends this question, and the answers I got suggested that the team would be exclusively ... Jewish. Responses included but were not limited to the following: the Los Angeles Kvetches, the Brooklyn Nazi Dodgers, the Kansas City Mohels, the Chicago Schlubs, the Miami Meshugeners, the Westchester Rhinoplasties, the Hollywood Indigestives and -- my favorite, a late entry from my brother Scott -- the Upper West Side Ativans.
LUBALIN--Herb 1918 - 1981 He lives on in his work. Rhoda S. Lubalin

Podcast Scheduled to appear this week: Michael Lind on his new book, ''Land of Promise: An Economic History of the United States''; John Leland on ''Jubilee Hitchhiker,'' William Hjortsberg's biography of Richard Brautigan; Julie Bosman with notes from the field; and Gregory Cowles with best-/seller news. Sam Tanenhaus, the editor of the Book Review, is the host. By the BookAn expanded version of our interview with Drew Gilpin Faust, the Civil War historian and president of Harvard University.

''Don't be all stiff'' was one of many instructions that Chuck Davis issued to the audience at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Friday. At DanceAfrica, the festival that Mr. Davis has been running for 35 years, audience behavior -- down to the mandatory hugging of strangers -- is as important as anything that happens onstage. But the instruction is theater. A DanceAfrica audience needs no reminder to loosen up. Neither do the dancers. United African Dance Troupe, from Queens, set the right tone with ''Remember to Love,'' a series of Malian and South African dances celebrating marriage. The troupe's children skipped onstage singing, holding tin cans that they beat together and passed between legs in a fast jumping-jacks sequence. Their elders came on with scarves and strutted their stuff in pairs. The company looked amateur in the best sense, dancing neighbors giving their irresistible all.
FRIEDMAN--Robin Beth, 61, predeceased by parents Jesse and Penni. Vibrant redhead, missed by Ithaca and NYC friends. John Sadwith, Karen Grote, Lindsey Fox, Ken Gordon

CARLIN--Barbara, on May 24, 2012. Beloved wife of the late Bernard Carlin. Survived by her daughter, Susan Carlin (Elliot) Galdy and her grandchildren, Gillian, Ian and Danielle. Known for her sense of style, Bobbie embraced New York City and all it had to offer. She will be missed by her family, friends, theatre community, department stores and "her boys." Contributions in her memory may be made to The Gay Men's Health Crisis.

The likelihood that any of the children in the article will ''end up just fine'' without intervention is extremely low. That's the approach our society has taken for too long: do nothing, wait until they grow up and commit crimes, then imprison them. The researchers in this article should be commended for their pioneering work in addressing an important, understudied societal problem. ERX, New York, posted on nytimes.com

Adam Lawrence Fried and Jeffrey Scott Green were married Saturday evening at 632 on Hudson, an event space in New York. Kimberly Worley, a nondenominational minister, performed the ceremony. Mr. Fried, 34, is the assistant director of the Center for Ethics Education at Fordham University. He is also the director of the center's master's program in ethics and society. He graduated from Rutgers and received a master's and a doctoral degree in clinical psychology from Fordham.

Petra Elliott Kann and Thomas Patrick Weir were married Saturday at Miller Chapel at the Princeton Theological Seminary in Princeton, N.J. The Rev. David C. Mertz, a United Methodist minister, led the ceremony with his wife, the Rev. Dr. Nancy J. Duff, a Presbyterian minister, taking part. Mrs. Weir, 25, graduated with a certificate in aesthetics from Hair Expressions, a beauty school in Rockville, Md.

CASSIDY--James D.,II. Around May 22, 2012 there was a knock on the front door. It was on this night that James D. Cassidy II's passing was announced to his wife Diane and their three children Megan, age 17, Brittany, age 14, and Jimmy, age 12. The detectives that stood before them had said "We are sorry to have to tell you that your father has been in a terrible accident. He was on his way home from work when an off duty officer following behind him witnessed him swerve off the road." From here the family had learned that when the man punched the window in to try and revive Jim he has already been unconscious. Born on April 10, 1964, at the age of 48 years and 42 days, his heart had stopped at 11:43pm. May 22nd will forever be considered the worst day in each of his family members' lives. Being a beloved son, husband, father, uncle, brother and friend, he would go to any extent to help the ones he loved. Jimmy was always the life of the party, and he was a great boss. He was an excellent father and devoted husband. He was thought of as Superman by his children. When it comes down to it, his family was the center of his world, nothing else could ever surpass the importance of his family. As the son of Jim and Mary Cassidy and son-in-law of Mike and Barbara Druckenbroad he was the eldest brother of seven children, Debbie, Karen, Donna, Michael, Christine and Brian. Jim was also the brother-in-law of Bonnie, Kathryn, Mike, Bruce, Lorraine and Keith. With so many siblings it was quite a sight to see his clan to get together with 29 nieces and nephews. With great heartache he had left children who had such a great love for him. Matt, Melissa, Jennifer, Stephanie, Letitia, Ashlee, Bryanne, Bruce, Alicia, Christen, Casey, Micaylee, Hailey, Michael, Keith, Andrew, Ryan, Kassandra, Shirley-Rebecca, Michael, Grace, Catherine, Marilyn, Joseph, Noah, Steven, Samantha, Anthony and Allison. His daughter recalls "I always knew that Daddy knew how blessed he was, whether it was work opportunity or the accomplishments of his children. He had always been so proud. He was the rock of our clan Our strength, no decision was made without Daddy" Prior to his passing the family had recently learned that James Cassidy I had developed a cancerous brain tumor. Earlier on the 22nd, Jimmy had gotten word that the Chemo wasn't working and that the tumor was growing. That night he had a conference call with his siblings in his office at the New York Times, questioning what they would do next. Little did they know that it was Jimmy they should have been most concerned about. Since learning of Jims passing it had become his father's dying wish to go to his son's funeral. So the hospital where he had been staying in Florida has released him and he will be transported to New York. "Daddy won't take him yet. He has everything planned out now. He knows exactly when Pop Pop will meet him again." His daughter said. He has always worked so hard. Jim was the proud General Foreman and Union Member of the Plate Room for The New York Times in College Point, NY. As stressful as his job was at times he loved it so much. He loved the men he worked with and made special bonds with Tony DeFelice, Deidre Deignan, Ernie Booth, Mike Connors and Nick D'Andrea. He loved bringing his family in for tours, he was always so proud. "I remember he would always put our school pictures up in his office." His daughter said "He would always call home to check up on us, he loved us so much." Jim's wake is going to be held at Robertaccios Funeral Home on Tuesday, May 29th from 2-4pm and 7-9pm. It is located on 85 Medford Avenue (Rt. 112) Patchouge, NY, 11712. The following day, Wednesday, May 30, there will be an 11 o'clock Mass held at St. Patrick's Church, located at 9N. Clinton Avenue, Bayshore, NY, 11706. The burial will follow immediately after at St. Patrick's Cemetery on Brentwood Rd., South of Sunrise Hwy. "It is still impossible to believe that he is no longer with us. But in spirit he will always be looking out for each and every one of us. He will forever be our angel and our love for him is everlasting."
Suggestions for what you'd like Jason to see and draw may be sent to thingsisaw@ nytimes.com

STEFANKIEWICZ--John K.,39, of Manhattan, New York passed away on May 24, 2012, after a long, courageous battle with pulmonary disease. He will be missed by those who were fortunate to be a part of his life. He is survived by his loving wife Suhana Han; his cherished son Henryk; his sister Tabitha Pia; his brother Eric; his aunt Sabina; and his nieces and nephew. He is the son of the late Karl and Carol Stefankiewicz. Raised on Staten Island, John graduated from The University of Chicago in 1994 and received his M.B.A. from the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania in 2005. John began his career in Boston at Investors Bank and Trust Company, before moving to New York to head a systems development team for many of the bank's largest clients. He also worked in UBS Investment Bank's Financial Institutions Group. Most recently, he was a Partner and Chief Operating Officer of Vastardis Capital Services, providing advice to financial institutions and alternative asset managers on fund administration. John's professional achievements were impressive but the most significant aspect of his life was his family. John married his long-time sweetheart Suhana on January 3, 2005 on Guam, with a New York reception on April 9, 2005. Their son Henryk was born on July 27, 2009. John was a devoted father who treasured spending time with his son, often walking the streets of New York and taking in the city's many construction sites and equipment. John also shared his eclectic taste in music with Henryk. Services will be held at 2pm on Tuesday, May 29, 2012 at Plymouth Church, 57 Orange Street (between Henry and Hicks Streets) in Brooklyn Heights. A reception will follow. A visitation will be held at Greenwich Village Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker Street, from 6 to 9pm that evening. In lieu of flowers, gifts in John's memory can be made to Trail's Edge Camp, c/o Mary Buschell, 310 West Valley Rd., Maple City, MI, 49664, or A Caring Hand, The Billy Esposito Foundation, P.O. Box 1232, New York, NY 10276.

(The latter is another writer, Douglas B. Levene, whose letter appeared only in the online version of the Sunday Dialogue.)

Mollie Alexandra Biewald, a daughter of Bruce E. Biewald of Cambridge, Mass., and Gayle Alexander of Granby, Mass., was married Saturday to Patrick O'Regan Perry, the son of Raymond H. Perry and Kerry A. Perry of Modesto, Calif. Mimi Graney, a Massachusetts justice of the peace, officiated at the John H. Pierce House in Lincoln, Mass. The bride, 28, who will keep her name, is a fourth-year medical student at Weill Cornell Medical College and expects to graduate on Thursday. She is to begin an internship in primary care internal medicine at Mount Sinai Medical Center in July. She graduated from Columbia University. The bride is a stepdaughter of Jean Ann Ramey.

In the trial of Alex Blueford, an Arkansas jury voted him not guilty on charges of capital and first-degree murder, but deadlocked on lesser charges. By a 6-to-3 vote last week, the Supreme Court misguidedly ruled that the state can retry him on all charges, including those for murder. Justice Sonia Sotomayor properly noted in dissent, ''the threat to individual freedom from reprosecutions that favor states and unfairly rescue them from weak cases has not waned with time. Only this court's vigilance has.''

BEIRUT, Lebanon -- The United Nations Security Council on Sunday unanimously condemned the Syrian government for its role in the massacre of at least 108 villagers, with new details emerging from international observers that appeared to prompt rare Russian cooperation in criticizing its ally in Damascus. The 15-member Council approved a statement that, while not blaming the Syrian government directly for all the deaths, rebuked it for its use of tanks and artillery against civilians despite agreeing to an April 12 cease-fire.

A MEMBER of the family that controls the German shoe company Birkenstock has sold a triplex penthouse in the South Beach section of Miami Beach for $25 million, a record price for a Miami-area apartment, eclipsing the previous record of $21.5 million reached five months before. The buyer of the 7,400-square-foot penthouse in the Continuum towers was an Italian who controls an investment company, said Pietro Belmonte, a broker at Prudential Douglas Elliman who has sold residences in the building. The seller was Alex Birkenstock, who withdrew from day-to-day operations of his family's company in 2008, according to one person familiar with the matter. He bought the apartment for $9.9 million in 2009.

Tiina Laakkonen has lived the ultimate life in fashion: model to William Klein, assistant to Karl Lagerfeld, stylist to top fashion magazines (including T). She even dated a rock star. But it turns out that inside the striking, platinum blond Finnish beauty has long been a homebody, dying to, well, stay in. The ultimate expression of Laakkonen's true self is the appropriately named Tiina the Store, a home furnishings store that opens May 23 on Main Street in Amagansett, N.Y., not far from where she and her husband, Jon Rosen, recently built their dream house. The store is in fact an extension of that house, and the two will contain many design objects in common, including vintage Marimekko quilts, rugs by Dosa, wallpapers by the Finnish ceramicist Birger Kaipiainen and Iittala tableware. It will also feel very homey. ''I'm setting the store up very much like our house,'' Laakkonen says. There will of course also be a smattering of stylish things like jewelry by Ten Thousand Things, sandals from Ancient Greek Sandals, Save the C bags from Finland, S.N.S. sweaters from Denmark and children's clothing by Makié. You can take the girl out of fashion, but apparently you cannot take the fashion out of the girl. Tiina the Store is at 216 Main Street, Amagansett, N.Y.; (631) 267-6200; tiinathestore.com.

Outsiders call it the street with little doors. That is, if they know it at all, because Dennet Place, a tiny lane near the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn, is something of a secret. It can evade GPS, and even some people who have lived nearby for years have never heard of it. Those who do pass by wonder about the doors. Dennet houses have miniature street-level entrances, more appropriate for hobbits than humans. Some lead into basements, others into kitchens or the bedroom and bath sections of a home. Residents crouch in and out of the doors as if it were the most natural thing in the world.

CAFFREY--Ingrid (Gustafsson). December 13, 1946, died May 24th. She was the beloved wife of Edward and mother to Kirsten, Scott and Sean. Calling hours Monday from 4-8pm at Gallagher & Son in Greenwich, CT.

OAKLAND, Calif. -- A visit to Northern California was the perfect setting for the Yankees to extend their modest winning streak. Winning has become a habit for the Yankees at Oakland-Alameda County Coliseum in recent years, and the good fortune continued Sunday as they beat the Athletics, 2-0, for their ninth consecutive victory in this building, and their 13th in their last 14 games here. The three victories over the weekend extended the Yankees' winning streak to five games over all, a season high, as Hiroki Kuroda provided his best start of the year.

Nastia Liukin hopped onto the balance beam at the U.S. Classic in Chicago on Saturday and walked right back into the mix for the American Olympic team that will compete in London. Liukin, the reigning Olympic champion in the all-around, gracefully flipped, twisted and split-jumped above the four-inch beam, receiving a score of 14.9, good enough to tie for third with Sarah Finnegan. Alexandra Raisman and Jordyn Wieber tied for first, with 15 points each. Liukin said she was thrilled with her performance after taking nearly three years off from the sport. More at nytimes.com.

Few investors are more bullish these days than public pension funds. While Americans are typically earning less than 1 percent interest on their savings accounts and watching their 401(k) balances yo-yo along with the stock market, most public pension funds are still betting they will earn annual returns of 7 to 8 percent over the long haul, a practice that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg recently called ''indefensible.''
REDDING CAPE $899,000

A STRING quartet has endless options in terms of repertory, but a classical saxophone ensemble has far slimmer pickings. Since Matt Levy founded the PRISM QUARTET 25 years ago he and his colleagues have been evangelizing on behalf of this unusual instrumentation. The group has commissioned at least 120 works for saxophone quartet, including one by Samuel Phillips-Corwin, which will have its premiere on Thursday at Symphony Space. The program, which focuses on minimalist composers and those they influenced, also includes pieces by Terry Riley, Philip Glass, John Adams and Michael Torke. 7:30 p.m., Symphony Space, 2537 Broadway; (212) 864-5400, symphonyspace.org; $21, $15 for students and 65+. Luna Pearl Woolf wrote ''APRÈS MOI, LE DÉLUGE,'' scored for a cappella choir and cello, as a tribute to the victims of Hurricane Katrina. The work, which takes its title from a quotation often attributed to the decadent and irresponsible Louis XV of France, will be performed with Julian Wachner conducting the excellent Trinity Choir and the cellist Matt Haimovitz as soloist. Mr. Wachner, who is also a composer, will lead the ensemble in his own ''Rilke Songs,'' as well as Laura Elise Schwendinger's ''Six Choral Settings,'' Du Yun's ''San'' and five spirituals. 7:30 p.m. on Thursday, Zankel Hall, Carnegie Hall; (212) 247-7800, carnegiehall.org; $48-$62.

The dessert bar calls to mind those first-grade birthday parties where the kids get to build their own sundaes. And with the exception of putting Gummi Bears on everything, why would you tinker with such perfection? If you can arrange cookies on a plate, scoop ice cream and slice peaches, you're ready to go. Much of these ingredients can be store-bought, and many of them keep well enough so that you can have them around to put something like this together on short notice. (I'm not suggesting that you put all of them out at once, but you could; just three or four of each make for terrific possibilities.)

LONDON -- London's commuters have been warned to expect gridlock on the roads and paralysis on the subways. They have been advised to leave home well before rush hour; to travel by foot, bicycle or boat; and to forget about trying to drive anywhere even remotely connected with the Olympics. And so John Horner, seasoned commuting veteran, has devised a simple personal transportation strategy for the Summer Games: go nowhere.

The five most viewed articles on nytimes.com/sports from May 18 to 24. 1. CABALLO BLANCO'S LAST RUN When Micah True went missing on a run, the search for him eventually turned to a section of Little Creek in the Gila Wilderness, near Silver City, N.M. (Published May 20)

The title of this influential film already has connotations of horror, and the poster grabs attention with simplicity. A big carving knife recalls ''Psycho,'' which came out in 1960. Movement suggested in the repetition of the knife and the hand indicates there will be not one murder, but several. The italicized tagline implies that there is a boogeyman being whispered about in Haddonfield, the fictional town terrorized by the masked killer Michael Myers. ''The beauty of the film and the poster is that it takes what was an idealized idea of American suburbs and brings evil into it,'' Mr. Kerswell said. ''You have this ancient evil, harking back to Samhain'' -- an ancient Celtic festival -- ''and pagan rituals, stalking the white picket fences of suburbia.''

Doug Dillard, a banjo virtuoso who began the 1960s by helping to introduce a generation of listeners to bluegrass and ended the decade as an early advocate of country-rock, died on May 16 in Nashville. He was 75. The cause was a lung infection, said Lynne Robin Green, the president of LWBH Music Publishers, which publishes his music.

Dear brother of the late Phillip Kabiller and Annabelle Shiffman. Fond brother-in-law of Wilma (the late Burt) Tunick. Will be missed by many nieces, nephews, cousins and friends. E), 7801 West Montrose Ave., Norridge, IL In lieu of flowers, memorials may be made in his memory to Smile Train, http://support.smiletrain.org/ goto/irvingkabiller or Fiedler Hillel Center at Northwestern University in Memory of Mr. Irving Kabiller, Check to Northwestern University (specify Hillel), Mail to Matt Ter Molen, Northwestern University Development Office, 2020 Ridge, 3rd Floor, Suite #

AMERICAN BALLET THEATER opens the third week of its Met season on Monday with one last ''Bayadère,'' sporting the rub-my-eyes-I'm-dreaming pairing of Alina Cojocaru and Natalia Osipova -- quite possibly, in very different ways, the most thrilling ballerinas on the planet -- in the two principal female roles. Don't miss them vying for the affections of Herman Cornejo's Solor, nor one of the subsequent performances, during the rest of the week, of Alexei Ratmansky's ''Bright Stream.'' That ballet is a rechoreographed version of a 1935 production by Fyodor Lopukhov, to music by Shostakovich, which despite its politically correct subject matter -- life on a collective farm -- was deemed unacceptable by Stalin and disappeared from view. Revived by Mr. Ratmansky, it gives us an idea of Soviet art, the idealized optimism of a lost Russia, and a very, very funny comedy that shows Ballet Theater as a unified ensemble of brilliant actor-dancers. You can't go wrong with any of the casts, but balletomanes will be keen to see the Danish-trained Royal Ballet principal Johan Kobborg trying out his pointe shoes and sylphide dress in his debut on Thursday as the Ballerina's Partner.

Martha McDonnell Staid and Andrew Kierr Stein were married Saturday evening at the Atlanta Contemporary Art Center in Atlanta. Rabbi Steven Lebow officiated. The bride, 29, will keep her name. She is pursuing a master's degree in international development at Georgetown. SAN ANTONIO -- The San Antonio Spurs looked closer to early retirement than in their ability to keep up with the Oklahoma City Thunder for three quarters Sunday night. Unable to cope with the flash of their younger opponent, the Spurs dipped deep into their reservoir of experience and guile. Challenged by Coach Gregg Popovich to get ''nasty,'' San Antonio opened the fourth quarter with a 20-5 rush.

Juan Martín Del Potro Nicknamed the Tower of Tandil, after his hometown in Argentina, the 6-foot-6 Del Potro has patiently climbed back into the top 10 after wrist surgery sidelined him for the 2010 season.

Alcoholics Anonymous has tens of thousands of groups worldwide today, but it had an identifiable beginning with its co-founder Bill Wilson. In their documentary, ''Bill W.,'' Kevin Hanlon and Dan Carracino recount Wilson's biography, which is inextricably linked to the developmental history of this lifesaving organization. But this film's impact is hampered by a slavish adherence to chronology and vintage audio materials. Bill W., as he was known in A.A. parlance, was a Wall Street analyst who battled the bottle during the Depression. In the 1930s he went from the proverbial rock bottom in an era of limited treatment options to proselytizing a fellowship-based model that would become the 12-step program. He was influenced by the evangelical Oxford Group, supported by his tireless wife and friends, and evidently aided by strong management skills and an entrepreneurial drive. (Wilson was 75 when he died in 1971.)

Thingoc Cuc Le, a daughter of Tua Thi Tran and Vinh Van Le of Adelaide, Australia, is to be married Sunday in New York to Bahn Dan Vo, a son of Ngoc Lien Banh and Nam Van Vo, also of Adelaide. Will the beleaguered horse racing industry finally have its historic moment? If I'll Have Another becomes the first horse in 34 years to win the Triple Crown next month in the Belmont Stakes, he will create the enduring memory that racing desperately needs.

WEST POINT, N.Y. -- For two centuries, the United States Military Academy has produced generals for America's wars, among them Ulysses S. Grant, Robert E. Lee, George S. Patton and David H. Petraeus. It is where President George W. Bush delivered what became known as his pre-emption speech, which sought to justify the invasion of Iraq, and where President Obama told the nation he was sending an additional 30,000 American troops to Afghanistan. Now at another critical moment in American military history, the faculty here on the commanding bend in the Hudson River is deep in its own existential debate. Narrowly, the argument is whether the counterinsurgency strategy used in Iraq and Afghanistan -- the troop-heavy, time-intensive, expensive doctrine of trying to win over the locals by building roads, schools and government -- is dead.

SMITH--Rodman Una, of Quiogue, NY, on April 14th 2012, in his 87th year. Born in Brooklyn, NY, on February 27th 25, son of James Theodore and Grace Una. Predeceased by his wife of 46 years, Joyce Galbraith. Survived by his son, William, daughter, Brooke DiCapua, son-in-law Lawrence Herrick DiCapua, and grandsons Henry and Blake DiCapua. Great Neck HS Class of 43. Skated professionally in '43: Sonja Henie's Stars on Ice, at Rockefeller Center. WWII Army Air Corps: Corporal, 513 Bomb Squad, 376 Bomb Group. Retired New York Life, Group VP, after 36 years of service. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, June 2nd, 11:15am, St. Mark's Episcopal Church, Westhampton Beach, NY.
A picture credit on May 13 with the Eat column, showing photographs of summer cocktails, misidentified the food stylist. He is Brian Preston- Campbell, not Maggie Ruggiero.

Philip Kaufman's midcareer run of great films, released from the late 1970s through 1990, can be seen as an examination of the varieties of heroism: physical and psychological (''The Right Stuff''), moral and political (''The Unbearable Lightness of Being''), artistic (''Henry & June''), existential (''Invasion of the Body Snatchers''). Combining historical sweep with cerebral humor, meticulous craftsmanship and an ability to mix and match tones and styles effortlessly -- jazzy, erotic, mythic, tragic -- he made 1980s hipster versions of big Hollywood studio productions. In a recent interview with The New York Times, he defined his own approach when he called his masterpiece, ''The Unbearable Lightness of Being,'' an ''intimate epic.''

Dr. William Yew-Wai Ho and Bruce Steven Stuart were married Friday at the American Hotel in Sharon Springs, N.Y. Douglas C. Plummer, a minister of the Universal Life Church, officiated. Dr. Ho, 46, (left) is a senior medical director and a developer of clinical trials for early-stage cancer drugs at Genentech, the biotechnology company in South San Francisco, Calif. He graduated summa cum laude from Princeton and received a medical degree and a doctoral degree in microbiology and immunology from Stanford.

8 P.M. (13); 9:30 P.M. (21) NATIONAL MEMORIAL DAY CONCERT This annual tribute will welcome troops who have returned from Iran and Afghanistan while examining the plight of homeless American veterans. Gary Sinise and Joe Mantegna team up for the seventh time as hosts of this live broadcast from the West Lawn of the United States Capitol. Selma Blair, Ellen Burstyn and Dennis Franz will read stories written by Brigette Cain, a young war widow; Amy Neil, a psychotherapist; and Larry Michaelis, who was injured during the Vietnam War. Jessica Sanchez, Daughtry (above), Natalie Cole, Trace Adkins and Russell Watson will perform, accompanied by the National Symphony Orchestra under the direction of Jack Everly. Other participants include Colin L. Powell, members of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, the Army Herald Trumpets, the Army Chorus, the Soldiers' Chorus of the United States Army Field Band, the Navy Band Sea Chanters and the Air Force Singing Sergeants. ''Hell and Back Again,'' an ''Independent Lens'' presentation at 9:30 on Channel 13, follows Sgt. Nathan Harris of the Marines as he transitions to civilian life after a life-threatening injury in Afghanistan. 9 A.M. (CNN) STATE OF THE UNION WITH CANDY CROWLEY The former New York City mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, a Republican, and Representative Debbie Wasserman Schultz, the chairman of the Democratic National Committee, discuss the presidential campaign and the parties' agendas. Gen. Peter W. Chiarelli, a former Army vice chief of staff, discusses medical treatment for veterans and post-traumatic stress disorder.

NESTLER--Harold. For 99 years, Harold was an unforgettable force of positivity. He was born in 1913, grew up in the Bronx, and attended Stuyvesant and CCNY. An outspoken leftist, he was once chased down the street after a soapbox speech. He met and fell in love with Gertrude Karlin at a Sylvan Lake camp. They wed in 1940, settling in Long Beach after the births of their daughters, Susan and Karen. His first business was a pet store on 125th St. in Harlem. He later founded Wil-Nes/Metaframe with his brother and cousins, manufacturing innovative aquariums that are still sought by collectors. An avid craftsman, he retired with Gertrude to Woodstock and then Florida, pursuing passions for woodworking, stained glass, and mosaics. Above all, Harold was generous and loving. Grandfather to Jessica and Rebecca and a father figure to many, he gave great advice and even better hugs. His booming Bubbeleh! was a joy to hear, and his humor and lust for life touched everyone. After 72 years of marriage, he died peacefully on May 16, 2012, holding Gertrude's hand. His family and friends will love him forever.

LOS ANGELES -- Maybe it's because the movies provide this city with more than enough Wagnerian Gesamtkunstwerk. Whatever the reason, even though Puccini's ''Bohème'' had its American premiere here in 1897, Los Angeles has never really been an opera town. There is evidence for this both big and small, statistical and anecdotal. It took until 1986 for the city to develop, in the Los Angeles Opera, a serious, stable opera company. And on Saturday evening, at the Los Angeles Philharmonic's performance of ''Don Giovanni,'' silence greeted Mozart's winking quotation of his own ''Nozze di Figaro'' during the final scene. It was an opera in-joke in search of an opera audience.
A listing on the ''On the Market'' page last Sunday, about a house in Sea Cliff, L.I., misstated its address. It is 21 Prospect Avenue, not 305 Sea Cliff Avenue.

EL SEGUNDO, Calif. -- Had circumstances been different, Dustin Brown could have spent the first round of the playoffs with the Vancouver Canucks. Had hearsay become fact, Brown could have been waiting for his first Stanley Cup finals as a member of the Devils.

April 15, Islamabad, Pakistan Every year, at the onset of spring, a mix of artisans, musicians and dancers from all over Pakistan travel to the twin cities of Islamabad and Rawalpindi to display their skills at the weeklong Lok Virsa Festival. This festival, which has been going for over 25 years, is meant to revive endangered Pakistani folk art by celebrating its traditional practitioners. Here, a Pakistani folk dancer from Punjab performs the dhamal, a spiritual dance signifying unity with the divine, while playing a traditional drumlike instrument called the dhol. In a typical performance, the dancer will rapidly twirl and enter a trance state. The depth of the trance and skill of the performer dictate the speed of these revolutions and also the duration of the dance. The act of the dhamal has a strong association with spirituality, symbolizing devotion to God, and is usually witnessed at religious shrines across Punjab, Pakistan. ASAD MALIK, Islamabad

Are Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and the City Council doing their traditional budget dance? Every year, the mayor proposes cutting certain vital city programs and then, at the last minute, the City Council comes to the rescue by restoring at least some of the money.

WILLIAM ANDERSON HATFIELD (known as Devil Anse) and Randolph McCoy (Ole Ran'l) were the best of friends -- until they became the worst of enemies. Civil War loyalties and the theft of a pig set off the feud along the Kentucky-West Virginia border between the men and their extended families. But all hell broke loose when McCoy's daughter Roseanna ran off with Hatfield's son Johnse, and their fathers decided it was a love that was not to be. By 1890 a dozen people had died and the governors of both states had called up their militias to restore order. Starting Monday at 9 p.m., History will recreate the saga in ''Hatfields & McCoys,'' a three-night mini-series starring Kevin Costner and Bill Paxton. The men recently spoke by phone with Kathryn Shattuck about the story's significance some 150 years after it began and -- no animosity here -- their budding bromance. Edited excerpts from the conversation follow:

The Streetscapes column on May 13, about the usage over the years of the path around the Central Park reservoir, misstated the year a mounted policeman jumped the fence on horseback to save a woman struggling in the water. It was 1923, not 1928.

CHESTER, Pa. -- Pia Sundhage's singing is not new. Sundhage, the coach of the United States women's soccer team, has incorporated music into her team addresses in the past, and she took her (very) Off Broadway act global last summer, when she infused a news conference at the Women's World Cup in Germany with a few bars from Simon & Garfunkel's ''The 59th Street Bridge Song (Feelin' Groovy).'' So it was hardly a surprise when Sundhage broke into song early Sunday night. Asked during an on-field interview before the United States team's exhibition game against China about the scene here at PPL Park, Sundhage showcased the Louisiana part of her repertory by serenading the fans with lines from the Southern classic ''You Are My Sunshine.''

Oster, the former dean of the Yale School of Management who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated. The bride, 31, and the bridegroom, 36, met in 2008 at the School of Management, where she is an assistant professor and he is an associate professor.

A NOTABLE decrease in motorcyclist deaths that began in 2009 has not been sustained, according to a new study released on Tuesday by the Governors Highway Safety Association. The report, based on analysis of preliminary data for the first nine months of 2011 from the 50 states and Washington, found that motorcyclist deaths fell in 23 states from their levels in 2010, but 26 states and Washington reported increases. Fatalities in Louisiana were unchanged.

WEBB--Nancy. Died May 22 at home with family. Widow of Bill Webb. Survived by her children Alexander, Patrick and Sophie and sister Janet Chapin. Nancy Webb had a long and productive life as an artist: art director for Noonday Press in the 50s; children's book author and illustrator; and sculptor whose sculptures and drawings where widely exhibited and collected. A Memorial Service will be held at the Provincetown Museum, September 9, 2012.

JACOBSON--Audrey Platt, died on Saturday, May 19, 2012. She was born in New York City on March 9, 1928, the daughter of Joseph Platt and Anne Eisenberg Platt. A lifelong visual artist, she worked at her creations every day from the time she was 10 to the last day of her 84 year life. As a 14 year old she took the ferry from her home in New Jersey to Manhattan to attend classes at the Art Institute and the New School and spent a summer at the Yale School of Art. She continued her art studies and was graduated from Skidmore College in 1949 and from Parsons School of Design shortly thereafter. She married Dr. Jerry H. Jacobson in December, 1951 at her family home in New Jersey and they left for his tour of duty in the Air Force. She worked as an illustrator at the Air Base in Amarillo, Texas while they were stationed there. When discharged from service, the couple returned to New York, after the first trip of a lifetime of travel, by ship to Italy. She worked as artist and art director at advertising agencies in the city, and then opened an art gallery in Englewood, across the river from Manhattan in New Jersey. She was an indefatigable wife, homemaker and hostess to her many friends. Her integrity, sincerity and outgoing personality resulted in an uncanny ability to make friends wherever she went, among people of all stations. Her sons, John and Benjamin, were born in 1959 and 1961. She was an utterly devoted mother, wife and grandmother to Ben and Lissa's boys, Zachary and Dylan. In 1971 she and her family moved to Ogdensburg, where she continued her studies in Potsdam State and St. Lawrence University, ran a busy household, worked as a medical photographer and produced a voluminous body of prints and paintings. For the past few years she and her husband spent winters in Charleston, SC. Her lithographs, etchings and monoprints were shown at galleries and shows throughout the Unites States. Her work was marked by utter femininity, wit, spontaneity, humor and beauty. She never went a day without painting, printmaking or drawing. Her sketchbook and watercolors were always at hand. She studied the Italian language assiduously and traveled to that country and other lands often, making friends wherever she went. She was an avid gardener. Her health deteriorated in the recent past, but she never complained about it, but persevered in her daily output of watercolors and cheer. Her friends and family are devastated. There will be a memorial service in the future.

The Olympic torch is on its way to London, but a Czech advertising campaign is set on getting Britons to flee their homeland this August and instead take part in ''the Prague Games,'' with events including ''Kafkarate'' and ''Heavyweight Shopping.'' The campaign was spurred by reports in the British news media that up to 50 percent of Londoners are thinking about leaving the city during the Olympic Games. ''Therefore we want to take advantage of this unique opportunity and invite them to Prague,'' said Katerina Buresova of that city's culture department.

It's possible to watch the six hours of ''Hatfields & McCoys,'' a three-night mini-series beginning on Monday on the History channel, and still be scratching your head over how, exactly, the whole thing got started. A Hatfield defected from the Confederate side during the Civil War and got a head start on postwar business, which irritated his former friend, a McCoy. But then there was already bad blood because a McCoy had accused another Hatfield of illicit relations with a dog.

Mary Lou Retton, the first American female gymnast to win a gold medal in the all-around, was the star of the 1984 Summer Olympics in Los Angeles. She won five medals, including two silvers, for team and vault, and two bronzes, for uneven bars and floor exercise. More recently, Sue Sylvester, Jane Lynch's fictional character on the Fox show ''Glee,'' made a passing reference to Retton as her worst enemy. And Retton is among the former athletes whose retro images are being featured on Wheaties boxes.

We had a taste of summer on our last visit to Corson's Brook Woods, equal parts blue sky, warm sun and green leaves. So why was it snowing just outside the forest? Drifts of white cottony fluff floated by, piling up among blades of a grassy lawn. I snatch one out of the air. Its silken hairs quickly separate to reveal a single tiny seed. I spot the source: a copse of cottonwood trees several hundred feet away. Walking across the street to the woods, I'm hit by the heady scent of a familiar flower, Japanese honeysuckle. The fragrance transports me back to childhood when my sister and I would pick them from a fence near our grammar school. We pulled the anthers out to slurp the nectar from the floral base. See a larger version of the forest from this week. Compare with the enlarged version of last week's image.

To the Editor: ''The Grand Old Party and the Sea'' (editorial, May 17) criticized House Republicans for leading efforts to slow the expansion of ''catch share'' mechanisms in coastal fisheries by which allowable fish harvest of coastal stocks is awarded or sold to groups, corporations or individuals.

THRILLING as it was to hear a sitting president endorse marriage rights for gay and lesbian Americans, there is one man whose opinion on the subject matters more than President Obama's. Justice Anthony Kennedy is the likely deciding vote when this issue reaches the Supreme Court. More than anyone, he has the power to transform what is now a license bestowed by the more enlightened states into an all-American civil right. Kennedy's role as the court weather vane has given rise to a species of argument that Jeffrey Rosen, the George Washington University law professor, calls ''the Kennedy brief,'' in which ''lawyers on both sides fall over themselves to court Kennedy's favor by repeatedly citing the opinions of Justice Kennedy.'' I've been trying to envision the Kennedy brief in defense of gay marriage.

REDWOOD CITY, Calif. -- By the time President Obama took the stage at the Fox Theater here, he was in the 18th hour of a 19-hour day. His tie was still knotted to the top as he launched into his stump speech, attacking his opponent's record and defending his own. ''I still believe in you,'' he said, ''and I hope you still believe in me.'' That is a proposition he is testing four years after the political winds converged behind his improbable journey to the White House. In marathon trips across the nation, he seeks to justify the faith supporters invested in him and earn it back. Sometimes he sounds like the outsider of 2008 running against an establishment that he now sits atop.

Were my eyes deceiving me? Or was Jessica Paré of ''Mad Men'' a last-minute substitute for Jennifer Sheehan at Feinstein's at Loews Regency on Wednesday evening? I had to blink twice. But no, it wasn't Ms. Paré but Ms. Sheehan, the rising cabaret star transformed into Ms. Paré's doppelgänger for her effervescent new show, ''I Know a Place,'' an anthology of 1960s songs that takes its title from the Petula Clark hit that led off the evening. Although her patter included obligatory references to that decade's traumas, Ms. Sheehan's version of the '60s was predominantly upbeat and innocent. Only at the end did ebullience give way to a more pensive mood, which also brought out her best singing.

Kaila Joan Pearlman and Marine First Lt. Nikolaos Bartolomeo De Maria are to be married Sunday evening at the country home of the bride's family in Spencertown, N.Y. Rabbi Joshua Burrows is to officiate, with Cantor Gabi Arad to take part. The couple met at the University of Rochester, from which they graduated, the bridegroom cum laude. Mrs. De Maria, 25, is completing her second year as a member of Teach for America. She is a preschool teacher at Dover Elementary School in San Pablo, Calif.

REISS--Herbert, of Newtown, PA, died on May 22, 2012 at age 89. His wife Laurel, children Peter and wife Ellen, Pam and husband Steven Stave, and grandchildren James, Elizabeth, Joshua and Mark survive him and will carry his love with them forever.

KATMANDU, Nepal -- Nepal descended into a new crisis on Sunday after rival political parties in the Himalayan nation failed to reach an agreement on a new constitution before the national legislature's term expired at midnight. Prime Minister Baburam Bhattarai, speaking on national television, announced that the legislature, known as the Constituent Assembly, would be dissolved. He said he would remain in power and that his government would hold November elections for a new assembly. Rival political leaders quickly denounced the plan as a power grab.

Elizabeth Scott Fischer and Jonathan Lansing Martin are to be married Sunday evening at the Airlie Center, an event space in Warrenton, Va. The ceremony is to be led by Michael Patrick Allen, a friend of the couple who received permission to officiate from the Commonwealth of Virginia. The bride, 42, will be known as Ms. Fischer Martin. She is the executive producer of ''Meet the Press'' on NBC. She graduated cum laude from American University, where she also received a master's degree in journalism and public affairs.

The Continuum towers, built from 1999 to 2008 and exceeding 40 stories in height, were among the last oceanfront buildings to go up in Miami Beach before zoning laws were changed. The new rules restricted maximum building heights along the ocean to 200 feet and 22 stories. The Continuum's particular zoning district is even more restrictive: oceanfront residential structures cannot exceed 100 feet and 11 stories, according to the city of Miami Beach's municipal code.

The Los Angeles Kings have been around for 45 years, but on the eve of their second trip to the Stanley Cup finals, they remain something of a mystery in Southern California. Without question, the Kings have a core of intensely loyal and knowledgeable fans, some of whom have followed the team since its founding in 1967. A surprising number of them found their way to Arizona during the Western Conference finals, snapping up unsold seats to watch their club take down the Phoenix Coyotes in five games.

Esha Udyavar and Dr. Varun Bhandarkar are to be married Sunday at the Cape Fear Botanical Gardens in Fayetteville, N.C. Pandit Shivananda Bhatis to lead a Hindu ceremony. The bride, 24, will be taking her husband's name. Until earlier this month, she taught first-grade at Brewer Elementary School in San Antonio as a member of Teach For America. She graduated magna cum laude from North Carolina State University. She is a daughter of Sharmila S. Udyavar of Fayetteville and the late Sanjay N. Udyavar. She is a stepdaughter of Arasu T. Ganesan. Her father was a marketing manager for Quest International, a retail manufacturer in Mumbai, India. The bride's mother is a program and data analyst for North Carolina Prevention Partners. a nonprofit firm involved in efforts to reduce smoking and prevent tobacco related illnesses. She works in Chapel Hill. Her stepfather is a chief information officer at Fayetteville State University.

Callan Marie Blount, a daughter of Phyllis Bisch Marwill and Sherwood E. Blount Jr., both of Dallas, was married Friday evening in Brooklyn to Benjamin Andrew Fleming, a son of Ruth Levy Fleming and Robert B. Fleming Jr. of Buffalo. Blair A. Heiser, who introduced the couple and who became an American Marriage Ministries minister for the event, officiated at the Old Stone House, a museum. Mrs. Fleming, 28, is a fund-raising manager at Teach for America and works in Manhattan. She solicits donations from corporations. She graduated from the University of Virginia and received a master's degree in education from Pace University. She is on the board of the Friends of the Joseph Loretan Campus, an organization that supports the Joseph O. Loretan public elementary school in the Bronx.

''A Study for the Center Is Everywhere,'' a seven-foot column of hand-cut crystal and brass suspended inches off the ground by Josiah McElheny, will be displayed for the first time as a part of a major retrospective of the artist's work, opening at the Institute of Contemporary Art in Boston on June 22.

To the Editor: As President Obama's endorsement of gay marriage is met with cynicism in some quarters, ''King's Forgotten Manifesto,'' by David W. Blight and Allison Scharfstein (Op-Ed, May 17), highlights the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s ambitious 1962 proposal for a presidential order outlawing segregation. The proposal, however, prompted little executive action.

The National Labor Relations Board announced on Sunday that one of its five members, Terence F. Flynn, had resigned after the board's inspector general found that Mr. Flynn, a Republican, leaked documents to G.O.P. allies. The board's chairman, Mark Gaston Pearce, said Mr. Flynn, who joined the board in January, had submitted his resignation on Saturday evening by fax and e-mail.

Jessica Tabor Wahman and John Jeremy Stuhr were married Friday evening in New York. The Rev. David J. Robb, a minister of the Unitarian Universalist Church, officiated at Pilgrim Hill in Central Park. Dr. Wahman, 44, is keeping her name. She is an associate professor of philosophy at Dickinson College in Carlisle, Pa. She graduated from Skidmore College and received a doctoral degree in philosophy from the State University at Stony Brook.

TAFT--Marlene R.,of Great Neck, NY, died on May 25, 2012. Devoted wife to the late Robert S. Taft and companion to the late Hy Sussman. Marlene graduated from Great Neck North High School in 1954 and received her BFA from Cornell University in 1958. After raising her children, she went back to school to receive her Masters in Education in 1991 from LIU. She enjoyed volunteering as a museum docent for the Nassau County Museum of Fine Arts and worked for Lord & Taylor's for over 11 years. She loved to travel collecting art from far ends of the earth. Survivors include a brother, Jack Medwin and sister-in-law, Maria Medwin; a daughter, Dr. Leslie Aiuto and son-in-law, Anthony Aiuto, a son, Peter S. Taft, Esq. and daughter-in-law, Tammy Taft; five grandchildren, Gabrielle McCaig, Stephanie Aiuto, Brandon Taft, Matthew Taft and Zachary Button; and many dear friends, including Barbara Anderson and Audrey Lambert. Funeral services will be held at 11:30am on Monday, May 28, 2012 at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza in Great Neck, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations should be made to the American Cancer Society.

An article on Page 18 this weekend about the home-birth movement misspells a kind of throat singing to which the noises made by a woman in labor are compared. It is Tuvan -- from the Tuva region in Siberia where the singing is practiced -- not Tuvian.

The Federal Aviation Administration has recommended using safety seats for small children on flights in recent years, but parents often have a hard time figuring out which ones are best. Now, the agency is offering some guidance. It recently announced a new Web site (www.faa.gov/passengers/fly--children/) to help air travelers choose and install the seats. ''Because not all safety seats are suitable for use in an aircraft, the site offers information about F.A.A.-approved safety devices for traveling with kids,'' Transportation Secretary Ray LaHood wrote on his blog FastLane this month.

PARIS -- When Italians said good riddance to Silvio Berlusconi, it turned out that they were ready for more than just a political change. Since Mr. Berlusconi stepped down from his post as prime minister last year, returning to life as a media mogul, the digital era finally seems to have dawned in Italy. Mr. Berlusconi's television company, Mediaset, an analog-era powerhouse that continued to dominate the Italian media scene well into his 17-year sojourn in or near the prime minister's villa, has suffered greatly since he left office for the third and presumably final time. Advertising has fallen, earnings have plunged and more Italians are tuning in to alternatives like Sky Italia, the satellite television broadcaster owned by Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation.

Abigail Rose Solomon and Jason Birkestrand Teuscher are to be married Sunday in Chilmark, Mass. Rabbi Carol Davidson is to officiate at the Captain R. Flanders House, an inn on Martha's Vineyard. The bride, 42, will keep her name. She is the executive producer and the founder of Rosalind Productions, which produces plays on and off Broadway in New York. She is also an actress who has appeared in the television shows ''Sex and the City'' and ''Law and Order,'' and appeared in the movie ''Mr. and Mrs. Smith.'' She graduated cum laude from Williams College and received a master of fine arts degree in acting from New York University.

GARDNER--George Peabody. George Peabody Gardner, formerly of Brookline and Prides Crossing, Massachusetts, passed away at his home in Palm Beach, Florida on May 9th. Mr. Gardner was born in Newton, MA in 1917. Son of George Peabody Gardner and Rose Grosvenor Gardner, he was one of six children. George attended the Park School in Brookline, MA, and continued his preparatory studies at the St. Marks's School in Southborough, MA. Mr. Gardner then went on to Harvard College and graduated in 1939. In 1940, George enlisted in the U.S. Navy and served for six years during WWII where he served aboard the USS Louisville and the USS Quincy. Mr. Gardner was honorably discharged in 1946 as a Lieutenant Commander. He worked in the Advertising Department at the Boston Herald, and the Batten Barton Durstine, and Osborn Advertising Agency. In 1952 he began work at Paine Webber, Jackson, and Curtis and became a general partner in 1955. He also joined the policy committee. He was a director of Arthur D. Little, Kaiman Aircraft Corporation, Barry Controls, Inc., The Wright Line, Inc., Macalaster Scientific Corporation, Instron, Lestoil, W.R.Grace, Oxbow Corp., Stanley Home Products, Inc., and a chairman of United Fruit. Co. and the Wang Center of Boston. George P. Gardner was a Trustee of the Boston Museum of Science, where he was also the President for three years from 1954-59 and was remembered for climbing the Ruth Glacier of Mt McKinley in Alaska with Brad Washburn. He joined the MIT Corporation's Board of Trustees in 1959, became a life member 1963-1992, was elected to the executive committee 1965-1967, and in 1979 was awarded the "Founding Life Sustaining Fellow" by MIT. Mr. Gardner was also a trustee of the JFK Library, the Institute of Defense Analyses, the World Peace Foundation, the St. Mark's School, and Children's Hospital Medical Center, Boston, and an honorary trustee of The Humane Society of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts. Additionally, he helped to build a multidenominational Chapel for the Escuela Agricola Pan Americana Zamorano in Tegucigalpa, Honduras. He became a trustee of Zamorano and remained a critical member of the board for 50 years. At his 55th Harvard Reunion he said, "I can only confirm that the best thing that ever happened to me was a chance meeting 47 years ago at a Ballet performance at the Teatro de Bellas Artes in Mexico City where I met a remarkable young lady, Tatiana Stepanova, a Prima Ballerina for the Ballet Russe, whom I married and who gave me a very close family and a wonderful life." He was predeceased by his beloved son G. Peabody Gardner Jr. and his wife of 63 years, Tatiana Stepanova Gardner. George leaves behind his two daughters, Alexandra and Tatiana, his daughter-in-law, Susan, his one son-in-law, seven grandchildren and six great grandchildren. The family is so grateful to the wonderful love and care provided by Terry, Gloria, Derrick, Bernice, Jean, and Marlene. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to; The Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum, Boston, Escuela Agricola Pan Americana, Washington, D.C., or The Boston Museum of Science. Boston. The Memorial Service will be on Saturday, June 16th at Trinity Church, Copley Square, 10:30am. The burial shall be private.

To the Editor: ''Tall Tales About Private Equity,'' by Steven Rattner (Op-Ed, May 23), got it right. The objective is to make a high rate of return, not to create jobs. As a 30-year veteran of the industry, I can truly say that job creation has never come up in discussions about the wisdom of a possible deal.

Svetlana Kimayeva and Yoav Lurie are to be married Sunday in Milwaukee. Rabbi Tamar Crystal is to officiate at the Milwaukee County Historical Society. The bride 31, who is known as Lana, will keep her name. She works in Boulder, Colo., as the deputy director for Europe and Eurasia at Internews Network, an organization in Arcata, Calif., that aids local news media organizations around the world. She manages programs that train journalists and provide resources. She graduated from the University of Wisconsin and received a master's degree in international development studies at George Washington.

On May 25, 2011, Kathy Hochul woke up a star. Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton called her from London with congratulations. Nancy Pelosi, the House Democratic leader, effusively praised her. News outlets from France, Denmark and Japan all covered the story of how she had pulled off an upset in a Republican district in a closely watched special election.

AS an actor Erich von Stroheim was billed as ''The Man You Love to Hate.'' As a director in the silent era, he was a filmmaker studios couldn't help but hate. With a mania for detail, he thought nothing of going over budget, missing deadlines and shooting mountains of footage. VON STROHEIM, on Mondays through July 30 at the Film Forum showcases his work, beginning with his troubled masterpiece ''Greed'' (1924), with a showing on Sunday as well as tomorrow, accompanied by Steve Sterner on piano. An adaptation of Frank Norris's ''McTeague,'' the film, not available on DVD, was chopped and chopped again (from about nine hours to about two and a half), but even truncated retains its power. (The Film Forum print runs just under two hours.) Next Monday, a double bill pairs von Stroheim's sole foray as a director into talking pictures, ''Hello, Sister!'' (he was pulled from the project and most of his scenes were reshot) with George Fitzmaurice's ''As You Desire Me,'' a 1932 Greta Garbo vehicle. Von Stroheim plays a controlling novelist and Garbo an amnesiac. She starts the film with a blond bob, and in her high black collar, black leggings and buckle shoes looks like a swashbuckling version of Laurence Olivier's Hamlet. (Film Forum, 209 West Houston Street, South Village; 212-727-8110, filmforum.com)

Binyamin Appelbaum's profile of Business Insider's star blogger hits that sweet spot between media gazing, implicit insanity gauging and soft-focus praise, meaning it's perfect fodder for journalists and bloggers who now can point out to everyone (especially their moms) that they do work (so hard) and for lay people to understand that, yes, bloggers must be driven by some kind of higher spirit to want to pursue this type of life. ALEXANDER ABAD-SANTOS, posted ontheatlanticwire.com

The poster for this Universal Pictures release may not look like it's promoting a slasher film. But Mr. Kerswell said it had several classic elements -- a terrified, beautiful young woman; a diabolical face; a foreboding tagline -- that make it an early example of the genre. (Whale is perhaps best remembered for 1931's ''Frankenstein'' and ''Bride of Frankenstein'' from 1935.) With a nod to Agatha Christie, the image shows a group facing misfortune, a scenario that fueled many films. The juxtaposition of beauty and horror is a slasher trope that Mr. Kerswell says is ''uncomfortable but undeniable.'' ''You've got a woman -- here it's Gloria Stuart -- dressed in evening wear that's seductive but not skimpy,'' he said. ''It's selling sex in a way.''

To the Editor: David L. Kirp (''Making Schools Work,'' Sunday Review, May 20) is right that school integration has done more to improve the life chances of poor and minority children than other known interventions. He is wrong to suggest that there's no longer any way to achieve integration and to pit it against recent school reforms that also improve life chances.

In a church nestled among a row of residential brownstones, parishioners clapped and danced as a woman began to testify. ''Aren't you glad Jesus got up?'' the woman, Twanna Gause, asked the predominantly black congregation, which responded with enthusiastic shouts of ''Amen'' and ''Hallelujah.''

Caroline Vu and Edward Namserk Cha were married Saturday at St. Thomas Aquinas Church in Palo Alto, Calif. The Rev. Matthew D. Stanley, a Roman Catholic priest and the church's pastor, performed the ceremony. Mrs. Cha, 36, is a senior counsel at Exelixis, a company in South San Francisco, Calif., that develops cancer drugs. She manages licensing agreements and transactions with organizations that test the drugs. She graduated from the University of Southern California, and received a master's degree in public health from Yale and a law degree from the University of California, Davis.

Rules and conventions about when to use and not to use commas are legion. But certain errors keep popping up. If I've seen it once, I've seen it a thousand times. I'm referring to a student's writing a sentence like:

REES--Natalie Bowes. The board members, staff of AMREF USA and the extended AMREF family are deeply saddened by the death of Nan Rees. Dr. Thomas Rees was a founder of AMREF more than 50 years ago, and Nan was at his side. She traveled back with him almost every year since, because she cared passionately about the people of Africa. She worked tirelessly for AMREF and Africa in many ways, through her ideas, her fundraising, and by promoting AMREF's work at every opportunity. Her enthusiasm was contagious. We will miss her tremendously. Our hearts go out to her husband Tom, daughter Liz and son Tom Jr. Lisa Meadowcroft, AMREF USA Executive Director Carol Jenkins, Chair of the Board, AMREF USA

Caleb Lloyd did not take his baseball glove to Great American Ball Park in Cincinnati last Monday. ''Every time I bring a glove, I never come close to catching anything, and I'm stuck carrying the glove around everywhere,'' Lloyd said. ''It's a hassle.''
