ST. LOUIS -- With fluorescent yellow eyes and tufts of hair sticking straight up behind their ears, Bonner and Etienne look like slightly crazed old men. These riotous and chatty lemurs -- known for elaborate rituals that include grooming and braying -- once ranged across eastern Madagascar.

Perhaps it was consolation for Canada's absence from the Stanley Cup finals. On Sunday, Ryder Hesjedal became the first Canadian to win the Giro d'Italia, or any of cycling's three major tours. After three weeks of racing over 2,177 miles, Hesjedal won the first of the season's major stage races by 16 seconds after a time trial that twisted through the streets of Milan.

Inside the Beacon Theater on Saturday afternoon a security officer was girding for war: ''When they come onstage you have to stay in your seats!'' ''You can't go to the front of the stage!'' Mostly she got her way. The crowd was young enough to be well behaved, many members with chaperones. A few of the smallest ones had huge noise-reducing headphones.

Dana Jill Fabrikant and Jonathan David Weinbach are to be married Sunday evening at the Boca Raton Resort in Boca Raton, Fla. Rabbi Robert P. Frazin is to officiate. The bride, 32, is a vice president of corporate partnerships in Newark for the New Jersey Devils of the National Hockey League and the Prudential Center, where the Devils play home games. She sells sponsorships for the team and the arena and works on other business development projects. She graduated cum laude from Duke.

LEITER--Naomi, M.D.,77, of New York City, NY, died May 25, 2012. She was born in Brooklyn, NY, the daughter of the late David Leiter, and Freda Pearlman Leiter. She was a Psychiatrist and Psychotherapist in private practice--and previously worked with the New York City Board of Education, Columbia-Presbyterian Hospital, Bellevue and St. Lukes-Roosevelt Hospital, among others. She was a graduate of Brooklyn College and the University of Buffalo Medical school, where she was among the first women to receive a medical degree. She is survived by her brother Elliot Leiter, her son Richard and her son Alec and his wife Lisa Servon and their children Carmen and Milo Servon--all of Brooklyn, NY. A graveside burial will be at Mt. Carmel Cemetery in Queens, Tuesday, May 29 at 11am. A Memorial Service will be held on Thursday, May 31 at 3:00pm, at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue at 91st St, NY, NY. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to the Lustgarten Foundation. www.lustgarten.org.

Jennifer Lynn Breckheimer, a daughter of Martha and Peter Breckheimer of La Cañada Flintridge, Calif., is to be married Sunday to Steven Carl Rosenzweig, a son of Lizanne Landsman Rosenzweig of Harrison, N.Y., and the late Jeffrey S. Rosenzweig. Rabbi Amy R. Bernstein is to officiate at the Langham Huntington, a hotel in Pasadena, Calif. The bride, 29, will take her husband's name. She is the acting manager for organizational planning at Save the Children, which is based in Westport, Conn. She graduated from the University of Michigan and received a master's degree in public policy from the University of Southern California.

One thing that CNBC's profile of Millard (Mickey) Drexler, the chief executive of J. Crew, made clear on Thursday night is that his life is not the stuff of novels. True, he had what sounded like a lousy childhood, sleeping in the foyer of his family's Bronx apartment. And later, as a very rich man, he bought classy real estate, including Andy Warhol's former compound at Montauk. And true, he got the boot from Gap, in 2002, after a mostly innovative 19-year run that included the creation of Old Navy. (According to a Wall Street Journal profile, Mr. Drexler collected around $350 million when he cashed out his Gap stake.) Standing with the 67-year-old retail legend outside his old Bronx digs, the CNBC correspondent David Faber tried to do a Rosebud moment, and to a degree Mr. Drexler played along. (''I always wished I had a bedroom.'') But CNBC couldn't avoid the obvious in its hourlong program, despite a jaunt to Italy and its Moses-like title, ''J. Crew and the Man Who Dressed America.'' The fact is, Mr. Drexler is the stuff of retailing. He's a genius of merch.

A review on May 13 about Elizabeth Wein's young adult novel ''Code Name Verity'' misidentified the British admiral whose death is alluded to in the book. He was Admiral Nelson, not Hardy. (A character in the novel says, ''Kiss me, Hardy.'' This was a phrase that Adm. Horatio Nelson, fatally wounded at Trafalgar, addressed to Thomas Hardy, his flag captain at the time and later an admiral himself.)

THERMAL, Calif. -- To understand the conditions at the Duroville mobile-home park here, a half-hour drive from Palm Springs, Calif., just look at the windows. Dotting the walls are stretches of plywood, cardboard, blankets and even tinfoil. Replacing the glass just costs too much for many of the residents to consider. Duroville is a collection of more than 200 trailers that serve as homes for farmworkers who, at this time of year, work 12-hour days plucking grapes and digging up onions in triple-digit temperatures. There is no sewerage: a patchwork of plastic pipes repaired with duct tape winds underground to a swampy pond. Cars kick up a load of dust on the dirt road, which quickly turns to mud when it rains. And this, it should be noted, is an improvement.

Abigail Pamela Seldin, a daughter of Judith Seldin-Cohen of Charlotte, N.C., and David M. Seldin of Tierra Verde, Fla. is to be married Sunday evening to Whitney Patrick Haring-Smith, the son of Tori Haring-Smith and Robert H. Haring-Smith of Washington, Pa. Harper S. Seldin, a brother of the bride who became a Universal Life Minister for the occasion, will lead the ceremony at their father's home. The couple met at Oxford, where they were Rhodes scholars, and from which he received a doctorate in politics. She is completing a doctorate in social anthropology.

ORTNER--Everett, age 92, passed away on May 22, 2012, following a brief illness. Everett was an active leader in local, national and international preservation activities and a recipient of the Lucy G. Moses Preservation Award for Lifetime Achievement from the Landmarks Conservancy. He will be missed by family and friends, and by scores of Park Slope neighbors for whom he, along with his wife Evelyn, brought about the rebirth of a dying Brooklyn neighborhood to create one of the nation's most desirable urban communities in which to live and raise a family. We thank you. Everett is survived by a nephew, Arthur Levin of Delray Beach, FL, a niece Roberta Feigenbaum of Fairlawn OH and a godchild, Monica Musich of Fairport, NY. A private memorial service will be held at Green-Wood Cemetery on a date to be determined. Contributions honoring Everett can be sent to Preservation Volunteers, 1995 Broadway, Suite 605, New York, NY 10023. Preservation Volunteers is an on-going not-for-profit co-founded by Everett and Evelyn Ortner.

THERE are no jazz festivals in town, but this is an ordinary week of extraordinary riches. On Monday at Dizzy's Club Coca-Cola (Broadway and 60th Street, jalc.org), the trombonist PAPO VAZQUEZ plays with his band, Mighty Pirates Troubadours, an Afro-Puerto Rican jazz septet that unspools tense, hard, miraculous rhythm and improvising. Tuesday through Sunday, again at Dizzy's, comes the pianist ERIC REED with a new band called the UnMonk Quintet (Etienne Charles, trumpet; Seamus Blake, saxophone; Matt Clohesy, bass; Henry Cole, drums), friskily taking apart Thelonious Monk tunes, as on his recent record ''The Baddest Monk.'' The saxophonist RAVI COLTRANE plays with his quartet at Birdland (315 West 44th Street, birdlandjazz.com) from Tuesday to Saturday; he's got a new record ''Spirit Fiction,'' out next month. The Polish trumpeter TOMASZ STANKO will join an A-list of New Yorkers he's never collaborated with (David Virelles, piano; Thomas Morgan, bass; Gerald Cleaver, drums) from Thursday through Sunday at the Jazz Standard (116 East 27th Street, jazzstandard.net). And at the Village Vanguard (178 Seventh Avenue South, villagevanguard.com), the Argentine pianist-composer GUILLERMO KLEIN reassembles his 11-piece New York band, Los Guachos, trained in his flowing, mutating, stacked rhythmic cycles and strong melodies.

Quick quiz: What's a good five-letter description of Chris Christie, the Republican governor of New Jersey, that ends in ''y''? The obvious choice is, of course, ''bully.'' But as a recent debate over the state's budget reveals, ''phony'' is an equally valid answer. And as Mr. Christie goes, so goes his party.

HOWELL--Nora, 88, died of Parkinson's Disease on May 16, 2012, in Chelsea, Michigan. Nora was born in Chicago and grew up in New York City. After graduating from Brooklyn College she received a Master's Degree in biochemistry from Duke University, pursuing graduate studies in science at a time when few women embarked on such careers. From 1962 to 2001 she taught at Mississippi State College for Women in Columbus, Mississippi, where she inspired numerous students to pursue careers in medicine and the sciences. Nora loved walking, zoos, dogs, music, teaching, reading and crossword puzzles. Her sharp intelligence and frankness left an indelible impression on all who came to know her. In 1948 Nora married Wilson Howell, a historian, of Birmingham, Alabama, who died in 1986. She is survived by her brother, Mitchel Levitas, three children, Abby, Marshall, and Joel Howell, and five grandchildren. A memorial gathering will take place Saturday, July 7th, at 2:30pm, at University Commons in Ann Arbor, Michigan. Donations in her memory may be made to the Nora L. Howell Science Scholar- ship Fund at Mississippi University for Women, http://web2.muw.edu/gift-making/
You can't build a new state by taking ''legal'' vengeance upon the oppressors. That's corruption, not a path to reconciliation. ROGER W. NORMAN, Silver Spring, Md., posted on nytimes.com

One property, in the Hudson Valley, includes a 16-car garage, a piggery and hundreds of yards of lake frontage. Another offers 69 acres of waterfront land on the west shore of Staten Island, complete with a two-story gymnasium, a baseball diamond and an open-air pavilion.

MONTE CARLO -- In the end, it was a typical Monaco Grand Prix procession: The man on pole finished first, the man who started second finished second, and none of many potential surprises came to be. Mark Webber in his Red Bull car led the race almost from start to finish -- except during the pit stop period -- to take his eighth career victory and his second victory in Monaco, where he won two years ago. He did, however, provide the series an unprecedented sixth different winner in the first six races.

A report last Sunday about the marriage of Mitchell Davis and Dr. Nathan Goldstein gave an outdated name for the New York synagogue where Dr. Goldstein is the executive director of the board. It is now Congregation Beit Simchat Torah, not Congregation Beth Simchat Torah.

Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about a new, more radical insurgent group that has begun a terrorist campaign in Afghanistan misstated, in some copies, the circumstances under which a quotation about the group by Jeffrey Dressler, an analyst at the Institute for the Study of War, in Washington, was obtained. It was published in an analysis Mr. Dressler wrote for the institute and e-mailed to the reporter; it was not from an interview with Mr. Dressler.

The special assistant to the San Diego Padres' general manager fell asleep watching a game on his iPad last weekend. ''Extra innings,'' Brad Ausmus, the special assistant, said, but he actually had a better excuse. He was watching the game in Israel. Ausmus, who played 18 major league seasons as a catcher for four teams, is the manager for Israel's inaugural entry in the World Baseball Classic. He spent last week touring Israel and scouting prospects and youth leagues, and on Thursday presented a jersey to President Shimon Peres.

The Practical Traveler column last Sunday, about paying less for rental cars, misstated the relationship of Dollar Thrifty Automotive Group to Hertz and Advantage, in a section about Autoslash.com, a site that checks for lower rates and coupons. Dollar Thrifty Automotive Group is a holding company that owns Dollar Rent A Car and Thrifty Car Rental; it does not own Hertz and Advantage.

A column on May 13 about Jean Renoir's 1937 film ''Grand Illusion'' misstated the nationality of Erich von Stroheim, who starred in the movie. He was born in Vienna, and came to the United States in his 20s. He was not German.

The world's most successful single-session charity bridge tournament, the UJA-Federation of New York's Women's Philanthropy pro-am, was played on Tuesday at the Harmonie Club in Manhattan. Organized by Marci Miron, Nancy Brown, Jennifer Hoine and Jacqui Weidman, the 49th such event raised over $115,000. The winners were Judi Radin and Ron Unger of New York City. They finished about one-fifth of a board ahead of James Sampson and Paul Cushman of New York City, with Joel Wooldridge of New York City and Gail Cannold of Rye, N.Y., third.
NEW YORK GOVERNMENT OFFICES Closed.

JOHNSON--Ralph V. - On behalf of the Calvary Hospital and Calvary Fund Boards of Directors, Administration, and staff of Calvary Hospital, Inc., we mourn the passing of our longtime Board member, Ralph V. Johnson. Mr. Johnson served on the hospital Board of Directors since 1993. He gave generously of his time as a member of the Human Resources Committee and the Planning/Facility Committee. His commitment to the special mission of Calvary Hospital, and his dedication and leadership contributed enormously to the quality of care of Calvary's special patients. We will miss Ralph V. Johnson, both as a loyal Board member and a member of the Calvary Family. We extend our condolences to his family. Thomas J. Fahey, Jr., MD, Chairman, Calvary Hospital Board of Directors Steven J. Golub, Chairman of Calvary Fund Board of Directors Frank A. Calamari, President Chief Executive Officer Michael J. Brescia, MD, Executive Medical Director Robert Brescia, MD Director of Calvary Palliative Care Institute Christopher P. Comfort, MD Medical Director Richard J. Kutilek, Chief Operating Officer Andrew V. Greco Chief Financial Officer Vincent J. Spinelli, Executive VP, Calvary Fund

BRODY--Claire, age 87. Psychotherapist, professor and author. Longtime resident of Englewood, NJ. Wife, mother, grandmother, beloved friend. Donations in her memory may be made to NJ Hospice (NJHPCO).

In a 1949 press release sent out after the publication of his first novel, ''I'll Be Right Home, Ma,'' about a light-heavyweight fighter with ''a sweet right-hand sock,'' Henry Denker declared his belief that ''a writer should be active in several forms of his trade.'' He added: ''Writing is a business and should be practiced as such. On days when you think you can't possibly write a line you do it anyhow.'' His prolific career is evidence that he followed his own prescription.

Jillian Eileen Martin and Andrew Adam Fitzpatrick are to be married Sunday. The Rev. Dr. Jennifer Copeland Duke University's United Methodist chaplain, is to perform the ceremony at the campus chapel in Durham, N.C. The couple met at Duke, from which they both graduated.

Emily Rose Heroy and Yale A. Fillingham are to be married Sunday evening in an outdoor ceremony at Millcreek Barns in Watervliet, Mich. Mariah P. Cunnick, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, is to officiate. The bride, 27, will continue to use her name professionally. She was until last month a co-founder and the executive editor of Gender Across Borders, an organization that advocated gender equality. In July, she will begin studying for a master's degree in teaching education at the University of Pennsylvania. She graduated from New York University.

THE docks in Malmo, Sweden, went bust during an economic recession in the 1980s. Decades later, as part of a city initiative to ''take back the sea'' (to borrow a phrase from the city planning office), the defunct shipyards are being transformed into places where locals love to hang out -- especially in the summer, when Malmo residents now flock to the new waterfront promenades for beach bars, long walks, picnics and sunbathing. As the new neighborhood comes to life, it is drawing art galleries, restaurants and cafes, making it an increasingly interesting place year round. SALLY McGRANE

PARIS -- The last time anyone played a Grand Slam tennis match, Novak Djokovic required nearly six hours to finish off Rafael Nadal in the Australian Open final. Just what extremes might be required of the leading men on the gritty, rally-extending red clay at the French Open, which begins Sunday?

CANNES, France -- Heavy rain dampened the final day of the 65th Cannes Film Festival, but it mattered not at all when the Palme d'Or was awarded to ''Amour.'' Brilliantly directed with an atypically tender touch by the Austrian director Michael Haneke, this story about an octogenarian husband and wife facing their mortality -- beautifully played by the French actors Jean-Louis Trintignant and Emmanuelle Riva -- had left audiences stunned with its artistry and depth of feeling. In the days leading up to the awards, the word buzzing through the festival was that ''Amour'' didn't stand a chance of winning a significant prize because the head of the competition jury, the Italian director Nanni Moretti, had profoundly disliked Mr. Haneke's violent 1997 shocker, ''Funny Games.'' Rounding out this year's jury were three other directors (Alexander Payne, Raoul Peck and Andrea Arnold); one fashion designer (Jean Paul Gaultier); and four performers (Hiam Abbass, Diane Kruger, Ewan McGregor and Emmanuelle Devos). That Mr. Haneke first won the Palme in 2009 for ''The White Ribbon'' was largely thought to be another factor working against him.
An article on Page 7 this weekend about Jodee Nimerichter, the new director of the American Dance Festival in Durham, N.C., omits the byline. The writer is Claudia La Rocco.

An article last Sunday about the latest developments in Egypt's presidential race misstated, in some copies, the given name of the socialist and Arab nationalist candidate in the tradition of Gamar Abdel Nasser. He is Hamdeen Sabahi, not Habdeed.

By the time we convene the next meeting of the Big City Book Club, it will officially be summer and well into baseball season. We'll honor the moment with a reading of a classic New York City ballpark novel, Mark Harris's ''Bang the Drum Slowly.'' Written in 1956, and a sequel to his ''Southpaw,'' the book revolves around a star pitcher for the New York Mammoths (based on the Yankees) and the illness of one of his teammates, the catcher Bruce Pearson. The book was adapted for television in the 1950s and then as a film in the '70s starring Michael Moriarty and Robert De Niro. Join us for the online conversation June 27 from 6:30 to 9:30 p.m. To join the Book Club and receive updates about chats, send an e-mail with the subject line ''Join'' to bigcity@nytimes.com.
FRUGAL TRAVELER Seth Kugel recounts some of his favorite characters from his recent budget-friendly road trip down U.S. 17, through a handful of Southern states.

After ''Halloween'' became a box office smash, other studios jumped on the bandwagon. But conjuring up real scares isn't as easy as John Carpenter made it look. This poster, for a film about a criminally insane killer of sorority sisters, came toward the end of the slasher's golden age. ''What it's saying is you're going to see a killer with an ax chasing a girl through the woods in 3-D,'' he said. ''It harkens back to some of the other types of horror films, especially the B-movie films of the 1950s, where low-budget filmmakers took ideas and made high-budget films and said, 'If we can throw more sex in, the more money we'll make.' ''

ANDERSON--Robert Lee. Robert ("Bob") Lee Anderson, 85, of Clearwater, FL, passed away peacefully on Tuesday, May 22nd surrounded by his family. His career spanned more than thirty years in engineering management operations, directing over 100 projects in the U.S. and abroad for more than 70 clients in the manufacturing, service, and information processing fields. For two years he was general manager of UNICEF at its headquarters in New York City. Before that he was based in Brussels, Belgium, working for World Standard as its coordinator for all U.S. and European systems. For many years, he was a senior government analyst for the National Archives in Washington, D.C. He also worked in the office of the Assistant Secretary of State for Public Affairs writing public statements on U.S. foreign policy. Born in Southbridge, MA to Charles August Anderson of Fall River, MA and Mildred Olman Anderson of Stensviken, Sweden, Robert was an artistic soul who loved music, particularly Dixieland jazz. He was an extremely gifted vocalist who sang at Washington Cathedral and as a member of an Air Force barbershop quartet was flown by helicopter over Greenland to sing over the airwaves during World War II. Robert served in the U.S. Army Air Corps and as a foreign affairs officer in the Army's Counter-Intelligence Reserve. He graduated from Williston Academy in Easthampton, MA, attended college at the University of Massachusetts in Fort Devens, and studied foreign affairs at George Washington University. He was very proud of his two daughters, Kathleen Anderson, a New York literary agent, and Laura Anderson Wood, a singer-songwriter and RN, who recorded "South Station Slide" -- a CD dedicated to her father's musical spirit. He is also survived by Allan Stowell of Clearwater, his best friend and loving stepson. As a memorial tribute, contributions can be made to the Louis Armstrong Educational Foundation, P.O. Box 3115, New York, NY 10163-3115 or by going to the website: http://www.louisarmstrong foundation.org/contribute.php

''It's a huge disappointment.'' David J. Abella, a portfolio manager at Rochdale Investment Management,after Facebook's shares tumbled on their second trading day. He tried but failed to get shares in the initial public offering. Regulators are scrutinizing the I.P.O. amid questions about its fairness.

Miami Beach THE Department of Veterans Affairs, already under enormous strain from the aging of the Vietnam generation, the end of the Iraq war and the continuing return of combat troops from Afghanistan, announced in April that it would increase its mental health staff by about 10 percent. But too many veterans waging a lonely and emotional struggle to resume a normal life continue to find the agency a source of disappointment rather than healing.

That R. A. Dickey has become the lone remaining purveyor of the enigmatic knuckleball has not slowed his unending search for mastery over it. Dickey nimbly ushered the Mets to a 2-0 victory over the San Diego Padres on Sunday afternoon at Citi Field, striking out 10 batters in seven and a third innings while extending the dominance he showed last week, when he struck out 11 in Pittsburgh.
The Evening Hours column last Sunday misstated the first name of a guest at the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum gala on May 12. She is Rebecca G. Campbell, not Susan.

SEAMAN--Alfred J.,passed away in his home in Oyster Bay, LI on May 26, 2012, three and a half months shy of his 100th birthday. Born in Hempstead, NY on September 17, 1912, he graduated from Columbia University, served in World War II on both the Atlantic and Pacific fronts as an aircraft carrier CIC officer and became one of the leading figures in the post-war advertising industry. At the time of his retirement in 1981, he was chairman and CEO of S, S, C & B (later Lintas Amirati Puris) and was a key figure in his agency's joining The Interpublic Group of Companies. He had served as chairman of the 4As, was elected in 1983 to the Advertising Hall of Fame and was the founding chairman of the Advertising Education Foundation. In 1987, he was awarded an honorary doctorate by Long Island University's C. W. Post College. As mayor of the Village of Upper Brookville from 1966 to '98, he was the longest serving elected official in New York State. He was predeceased by his first wife and the mother of his four children, Mary Margaret Seaman, and by his second wife, Honor Mellor Seaman. He is survived by three daughters: Marilyn S. Hollingsworth and Susan and Debbie Seaman; and a son, A. Barrett Seaman, as well as three step-children, eight grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. A Funeral Service at St. John's of Lattingtown will be held 4pm Wednesday, May 30. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Samuel Waxman Cancer Research Foundation 420 Lexington Ave. Suite 825 New York, NY 10170 or visit: www.waxmancancer.org would be appreciated.

Beaches along the southern Atlantic coast were closed on Sunday, and visitors and residents in some low-lying regions were told to seek higher ground as Tropical Storm Beryl threatened to upset holiday weekend plans for thousands of beachgoers. By Sunday afternoon, the waves had picked up and sharp winds had begun to lash northern Florida and southern Georgia.

Payal Agrawal, a daughter of Kusum Agrawal and Subhash Agrawal of Dracut, Mass., is to be married Sunday to Dr. Sanjay Divakaran, a son of Maria D. Divakaran and Dr. Diva Divakaran of East Meadow, N.Y. Pandit Srinivasa Shastri, a Hindu priest, is to officiate at the Seaport World Trade Center in Boston. The couple, both 25, met at M.I.T., from which they graduated.

THE Accademia Carrara in Bergamo holds one of Italy's most distinguished collections of Venetian painting. And while it is closed for restoration, some of its choicest items are on the road. The itinerary brings 15 pictures to the Metropolitan Museum of Art in ''BELLINI, TITIAN AND LOTTO: NORTH ITALIAN PAINTINGS FROM THE ACCADEMIA CARRARA, BERGAMO.'' There are, of course, things by the superstars of the title. Giovanni Bellini's ''Pietà with the Virgin and Saint John,'' dated between 1455 and 1460, is a mournful complement to his later ''Madonna and Child,'' which is in the Met's collection. The single Titian is the very early ''Orpheus and Eurydice,'' thought to have been done between 1508 and 1512. And from Lorenzo Lotto we have a charming portrait of Lucina Brembati, who wears a large jeweled toothpick on a gold chain around her neck. Less familiar sights are three smallish narrative paintings from a Lotto altarpiece that has not traveled. And then there are artists you probably won't know at all, like Giovanni Cariani, Andrea Previtali, Moretto da Brescia and Vincenzo Foppa. But really, they're just old friends that you have yet to meet. Through Sept. 3; Metropolitan Museum of Art; (212) 535-7710, metmuseum.org.

Lauren Elizabeth Belive and Jeffrey Ryan Zubricki are to be married Sunday evening at the Wequassett Resort and Golf Club in Chatham, Mass. The Rev. James F. David, a priest with the Ecumenical Catholic Diocese of America, is to perform the ceremony. The bride, 28, will keep her name. She works in Washington as an associate counsel for the Democratic staff of the House Rules Committee, helping bring legislation to the House floor. Until last month, she was a legislative assistant in the White House. She graduated from Barnard College.
To the Sports Editor: Re ''10 Games Worth Bringing Back,'' May 22: Tennis has long had mixed doubles, so why not mix the sexes in other sports at the Olympics?

PARIS -- The scars remind Brian Baker of the career that never really started. They number five, one for each operation in the six years Baker spent away from professional tennis. Each scar tells a story: of the hips that refused to heal, of the sports hernia, of the hundreds of hours spent not on tennis courts but inside doctors' offices. One scar, which runs along Baker's right elbow, resulted from his longest and most unusual operation, one performed overwhelmingly on baseball players, one even named after a pitcher, Tommy John.

Holly Helen Slimak, a daughter of Theresa J. Linger and Sheldon L. Linger of Gloucester, Va., is to be married Sunday to Christopher Stuart Colby, the son of Janet Colby and W. Stuart Colby of Ossining, N.Y. The Rev. Robert Michael Dunn, a Roman Catholic priest, is to perform the ceremony at St. Bernard Catholic Church in Holmes Beach, Fla. The bride, 30, is a kindergarten teacher at Dumbarton Elementary School in Henrico, Va. She graduated cum laude from Virginia Commonwealth University, from which she also received a master's degree in early childhood education.

Donna Summer, Adam Yauch, Robin Gibb, Levon Helm, Whitney Houston. In the last few months we've lost major pop figures, and in addition to the tide of news reports and candlelight vigils, social media has become a bonfire of remembrance. What is it about music stars that makes their deaths something that we hold in common? In the latest installment of ''The Sweet Spot,'' a weekly video devoted to cultural matters, A. O. Scott and David Carr of The New York Times discuss how we memorialize the people who sang the songs we grew up on: nytimes.com/video.

DENISON--Violet. With great sadness we announce the passing of Violet Denison. She died peacefully on May 18, 2012 at the Amsterdam Nursing Home. Born in the Bronx in 1924, she lived all her life in NYC except for a stint in Munich after WWII. She was an admissions officer for many years at Teacher College, Columbia University. She is mourned by her legion of friends, including her 13 godchildren. There will be a service soon at her church Trinity Lutheran and a memorial in the fall.

With its space shuttle in retirement, NASA is now preparing to land humans on Mars. The other Mars, that is. To set foot on a more down-to-earth model, all anyone needs is a slight suspension of disbelief. On arrival, Tom Sachs will be waiting - by the espresso machine.

ROSEN--Joy, 77, a beloved pottery teacher and co-founder with her husband Joel of the Performers of Westchester, died peacefully at home in Ardsley on May 17, 2012. Born in Dayton, she attended Washington University and studied painting with Oskar Kokoschka. She is survived by her daughter and son-in-law, Linda and Rob Macomber, her son and daughter-in-law, Jeff and Daphne, her grandsons Brian, Jamie, Michael and Bobby, her brother and sister-in-law David and Joan Marcus, and her sisters- and brother-in-law Martha Rosen and Rhoda and Paul Redleaf.

The Look: Dolled up. A pleated mini takes a prim spin with the addition of a crocheted pilgrim collar. The Girl: The model Natalia Vodianova at the Caramel Baby & Child Enchanted Tea Party in London, England.

An opinion essay on May 20 about the effect of the debt crisis on Spanish democracy referred incorrectly to a constitutional amendment, adopted in September, which includes a deficit-reduction clause. It was the second change made to Spain's 1978 Constitution, not the first. (In 1992, an amendment brought local election procedures in line with European Union rules.)

FRANKFURT -- To euro zone countries in need, euro bonds would be a noble expression of European solidarity and a crucial instrument for preserving the common currency. To Germans and quite a few others, though, euro bonds would be a lot like co-signing a loan for a deadbeat brother-in-law.
'I can't believe my team went soft. S-O-F-T. I'm disappointed. I never thought it would happen.' LARRY BIRD,

Lou Lamoriello, the longest-tenured general manager of a major league team in North America, was preparing for the Devils' trip to the Stanley Cup finals against the Los Angeles Kings, so he was not inclined to look back, either on his 25 years running the team or on any of its four previous appearances in the finals. But there was one thing Lamoriello did take a moment to look back on: beating the Rangers.

Samantha Nicole Mirth and Eric Scott Tarr were married Saturday evening at the Chateau at Coindre Hall, an events space in Huntington, N.Y. The Rev. Deb Viola, who is affiliated with the Sanctuary of Peace and Harmony, an interfaith seminary, officiated. Mrs. Tarr, 26, is a catering coordinator for the Compass Group, the English food-service management company, and is based at the New School in Manhattan. She graduated from the Culinary Institute of America in Hyde Park, N.Y.

Oklahoma City Thunder vs. San Antonio Spurs It would be easy to label the Western Conference finals as a battle of young versus old, but that may be unfair to the San Antonio Spurs as it is not clear that Tim Duncan actually ages.
MY CROSS TO BEAR By Gregg Allman

CAIRO -- Ahmed Shafik said he never regretted calling former President Hosni Mubarak ''a role model.'' At the lunch of elite businessmen held this month by the American Chamber of Commerce in Egypt, an umbrella group for multinationals and those who work with them, the crowd erupted in applause.

Katrina Natalie Chapman and Edward Gaillard Brett deBary were married Saturday at Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Dr. James B. Lemler, the rector of the church, performed the ceremony. The bride and the bridegroom, who are both 32, met at Connecticut College, from which they graduated, she summa cum laude.

An article last Sunday about a fatal bombing in front of a school in the southern Italian city of Brindisi misidentified, in some copies, the organized crime syndicate that is one focus of the investigation into the bombing. It is Sacra Corona Unita, not 'Ndrangheta. The article also referred incorrectly to elections being held in the country. Brindisi held a mayoral runoff election two weeks ago; it is not the case that it was not among cities holding runoff elections.

NO NAME KEY, Fla. -- It is the promise of tranquillity that attracts the hardy few to this tiny wooded island that lies unspoiled off the road to Key West and off the grid altogether. What keeps them here is the pristine fishing, fantastic vistas, ambling Key deer and winter breezes blowing in sighs of contentment. But these days, good karma is sorely missing on No Name Key. The 1,200-acre island has been riven by two warring camps of residents who have pleaded, sued, offended and, ultimately, turned their backs on each other in a fight over power, the kind that gets piped in by an electric company.

Melanie Yuko Nakagawa and Michael Gabriel Marino were married Saturday evening at the Woodend Nature Sanctuary, a property of the Audubon Naturalist Society in Chevy Chase, Md. Ryan Nakagawa, the bride's brother, who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated. The bride, 32, is keeping her name. She works in Washington as a counsel to the United States Senate Foreign Relations Committee, advising the chairman, Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts. She graduated from Brown and received a law degree and a master's in international relations from American University in Washington.

Nine months after Tropical Storm Irene struck Vermont, causing extensive property damage, the state's third-largest tourist attraction has been rebuilt. The glassblowing workshop at the popular Simon Pearce Mill in Quechee, Vt., which draws 300,000 people a year, has reopened in a restored and enlarged space. ''We're very excited to have it back again,'' said Mr. Pearce, the mill's namesake. ''There was never any question of rebuilding. It's the heart of the company.''

KABUL, Afghanistan -- Both President Hamid Karzai and NATO commanders ordered an investigation on Sunday into reports that a family of eight had been killed in a coalition airstrike in eastern Afghanistan. NATO and Afghan provincial government officials gave somewhat divergent accounts of the episodes. The casualties took place in eastern Paktia Province on Saturday night when the family's home was hit by a bomb, said Rohullah Samoon, a spokesman for the governor of Paktia. Six children were killed, four boys and two girls, as well as their mother and father, whose name was Safiullah.

CONCORD, N.C. -- After Jimmie Johnson won the Southern 500 on May 12 to deliver victory No. 200 to Hendrick Motorsports, he presented the team owner Rick Hendrick with a helmet signed by almost all of the drivers who had won races for the team over nearly 30 years. Kasey Kahne's name was not on that helmet. After joining the powerhouse Hendrick team this season to drive the No. 5 Chevrolet, Kahne had struggled through bad breaks and miscues at the start of the season and had not won a race.

BLANCH--Roselind D. 77, of Naples, FL passed away May 19, 2012 after suffering a stroke. Born in Watervliet, NY on December 11, 1934, she is survived by her sisters, Catherine Herman of New Jersey and Patricia Warrington of Alabama; and her devoted friend, Ina C. Marra of Naples. Roselind retired as Senior Vice President of Sony Music in New York City and had been a resident of Naples since 1998. A special thank you is extended to the Naples Fire Dept. and EMS, Naples Community Hospital, and Avow Hospice. Services will be private. For online condolences, visit: fullerfuneralhome.com.

Here are a few of the ways that Ronald P. Stewart, co-founder and headmaster of the York Preparatory School, thinks his school is different from other New York City private schools: It has no board of directors (''why would I hire someone who could fire me?''). It accepts more than half the students who apply (''we do not seek to be the most exclusive school in Manhattan''). And after York takes $36,000 or more from parents each year, Mr. Stewart has no qualms about telling them to back off. ''The student is our client,'' he says.

Dr. Katherine Morgan Small and Dr. Daniel Billy Sims were married Friday at Eleven Madison Park, a New York restaurant. Rabbi Richard Levy officiated. The couple met at Yale University, from which they graduated, the bridegroom magna cum laude.
International PERU FORCED TO CONFRONT

The ''Getting Started'' article last Sunday, about income-restricted apartments in New York City, described incorrectly the partnerships that created 1,767 units of affordable housing in the city since 2003. Those units were financed with the help of only the city's Housing Development Corporation, not all city agencies.

What stands out in the American poster for this girls-school splatter movie is the promise of a high body count. Mr. Kerswell said the trope of people being trapped and killed one by one -- something fans of Christie murder mysteries would also recognize -- would be picked up by later films like ''Friday the 13th'' and ''My Bloody Valentine.'' The image of sharp glass dripping with blood suggests the villain is not your grandmother's monster. This poster is an example of how the taboo against depicting violence in advertising changed as the 1960s came to an end.

WASHINGTON -- When Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton met Pakistan's president at the NATO summit meeting in Chicago last week, the two spent most of the meeting talking politics, and Mrs. Clinton was nothing if not blunt. President Asif Ali Zardari complained about the difficulties of unifying Pakistan's fractious political parties to support a more aggressive campaign against extremists and noted it was an election year in both countries.

The International Contemporary Ensemble has contributed handsomely to the Miller Theater's Composer Portraits series over the years, and when the theater turned its spotlight on Georges Aperghis on Thursday evening the group was on hand to do the honors. The performance had something of a guest star, as well. Ludovic Morlot, the recently appointed music director of the Seattle Symphony, conducted the ensemble in two chamber orchestra works. Mr. Aperghis, who was born in Athens in 1945 and has lived in France since he was 17, was a student of another Greek expatriate in France, Iannis Xenakis. You can hear Xenakis's influence in Mr. Aperghis's often dense, biting harmonic language, but Mr. Aperghis has moved into a world of his own, with abstract theater pieces and chamber works pulling him in different directions.

Burden, New York's City Planning Department director, misidentified, in some editions, the official who appointed her to the City Planning Commission in 1990. It was Andrew Stein, then the City Council president -- not Mayor David N. Dinkins.
Roasting deepens the appeal of all sorts of vegetables, adding a rich dimension to these light but satisfying baked pasta dishes.
The number of people out of work more than six months has declined a little, but it remains far higher than it was before the recession.
VHS tapes have long been declared dead. But in New York City’s immigrant communities, from South Asian to Senegalese, those chunky workhorses of the past still endure.
A view of the day in sports, including the many chapeaux at the French Open.

While I was asking people to describe the hardest shot in golf, several top golf teachers instead wanted to talk about the shot that recreational golfers misplay most often, which is not the same thing, even if it is related. There was no consensus on the subject, but one shot came up repeatedly as the most misplayed: the wedge shot from 50 to 80 yards.

The signs dotting the parking lot outside the Owens Corning headquarters in Toledo, Ohio, make the company's new policy clear: ''No cell phone while driving.'' In the wake of the National Transportation Safety Board recommendation last December that states and the District of Columbia ban the use of cellphones while driving, the company decided to adopt a similar ban: no employees may use their cellphones for business calls when they are driving. The policy took full effect on March 31.

To the Editor: Re ''The Claim: Never Brush Your Teeth Immediately After a Meal'' (Really?, May 22): It is questionable that reliable claims about dentin loss could be made in a study of such limited duration, but the conclusion that teeth should be brushed before eating can be defended.
GOD'S HOTEL A Doctor, a Hospital and a Pilgrimage to the Heart of Medicine.

Nineteen people, including 13 children, died Monday in a fire that raged through an upscale shopping mall in Doha, Qatar's Interior Ministry said. The fire started late in the morning and centered on a children's play area in the Villaggio Mall, a glittering collection of shops and indoor canals in Doha, the capital, frequented by expatriates in the oil-rich emirate. The ministry did not immediately provide the nationalities of those killed. Local news reports said no Qatari children were among the dead, and Reuters said four of the children who died in the fire were from Spain. French media reported that one French child died in the fire.

ATLANTIC CITY -- Beyoncé gave birth to her daughter, Blue Ivy Carter, on Jan. 7, and is now between albums and tours. From a distance, her four-night run of shows through Monday at Revel, on the Boardwalk here, seemed to be functioning as an advertisement for the grand opening of a $2.4 billion casino, hotel, and luxury-shopping cosmos. It was a little unclear what she was going to do for her first post-maternal gig. She didn't hit the stage until 10 p.m. on Friday, after the unannounced opening act, Luke James, a young R&B singer with a gym build and a pretty falsetto. The signals from anmade in the rehearsal period before her gigs had been mixed. In it, her chorcoseographer Frank Gatson Jr. tells the camera: ''I think this show has the potential of being probably one of the greatest shows we've done.'' Beyoncé herself seems more realistic. ''I don't want to have to disappear from the stage too many times,'' she tells her crew during a meeting. So: a reduced, low-concept show, to break slowly into shape again?

A hit song is not born but made. No matter how clever the lyrics, no matter how catchy the tune, no song climbs the charts on its own. To become a hit -- or to have even a chance of becoming one -- a fledgling pop song needs a behind-the-scenes campaign as tireless and well choreographed as any military offensive. That is where music publishers like Howie Richmond came in. Mr. Richmond, who died on May 20 at 94 at his home in Rancho Mirage, Calif., was among the last of a Runyonesque breed that was long a vital if largely unheralded segment of the music business.

Infants are constantly trying to make sense of the world around them, and they do this by seeking out situations that are neither too simple nor too complex. Writing in the journal PLoS One, a team of researchers from the University of Rochester call it the ''Goldilocks effect.''

As if the inside story of our planet weren't already the ultimate potboiler, a host of new findings has just turned the heat up past Stygian. Geologists have long known that Earth's core, some 1,800 miles beneath our feet, is a dense, chemically doped ball of iron roughly the size of Mars and every bit as alien. It's a place where pressures bear down with the weight of 3.5 million atmospheres, like 3.5 million skies falling at once on your head, and where temperatures reach 10,000 degrees Fahrenheit -- as hot as the surface of the Sun. It's a place where the term ''ironclad agreement'' has no meaning, since iron can't even agree with itself on what form to take. It's a fluid, it's a solid, it's twisting and spiraling like liquid confetti.

Those who have misplaced personal belongings on the streets of New York know this: The city does not care if you need your keys or wallet back. But one recent weekend, I discovered there are instances when she takes pity.

CIUDAD JUÁREZ, Mexico -- Every time Erica González put the video goggles on, the details of her four days in captivity came rushing back to her. She could smell the sweaty T-shirt used to cover her head, taste the ash in the beer bottles that she was made to drink water from and hear her abductors' muffled conversations. ''It was scary to go through it again,'' Ms. González said, ''but I said, 'It's good for me.' ''

SEAMAN--Alfred J.,passed away in his home in Oyster Bay, LI on May 26, 2012, three and a half months shy of his 100th birthday. Born in Hempstead, NY on September 17, 1912, he graduated from Columbia University, served in World War II on both the Atlantic and Pacific fronts as an aircraft carrier CIC officer and became one of the leading figures in the post-war advertising industry. At the time of his retirement in 1981, he was chairman and CEO of S, S, C & B (later Lintas Amirati Puris) and was a key figure in his agency's joining The Interpublic Group of Companies. He had served as chairman of the 4As, was elected in 1983 to the Advertising Hall of Fame and was the founding chairman of the Advertising Education Foundation. In 1987, he was awarded an honorary doctorate by Long Island University's C. W. Post College. As mayor of the Village of Upper Brookville from 1966 to '98, he was the longest serving elected official in New York State. He was predeceased by his first wife and the mother of his four children, Mary Margaret Seaman, and by his second wife, Honor Mellor Seaman. He is survived by three daughters: Marilyn S. Hollingsworth and Susan and Debbie Seaman; and a son, A. Barrett Seaman, as well as three step-children, eight grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. A Funeral Service at St. John's of Lattingtown will be held 4pm Wednesday, May 30. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Samuel Waxman Cancer Research Foundation 420 Lexington Ave. Suite 825 New York, NY 10170 or visit: www.waxmancancer.org would be appreciated.

Can a software company build its own smartphone? We may find out soon. This past week, Google completed its acquisition of the hardware maker Motorola Mobility for $12.5 billion, which could lead to the search giant's making its own smartphone. But another software titan might be getting into the hardware game as well: Facebook.

Can a laundry detergent laced with sunscreen turn your clothes into protection from harmful ultraviolet rays? How about a shampoo that claims to do the same? As another hot summer looms, consumers are once again stocking up on products that promise scientifically formulated sun protection. Only now, amid a steady drumbeat of bad-news stories about global warming, manufacturers are upping the ante with whole new categories of chemically treated products that purport to block ultraviolet light. The products range from clothing and shoes to makeup and umbrellas. There are even sunscreen bikinis that pledge to shield those patches of skin that they actually cover.

MADRID -- Spain's borrowing costs approached record highs on Monday as investors fretted over how the government would find additional money to bail out Bankia, the country's largest mortgage lender, and other troubled banks. Shares in Bankia plunged almost 30 percent early Monday before recovering somewhat, closing down 13.4 percent. Trading had been suspended Friday before the bank's board called for an additional 19 billion euros, or almost $24 billion, of government money after reviewing the latest losses.

WASHINGTON -- For years, Charles B. Rangel was among the Democratic Party's most generous colleagues, crisscrossing the country to raise vast sums of money for other House candidates at election time. Now, as Mr. Rangel faces one of the toughest races of his career, he is among the party's neediest. With campaign contributions to Mr. Rangel, the Harlem congressman since 1971, dropping precipitously -- he barely broke $60,000 over the last three months -- his political fate has become a source of concern for colleagues in Washington who are suddenly opening their wallets for him.

BEIJING -- One of China's largest hosts of Twitter-like microblogs decreed new punishments on Monday for users who post comments that its editors -- and by extension, China's government censors -- deem inappropriate. The service, Sina Weibo, imposed ''user contracts'' that award each of its 300 million microbloggers a starting score of 80 points.
BASS--Edwin L.,dearest father, father-in-law and poppy, the sweetest memories of having your love and wisdom in our lives will endure forever. Our hearts are broken. Karel, Frank, Alix & Danielle

To the Editor: ''Physics Dreams Deferred'' (May 22) rightly describes the loss of the United States' competitive edge in fundamental physics and astronomy research. But it is misleading to say, vis a vis dark energy, that ''for at least the next decade, Americans will be relegated to a minor role in following up their own discovery'' of cosmic acceleration. Later this year, the United States starts pushing the boundaries of our understanding of dark energy, using a new, state-of-the-art camera on a United States telescope in Chile.

I grew up in the New York City so often invoked as the horror to which we might return if the police stopped illegally frisking hundreds of thousands of black and Latino men. There were many things that I loved about life on the Upper West Side in the 1970s, but crime was not among them. As a kid I had the requisite five bikes stolen, one at knife point. My friends and I held tight to stacks of books as we sprinted to the public library on the risky territory of 81st Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Roaming gangs periodically disrupted our baseball games in Riverside Park, causing us to scamper up the hill.

The airwaves are already filled with blaring political attacks masquerading as ''issue ads,'' such as the one in Missouri in the United States Senate race that ends with: ''Call Claire McCaskill. Tell her Missouri doesn't need government-run health care.'' This ad, and dozens like it, is sponsored by the United States Chamber of Commerce, which likes to claim that it is merely educating voters about the issues rather than telling them how to vote. A few weeks ago, though, a federal judge issued a decision that upended this system, requiring that the donors for these kinds of ads be publicly disclosed, as Congress intended in its 2002 campaign finance law, before the Federal Election Commission incorrectly changed the rules.

ROISEN--Jacques, passed away on Saturday, May 26th, 2012 at the age of 91. For a man to whom family meant everything, he is survived by the love of his life, his wife of 67 years, Alice. He also leaves behind his loving children Shelley and Rita, his son-in-law Sheldon whom he loved as a son, his cherished grandchildren Michele and Steven and their spouses Steve and Allison, and his twin grandchildren, Lola and Brody. Born in Antwerp, Belgium, he fled to the U.S. during World War II, served in the U.S. Army, married his childhood sweetheart Alice, and began a life of boundless dedication and commitment to family, philanthropy and his profession. He was a natural leader with a magnetic personality, a man of wisdom with a generosity of spirit and the highest level of integrity, a man who knew how to live and love fully -- an outstanding role model for life's journey. He has been an inspiration to all of us and he will be in our hearts forever. Funeral services will be held on Tuesday, May 29th at 12 noon at the Riverside Chapel, 76th and Amsterdam Avenue, New York City. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to UJA-Federation or ORT America.

MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. -- At 7:22:07 p.m. on a recent Thursday, an electronic alarm went off in the soundproof control room of a suburban office building here. A technician quickly focused on the computer screen, where the words ''multiple gunshots'' appeared in large type. She listened to a recording of the shots -- the tat-tat-tat-tat-tat of five rounds from a small-caliber weapon -- and zoomed in on a satellite map to see where the gun had been fired: North 23rd Street in Milwaukee, 2,200 miles away.

Not many of us get to play with a caddie, which is too bad because it is a great, productive pleasure - the confluence of two trying to master a golf course together. Can modern technology somehow replicate the caddie experience? No, it cannot. Can it do more than maybe you suspected? You bet.
