An article on Wednesday about the use of natural gas instead of coal as fuel for power plants misstated the amount of coal burned each day at the Big Sandy plant in Kentucky. It is about 90 rail carloads, not nine.

GEORGE--Sally. May 31, 1991. Dearest Aunt Sally, You are in my heart forever and in my thoughts everyday. I will never get over losing you. How lucky I was to have you by my side. Love Always, Catherine

Summer camp was a foreign concept where I grew up. I never went, and neither did anyone I knew. But after decades on the East Coast, surrounded by people for whom camp was an annual ritual, I've started to feel as if I missed out. Every former camper I know extols benefits that stretch beyond learning to shoot arrows. In recent posts to Motherlode, Dan Fleshler describes his daughter's decision to spend a final summer as a camp counselor, a job she convinces him is more ''real'' than any internship. Michael Thompson, author of ''Homesick and Happy,'' wrote ''Why Camp Counselors Make the Best Parents.'' If he's right, Dan Fleshler's daughter and her compatriots learned something parents can't teach.

Because of an editing error, a report in the ''Arts, Briefly'' column on Wednesday about a gift of artworks to the Tate in London misidentified the Lucian Freud work that is part of the gift and also misidentified the bust shown in a picture with the report. The Tate received a Freud painting, ''Girl in a Striped Nightdress, or Celia,'' not a bust. The bust, also included in the gift, is a depiction of Freud by Jacob Epstein; not a bust of Epstein by Freud.

LONDON -- Two of the world's best-known banking families are combining forces after RIT Capital Partners, the investment trust led by Jacob Rothschild, said on Wednesday that it was buying a minority stake in the investment and wealth management firm Rockefeller Financial Services. Under the deal, RIT Capital will buy a 37 percent stake in Rockefeller Financial Services, a firm founded in 1882 that now handles about $34 billion in client assets.

KROSNICK--Arthur 88, passed away on May 23, 2012. He was born in Trenton New Jersey, the youngest of eight children of Latvian Immigrants. After public primary education he attended Temple University. With his three older brothers, Dr. Krosnick enlisted in the Armed forces at the onset of WWII. He attended Officer's training at Tufts University to join the Navy as an Ensign in the Pacific Theatre on the ATA Burleson. He assisted in the liberation of Hong Kong and, at the end of the war, the atomic bomb testing in the Bikini Atoll. He married college classmate Evelyn Rieber of Philadelphia PA, at the end of the war and returned to Philadelphia to attend Temple University School of Medicine from which he graduated in 1951. Following Residency in internal medicine and diabetes at Graduate Hospital he opened a practice in Trenton, New Jersey. He was elected Fellow of the American College of Physicians. Dr. Krosnick was instrumental in research proving the efficacy of combination long and short acting animal derived insulin and later, biosynthetic human insulin. His fine medical writing earned him editorial-ship of the New Jersey Medical Journal, Diabetes Forecast Magazine and Acta Pharmaceutica. He received numerous accolades and awards including a lifetime achievement award from the American Diabetes Association. Dr. Krosnick retired from medical practice at the age of 81 and moved to Scottsdale Arizona with his wife to enjoy retirement in the southwest. He was preceded in death by his parents, Samuel and Rose Krosnick of Trenton, New Jersey and his seven siblings. He is survived by his wife, Evelyn R. Krosnick, 87 of Scottsdale Arizona, his son, Jon Krosnick, of Palo Alto California and daughter, Jody Rodgers of Holts Summit, Missouri. He has four grandchildren. Condolences may be sent to Evelyn Krosnick of Scottsdale. Memorials may be made to the American Diabetes Association.

Mrs. Ludlow treated all with dignity and respect and always enjoyed sharing a glass of champagne with her guests at the end of an evening. Mrs Ludlow was predeceased by her husbands Berthold Hahnebach and John Ludlow. She is survived by her daughter Daisy Hahnebach of New York City and a son, William Hahnebach of Verona NJ, her three granddaughters, Carla Egbert, Lisa Nevins, Christina Shannon and seven great-grandchildren. A private service will be held at Greenwood Cemetery, New York at a later date. A Memorial Service will be held at the Presbyterian Church of Upper Montclair on Thursday, June 14th at 11:00 in the morning. In memory of Louise Hahnebach Ludlow, memorial donations may be made to Van Vleck Gardens, 21 Van Vleck St., Montclair, NJ. For online condolences please visit: www.moriartyfuneralhome. com

Doc Watson, who died on Tuesday at the age of 89, was the first truly great guitar player I ever saw up close. For me growing up in Santa Monica, Calif., in the 1950s meant that great musicians were only manifested on records and radio, making it hard to catch a glimpse of the person behind the layers of sound and presentation. You knew people like Hank Snow and Merle Travis were great, but you couldn't be sure how much the Nudie suits and custom boots had contributed to the sound you heard on KXLA radio. Then Doc and the banjo player Clarence Ashley and some of the boys drove out to Los Angeles for the first U.C.L.A. Folk Festival in 1963. On the lawn by Royce Hall, the gothic classical music site, they gathered around and sang ''Daniel Prayed,'' an intricate call-and-response-style gospel tune. People were here and there, wandering around aimlessly, as they do at these events. It was casual and unannounced. We hadn't entered into the hyperorganized way of music appreciation just yet. That came later with the big rock shows.

LEVINE--Ellen. Scholastic mourns the passing of award-winning author Ellen Levine, who died on May 26 at age 73. Her brilliant books for young readers focused on important social issues and historical periods and were made more compelling by her rigorous research and devotion to accuracy. Titles like Henry's Freedom Box (Caldecott Honor), about slavery, Darkness Over Denmark, about the Holocaust, A Fence Away From Freedom, about Japanese American internment, Freedom's Children, about young black civil rights activists, and I Hate English, about a Chinese girl struggling to learn English, will be read by children for generations to come. We extend our deepest sympathies to her spouse and partner, Anne Koedt, and all her family. Richard Robinson Chairman, President, CEO

The producers and investors in the Broadway musical ''Leap of Faith'' lost more than $14 million when the show closed on May 13 after receiving terrible reviews from critics. Usually the only thing left would be the tax write-offs. But even as the biggest flop of the season, ''Leap of Faith'' had an unusual asterisk - its single Tony Award nomination, a major one, for best musical. And so the producers had a decision to make: Whether to leave ''Leap of Faith'' dead and buried, or capitalize on the nomination and pay to stage a musical number on the Tony Awards telecast on CBS on June 10? The producers opted to go for it, and have raised roughly $150,000 to secure a spot for the number at the Tonys ceremony, according to two Broadway industry executives familiar with the plans; they divulged the information on condition of anonymity to preserve their relationships with the ''Leap'' producers, who declined to comment. But a spokeswoman for the producers said that they had raised enough money to stage the number, though she declined to confirm the amount.

(CUNY) MOZART IN SALZBURG The conductor and pianist Daniel Barenboim and the violinist Gil Shaham help chronicle the early years of Mozart amid the political and historical circumstances of mid-18th-century Austria. The film also explores how Mozart dealt with authority and Roman Catholic norms, and why he fled to Vienna at 25.

The Paris Review, which celebrated its 200th issue in April, has been called ''the biggest little magazine in history.'' Now a long article at Salon adds another epithet: ''a covert international weapon of soft power.'' The article, by Joel Whitney, details The Paris Review's indirect connections to the Central Intelligence Agency, rumors of which had circulated for decades but gained new steam a few years ago when the novelist Peter Matthiessen acknowledged that in 1953 -- the year he founded the magazine with George Plimpton, Harold L. Humes and others -- he was working for the C.I.A.

South Carolina legislators voted Wednesday to reopen an ethics investigation into whether Gov. Nikki Haley, right, illegally lobbied fellow politicians while she was a state representative. Ms. Haley, a high-profile Republican and a vocal supporter of Mitt Romney's presidential campaign who has been discussed as a potential vice-presidential candidate, has denied any wrongdoing.

An article last Thursday about Crafting Design, an event at which discarded chairs were refurbished, misstated the location of Partners & Spade, the storefront and studio in Manhattan where the event took place. It is on Great Jones Street, not on Bond Street.

President Obama telephoned Mitt Romney on Wednesday to congratulate him on securing the Republican presidential nomination, and told Mr. Romney that he looked forward ''to an important and healthy debate about America's future,'' a spokesman for the Obama campaign, Ben LaBolt, said. The president, Mr. LaBolt said in a statement, ''wished Governor Romney and his family well throughout the upcoming campaign.'' That may be the gentlest thing Mr. Obama says about Mr. Romney for the foreseeable future, as both candidates settle into a steady streams of attacks on each other in an increasingly rancorous campaign.

6:53 p.m. | Updated The Fox News Channel came under withering criticism on Wednesday for a four-minute video broadcast on its morning show ''Fox & Friends'' that portrayed President Obama's tenure as a series of failed promises. The video had most of the hallmarks of a campaign attack ad, except that it was produced and paid for by a news network rather than a candidate or a political action committee.

An article last Thursday about crafts experts at the International Contemporary Furniture Fair in New York misidentified Andrew Mau's position at Studio Dunn, a furniture company in Providence, R.I. And an accompanying picture caption referred incorrectly to a highboy designed by Richard Watson. The highboy is nameless; it is not a ''Piazza highboy.'' (The photographer who took the picture of the highboy is Michael Piazza.)

In the days since the highly anticipated opening of Facebook turned into a flop last week, the impact has become worse as would-be issuers have taken a second look at what they're getting into. Want an alternative way to jump back to the main screen of the iPad without fumbling around for the Home button? The ''multitasking gestures'' feature, new with last year's iOS 5 update, lets you use movements from all four fingers on the screen to replicate certain functions normally performed by clicking the Home button once or twice. To use the multitasking gestures, first make sure the feature is activated. Tap the Settings icon on the iPad home screen, select the General category and make sure Multitasking Gestures is set to On.

American Electric Powerconceded defeat on Wednesday, at least temporarily, in its push to save Big Sandy, its 49-year-old coal-burning plant in eastern Kentucky, surprising state officials there by withdrawing its $1 billion plan to retrofit the power plant so that it can meet tough new federal environmental regulations. AEP, as the Ohio-based company is known, did not formally declare that it was retiring Big Sandy. But it will now need to at least temporarily shut it down because it will not have enough time to install the required pollution controls before the first deadline it faces in 2015, a company official acknowledged.

LOS ANGELES - The new movie museum planned by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences has its architects. Renzo Piano, whose work includes the recent expansion of the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, and Zoltan Pali, who has helped restore the Greek Theater and other buildings here, will join in building the film museum. The institution will be located in the old May Company department store next to Lacma. Under an earlier plan, the French architect Christian de Portzamparc was to have designed the museum, on Academy-owned land in Hollywood. But that plan collapsed as the economy softened in 2008 and was eventually replaced by current one, which calls for renovation of the 325,000-square-foot store space now known as Lacma West, rather than new construction. Mr. Piano, who won the Pritzker Prize for architecture in 1998, has designed a number of museums, including the Modern Wing of the Art Institute of Chicago, as well as the building in which The New York Times is headquartered.

''Battleship'' may be sinking at the box office, but you can still put on your captain's hat and duel with alien warships at sea with a movie-inspired version of the Battleship iPhone app from Electronic Arts. The movie version has been updated to include alien ships that are deployed on one-half of the digital board, which looks similar to the physical board game from Hasbro. The alien crafts also show up in the cut-away scenes that appear when a ship is hit or sunk, adding an extra bit of flair to the game. And best of all, the updated app is free.

Michael J. O'Neill, a former editor of The Daily News in New York who directed its breathless coverage of the ''Son of Sam'' serial killer, then became a strong national voice for responsible media behavior, died on Tuesday at his home in Scarsdale, N.Y. He was 89. The cause was complications of pulmonary fibrosis, his family said.

The Books of The Times review on Friday, about various books for summer reading, including ''Turing's Cathedral'' by George Dyson, misstated part of the name of the institute in Princeton, N.J., where Mr. Dyson's father, Freeman Dyson, worked and is now a professor emeritus. It is the Institute for Advanced Study (not Studies).

AUSTIN, Tex. - Representative Silvestre Reyes, a Democrat in his eighth-term who is a former chairman of the House Intelligence Committee, was defeated Tuesday in the Democratic primary by a former El Paso city councilman, Beto O'Rourke. Mr. Reyes becomes the sixth House incumbent to lose a primary battle this year.

An obituary on Monday about the Italian fencer Edoardo Mangiarotti erroneously attributed a distinction to him. It was the American diver Marjorie Gestring -- not Mr. Mangiarotti -- who was the youngest person to win a gold medal at the 1936 Summer Olympics in Berlin. (Ms. Gestring, who won a gold medal in three-meter springboard diving at those Games, was 13 years 9 months old at the time -- about three and a half years younger than Mr. Mangiarotti.)

APPLEBY--William Richard, Jr. Died on May 25, 2012 at age 66. Predeceased by parents Gerda and Bill, brother to John and Peter and wife Stephanie. Uncle to Kyra, David, and Gabriel. Dearest cousin to Joan M. Greene as well as Marko, David, Karina, Julie, Richard, Lilli, Michael, and Tom. Richard graduated from Harvard University in 1967, and NYU Law School in 1971. He was a successful attorney and accomplished tennis player. Taken from us much too soon. Burial will take place on Friday, June 1st at 10:00am at Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, New York. Services being handled by Gallagher & Sons, Stamford, CT.

An article on Friday about the insider trading trial of Rajat K. Gupta, a former Goldman Sachs director, misstated in some editions the date of the commencement at Brown University, from which Mr. Gupta's daughter graduated. It was on Sunday, not on Thursday.

MIAMI -- They watched Rajon Rondo whirl through them like a blender, witnessed a Ray Allen renaissance and felt the full force of the Boston Celtics' survival reflex. For three stressful, strenuous hours Wednesday, the Miami Heat lived the mantra coined by their slogan-happy coach: ''Embrace the difficult.'' The Heat embraced it, cradled it and finally crushed it, and perhaps put a crimp in the Celtics' spirit, with an exhilarating, exhausting 115-111 overtime victory in Game 2 of the Eastern Conference finals. Miami came within minutes of losing home-court advantage in the series but instead took a 2-0 advantage after a late push from LeBron James and Dwyane Wade.

A picture credit on Wednesday with an article about a Chinese maker of electric cars misspelled the surname of the photographer in some copies. Colin Beere, not Beer, took the photograph of a BYD e6 electric car having its batteries recharged.

Arborists and tree-care experts say that New York City could significantly improve public safety by ensuring that the workers who evaluate trees understand the warning signs of decay and failure. With 2.5 million trees in its care, the city has a daunting task: both to preserve the green canopy that cools parks and streets, and to protect the public that passes under it. For street trees, the city generally relies on outside contractors, while for trees in parks, it dispatches in-house forestry crews. In recent years, budgets for both have shrunk.

Because of an editing error, an obituary on May 19 about the interior designer Barbara D'Arcy White misstated the name of one of the styles she was credited with popularizing. It is Country French, not Country Fresh.

MORAN--Marjory R.,on May 24, 2012. Beloved wife of late Gerard R. Moran, loving mother of Michael T. Wyman, Nicholas A. Wyman, James H. Wyman, and Meredith Gatschet, and devoted grandmother of seven. Services Friday 10:30am at John Knox Village Auditorium, 651 Village Dr., Pompano Beach FL. Visitation Thursday 4-7pm at Kraeer Funeral Home, 200 N. Federal Highway., Pompano Beach, FL.

The family of Dwight D. Eisenhower on Wednesday said it welcomed some aspects of a modified design for a memorial to honor the former president on the National Mall, but still has reservations about other components. The architect Frank Gehry changed the design in response to concerns raised by the family and others. The family had primarily objected to Mr. Gehry's sculptural depiction of Eisenhower as a young man, a characterization inspired by a speech the returning general made upon his return from World War II in which he recalled his days as a ''barefoot boy.'' But the family said the focus on youth had diminished Eisenhower's other accomplishments.

GoPro, makers of the wearable Hero cameras commonly used to film skiing, surfing and racing, has added a new underwater housing to its lineup. Now GoPro owners already know that the camera comes with a waterproof housing, so why did they add a new one? Because the standard housing has a lens that increases the wide-angle view of the camera's own wide-angle lens. That is fine on land or in the air, but a problem at sea because water has its own optical properties.

Broadway musicals and plays had another record-setting season at the box office, grossing a total of $1.139 billion from 40 new productions and other long-running shows during the 2011-12 theater season, according to data released by the Broadway League on Tuesday. Audience attendance was 12.33 million, roughly the same as in the 2010-11 season, according to the League, a trade association of theater owners and producers. Revenues increased at a faster rate than theater-going because several Broadway producers have raised the prices of so-called premium tickets, which includes seats in the best location and those that are sold at the last minute; some producers have also increased the number of premium tickets.

SALISBURY--Charlotte Young, 98, died quietly in Salisbury, CT on April 25. She was the widow of Harrison E. Salisbury. Born in Boston, she became a Powers model, mother, passionate gardener and author. During the often harrowing treks around Asia with her husband, she kept diaries which were published and enthusiastically received. Mrs. Salisbury is survived by three of her four children: Ellen Rand, Rosina Rand, and Curtis Rand, and two stepsons: Michael Salisbury, and Stephan Salisbury, 14 grandchildren and five great- grandchildren. Her first child, Charlotte Boyer Parkinson died in 2007. A memorial celebration of her life is planned for June 30, in Salisbury, Ct. For information call 718-782-2541.

The first courtroom arguments will take place in Manhattan on Friday in the legal battle between the Broadway producers of ''Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark'' and their former director, Julie Taymor, with three procedural motions before the judge in the case, according to people on both sides. Private settlement talks broke off in late winter, and both camps are now focused on assembling evidence and arguments for a full-blown trial next year when boldface reputations and millions of dollars would be at stake. The ''Spider-Man'' producers - with the backing of Ms. Taymor's onetime allies, Bono and the Edge of U2 - fired her in March 2011 after three months of preview performances of the $75 million show; the firing came after the producers and the two musicians clashed with Ms. Taymor over script and staging changes meant to improve the show. The musical was subsequently overhauled and then opened in June, to negative reviews; it has since gone on to be a box-office hit, grossing about $1.5 million a week.

A new Broadway revival of ''Cat on a Hot Tin Roof'' is in the works for the spring of 2013, with Scarlett Johansson starring as Maggie the Cat and Chris Pine (''Star Trek'') and the Academy Award nominee Jeremy Renner (''The Hurt Locker,'' ''The Town'') among the actors under consideration to play her alcoholic husband, Brick, according to theater executives with knowledge of the project. Ms. Johansson, who won a Tony Award for featured actress in 2010 playing the sheltered niece in ''A View From the Bridge,'' has said publicly that she is negotiating a return to Broadway as Maggie in Tennessee Williams's Pulitzer Prize-winning play from 1955 about the disintegration of a wealthy Southern family. Mr. Renner, who is one of her co-stars in the recent film ''The Avengers,'' has been mentioned by Hollywood media outlets as a possible Brick. But the theater executives with knowledge of the project - who spoke on condition of anonymity because casting is confidential - said that Mr. Pine was now a leading contender to play Brick and that no final decisions on the role had been made.

Cy Twombly spent most of his life outside the high-octane New York art world, working quietly either in his hillside house in Gaeta, south of Rome, or in his home in Lexington, Va. Now, less than a year after his death, the artist, who is best known for canvases filled with childlike scribbles, is poised to have a presence in New York after all, according to a report in The Wall Street Journal. On Tuesday a foundation he set up paid $27.5 million to buy a 25-foot-wide Beaux-Arts mansion at 19 East 82nd Street.

ZARET--Milton M.,M.D., of Rye Brook N.Y., passed away peacefully on May 29 at the age of 91. Pearl Harbor survivor, renowned ophthalmologist, and champion of safeguards against microwave radiation, he is survived by his daughters, Dr. Wendy Snyder and Dr. Dana Luck, sons-in-law Dr. Jon Snyder and Dr. Edward Luck, grandchildren Scott and Susannah Snyder and Jessica Luck, and two great- grandchildren, Jack and Emmett Snyder.

Judging from his recent ''Saturday Night Live'' appearance, Usher already looks plenty busy when he's onstage. But for a concert he will play on June 11 at the Hammersmith Apollo in London, and which will be broadcast live on the Internet, his collaborators say they have devised a way for Usher to be joined in performance by digital dancers created by online viewers. ''Literally, people will be able to create their own avatar and have it dance on the screen with Usher,'' said Hamish Hamilton, who will be directing the concert broadcast.

After rejecting the idea of a sale for months, Research in Motion acknowledged on Tuesday that it was considering ''strategic business model alternatives'' - or in banker's speak, RIM, which makes the BlackBerry, said it was pondering a potential deal for all or parts of the company. But did it wait too long?
WALLACH--Richard W. Hon. 9/16/27-6/1/03 Loved and missed forever and a day by your Marli
ANDERSON--Alvin. Dear Uncle Andy, we will miss you. Love, Dale & Doug

LETVIN--Norman L.,M.D., at 62 years of age, Boston, MA, May 28, 2012. Beloved husband of Marion C. (Stein) Letvin. Devoted father of Andrea Ricka, Rebecca, Adam, and Elizabeth. Beloved son of Esther and the late Albert Letvin. Dear brother of David and of Judith Liebman, and uncle of 14 nieces and nephews. He was Professor of Medicine at Harvard Medical School. He will be sorely missed by his family, friends, colleagues, and students. His qualities as mentor, teacher, physician, researcher, and musician, and his love of family will always be remembered. A private funeral service took place on May 29. A memorial service will be held in the fall. Donations in memory of Dr. Norman L. Letvin may be made to the Interlochen Arts Camp (www. interlochen.org/support) or the Harvard-Radcliffe Orchestra (www.hcs.harvard.edu/hro/).

Perhaps the most amazing thing about Nicklas Lidstrom's career is that his extraordinarily consistent excellence redefined amazing. Who could possibly play 20 seasons in the N.H.L. and do almost nothing wrong? Who could make a grueling game look effortless night after night, leading a Red Wings team that made Stanley Cup contention its default position, without any down seasons or even, as his teammates claim, any bad games? Only Lidstrom.

PARIS - When the American Varvara Lepchenko topped the former world No. 1 Jelena Jankovic, 7-6, 4-6, 6-4, Thursday, she advanced to the third round of the French Open. That was significant. So, too, was the fact that this victory put her ahead of Vania King in the WTA rankings, which was also significant because the top four American women could qualify for the London Games in July. For Olympic purposes, the rankings matter on June 11, the day after the men's singles final at the French Open. The women's singles final is June 9. Serena Williams is ranked highest in the latest version (5), followed by Christina McHale (36), Venus Williams (53) and, when next week's rankings come out, Lepchenko (she is currently 63rd). For women's singles at the Olympics, players must rank in the top 56 and no more than four can come from one country.

The Yankees and the Mets have spent the last 51 baseball seasons being as different as two teams can be. Whereas the Yankees have tradition and more titles than anyone wants them to count, the Mets have often been an exercise in frustration with occasional bouts of miraculous behavior. This year the teams remain opposites. And yet, as the season careers toward the one-third mark, their won-lost records are a half-game apart. It is enough to bring back the debate about whether it is better to be lucky or good.

JORDAN--Horace R. May 29, 1928 - May 24, 2012. Loving Husband, Father, Grandfather, Godfather and great friend to all who knew him. Architect at The Department Of General Services/ NYC for 25 years. Army Veteran. Jazz Aficionado. Faithfully completed The New York Times crossword puzzle daily. He'll be sorely missed.

FURMAN--Eleanor, wife of the late Sylvan Furman, has died at age 99. Mother of Ellen (Karl) Sklar ; stepmother of Emily Furman, Laura Furman (Joel Barna), Hester Furman. Grandmother of Rebecca (Ari) Shalam, Jessica (Jerry) Seinfeld, Elzy (Jeff) Wick, and Solomon Barna; Great-grandmother of 10 spectacular great-grandchildren. She led a life that was rich in friendships, work, varied interests, books, and devotion to family. All was kept in balance by her wonderful sense of humor. Her integrity and commitment to social justice was unending. Role model and mentor to many. Her residences in NYC, and in the Berkshires were warm gathering places for family and a diverse group of friends. A loyal Barnard College alumna, she was proud that her first job as a graduate in the midst of the Depression, was at the New York Times. Her career as an employment specialist led her to found and become Director of the Placement Office at the Fashion Institute of Technology where she spent more than 30 years. She wrote several books,addressing both professional and personal topics. She was a passionate supporter of the arts. She was a risk taker and lived life fully - moped riding, skinny dipping in her cold Berkshire pond , taking college courses through her 80's in previously unexplored subjects. She made everything more fun. She taught us to appreciate the ordinary and the extraordinary. Eleanor, Ellie, Granny, GG-you will continue to be with us. Memorial service to be arranged.
HALLINGBY--Paul Jr. We love you, miss you and forever keep you in our hearts and prayers. Jo and Chloe Jane

SUGRUE--Daniel, on May 30, 2012 of Forest Hills, NY. Devoted husband of Sophia; Loving father to the late John, Daniel (Deirdre), Brendan and Denis. Visiting Fox Funeral Home, Ascan Ave. (Cor. Metropolitan Ave.) Forest Hills, 2-5 and 7-9pm, Thursday and Friday. Funeral Mass, Saturday June 2nd. Interment, Calvary Cemetery, Woodside, NY. Donations in lieu of flowers, to: Disabled American Veterans, P.O Box 14301, Cincinnati, OH, 43250.

10 P.M. (Cooking) THE CULINARY ADVENTURES OF BARON AMBROSIA Some people call Baron Ambrosia, the alter ego of the Bronx filmmaker Justin Fornal (above left, with a chef), ''the Ali G of food,'' a reference to the Sacha Baron Cohen character. He prefers to call himself a ''quaffer of culinary consciousness.'' Along with a camerman, he documents New York's ethnic pockets and their cuisines for his video podcast ''Underbelly NYC'' and his public-access show, ''Bronx Flavor.'' In this new series Mr. Fornal expands his horizons to places like Bridgeport, Conn., where, treasure map in hand, he follows in the footsteps of the showman P. T. Barnum, who was the city's mayor in 1875, and samples Peruvian ceviche, Haitian oxtail and Jamaican jerk chicken along the way. 7:35 A.M. (Cinemax) TOM JONES (1963) Albert Finney stars as an 18th-century English foundling turned Casanova in Tony Richardson's Academy Award-winning adaptation of the classic novel by Henry Fielding. Susannah York is Sophie, the passionate daughter of the blue-blooded Squire Western (Hugh Griffith), and the woman Tom hopes to wed -- through her father has other plans. Writing in The New York Times, Bosley Crowther called the film ''surely one of the wildest, bawdiest and funniest comedies that a refreshingly agile filmmaker has ever brought to the screen.''

LOS ANGELES - Alan F. Horn, a former movie chief at Warner Brothers who was responsible for guiding that studio's highly profitable ''Harry Potter'' franchise, was named chairman of Disney's movie studio on Thursday. Mr. Horn's responsibilities at Walt Disney Studios will extend to the Marvel, Pixar and DreamWorks Studios brands; the job also includes oversight of Disney's music label and Broadway division.

FRANKFURT - Josef Ackermann bowed out Thursday as the chief executive of Deutsche Bank after more than a decade in which he transformed the institution into a global contender but also became a symbol to many Germans of the excesses of capitalism. At the bank's annual meeting, Mr. Ackermann passed his responsibilities to two subordinates who will run the bank in tandem. Anshu Jain, a native of India who has been in charge of Deutsche Bank's investment banking operations, will serve as co-chief executive with Jürgen Fitschen, a German whose title is head of Deutsche Bank regional management.

The Fox News producer behind a provocative four-minute anti-Obama video that aired Wednesday and caused the network considerable embarrassment has found his career on ice. The producer, Chris White, had been offered a job by CNN before the video was broadcast. But on Thursday, a CNN spokeswoman said that the network would not be hiring him.

Hines Ward evidently made a strong impression as a guest analyst on NBC's Super Bowl pregame show. On Thursday, the NBC Sports Group hired Ward, the former Pittsburgh Steelers receiver, for a three-job portfolio. The Steelers released him in late February after a 14-year career that included 1,000 receptions. ''You see a guy you want to listen to,'' said Sam Flood, the executive producer of NBC Sports and NBCSN. ''We know what we're getting with him. He's got a lot of skills. And the reps will help him.''

NIERMAN--Morris, 91, of Chevy Chase, MD, formerly of Flushing, NY, passed away peacefully on May 29, 2012. Predeceased by his wife, Corinne, he is survived by his children Deborah Linzer, Elena (Joel) Widder, and David (Mara) Nierman as well as six grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. Memorial donations may be made to Fun and Fancy Theatre Group, c/o Michael Schwartz, 3210 N. Leisure World Blvd., Apt. 210, Silver Spring, MD 20906.

An article in some editions on Thursday about an effort to urge increased training for workers in New York City who evaluate trees for signs of decay and failure misspelled, in some copies, the surname of the executive director of the advocacy group New Yorkers for Parks. She is Holly M. Leicht, not Leight.

An article on Wednesday about the worsening relationship between American law-enforcement officials and the Mexican Army because of the biggest military corruption case in Mexico in recent years misstated the type of salaries paid to three generals and a lieutenant colonel accused of supplementing their official incomes with drug profits. They receive government -- not civil servant -- salaries.

3:34 p.m. | Updated Elizabeth Warren, the embattled Democratic candidate for Senate in Massachusetts, has said for the first time that she had told Harvard and the University of Pennsylvania law schools that she had Native American ancestry. Ms. Warren, who teaches at Harvard, has been dogged by questions about her ancestry for a month, overshadowing her campaign against Senator Scott P. Brown. When the story first arose last month, she told the Boston Herald that she did not know that Harvard had promoted her as a minority when it was under pressure to diversify its faculty and she has said very little since then.

A filly got loose and almost slammed into I'll Have Another before his gallop at Belmont Park on Thursday morning, nearly putting his Triple Crown bid in jeopardy. I'll Have Another, accompanied by his stable pony, Lava Man, was walking a few feet off the outer rail along the clubhouse turn after the 8:45 a.m. renovation break when Isleta, a 3-year-old maiden filly bred and co-owned by the Steinbrenner family's Kinsman Stable, dumped her rider and ran through the opening between I'll Have Another and the rail.

When you think of the Joe Fresh flagship store -- to the extent that you do -- what comes to mind? Cheery clothing in primary colors as bright as the inside of a crayon box? Bargain-basement prices that put everything on the shelves and racks within fairly easy reach? How about: home of a 70-foot-long, 16-foot-high, 5.25-ton honeycomb of 800 bronze, copper and nickel panels welded together almost 60 years ago by the sculptor Harry Bertoia into a midcentury masterwork that has been called the three-dimensional equivalent of a Jackson Pollock canvas?

KAHN--Ruthe, on May 27, of NY, New York. Beloved wife of the late Philip Kahn. Devoted mother of Melissa, Eric (Kate), and Richard (Mary Jo). Loving grandmother to Meryl, Nicole, Julia, Alec and Kyle. Also survived by sisters Mimi Nitzberg and Estelle Kellner. Contributions in Ruthe's memory may be made to the Alzheimer's Association. There was nothing she could not do.

SEGAL--Ellen Sue, after a very long and courageous battle, early Wednesday morning May 30, 2012, succumbed to the ravages of the treatments she received for Hodgkin's Disease almost 40 years ago. Ellen was 66 years old and lived in New Vernon, NJ with Peter, her loving husband of 46 years. Ellen grew up in Englewood, NJ and, after she was married, lived in South Orange, NJ for 20 years. She also spent time at their homes in Florida and New Hampshire. In addition, she is survived by her adoring children Oliver & Kelly Segal and Leslie & Jordan Klein as well as the loves of her life: grandchildren James, Molly & Morgan Klein and William & Max Segal. Ellen graduated from American University in Washington, DC in 1967 with a BS in Government & Public Administration and also received a Masters in Museum Education from Bank Street School in NYC in the mid 1980's. She taught Math and Social Studies in the Morris Township and Summit Public School Systems in the late 1960's and early 1970's. Additionally, she worked as a teacher's aide at Far Brook School in Short Hills, NJ in the 1980's. Later in the 1980's and 1990's, she worked for Lee Skolnick Architecture + Design Partnership, an architectural firm in NYC, where she specialized in museum education, designing and implementing many exhibits as well as preparing docent manuals. A memorial service will be held this Sunday, June 3rd at 2:00pm at Bernheim Apter Kreitzman on 68 Old Short Hills Road, Livingston, NJ followed by a reception at Peter Segal's home in New Vernon, NJ. In lieu of flowers, food, etc. please consider making a donation in Ellen's memory to The MJ Lacher Lymphoma Foundation, Box 286236, New York City, NY 10128.

LEVINE--Ellen. The Arthur Garfield Hays Civil Liberties Program at NYU School of Law mourns the loss of Ellen Levine, a Fellow in the Program in 1978-1979. Through her wonderful writings and other works, Ellen devoted her life to enhancing the liberty and dignity of all persons. Norman Dorsen Sylvia Law Helen Hershkoff Faculty Directors

O'NEILL--Michael J. The American Irish Historical Society mourns the death of our friend, long time Board Member and Executive Council Officer, and Previous Gold Medalist, Michael J. O'Neill. Kevin M. Cahill, M.D., President-General

The crowd-sourced global diary, a new kind of documentary in which thousands of videos shot around the world at the same time are assembled into a concise chronicle of a day in the life of the planet, is an astonishing technological and organizational achievement. The visual feast it provides is inspiring and breathtaking, introducing audiences to cultures, customs and languages while underscoring humanity's inescapable connectedness. Even so, ''Life in a Day,'' which was released last year and sponsored by YouTube, seemed a bit too scattered. The same problem now bedevils ''One Day on Earth,'' which was partly underwritten by an arm of the United Nations. Founded by Kyle Ruddick in 2008, the project claims to have enlisted filmmakers in every country (192 or so) on Oct. 10, 2010. Yes, 10/10/10.

In America, the British comedian Simon Amstell may not yet have the name recognition of Eddie Izzard or Billy Connolly, but a New York producer who helped break those better-known names in the United States is betting that he'll be the latest stand-up to find success on the opposite side of the Atlantic. On Thursday, the producer Arnold Engelman said that his WestBeth Entertainment company will present Mr. Amstell's new one-man show ''Numb'' at Theater 80 in Manhattan's East Village for a five-week run starting July 10.

I did an awful, awful lot that was wrong. I am responsible. I don't have to go any further than the mirror. It's me and me alone. JOHN EDWARDS,former senator from North Carolina, after a jury acquitted him on one count in his trial on campaign finance charges and a a mistrial was declared on the other counts. [A1]

An article on May 24 about the anger of people on the Mosquito Coast of Honduras over drug trafficking in their area described incorrectly a group known as Masta, whose leader called on American antidrug forces to leave the area and be replaced by those who can help with development. Masta, an acronym that stands for Miskitu Asla Takanka, or Unity of the Miskitu People, is an association of various indigenous communities on the coast. It is not an ethnic group.

JURKA--Dr. Edith M.,December 4, 1915, died May 19 2012. Grad Yale/Smith College. Psychiatry/ Parapsychology. Croton-on-Hudson/NYC. Survived by attending nieces Heidi Jurka, Wendy Pressoir, Clearwater, FL. Sister, Carol Coggeshall, nephew Joss Coggeshall, Maine.

RIMOIN--David L.,MD, PhD. The Board of Trustees, staff, and volunteers of the March of Dimes mourn the passing of our esteemed volunteer David L. Rimoin, MD, PhD. Dr. Rimoin served on numerous scientific committees for our foundation, most recently as a member of the Transdisciplinary Research Advisory Committee. He was a leader and a visionary in the field of medical genetics, and a trusted mentor. He was founding president of both the American College of Medical Genetics and Genomics and the American Board of Medical Genetics. David's dedication and guidance were incalculable to our organization and he will be greatly missed. We extend our deepest condolences to his entire family. Jennifer L. Howse, Ph.D. President

Among the government's hurdles in its insider trading case against Rajat K. Gupta is proving that he benefited from any illegal trades. Mr. Gupta, 63, a former head of the consulting firm McKinsey & Company, did not make any direct profits on the trades in question. He lost money on his investment with the Galleon Group, a hedge fund run by Raj Rajaratnam. Prosecutors say Mr. Gupta provided insider tips to Mr. Rajaratnam, who was convicted by a jury last year.
PALAY--Earl May 12, 1932 - June l, 1982 Remembered with love, always Elizabeth and Gabrielle

A Brooklyn high school teacher accused of having sex with a 16-year-old student surrendered to the police on Thursday, two days after Mayor Michael R. Bloombergcalled on state lawmakers to pass legislation that would give New York City greater power to fire teachers accused of sexual misconduct. The teacher, Erin Sayar, an English teacher at James Madison High School, in the Midwood neighborhood, is accused of having sex with the boy at least eight times in the past school year, according to a report issued by Richard J. Condon, the special commissioner for investigation for the city's schools. The Daily News reported on the case on Thursday.

PARIS -- The United States and the European Union were expected Friday to announce an agreement to recognize each other's air cargo security regimes, putting an end to a costly duplication of security controls on the more than $130 billion in air freight that crosses the Atlantic from Europe each year. Under the terms of the accord, which was to take effect immediately, the U.S. Transportation Security Administration will fully accept a set of E.U. rules that holds all airlines and freight shippers flying cargo and mail into, or transiting via, the Union to a strict set of obligations on the screening of consignments and on the maintenance of a secure supply chain.

An obituary on Thursday about Michael J. O'Neill, a former editor of The Daily News in New York, misspelled, in some editions, the surname of a columnist he hired and later dismissed. He is Michael Daly, not Daley.

A picture caption on Tuesday with a critic's notebook article about the actress Linda Lavin, who has been nominated for a Tony Award for her performance in ''The Lyons,'' and two other nominees who are in roles previously played by Ms. Lavin, misstated the surname of the playwright who wrote ''The Lyons.'' As the article correctly noted, he is Nicky Silver, not Silvers.

Doctoroff, Chair of the Board, John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

The injured Giants receiver Hakeem Nicks delivered some encouraging news Thursday when he told reporters that he planned to rejoin the team next week. Nicks plans to be with the team when it visits the White House on June 8, though the timetable for his return to football activities remains fluid. Nicks is confident, however, that he will be recovered from his broken foot in time to play in the Giants' season-opening game Sept. 5 against the Dallas Cowboys.

After months of searching, WebMD has found a new chief. WebMD, the online health company under pressure from big shareholders to bolster its share price, is naming Cavan M. Redmond, a senior executive at Pfizer, as its chief executive.

Both Mike and Mary Jane have been long-time staunch supporters of Pro Mujer, always giving generously of their time and their talents. Because of an editing error, schedule information on Thursday with a dance review about the Bolshoi Ballet's performance of ''Coppélia,'' at the Kennedy Center in Washington, misstated the dates of the company's performances of ''Swan Lake'' next week in Los Angeles. They are Thursday through Sunday, not Monday through Wednesday. The review misstated the duration of the Bolshoi's North American tour. It is four weeks, not five. And the review referred incorrectly to the company's performances of ''Swan Lake'' in Toronto. They took place two weeks ago, not last week. (Last week it performed ''Don Quixote'' in Ottawa.)

EWEN--Elizabeth Rose Wunderlich. On May 29th Elizabeth Ewen died peacefully at her home in Manhattan, surrounded by family and friends. An influential author, distinguished teacher, brilliant thinker, and long-time activist for social and economic justice, Liz inspired generations of students, teachers and countless others whose lives she touched so profoundly. Her passions and ideas live on in her writings, which continue to be read, and in the knowledge, insight and love she gave to so many across the decades. She leaves behind her soul mate and lifelong collaborator, Stuart Ewen; two sons, Paul Ewen and Sam Ewen; adored grandchildren Stella Ewen-Tanaka and Henry Ewen; daughter-in-law, Gretel Smith, and sisters and brothers-in-law, Phyllis Ewen, Andy Ewen, Jim Campen and Catherine Onsrud. As her physical being slowly waned, her spirit -- she proclaimed from her bed not long ago -- is "here to stay." And it is. Service: Monday, June 4 at 2pm, at "The Riverside" 76th St. and Amsterdam Avenue.

Father of Patricia Mary Dinneen and her husband Dr. John Mooney of Belmont, Barbara Dinneen Sehr and her husband Timothy of Kokomo, Indiana, and Dr. Michael Paul Dinneen and his wife Patricia of Rockville, MD. Gerry is also survived by five grandchildren: Elizabeth, Catherine, Stephen, Andrea, and Jessica, and by many nieces and nephews and by his brother, David Dinneen and two sisters-in-law, Joan Davenport and Joan Dinneen. WWII Army Air Corps Veteran; Director of MIT Lincoln Laboratory, Professor of Electrical Engineering at MIT, Assistant Secretary of Defense under President Jimmy Carter, Chief Scientist Honeywell, Foreign Secretary National Academy of Engineering, Fellow of Royal Academy of Engineering, Ph.D. University of Wisconsin, B.A. Queens College. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated Saturday June 9 at St. Peter Church, 100 Concord Ave. in Cambridge at 10am. Relatives and friends are cordially invited to attend. Visiting hours will be held Friday June 8 at the Douglass Funeral Home, 51 Worthen Rd. Lexington from 4pm to 8pm. Donations in his memory may be made to Catholic Relief Services, P.O. Box 17090, Baltimore, MD 21203. Interment St. Bernard Cemetery, Concord.

Madeline Miller, an American debut novelist, won the Orange Prize on Wednesday for her book, ''The Song of Achilles,'' a lyrical retelling of ''The Iliad'' that was published by Bloomsbury in Britain and Ecco, an imprint of HarperCollins, in the United States. The Orange Prize is given annually to a novel written by a woman in English. It is accompanied by an award of £30,000, or about $46,600.

The electric light was a failure. Invented by the British chemist Humphry Davy in the early 1800s, it spent nearly 80 years being passed from one initially hopeful researcher to another, like some not-quite-housebroken puppy. In 1879, Thomas Edison finally figured out how to make an incandescent light bulb that people would buy. But that didn't mean the technology immediately became successful. It took another 40 years, into the 1920s, for electric utilities to become stable, profitable businesses. And even then, success happened only because the utilities created other reasons to consume electricity. They invented the electric toaster and the electric curling iron and found lots of uses for electric motors. They built Coney Island. They installed electric streetcar lines in any place large enough to call itself a town. All of this, these frivolous gadgets and pleasurable diversions, gave us the light bulb.
Richard Ruble Siloam Springs, Ark.

Memorial services will be held 11am Friday, June 1, 2012 at St. William Catholic Church, St. Simons Island, GA with Msgr. John Kenneally officiating. Jimmy was best friend and cherished husband of Gail Palmer (Smith) for 60 years. He is also survived by his five children Christine Hart (Michio Soga), Patricia Papa (the late Edward), James F. Nick, III, Deborah Meyer (Robert), Stephen M. (Margaret) and his 14 grandchildren, Jason Hart, Sara Hart (Maxime Turgeon), Brendan Hart, Michelle Papa, Margaret Papa, Elizabeth Simons (Andrew), Kathleen Papa, James F. Nick, IV, Megan Meyer, Annie Oneal (Kevin), Christine Meyer, Eileen Meyer, Stephen M. Nick, Jr., and Amanda Nick. Jimmy was a loving husband, father, father-in-law and grandfather. He was a graduate of Fordham University (1951) and was a 50-year member of the New York Stock Exchange at J. F. Nick & Co. He was a member of St. William Parish, Nassau Country Club, The Sea Island Club and was a 65-year member of the New York Athletic Club. Jimmy was a lifelong and avid fan of the New York Giants and Boston Red Sox. He was a ranked squash player and fine golfer. He will be missed by many dear and loving friends, both near and far. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to St. William Parish, 2300 Frederica Road, St. Simons Island, GA 31522, or the American Cancer Society. Edo Miller and Sons Funeral Home is in charge of services. www.edomillerandsons.com

WITNESS SEAT Jamie Dimon, below, the JPMorgan Chase chief executive, is scheduled to testify twice this month before both the House and the Senate. After days of discussions, Mr. Dimon agreed to testify before the Senate Banking Committee on June 13. Mr. Dimon, who will face questions about his bank's recent multibillion-dollar trading loss, is also set to appear before a House panel on June 19, according to people briefed on the matter. Among the people who reached out to congratulate Johan Santana, the Venezuelan left-hander who had just thrown a the first no-hitter in Mets history Friday night, was Hugo Chavez, the Venezuelan president who is a huge baseball fan.
Jenna Wortham, a technology reporter, introduces new applications that have the potential to offer the private experience missing from Facebook and Twitter.

SEGAL--Ellen Sue, after a very long and courageous battle, early Wednesday morning May 30, 2012, succumbed to the ravages of the treatments she received for Hodgkin's Disease almost 40 years ago. Ellen was 66 years old and lived in New Vernon, NJ with Peter, her loving husband of 46 years. Ellen grew up in Englewood, NJ and, after she was married, lived in South Orange, NJ for 20 years. She also spent time at their homes in Florida and New Hampshire. In addition, she is survived by her adoring children Oliver & Kelly Segal and Leslie & Jordan Klein as well as the loves of her life: grandchildren James, Molly & Morgan Klein and William & Max Segal. Ellen graduated from American University in Washington, DC in 1967 with a BS in Government & Public Administration and also received a Masters in Museum Education from Bank Street School in NYC in the mid 1980's. She taught Math and Social Studies in the Morris Township and Summit Public School Systems in the late 1960's and early 1970's. Additionally, she worked as a teacher's aide at Far Brook School in Short Hills, NJ in the 1980's. Later in the 1980's and 1990's, she worked for Lee Skolnick Architecture + Design Partnership, an architectural firm in NYC, where she specialized in museum education, designing and implementing many exhibits as well as preparing docent manuals. A memorial service will be held this Sunday, June 3rd at 2:00pm at Bernheim Apter Kreitzman on 68 Old Short Hills Road, Livingston, NJ followed by a reception at Peter Segal's home in New Vernon, NJ. In lieu of flowers, food, etc. please consider making a donation in Ellen's memory to The MJ Lacher Lymphoma Foundation, Box 286236, New York City, NY 10128.

In one of his last appearances on the season finale of ''Saturday Night Live,'' a rapping Andy Samberg traded a rhyme with Chris Parnell that seemed loaded with underlying meaning: ''On these New York streets I hone my fake rap penmanship / That's how it began, and that's how I'm-a finish it.'' This lyric from ''Lazy Sunday 2'' was not only a bookend to the hit series of digital shorts that Mr. Samberg helped pioneer during his seven-season career on ''S.N.L.''; it was also, as many had suspected, his farewell to that NBC late-night sketch series.

Oprah Winfrey, the publishing industry's unrivaled tastemaker, will revive her popular book club next week after a two-year hiatus, promising the book business some of the sales and publicity it thought had vanished along with her weekday talk show. The move could also be a boon for her beleaguered cable channel, OWN, which has struggled with low ratings.

Mitt Romney remains a very wealthy man, according to the personal financial disclosures his campaign filed Friday with the Office of Government Ethics. Mr. Romney and his wife, Ann, have assets worth $83 million to $255 million, according to the forms, which require candidates and office holders to list the minimum and maximum values for most of their holdings. Those ranges are slightly less than the $85 million to $264 million Mr. Romney reported in June 2011, though it is impossible to know whether the family's net worth actually increased or decreased in that period. A campaign official said that a more accurate range of values for both periods was $190 million to $250 million.

Giants defensive end Osi Umenyiora avoided a second straight off-season of contract controversy by agreeing to a restructured deal Friday, the team announced. Umenyiora, whose 69 career regular-season sacks places him fourth on the Giants' all-time list, was unhappy with his contract last off-season and did not report to training camp on time. He had skipped all previous team workouts this off-season as he sought a new deal again, and Umenyiora said in the team's release that he was excited to put the negotiations behind him and will be present for Monday's training session.

MEDOLLA, Italy -- Until 11 days ago, this district in northern Italy was renowned as the home of some of the world's leading manufacturers of disposable medical devices used for dialysis, transfusion and surgery. Then the earth shook. First on May 20, and then again nine days later, on Tuesday, when a second earthquake and a series of strong aftershocks reduced this industrial area to a wasteland of closed factories and collapsed warehouses.

An article and a headline on Friday about the completion of a private company's first mission to supply the International Space Station described incorrectly the cargo carried by the SpaceX Dragon capsule on its return to earth. The capsule was loaded with about 1,400 pounds of used equipment, experiment samples and other items -- but not garbage. (Trash from the space station goes in other cargo vehicles that are destroyed during their return.)

HARTE--Dr. Maurice S. passed away on May 17 ,2012 at the age of 97. Born in NYC October 25, 1914,he graduated from CCNY in 1935, and then NYU School of Medicine in 1939. Dr. Harte was a surgeon specializing in thoracic surgery in NYC for 40 years before retiring in 1981. He married the late Ruth Louise Aplin. One son was born in 1960. In 1974, Dr. Harte was divorced. Surviving Dr. Harte are his son Heath D. Harte and his wife Tammy of Stamford, CT, grandsons Justin and Brandon of Stamford, CT, and his four-legged friends, Mischief and Junior. Burial was private, but a Memorial Service for the community will be held on June 3, 2012 at 3:15pm at the JCC, 1035 Newfield Ave, Stamford, CT 06905.

5:58 p.m. | Updated Winger Marian Gaborik, the Rangers' top scorer during the regular season, will have surgery to repair a torn labrum in his right shoulder and will miss five to six months, he said Friday at a news conference in his hometown, Trencin, Slovakia. The surgery will be performed on June 6 by Dr. Andrew Feldman and Dr. Anthony Maddalo at New York University Medical Center's Hospital for Joint Diseases, the Rangers said in a separate statement. If Gaborik's estimate is correct, he will not be ready to return to action until November, the second month of the 2012-13 season.

5:17 p.m. | Updated LOS ANGELES - Having told a movie magazine that he plans to retire soon, George Lucas on Friday announced a surprise successor for his posts at privately held Lucasfilm: the Hollywood producer Kathleen Kennedy. Ms. Kennedy will immediately become co-chairwoman of Lucasfilm, while Mr. Lucas for the moment remains co-chairman of the board and chief executive. Micheline Chau, the company's president and chief operating officer, will remain in those posts.

Lawyers for the Broadway producers of ''Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark'' argued in federal court on Friday that the musical's former director, Julie Taymor, had borrowed so many ideas from Spider-Man superhero lore that she was not entitled to copyright protection for her initial three-page script outline for the musical, which features characters and subplots from Spider-Man comics and movies. Ms. Taymor's lawyers, who regard the outline as crucial to her copyright claims and battle for more than $1 million from the producers, countered that the document reflected what they termed originality and the singular vision that she had demonstrated as the Tony Award-winning director of ''The Lion King.'' The two-hour hearing on procedural motions was the first oral argument in the case before Judge Katherine B. Forrest of federal district court in Manhattan. Judge Forrest - who at one point revealed that she knew plenty of Spider-Man minutiae, thanks to her 10-year-old son - bore down on the copyright claim for the script outline, which was the most complex issue before her. The judge said she would issue rulings soon; a jury trial on the case is to start in early 2013.

Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah, and is the director of investor education at BAM Advisor Services. His book, ''The Behavior Gap,'' was published earlier this year. At this time of year, some people like to buy savings bonds for their grandchildren, nieces and nephews who are graduating from high school or college, or getting married. As of last January, though, you can no longer buy paper savings bonds to give as gifts.

Verizon Communications said on Friday that it had agreed to buy Hughes Telematics, a maker of wireless systems for vehicles, for $612 million in cash. Under the terms of the deal, Verizon will pay $12 a share, an exorbitant premium to Hughes' Thursday closing price of $4.35.

LAUB--Robert, age 96, passed away June 1, 2012. He is survived by Hortie, his beloved wife of 65 years, his devoted children Deborah and Alan Bender, Donna and Jeffrey Kramer. He was a role model for adoring grandchildren Marc Bender/Rachel, David Bender/Jen, Rachel Mazor/Mark, Joshua Kramer, and five great-grandchildren who were the loves of his life. He was a proud veteran of WWII, and a successful sportswear manufacturer. A true gentleman whose charisma enriched the lives of everyone he met. He will be greatly missed. Funeral service Sunday, 11am at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, NY.

New York City Title I public schools -- which have the highest percentage of children from low-income families - have been known to hold art classes in broom closets and to scrounge for art supplies. But next week some of their students are going to get the artist Jeff Koons as their art teacher -- at least for a day. It's part of Visual Arts Appreciation Week, organized by Studio in a School, a nonprofit organization founded by the philanthropist Agnes Gund that brings arts education into the city's public schools.

A listing of credits on Friday with a theater review of ''Jukebox Jackie,'' at La MaMa's Ellen Stewart Theater in the East Village, gave an incorrect spelling from the program for the given name of a performer. He is Steve Welsh, not Seve.

The New York Times recently wrote about increasing tax refund identity fraud. That's when a thief uses your name, Social Security number and birth date to file a fake tax return with fabricated income and tax-withholding data to collect an improper refund - often, on an easy-to-use prepaid debit card, sent to a specially chosen address. Then, when you come along and file your (real) tax return, the Internal Revenue Service flags it because one with the same Social Security number has already been submitted. The agency then processes your return manually and scrutinizes everything in it, to authenticate your identity and determine which return is legitimate. The result is months of delays in processing your return and any refund you may rightly be owed.

ANKER--Sylvia, on May 29, age 94. Beloved wife of the late Harold. Loving mother of Jeffrey (Priscilla), Stephen (Susan) and Andrew (Nancy). Cherished grandmother of Jocelyn, Devon and Henry. Proud great-grandmother of Esme. Devoted sister of the late Rose Stern. Dearest aunt and great-aunt. Supervisor of the New York City Board of Education. Services: Sunday, 1pm at Congregation Mt. Sinai, 250 Cadman Plaza West, Brooklyn Heights.

ADLER--Sheldon B.,M.D., passed away June 1 at age 84. Beloved husband of Marcia, loving father of Deborah (Poppel), Daniel and Sheree Adler, Edward and Cheryl Adler, six grandchildren, Max, Elissa, Sam, Erica, Julia and Jackson. As a surgeon, Dr. Adler rose to the top of his profession earning many honors. He retired in 2000 as Chief of Surgery at Good Samaritan Hospital in Suffern, New York when the ambulatory care center was named for him. He enjoyed golf and his passion for purebred dogs allowed him to show over 50 home-bred giant Schnauzers to championships. Interment will take place at New Montefiore Cemetery in Farmingdale, NY on June 4. Two days of mourning from 2-6pm will be observed at the home of Edward and Cheryl Adler in Rye, New York. Donations may be made in Dr. Adler's honor to the Canine Health Foundation, 1-888-682-9696 or Hospice of Palm Beach County, 1-800-Hospice.

SALISBURY--Charlotte Young, 98, died quietly in Salisbury, CT on April 25. She was the widow of Harrison E. Salisbury. Born in Boston, she became a Powers model, mother, passionate gardener and author. During the often harrowing treks around Asia with her husband, she kept diaries which were published and enthusiastically received. Mrs. Salisbury is survived by three of her four children: Ellen Rand, Rosina Rand, and Curtis Rand, and two stepsons: Michael Salisbury, and Stephan Salisbury, 14 grandchildren and five great- grandchildren. Her first child, Charlotte Boyer Parkinson died in 2007. A memorial celebration of her life is planned for June 30, in Salisbury, Ct. For information call 718-782-2541.

Ramon Henriquez slings a black tool bag over his shoulder every day, walks out of his basement room and trudges up and down Broadway looking for work. He calls himself a handyman, which is an understatement: he can just as easily fix a stove as fix a meal, having spent 27 years working as counterman, cook and fix-it man at Floridita, the famed Cuban restaurant. That job - the only one he has ever had since coming to this country from the Dominican Republic in 1984 - is gone, vanished along with the restaurant two years ago when the building was closed and demolished to make room for Columbia University's ambitious Manhattanville campus expansion. Like many of the shuttered restaurant's 43 employees, he has gone without steady work ever since.

Regulators on Friday announced new protections against market volatility, aiming to avert a repeat of the 2010 flash crash. The Securities and Exchange Commission adopted two measures: one would enforce market-wide circuit breakers to halt trading temporarily when trading goes awry; another would prevent erroneous trades from entering the system. In response to the new era of rapid-fire trading and wildly fluctuating stocks, the new round of sophisticated tools would address price disruptions that threaten the broader stability of the markets.

TYREEWilliam F. The Board of Directors and Staff of SCO Family of Services are deeply saddened by the passing of William F. Tyree and extend our condolences to the Tyree family. Bill Tyree served as Chairman of the Board of SCO from 1997-2001 and his involvement with the organization spanned more than 35 years. Bill's legacy and commitment to serving those most in need is reflected at SCO's Tyree Learning Center for developmentally disabled children and is carried on by his son Stephen who currently serves on the SCO Board. He will be missed.

An article on Friday about the indictment of Abacus Federal Savings Bank, a small bank with a major presence in New York City's Chinese community, and 19 of its former employees in a scheme to inflate the qualifications of mortgage applicants misidentified a lawyer representing a defendant, Yuh Wah Wong. He is Sanford Talkin -- not Scott B. Tulman, who represents another defendant in the case.

The group that hands out the Emmy Awards is making a controversial change to the nominations in its movie and miniseries category. Starting in 2013, the four separate categories for actors and actresses will be reduced to two - the leading and supporting roles will be lumped together, effectively narrowing the number of nominees, The Associated Press reported.

DUBLIN, Ohio - Because of bad weather in the morning, Rory Sabbatini didn't start his second round at the Memorial until well after 3 p.m. To pass the time, he watched a documentary about the reggae star Bob Marley. Playing in overcast, windy conditions, Sabbatini scored so well he could be forgiven for whistling ''The Sun Is Shining'' from Marley's song list. With his second consecutive 69, Sabbatini took a one-stroke lead at the halfway point, at six-under. His best finish in 2012 was a tie for ninth in his first start, the Tournament of Champions. In his previous start, a tie for 47th at Colonial, Sabbatini birdied four of his final eight holes to build some much-needed momentum.

The Grammy Awards will be held on Feb. 10 next year at the Staples Center in Los Angeles, its home for years, the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences has announced. The nominations will be revealed two months earlier, on Dec. 5, during a live prime-time concert. Both events will be broadcast on CBS. This year's broadcast was seen by almost 40 million viewers, making it the second-most-watched Grammy Awards ceremony in the event's 54-year history. (The highest was in 1984.) This year's highlights were a sweep of the major awards by Adele, the British soul singer, and a tribute to Whitney Houston, the pop diva who died the night before the broadcast. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

9 P.M. (Starz) THE IDES OF MARCH (2011) George Clooney, Grant Heslov and Beau Willimon got an Oscar nomination for best adapted screenplay for this political drama, which Mr. Clooney also directed and stars in. The film concerns Mike Morris (Mr. Clooney), a Pennsylvania governor turned dream candidate for the Democratic presidential nomination. Ryan Gosling, above, plays Stephen Meyers, a hotshot tactician who becomes involved with an intern (Evan Rachel Wood) with a powerful daddy and a secret that could derail Stephen's career and the Morris campaign. Philip Seymour Hoffman and Paul Giamatti are the senior advisers battling for Stephen's loyalty. And Marisa Tomei is a reporter trying to get at the truth. ''Mr. Clooney handles the plot complications with elegant dexterity,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times about this adaptation of Mr. Willimon's play ''Farragut North,'' loosely based on the 2004 Democratic primary campaign of Howard Dean. ''As an actor, he works best in long, understated scenes that allow him to play with nuances of charm and menace, so it is not surprising that, as a director, he gives the rest of the cast room to work,'' Mr. Scott added. ''But the parts of 'The Ides of March' -- quiet scenes between Mr. Gosling and Ms. Wood; swirling, Sorkinesque exchanges of banter; any time Ms. Tomei or Max Minghella (as a campaign worker grooming himself to be the next Stephen Meyers) are in the room -- are greater than the whole.'' 8 P.M.
